('48', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. NOTES
('48', 0, 2, 3, 53) INDIANS IN FIJI 1
('48', 0, 3, 4, 71) A cablegram from Suva says, “Indian members motion common franchise rejected Council today all three resigned”.
('48', 0, 3, 5, 183) This means that the Fijian Legislative Council would not have Indians on a common franchise.
('48', 0, 3, 6, 276) That would be too much for the white exploiters of Indian labour.
('48', 0, 3, 7, 342) The Indian members elected by Indian electors only have really no influence in the Legislative Council.
('48', 0, 3, 8, 446) I congratulate the three members on their patriotic spirit in having resigned from the Council by way of protest.
('48', 0, 3, 9, 560) I hope that they will on no account reconsider their decision unless a common franchise is obtained.
('48', 0, 3, 10, 661) Having resigned however they must not sit idle but continue their agitation for the simple justice to which they are entitled.
('48', 0, 3, 11, 788) If the Indian colony in Fiji is well organized, the citadel of anti Indian prejudice is bound to break down through united effort.
('48', 0, 3, 12, 919) IS IT A SALE OF INDULGENCES ?
('48', 0, 3, 13, 949) A student writes from Lucknow as follows: 2
('48', 0, 4, 14, 993) I should be sorry to discover that the students and others who pay to the khadi fund do so not with the intention of using khadi themselves but merely as a salve for their conscience.
('48', 0, 4, 15, 1177) I have warned audiences paying their subscriptions that their payment of subscri ption is an earnest of their desire to wear khadi as far as they can.
('48', 0, 4, 16, 1328) The writer of the letter seems to think that khaddarites do not subscribe.
('48', 0, 4, 17, 1403) The fact however is that those who wear khadi are the largest single subscribers.
('48', 0, 4, 18, 1485) If people merely paid subscriptions to the khadi fund and none used khadi, the subscriptions would be perfectly useless, for they are not given as donations to the poor but as a return for work done, and if the fruits of their work are not used by the people, their work becomes useless.

('48', 1, 2, 11, 3593) 2. HONEST DIFFERENCES 1
('48', 1, 3, 12, 3617) Mr. J. B. Pennington whom the readers of Young India will recognize as the nonagenarian friend writes under date 6th October:
('48', 1, 4, 13, 3743) This is most likely the last time I shall worry you with my despairing efforts, but I must just say that I am glad you declined the Presidentship of the Congress because I suppose it means that you prefer to be independent, and I hope, determined to exercise your own judgment in these critical times, no matter what happens.
('48', 1, 4, 14, 4069) You never answered my question as to whether you were prepared to be the first president of the Indian republic, perhaps because you thought it was a ridiculous question which it certainly was not; because if you with your unrivalled experience and reputation, are not fit for the job, I don’t know who is —and it must be a republic or chaos, if you get rid of us.
('48', 1, 4, 15, 4434) Is it quite impossible for you to work with the present administration, say, for another 10 years, till you find your feet?
('48', 1, 4, 16, 4558) Your experience at Bardoli shows that you can influence even the Present Government by ordinary means and once associated with it on equal terms you could easily get all you want without bloodshed of which, God knows, we have had more than enough for one generation.
('48', 1, 4, 17, 4825) Still hoping for the best in India.
('48', 1, 4, 18, 4861) I have no doubt the reader will share with me the wish and the hope that Mr. Pennington may live many a long year to send his letters and even to see India reach her cherished goal.
('48', 1, 4, 19, 5043) Who can withhold admiration for the consistent zeal and industry Mr. Pennington is evincing in the pursuit of what he considers to be the
('48', 1, 5, 20, 5181) 1 Vide also “Letter to J. B. Pennington”, 14 11 1929.
('48', 2, 0, 1, 5235) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 3
('48', 2, 1, 2, 5279) right course?
('48', 2, 1, 3, 5293) Nor can one deny his downright honesty.
('48', 2, 1, 4, 5333) That he may not think as we toiling under the British harrow do is a limitation for which he is not responsible.
('48', 2, 1, 5, 5446) In any case his wonderful zeal, industry and optimism are worthy of imitation by the youth of the country.
('48', 2, 1, 6, 5553) And now for the reply to Mr. Pennington’s question.
('48', 2, 1, 7, 5605) I do remember his question about the first president of the future Indian republic.
('48', 2, 1, 8, 5689) If I must for the time being give up my modesty, I must tell Mr. Pennington in confidence that if there was an Indian republic in my lifetime and the burden was imposed upon me by the simple people of the country, I daresay that it would not break me.
('48', 2, 1, 9, 5941) At any rate I should make a fair effort to shoulder it.
('48', 2, 1, 10, 5997) What however I am striving for is not a life of isolation for India but a life of association with the British on absolutely equal terms.
('48', 2, 1, 11, 6135) Republic or chaos is, in my opinion, an easy thing to get if we would but make up our minds to copy our English tutors and begin to break heads here, there and everywhere without dreading the consequences.
('48', 2, 1, 12, 6341) That however would not please me, and a republic so gained would not probably find me alive, but if it did, its first duty would be not to install me on the throne but to put me under the gallows.
('48', 2, 1, 13, 6538) The republic therefore of my imagination would have to be a republic gained by non violent means, and if the country would continue its choice of non violence and truth as the method par excellence fo attaining its goal, it would not need to drive the English out, but it would have converted the English who under that state of conversion would work as willing servants of the country and would deem it an honour to live on Indian sufferance.
('48', 2, 1, 14, 6982) If such a consummation comes to pass, it would be something of which India will have every reason to be proud and forwhich the world will be the richer.
('48', 2, 1, 15, 7135) It may be a dream never to be fulfilled but it is enough for me that it makes me happy.
('48', 2, 1, 16, 7223) Mr. Pennington will now see why it is quite impossible for me to work with the present administration, even for a day, let alone 10 years.
('48', 2, 1, 17, 7362) Under the present administration equality is an impossibility.
('48', 2, 1, 18, 7425) It is an administration which, I hold, has proved ruinous to India and is based upon brute force.
('48', 2, 1, 19, 7523) The fundamental difference between Mr. Pennington and Indian nationalists is that the latter consider.
('48', 2, 1, 20, 7626) that India is fit today for administering her own affairs without the patronizing help of any outsider.
('48', 2, 1, 21, 7730) If a robber by sheer force of arms has dispossessed me of my estate and holds me as his slave, it does not mean that I therefore consider myself to be unfit to own my estate although I may not have sufficient arms to enable me to dispossess him of the estate unlawfully gained by him.
('48', 2, 1, 22, 8015) Thirdly, Mr. Pennington’s memory surely betrays him when he says that the present Government was influenced by ordinary means with reference to Bardoli 1. It was just the extraordinary means discovered by non co operators that were
('48', 2, 2, 23, 8247) 1 The Bardoli Satyagraha.
('48', 3, 0, 1, 8273) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 3, 1, 2, 8313) employed by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel with consummate skill and absolute faithfulness that influenced the Government, and it is just these extraordinary means which I would like the country to adopt, and I know that it will reach its goal as surely as the simple peasants of Bardoli did.
('48', 3, 1, 3, 8600) Lastly, I would like Mr. Pennington to follow up the ideal for which the Association with which he is intimately connected is working.
('48', 3, 1, 4, 8735) The printed letter heads which Mr. Pennington uses for his letters are issued from the office of the National Homecroft Association Ltd., whose object is to promote the development of homecroft settlements; i.e., suburban food raising areas designed to accommodate working class families in individual homes, erected upon individual crofts, of such size and equipment as will enable the family food to be produced from the family’s soil by the family’s own off time labour.
('48', 3, 1, 5, 9209) At the bottom of each sheet the following quotation from Ruskin is printed: But since we live in an epoch of change and too probably of revolution, and thoughts which are not to be put aside are in the minds of all men capable of thought, I am obliged to affirm the one principle which can and in the end will close all epochs of revolution—that each man shall possess the ground he can use and no more.
('48', 3, 1, 6, 9613) I hope both Mr. Pennington and the readers will recognize the inconsistency between the mentality which on the one hand tolerates an empire based on exploitation and on the other believes in ‘each man possessing the ground he can use and no more’.
('48', 3, 1, 7, 9861) I wonder if Mr. Pennington thinks that the 100 thousand English men and women who are in possession of India can really use an area 1,800 miles long and 1,500 miles broad.
('48', 3, 1, 8, 10033) Again, how can the dispossession of 300 millions of people by a nation which has its own home possibly be justified?
('48', 3, 1, 9, 10150) Young India, 21 11 1929
('48', 3, 2, 10, 10174) 3. IMPLICATIONS OF THE WHEEL A friend sends the following cutting 1 headed “A Century Behind the Times” from the Textile World: This is an instance of argument suiting preconceived ideas.
('48', 3, 2, 11, 10362) The author of the note has evidently not taken the trouble of understanding the implications of what he calls the “Gandhi Movement”, meaning of course the hand spinning movement.
('48', 3, 2, 12, 10541) The spinning movement aims at restoring spinning to the millions of
('48', 3, 3, 13, 10609) 1 Not reproduced here.
('48', 3, 3, 14, 10632) It described the offer of a prize by the “Gandhi Movement” for a speedier spinning wheel as an open admission of its basic economic error.
('48', 4, 0, 1, 10771) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 5
('48', 4, 1, 2, 10815) cottages of India from which it was removed by unjust, illegal and tyrannical methods.
('48', 4, 1, 3, 10902) The movement could not have been started, if somehow or other the cottages which were deprived of this universal supplementary industry had had a substitute provided for it.
('48', 4, 1, 4, 11076) Unfortunately or fortunately no substitute was provided.
('48', 4, 1, 5, 11133) Hence sheer necessity compelled the students of village life, after having exhausted all other means, to resort to the spinning wheel as the only immediate solution for the serious economic distress that had overtaken the millions of India’s homes by reason of the extinction of cottage spinning.
('48', 4, 1, 6, 11430) The moment these millions can have a better substitute, they are at liberty to give up the spinning wheel, and no one would be more glad than I to see these millions possess a better substitute.
('48', 4, 1, 7, 11625) No doubt the authors of the movement do think that so far as human understanding can go, there seems to be no hope of finding a better substitute than the spinning wheel.
('48', 4, 1, 8, 11796) Indeed their conviction is that, as soon as the existing exploitation of the so called weaker nations of the earth by the strong nations of the West ceases as it is bound someday to cease, the whole world will have to return to the spinning wheel.
('48', 4, 1, 9, 12044) Whether however that event comes to pass or not, unless India becomes an exploiting nation and discovers new nations to exploit, or unless an independent India develops brute strength enough to compel the nations of the West to buy the goods that she may dump down on their soil as India is virtually compelled today to receive goods dumped down on her soil, India must, if she is to rid herself of her economic distress, manufacture the articles of necessity in her own cottages just as she produces her corn, the prime necessity of life, in her own fields.
('48', 4, 1, 10, 12603) There is therefore no contradiction in the authors of the spinning movement trying to secure a wheel or a machine which would enable the cottagers in their own cottages to spin more or finer yarn in the same given time as the existing spinning wheel does.
('48', 4, 1, 11, 12859) The writer of the note should know that this progressive method of improving home machines has been handed down from ancient times.
('48', 4, 1, 12, 12991) The takli or the distaff was displaced by the spinning wheel.
('48', 4, 1, 13, 13053) The spinning wheel itself underwent gradual improvement as one sees even today from the different old patterns working in different provinces.
('48', 4, 1, 14, 13196) The process of improvement was suddenly arrested when the spinning wheel went out of fashion.
('48', 4, 1, 15, 13290) The Council of the All India Spinners’ Association is therefore but following the course that was suddenly stopped by the machinations of the East India Company’s agents.
('48', 4, 1, 16, 13461) The fact is that neither the Council nor I have any objection to machines as such, but we do submit that it is wrong to carry the process of mechanization of industry so far as to kill the cottage industries and concentrate them within a narrow field; in other words,
('48', 5, 0, 1, 13729) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 5, 1, 2, 13769) they are against urbanization of India at the expense of her rural civilization and rural life.
('48', 5, 1, 3, 13865) The writer in the Textile World states that a machine meeting practically all the requirements of the contest was in use in America more than a century ago.
('48', 5, 1, 4, 14022) The adverb ‘practically’ is a disturbing factor, but if there is such a machine in America in existence and if any American inventor will take the trouble of so adjusting it as to meet all the requirements of the contest, he will not only receive the prize offered by the Association, but he will earn also the thanks of the dumb millions.
('48', 5, 1, 5, 14362) But let the critics understand that even if such a machine is not invented and the prize is not won, the spinning movement will still continue its onward march.
('48', 5, 1, 6, 14523) The Association feels thankful for its ability to serve l,50,000 women in nearly 2,000 villages of India and through them serve also a number of weavers, washermen, tailors, printers and the like.
('48', 5, 1, 7, 14720) The Association hopes, too, to cover every one of the seven hundred thousand villages and bring a ray of hope to their cottages where today blank despair reigns supreme.
('48', 5, 1, 8, 14890) Young India, 21 l l 1929
('48', 5, 2, 9, 14915) 4. IN THE NAME OF RELIGION
('48', 5, 3, 10, 14942) The Secretary of the Youth League, Dharwar, writes: 1 If what is stated in the letter is at all true it betrays a shocking state of things and an undoubted reversion to barbarism.
('48', 5, 3, 11, 15122) It is a matter for deep sorrow and humiliation that there should be educated men enough in the country who believe that there are gods who can be appeased or conciliated by the sacrifice of animals and if the manner of killing the innocent goats is correctly described by the Secretary of the Youth League of Dharwar, it is an inhuman act done in the name of religion.
('48', 5, 3, 12, 15491) I should hope that there is exaggeration in the statement made by the Secretary.
('48', 5, 3, 13, 15572) There is a similar letter from Bengal also in which the writer asks me to condemn the animal sacrifices that go on daily in the name of religion in that great province.
('48', 5, 3, 14, 15741) If my condemnation of these sacrifices can save a single animal from slaughter it is there with all the force It can command.
('48', 5, 3, 15, 15867) But there seems to be just now the fashion to encourage such sacrifices and to justify them.
('48', 5, 3, 16, 15960) A correspondent from Madras sends me papers containing accounts of such slaughter done by learned Brahmins in the Madras Presidency.
('48', 5, 3, 17, 16093) I wish that Youth Leagues all over the country will rise in revolt against these sacrifices and cultivate public opinion so as to

('48', 6, 2, 8, 16935) 5. ILLUSTRATED KHADI CATALOGUE
('48', 6, 3, 9, 16966) Vithaldas Jerajani has brought out an illustrated khadi catalogue in English in connection with the A.I.S.A. Khadi Bhandar, 396 Kalbadevi Road, Bombay.
('48', 6, 3, 10, 17118) One finds in that catalogue numberless varieties of khadi and many varieties of ready made clothing such as banians, half sleeves bandis, shirts in several styles, coats, jackets, caps, hand spun woollen frocks, jumpers, baby suits, etc.
('48', 6, 3, 11, 17356) The catalogue enables one clearly to see what evolution khadi has undergone.
('48', 6, 3, 12, 17433) I would recommend all lovers of khadi to possess a copy of the catalogue whether for themselves or their friends.
('48', 6, 3, 13, 17547) Young India, 21 11 1929
('48', 6, 4, 14, 17571) 6. THE U. P. TOUR X 1
('48', 6, 5, 15, 17593) As the U.P. tour is drawing to a close the programme is becoming more and more crowded if also less eventful.
('48', 6, 5, 16, 17703) During the past week we passed through Rohilkhand where not much Congress work has been done and where the possibilities are very great.
('48', 6, 5, 17, 17840) From Brindaban we went to Hathras 2 taking several places on the way.
('48', 6, 5, 18, 17910) Hathras having many spinning wheels and being a good cotton centre could easily have paid much more than it did.
('48', 6, 5, 19, 18023) From Hathras we passed hurriedly to Etah, thence to Kasganj, thence to Badaun 3 and from Badaun we went to Shahjahanpur 4 where Gandhiji peeped even though it was a Monday into an American Methodist Mission Girls’ School which has introduced hand spinning and weaving with some degree of success.
('48', 6, 5, 20, 18320) The girls all belonged to the so called depressed
('48', 6, 6, 21, 18370) 1 Vide 1st footnote to “The U. P. Tour IV”, 24 10 1929. 2 On November 8 3 On November 9 4 On November 10
('48', 7, 0, 1, 18475) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 7, 1, 2, 18515) classes.
('48', 7, 1, 3, 18524) From Shahjahanpur we went to Pilibhit which with its fabulously rich zamindars could easily have paid much more than it did.
('48', 7, 1, 4, 18649) From Pilibhit we passed through Lakhimpur which was slightly better.
('48', 7, 1, 5, 18718) From Lakhimpur we reached Sitapur 1 where the energy ofLala Shambhunath of non co operation fame and the zealous sacrifice of Pandit Shivaram brightened things a bit.
('48', 7, 1, 6, 18885) There can be no doubt that wherever some solid work has been done amongst people, some sacrifice shown even by one or two leading lights, the results have been obvious.
('48', 7, 1, 7, 19054) We found a fairly well attended national school still going in Sitapur.
('48', 7, 1, 8, 19126) Everywhere one could see the Biblical saying exemplified “The harvest is indeed rich but the labourers are few.” Given a few labourers there is absolutely no reason why we should not show much better results.
('48', 7, 1, 9, 19335) From Sitapur we went to Sidhauli.
('48', 7, 1, 10, 19369) There a summons was waiting for Gandhiji from Pandit Motilalji, asking him, instead of going by train as he had intended, to go by car to Lucknow through which he had to pass en route to Rae Bareli.
('48', 7, 1, 11, 19568) So he went by car in advance of the party, passed an hour with Panditji and went straight to Rae Bareli.
('48', 7, 1, 12, 19673) 2 At Rae Bareli the perfection of all the arrangements arrested attention of every one of the party.
('48', 7, 1, 13, 19774) There was perfect order observed from start to finish at the public meeting.
('48', 7, 1, 14, 19851) No rush was made by the crowds towards Gandhiji although the meeting was very largely attended and was composed of peasants.
('48', 7, 1, 15, 19976) The platform was made of solid brick mud plastered, sides of which were painted in yellowish colour, a colour that was in perfect keeping with the surroundings.
('48', 7, 1, 16, 20137) Broad avenues were kept in order to allow the motor car to pass to and fro without any difficulty.
('48', 7, 1, 17, 20236) The decorations also were mild, cheap and effective.
('48', 7, 1, 18, 20289) There were two arches for ingress and egress.
('48', 7, 1, 19, 20335) They were made of evergreens.
('48', 7, 1, 20, 20365) What delighted Gandhiji most was to find that the whole of the decorations had cost no more than Rs. 4 for the simple reason that bricks were lent, labour was given free by the District Board, fencing materials were lent by a dealer and so there was little expense to be incurred.
('48', 7, 1, 21, 20646) From Rae Bareli taking Lalganj and Salon on the way we went to Kalakankar.
('48', 7, 1, 22, 20721) 3 We had made the discovery at Lucknow and it was strikingly confirmed at Kalakankar that the young Talukdars of Oudh were gradually shedding their fear and helping in their own way the national cause.
('48', 7, 1, 23, 20923) Some of these young men had contributed to the khadi purse and Lalaji Memorial.
('48', 7, 1, 24, 21003) The Raja Saheb of Kalakankar was anxious for Gandhiji to pass a day or two in his unpretentious ancient well built
('48', 7, 2, 25, 21118) 1 On November 12 2 On November 13 3 On November 14
('48', 8, 0, 1, 21169) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 9
('48', 8, 1, 2, 21213) palace just on the bank of the beautiful Ganges.
('48', 8, 1, 3, 21262) And as we went through this little village we realized what natural beauty there was about the peaceful surroundings of this little palace.
('48', 8, 1, 4, 21402) Gandhiji andindeed the whole party were quite glad to be away even for 24 hours from the din and noise of eager crowds.
('48', 8, 1, 5, 21522) But there were also several other things here that added to Gandhiji’s happiness.
('48', 8, 1, 6, 21604) The young ladies of the Kalakankar house do not observe the purdah.
('48', 8, 1, 7, 21672) The Raja Saheb and they are habitual wearers of khadi.
('48', 8, 1, 8, 21727) But in order to clear his wardrobe of every vestige of foreign cloth the Raja Saheb had devised a foreign cloth burning ceremony as part of the public meeting.
('48', 8, 1, 9, 21887) There was a new bride who had arrived only eight days ago.
('48', 8, 1, 10, 21946) She had a fair amount of foreign cloth in her wardrobe.
('48', 8, 1, 11, 22002) She too gave up its foreign contents for the altar.
('48', 8, 1, 12, 22054) But the largest and the richest contribution had come from Raja Lal Saheb of Samaspur.
('48', 8, 1, 13, 22141) Before igniting the pyramid of foreign cloth arranged on the altar in a corner of the meeting well fenced and well protected, Gandhiji scanned every article carefully, and we could observe that it delighted him to see heavily embroidered robes, richly decorated fine Parisian lace, very expensive saris and the like.
('48', 8, 1, 14, 22458) As he ignited the pyramid and the flames rose to the skies, there arose also a loud shout of joy from the crowds who now eagerly surrounded the fence and witnessed the ceremony.
('48', 8, 1, 15, 22636) The handle of the torch which was given to Gandhiji for igniting the pyramid was silver mounted.
('48', 8, 1, 16, 22733) It was of course auctioned and it was knocked down to Lal Saheb of Samaspur for Rs. 500. I must close this rapid sketch of the events of the past week with a summary of a portion of Gandhiji’s speech to the Kalakankar public meeting.
('48', 8, 2, 17, 22967) ‘It gives me great joy,’ said Gandhiji, ‘to see you all and to see the Raja Saheb dressed even as you are and mixing freely with you.
('48', 8, 2, 18, 23101) I had the privilege of meeting him in Lucknow when on behalf of the Reception Committee he had housed me in his Lucknow residence.
('48', 8, 2, 19, 23232) As he was dressed like a volunteer, the members of my party could not distinguish between him and the other volunteers, and he had therefore been unconsciously entrusted with menial duties without the slightest hesitation by one of my party.
('48', 8, 2, 20, 23474) As if it was perfectly natural for him he performed that duty with alacrity.
('48', 8, 2, 21, 23551) When a member of the party subsequently came to know who it was who was given menial work he reported the matter to me.
('48', 8, 2, 22, 23671) Personally I was delighted that the zamindars and Rajas were to be found to delight in rendering service involving menial work.
('48', 8, 2, 23, 23799) It gives me additional joy to find that the Raja Saheb is living here in the midst of his own ryots just as simply and naturally as I found him living in Lucknow.
('48', 8, 2, 24, 23962) I hope that the other young talukdars will copy this example, and
('48', 9, 0, 1, 24028) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 9, 1, 2, 24069) if only the rich people whether titled or not will act as I believe the Raja Saheb is actingthat is, as trustee for the people and holding the zamindari as their trustee and protector, they should soon be perfectly happy.
('48', 9, 1, 3, 24291) The dream I want to realize is not spoliation of the property of private owners but to restrict its enjoyment so as to avoid all pauperism, consequent discontent and the hideously ugly contrast that exists today between the lives and surroundings of the rich and the poor.
('48', 9, 1, 4, 24564) The latter must be enabled to feel that they are co partners with their zamindars and not their slaves, to be made to labour at the latter’s sweet will and to be made to pay all kinds of exactions on all conceivable occasions.
('48', 9, 1, 5, 24791) You and they the zamindars should shed mutual fear and mutual distrust, and if both do so, you will also shed the common fear of authority.
('48', 9, 1, 6, 24931) The Government can do no harm to you or to them if only you both act on the square.
('48', 9, 1, 7, 25015) You have seen me give up to flames expensive robes and other clothing of zamindars made of foreign yarn.
('48', 9, 1, 8, 25120) I regard it as a sacred rite.
('48', 9, 1, 9, 25150) You may not today understand the significance of this havan —sacrifice.
('48', 9, 1, 10, 25222) But I doubt not that this silver mounted torch will, if it is preserved by its would be buyer, find a lodgment one day in the national museum which the future national Government is bound to establish for all such collections reminding posterity of the phases that the struggle for freedom went through.
('48', 9, 1, 11, 25526) This campaign against foreign cloth through khadi and all it means for the starving millions will, I have not a shadow of a doubt, go down in history as one of the most important if not the most important item in the national programme.
('48', 9, 1, 12, 25763) The burning of foreign fineries means that the owners have from today established a living bond between you and them, and secondly it means that they have discarded the enervating, debasing and unmanly taste for gaudy garments and jewellery and have made up their minds henceforth voluntarily to live as simply even as you are living, perhaps under compulsion.’
('48', 9, 2, 13, 26125) Young India, 21 11 1929
('48', 10, 0, 1, 26149) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 11
('48', 10, 1, 2, 26194) 7. SOME POSERS
('48', 10, 2, 3, 26209) A reader writes:
('48', 10, 3, 4, 26226) I have the honour to state that I am a humble servant and a faithful follower of the Congress.
('48', 10, 3, 5, 26321) In connection with your non co operation movement I have also undergone nine months rigorous imprisonment.
('48', 10, 3, 6, 26428) I hope you will kindly answer the following questions and remove my doubts.
('48', 10, 3, 7, 26504) His first question is:
('48', 10, 4, 8, 26527) Do you know that .
('48', 10, 4, 9, 26546) has co operated with the Simon Commission and has sent in a memorandum also notwithstanding the fact that he is a prominent Congressman and wears khadi?
('48', 10, 4, 10, 26699) With such gentlemen in the Congress do you still expect the country’s deliverance through the Congress ?
('48', 10, 4, 11, 26804) A country’s deliverance does not depend on one man.
('48', 10, 4, 12, 26856) Every one whether good or bad, has a right to be in the Congress.
('48', 10, 4, 13, 26922) If the number of those that follow all the mandates of the Congress is large, then the country’s deliverance is certain.
('48', 10, 4, 14, 27043) So we should not worry about what others do.
('48', 10, 4, 15, 27088) Let each one ask himself ‘what am I doing?’ The second question is:
('48', 10, 5, 16, 27156) By encouraging the students to boycott schools and colleges have you benefited the country?
('48', 10, 5, 17, 27248) I am thoroughly convinced that those who boycotted schools and colleges have done nothing but good to themselves and to their country.
('48', 10, 5, 18, 27383) On account of this the colleges and other institutions have lost prestige.
('48', 10, 5, 19, 27458) The country has gained good volunteers in the few students who left these institutions.
('48', 10, 5, 20, 27546) It is to the credit of the boycott that today, even though in a small number, there are some natio nal schools in the country that help much in the struggle for freedom.
('48', 10, 5, 21, 27716) I have already mentioned in the Hindi Navajivan how much the Gujarat Vidyapith alone has helped in this struggle.
('48', 10, 5, 22, 27830) If we evaluate in this manner the work of the other national universities we shall understand, to a certain extent, the importance of the boycott of Government schools and colleges.
('48', 10, 5, 23, 28012) I have up till now met very few people who find fault with the principle of boycott.
('48', 10, 5, 24, 28097) People are mostly of the opinion that the country was not prepared for such sacrifice in 1920 21 nor is it even now.
('48', 10, 5, 25, 28214) This meansthe country was not prepared for swaraj in those days, nor is it now.
('48', 10, 5, 26, 28294) If this is true let us stop denouncing boycott and prepare the ground for it.
('48', 10, 5, 27, 28372) Here is his third question:
('48', 10, 6, 28, 28400) How far is it profitable for each and every person to spin on the charkha and what can he earn from this for his living?
('48', 10, 6, 29, 28521) In that same time can he not earn more by doing some better work?
('48', 11, 0, 1, 28587) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 11, 1, 2, 28628) This question has been asked several times and the answer has been given again and again.
('48', 11, 1, 3, 28718) It is that those who ply the charkha for pecuniary gain can certainly give it up if they get a more profitable occupation.
('48', 11, 1, 4, 28841) The main object of the promoters of the charkha has been to provide occupation for crores who have no other occupation.
('48', 11, 1, 5, 28961) To those who consider it a sacrifice to ply the charkha the question of gain or loss does not arise.
('48', 11, 1, 6, 29062) The sacrificer never thinks of his own gain.
('48', 11, 1, 7, 29107) He considers the good of all as his own good.
('48', 11, 1, 8, 29153) The fourth question is:
('48', 11, 2, 9, 29177) From the political point of view, how far can the charkha help?
('48', 11, 2, 10, 29241) In the olden days widows and women of ordinary families used to spin on the charkha.
('48', 11, 2, 11, 29326) Today why do you force men to ply the charkha?
('48', 11, 2, 12, 29373) In my opinion, the political contribution of the charkha is very great; because from the political point of view it is very essential to boycott foreign cloth and this can be successful only with the help of khadi.
('48', 11, 2, 13, 29588) In such matters there can be no difference between man and woman, between widow and married woman.
('48', 11, 2, 14, 29687) The charkha sacrifice is universal.
('48', 11, 2, 15, 29723) The fifth question runs thus:
('48', 11, 3, 16, 29753) Did you and other leaders ever give any help to the workers who have come out of jail?
('48', 11, 3, 17, 29840) If not, what advice did you give them regarding their future career ?
('48', 11, 3, 18, 29910) What should they do now ?

('48', 11, 3, 20, 30177) I have not come across even one such worker released from jail who, deserving help, has not received it.

('48', 11, 4, 27, 30670) In my opinion the satyagrahi prisoners should not ask for any special privilege.
('48', 11, 4, 28, 30751) They should not even expect any such favour.
('48', 11, 4, 29, 30796) The seventh question is as follows:
('48', 11, 5, 30, 30832) You collected one crore of rupees for the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('48', 11, 5, 31, 30893) Can you kindly say how that money which was collected in the name of the poor is being spent and how the common people benefit from it?

('48', 18, 5, 7, 43394) 16. BECOME A CHILD
('48', 18, 6, 8, 43413) A four year old boy asked: “Father, what do you mean by women ?” Father, disconcerted, said: “Sisters and mothers are known as women.” The boy said: “I see, women are persons who cook, clean utensils and wash clothes, is it not so?” This is not an imaginary conversation but one which has been selected from many conversations which have actually taken place.
('48', 18, 6, 9, 43773) The father’s definition did not appeal to the child as he had seen women mostly engaged in the tasks described by him.
('48', 18, 6, 10, 43892) A friend sent me a collection of such dialogues for my amusement, and, when I read them, I felt that, if we could become innocent like children and derive our meanings from innocent observations like theirs, we could spare ourselves much trouble, many disputes and much waste of time.
('48', 18, 6, 11, 44177) And our intellect would become increasingly keener.
('48', 18, 6, 12, 44229) A great deal of argumentation may sharpen our wits but it does not sharpen our intellect.
('48', 18, 6, 13, 44319) Who has not come across instances of too much argumentation leading to intellectual confusion?
('48', 18, 6, 14, 44414) This child is—in fact, all innocent children are—unconscious worshippers of truth and hence they go an advancing We should, therefore, become children, that is to say, we should shed all fear and worship truth.
('48', 18, 6, 15, 44625) We should do that which our heart believes to be true.
('48', 18, 6, 16, 44680) We shall certainly err, but we should put up with the penalty and see to it that such error is not repeated.
('48', 18, 6, 17, 44789) If we make another mistake, it does not matter; on every occasion we should suffer the penalty and go on rectifying our mistakes.
('48', 18, 6, 18, 44919) Whoever errs does not commit a fault.
('48', 18, 6, 19, 44957) In the case of a fault knowledge is presumed.
('48', 18, 6, 20, 45003) Knowingly committing a wrong is both a fault as well as sin.
('48', 18, 6, 21, 45064) If we err unknowingly, that act will not be called
('48', 19, 0, 1, 45115) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 19, 1, 2, 45156) sinful.
('48', 19, 1, 3, 45164) Punishment may be meted out for both— error and sin—one meted out for the former is welcome, whereas that meted out for the latter is as bitter as poison.
('48', 19, 1, 4, 45319) Both society and God shudder to punish anyone for the former, but are furious in punishing anyone for the latter.
('48', 19, 1, 5, 45433) It is not easy for a person advanced in age to become and continue to be, like a child, innocent and simple and, a conscious worshipper of truth.
('48', 19, 1, 6, 45579) But it is our duty to do so.
('48', 19, 1, 7, 45608) The perfect incarnation of God as conceived by Hinduism is the child Krishna.
('48', 19, 1, 8, 45686) Jesus said: “Wisdom flows from the mouths of babes and sucklings.” He said to those who desired salvation: “Become like children.” [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 24 11 1929
('48', 19, 2, 9, 45855) 17. MY NOTES
('48', 19, 3, 10, 45868) GUJARAT’S DUTY
('48', 19, 4, 11, 45883) The Viceroy’s pronouncement has created such a sensation that the newspapers are full of discussion over it.
('48', 19, 4, 12, 45992) Likewise, we also come across all sorts of speculation about it.
('48', 19, 4, 13, 46057) I want that Gujarat should not indulge in any kind of conjectures, good or bad.
('48', 19, 4, 14, 46137) Whether a conference is held or not, whether it be a round table conference or a square table one, let no one worry about it and let everyone do only his own work.
('48', 19, 4, 15, 46301) Let no one get entangled in a wordy maze.
('48', 19, 4, 16, 46343) If anyone gives a poisonous name to a rose, the latter will neither lose its colournor its fragrance, and a poisonous flower, if called a rose, cannot change its colour or its fragrance.
('48', 19, 4, 17, 46530) Likewise slavery will not cease to be so by being referred to as independence, and real independence will not become foreign domination by being called Dominion Status.
('48', 19, 4, 18, 46699) Gujarat is regarded as having practical sense.
('48', 19, 4, 19, 46746) A practical person is concerned with actual results and never with mere words.
('48', 19, 4, 20, 46825) Let the administration under swaraj be given any name, but it must fulfil certain conditions.
('48', 19, 4, 21, 46919) The principal among these is that India should be free to sever its connections with the British Empire whenever it wishes.
('48', 19, 4, 22, 47043) Another condition, which is included in the first, is that the safety of the Britishers living in India at present must rest, not on their swords, cannons or their frightening forts, but on the fortress in the form of our goodwill and friendship.
('48', 19, 4, 23, 47290) The third condition should be that the British officials and the so called Indian officials, who have the same attitudes as the former, should cease to consider themselves as masters and start regarding them selves as true servants
('48', 20, 0, 1, 47522) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 21
('48', 20, 1, 2, 47567) of the people of India.
('48', 20, 1, 3, 47591) In my opinion, a scheme which would truly fulfil these three conditions implies true independence.
('48', 20, 1, 4, 47690) At the moment, I do not see here the climate which would bring about such a situation.
('48', 20, 1, 5, 47777) Hence there is no reason to hope for such a swaraj, but if it comes our way, it should not be turned down.
('48', 20, 1, 6, 47884) True swaraj can also be established if the attitude of eminent Britishers undergoes a change and they are prepared to be just despite the fact that we have not become strong enough to deserve swaraj.
('48', 20, 1, 7, 48084) We do not at all ask for any favour.
('48', 20, 1, 8, 48121) That which has been granted as a favour has never till this day been anywhere recognized as independence.
('48', 20, 1, 9, 48227) If, however, the sense of justice is awakened in Britishers, a part of our task will become straight and simple.
('48', 20, 1, 10, 48340) At the root of a peaceful struggle lie the hope and the effort to bring about a change of heart in the adversary.
('48', 20, 1, 11, 48454) It is my confirmed belief that if India adheres to the path of peace till the very end, the hearts of the most callous of British officers is bound to undergo a change.
('48', 20, 1, 12, 48623) Hence, if an honourable settlement is possible, I am always ready to accept it.
('48', 20, 1, 13, 48703) And by adopting this attitude, neither my leaders nor I have ever lost anything.
('48', 20, 1, 14, 48784) I would, therefore, specially request Gujarat not to let its mind be even slightly affected by all that is being said at the moment but to utilize all its time in completing the programme drawn up by the Congress.
('48', 20, 1, 15, 48998) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 24 11 1929

('48', 21, 1, 2, 49748) 19. A LETTER
('48', 21, 2, 3, 49761) ETAWAH, November 24, 1929 Your brother has given me news of your husband’s passing away.
('48', 21, 2, 4, 49850) In his letter he has dwelt on your late husband’s goodness and vividly described your grief at your bereavement.
('48', 21, 2, 5, 49963) Your brother writes that you are unable to eat from grief and that when you try to eat under the loving pressure of friends and relatives you throw up the food.
('48', 21, 2, 6, 50124) I can understand your grief.
('48', 21, 2, 7, 50153) Please know that I fully share it.
('48', 21, 2, 8, 50188) But from what I heard about you I believe that you are a sensible and wise woman.
('48', 21, 2, 9, 50270) You should therefore spiritualize your grief.
('48', 21, 2, 10, 50316) You are overcome by ignorant attachment.
('48', 21, 2, 11, 50357) Spiritualizing grief means that you should engross yourself in your husband’s work and imbibe and improve upon the virtues you may have seen in him.
('48', 21, 2, 12, 50506) There is no better memorial than this to your husband and no better way of performing his shraddha and of consoling yourself.
('48', 21, 2, 13, 50632) If you have understood this, you should try to sustain your body if only for your husband’s sake and take food as you would take medicine.
('48', 21, 2, 14, 50771) May God grant you peace.
('48', 21, 3, 15, 50796) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('48', 21, 4, 17, 50864) 20. DECLARATION OF TRUST 1
('48', 21, 5, 18, 50891) November 26, 1929
('48', 21, 6, 19, 50909) 1. We, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, age about years 60, Hindu, profession weaving and farming, residing at Satyagraha Ashram, Vadaj, Taluka Uttar Daskroi, District Ahmedabad, and Mohanlal Maganlal Bhatt, age about years 31, Hindu, residing at Bhoivadani Pole, Kalupur, Ahmedabad, declare by this Deed: That in the year 1919 with the object of serving the people we, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi and some of our colleagues, together started a printing press named “Navajivan Mudranalaya” in the city of Ahmedabad and with its help began to print, circulate and conduct as an institution for the service of the public, two weeklies, the Navajivan and the Young India, both of which we had begun to conduct some time before after securing them by buying them fromtheir previous owners and managers with their total rights of ownership and possession.
('48', 21, 6, 20, 51754) The weekly Hindi Navajivan and a department for publishing books under the name “Navajivan
('48', 22, 0, 1, 51845) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 23
('48', 22, 1, 2, 51890) Prakashan Mandir 1” and other activities were carried on afterwards by us through the same institution.
('48', 22, 1, 3, 51994) The said weeklies, printing press, and the department for publishing books have continued as a public institution for the education of the people under one comprehensive name of the “Navajivan Institution”.
('48', 22, 1, 4, 52201) When the said Navajivan Institution was started under the name of the Navajivan Mudranalaya, its property was worth about ten thousand, in figures 10,000 rupees.
('48', 22, 1, 5, 52363) Together with the said printing press and the increase earned through the weeklies the property that belongs to the Institution today without any burden on it is worth about rupees one lakh.
('48', 22, 1, 6, 52554) 2. The management of the said Navajivan Institution and the use and administration of its property was carried on by Swami Anand for the past several years and is now being carried on for the past two years by one of us Mohanlal Maganlal Bhatt on its behalf in pursuance of the aims and objects of the Institution as mentioned in paras 3 and 4 of this Deed.
('48', 22, 1, 7, 52912) Having declared these aims and objects, we declare by this Deed that the said printing press, weeklies, the publishing house, its rights of publication and goodwill and all other property belong to the said Navajivan Institution; that its management and administration was carried on behalf of the Institution in the name of Swami Anand in the beginning and is now being carried on in the name of one of us Mohanlal Maganlal Bhatt as Trustee of the Institution; that we, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi and Mohanlal Maganlal Bhatt or guardians and heirs of both of us never did have or have any personal share, interest or right in it, and that we have not drawn for our personal profit or benefit or in any other manner any amount of money from it.
('48', 22, 1, 8, 53657) 3. The aims and objects of the said Navajivan Institution which have been referred to in the previous para 2 are as under:
('48', 22, 2, 9, 53780) OBJECTS: To propagate peaceful means for the attainment of Hind Swaraj, i.e., swaraj for India, by educating the people through cultivated and enlightened workers devoted to the Gujarati language who desire to identify themselves with the life of Gujarat through the means of Gujarati and to serve India in this pure manner.
('48', 22, 2, 10, 54105) 4. For the fulfilment of this object to conduct the Navajivan, through it to carry on propaganda for peaceful attainment of swaraj; and particularly (a) to propagate the spinning wheel and khadi; (b) to propagate for the removal of untouchability; (c) to propagate for unity between the Hindus and Mussalmans and the various communities who have settled in India;
('48', 23, 0, 1, 54469) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 23, 1, 2, 54510) (d) to present before the people constructive ways for protecting the cow by propagating for starting and managing tanneries, dairies and such other establishments; (e) to propagate for ways for the advancement of women such as 1. Opposition to child marriage, 2. Propagation of the idea of widow remarriage in a restrained manner, 3. Education for women; (f) to break the unnatural glamour the English language has gained in the eyes of the people all over the country and to propagate for the establishment of Hindi or Hindustani in its place; (g) to propagate by publication of journals and books such other ways as would conduce to the religious, social, economic and political advancement of the people; (h) not to take advertisements in the newspapers conducted by the Institution and in pamphlets, books, etc., published by it; nor to accept in the printing press of the Institution such work for printing as is against the aims and objects of the Institution; (i) to publish a statement of the activities of the Institution and of its accounts within three months after the end of the administrative year; (j) always to insist on carrying on all the activities of the Institution on the basis of self reliance.
('48', 23, 1, 3, 55729) 5. We declare hereby that the following persons have been appointed Trustees to carry on the entire administration and management of the Institution in accordance with the said aims and objects: NAMES OF TRUSTEES SHRI VALLABHBHAI JHAVERBHAI PATEL SHRI JAMNALAL BAJAJ SHRI DATTATREYA BALKRISHNA KALELKAR SHRI MAHADEV HARIBHAI DESAI SHRI MOHANLAL MAGANLAL BHATT 6. We declare that the said Trustees have the following rights regarding all the property of the said Navajivan Institution: (1) To perform all acts and to take all measures as seem necessary from time to time for the fulfilment of the aims and objects of the Trust; to administer and use the property of the Trust for that purpose as they deem proper; and to keep the property of the Trust in the names of two of the Trustees.
('48', 24, 0, 1, 56517) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 25
('48', 24, 1, 2, 56562) (2) To sell or mortgage the property of the said Trust for the fulfilment of the aims and objects of the Trust.
('48', 24, 1, 3, 56674) (3) To appoint as Trustee by a majority decision another pers on in the event of one of the Trustees resigning his place or in the event of his demise.
('48', 24, 1, 4, 56826) (4) For carrying on the business of the Trust the minimum number of Trustees is three.
('48', 24, 1, 5, 56913) (5) If deemed necessary to add two more Trustees to their present number by a majority decision.
('48', 24, 1, 6, 57010) 7. The Trustees will continue the publication of the weekly Hindi Navajivan so long as they deem it proper for the fulfilment of the object as mentioned in sub clause (f) of para 4 of the Deed.
('48', 24, 1, 7, 57204) The Trustees have the right to run newspapers or publish and propagate books or pamphlets, etc., in other languages when they deem it inevitable for the fulfilment of the aims and objects of the Institution for a definite period but they shall consider such activity as secondary or subsidiary.
('48', 24, 1, 8, 57499) The Trustees will carry on the same basis the activity of conducting the weekly Young India and publication of books in English as at present carried on under the Navajivan Institution and such other activities till they deem it proper.
('48', 24, 1, 9, 57736) 8. The Trustees have the right to add to or modify the objects of the Trust in such manner as is not opposed to the principles of truth and non violence.
('48', 24, 1, 10, 57890) 9. The Trustees have the right to manage and administer affairs of the Institution in such manner as is not in any way detrimental to the aims and objects of the Institution; to form a body of workers who pledge themselves to their work for life and will perform their work in the spirit of pure service and to give the charge of the internal management or the whole conduct of the affairs of the Institution to such a body of workers if they deem it proper; to lay down rules, bye laws, etc., and to execute them for such a body of workers and for other purposes regarding management and administration.
('48', 24, 1, 11, 58495) 10. The property of this Trust as mentioned in para 2 of the Deed is at present housed in the building in the Sarkhigarani Wadi in Sarangpur bearing municipal numbers of 5512 to 5521 which has been rented by the Navajivan Institution.
('48', 24, 1, 12, 58730) Besides, the land described below is situated in the village Achar, Taluka and Petatukadi 1 Uttar Daskroi, District Ahmedabad.

('48', 28, 0, 1, 62471) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 29
('48', 28, 1, 2, 62516) 26. THE U. P. TOUR XI 1
('48', 28, 2, 3, 62540) From Kalakankar taking Pratapgarh and other places on the way we reached Allahabad on 15th instant, to face a crowded programme and, as in Delhi, a meeting of the Working Committee and the Joint Conference to consider the situation in the light of the events subsequent to the Delhi manifesto.
('48', 28, 2, 4, 62834) But the strain in Allahabad was less because the hand of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru was visible in everything.
('48', 28, 2, 5, 62942) When all is well arranged, times are kept and noises and rush avoided, the strain is but little felt.
('48', 28, 2, 6, 63044) The programme began with a visit to Dr. Sam Higginbottom’s experimental farm and agricultural institute.
('48', 28, 2, 7, 63149) Gandhiji wanted to visit it not for collecting funds for Daridranarayana but as a farmer to learn what he could of Dr. Higginbottom’s experiment.
('48', 28, 2, 8, 63295) It was a packed one and a half hours’ programme.
('48', 28, 2, 9, 63344) Gandhiji was hurried through the workshop, cattle farm, sewage farm, soil reclamation area, etc.
('48', 28, 2, 10, 63441) Cross cattle breeding is being tried at the farm.
('48', 28, 2, 11, 63491) Sewage is buried in shallow pits and used with good results on the very spot where it is buried.
('48', 28, 2, 12, 63588) The liquid manure in cattle shed is treated separately from the solid and is carried in a diluted form to a farm prepared for lucerne growing and the like.
('48', 28, 2, 13, 63744) Gandhiji could not help noticing the contrast between this economical and scientific treatment of sewage and the woeful neglect of the Municipal Board which allowed thousands of rupees worth of sewage to be annually wasted and the sacred waters of the Ganges and the Jamna to be polluted at the very spot where they meet and to view which tens of thousands of devotees travel long distances from all parts of India.
('48', 28, 2, 14, 64160) We had a peep at the little children whom Mrs. Higginbottom is bringing up with a mother’s care.
('48', 28, 2, 15, 64257) Most of these are children born of lepers.
('48', 28, 2, 16, 64300) This part of the visit finished with a five minutes’ function at which the students presented a purse containing earnings from their own labour specially dedicated to Daridranarayana and a huge basket full of the delicacies that mother earth had yielded at this farm.
('48', 28, 2, 17, 64568) From this function Dr. and Mrs. Higginbottom took the party to the leper asylum nearby conducted by them.
('48', 28, 2, 18, 64674) They seemed to take special pride in this work of theirs and Gandhiji could not help envying Mrs. Higginbottom the spontaneous love that the little children bestowed upon their adoptive mother who with pardonable pride introduced the ‘troupe’ to Gandhiji as “my children”!
('48', 28, 2, 19, 64947) The chaulmoogra oil injections are regularly given to the lepers with, it is said, 80 per cent success
('48', 28, 3, 20, 65050) 1 Vide 1st footnote “The U.P. Tour VI”, 24 10 1929.
('48', 29, 0, 1, 65102) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 29, 1, 2, 65143) complete or partial in recent cases and less success in advanced cases.
('48', 29, 1, 3, 65215) But it is claimed that the ravaging progress of the fell disease is arrested even in advanced cases.
('48', 29, 1, 4, 65316) From the farm the party visited the Ewing College and School students and received a good purse and address.
('48', 29, 1, 5, 65425) Thence we went to Crosthwaite Girls’ School where the proceedings were protracted though interesting.
('48', 29, 1, 6, 65527) The girls sang Mirabai’s bhajans and some of the little girls danced with admirable rhythm as they sang the famous bhajan of Mirabai: “ ” (I shall dance as I sing the praises of the Lord) This gave Gandhiji the cue for his address.
('48', 29, 1, 7, 65759) He asked the girls to sing these sacred hymns with understanding and from their hearts.
('48', 29, 1, 8, 65847) From the girls’ function the party went to Kayasth Pathashala to receive their purse and address.
('48', 29, 1, 9, 65945) The afternoon was devoted to visiting villages in the district.
('48', 29, 1, 10, 66009) This was Saturday 16th.
('48', 29, 1, 11, 66033) The morning of the 17th opened with a meeting of the University students and professors.
('48', 29, 1, 12, 66122) 1 It was presided over by the Vice Chancellor Sjt.
('48', 29, 1, 13, 66173) Ganganath Jha.
('48', 29, 1, 14, 66188) The largest purse yet presented by students and professors was presented here.
('48', 29, 1, 15, 66267) It was over Rs. 3,000 and the address was taken up by the Students’ Union at Rs. 357. The tour has been remarkable for the fact, among others, that the students’ purses have been rising almost invariably at every stage.
('48', 29, 1, 16, 66487) Allahabad beat all previous records and came miles ahead of the others.
('48', 29, 1, 17, 66559) From the students the party migrated to the Municipal Offices for Gandhiji to receive addressees from the Municipal and District Boards.
('48', 29, 1, 18, 66696) 2 Gandhiji drew the attention of the members of the Municipal Board to the question of sewage disposal, and suggested that it was criminal to pollute with the city sewage the sacred rivers at their very confluence.
('48', 29, 1, 19, 66911) He said that it was the duty of the Board to adopt a wise and scientific system of disposing of the sewage and thereby to replenish their empty treasure chest.
('48', 29, 1, 20, 67071) The Municipal Board is runninga leather manufacture school.
('48', 29, 1, 21, 67131) Congratulating the Board on having such a school, Gandhiji told the Board that it should begin with indigenous tanning of dead cattle hide of which there must be a considerable quantity available out of the cattle dying in Allahabad.
('48', 29, 1, 22, 67365) It was possible, he added, to increase the wealth of the country if tanning instead of remaining in the hands of a despised neglected class received a proper treatment.
('48', 29, 1, 23, 67534) The afternoon opened with a monster meeting of ladies where little Indira, now rendered famous by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru’s letters
('48', 29, 2, 24, 67666) 1 Vide “Speech at Allahabad University”, 17 11 1929. 2 Vide “Speech at Civic Reception, Allahabad”, 17 11 1929.

('48', 30, 1, 2, 67823) to her, presented a purse containing a cheque for over Rs. 8,000. This cheque represented by far the largest purse presented during the tour by the women.
('48', 30, 1, 3, 67978) This was followed by the public meeting where the balance of the collections amounting to Rs. 10,000 was presented.
('48', 30, 1, 4, 68094) The total for the Allahabad district amounted to nearly Rs. 35,000. This was wholly unexpected.
('48', 30, 1, 5, 68190) Gandhiji, the most optimistic of the party, never expected it to go beyond Rs. 25,000. Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru was the most diffident.
('48', 30, 1, 6, 68325) But Shrimati Kamala Nehru, who though only recently discharged from the hospital after a difficult operation had taken up the onerous duty of Secretary of the Reception Committee and had given herself and her co workers no rest, made the great response possible.
('48', 30, 1, 7, 68588) Pandit Motilalji had headed the list with Rs. 2,500. From Allahabad the party visited Mirzapur and Chunar.
('48', 30, 1, 8, 68695) The latter is situated on the banks of the Ganges and is a place of historic importance.
('48', 30, 1, 9, 68784) But it was visited solely for the fact that it was the place chosen by Dr. Bhagvandas for leading vanaprastha 1 life.
('48', 30, 1, 10, 68902) There, in perfect quiet and beautiful surroundings, he is living not far from his beloved Kashi, the seat of his life long activities, and yet protected from all noise and bustle of a great city.
('48', 30, 1, 11, 69098) From Chunar we retraced our steps to Allahabad en route for Bundelkhand the last of the great group of provinces known as the United Provinces.
('48', 30, 1, 12, 69242) Taking Fatehpur on the way we passed into Bundelkhand, impoverished through a pitiless visitation of famines.
('48', 30, 1, 13, 69352) At Kulapahar there is a khadi ashram.
('48', 30, 1, 14, 69390) Bundelkhand needs more than one khadi centre and many workers.
('48', 30, 1, 15, 69453) It can give relief to thousands of semi starved families and enable them to tide over years of scarcity and add to their scanty income even during good years.
('48', 30, 1, 16, 69612) Years of plenty the Indian peasant has not known for generations.There are in Bundelkhand thousands of families belonging to the Kori class.
('48', 30, 1, 17, 69753) They are hereditary weavers who do also their own spinning.
('48', 30, 1, 18, 69813) A family of four having one loom earns no more than from 11 to 12 rupees per month and therefore ekes out a bare living only on an indigenous grain corresponding to ragi or bajri 2. They have no milk nor ghee !
('48', 30, 1, 19, 70024) It was a sad sight to meet them.
('48', 30, 1, 20, 70057) There is no reason whatsoever why, like the Raniparaj 3 of Bardoli, these men and women should not be transformed in a few years and the winter of their despair turned into the summer of hope through the life giving wheel.
('48', 30, 1, 21, 70280) From Kulapahar we passed to Jhansi and thence to Orai,
('48', 30, 2, 22, 70335) 1 The third of the four ashramas of life during which one prepares for complete renunciation 2 A variety of millet 3 A scheduled tribe of South Gujarat

('48', 31, 1, 3, 70710) The U.P. tour commenced at Agra on 11th September and ended at Etawah on 24th November, i.e., after exactly two months and a fortnight.

('48', 31, 7, 20, 71854) 28. SOME THOUGHTS ON U.P. TOUR
('48', 31, 8, 21, 71885) The long awaited U.P. tour was by the grace of God finished on 24th instant.
('48', 31, 8, 22, 71962) Friends had feared a breakdown in my health but the wall of protection that Acharya Kripalani and the other companions had erected round me ensured for me as much comfort and rest as was necessary and possible in the circumstances.
('48', 31, 8, 23, 72194) The brunt of this
('48', 31, 9, 24, 72212) 1 From June 13 to July 2, 1929 2 The circular, not reproduced here, requested Congress Committees to send reports of the year’s foreign cloth boycott work,
('48', 32, 0, 1, 72368) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 33
('48', 32, 1, 2, 72413) protection however fell upon the broad shoulders of Acharya Kripalani who was sometimes really angry and more often feigned anger when leaders of places visited wanted more time and more appointments or when people insisted on seeing me or crowding into my car.
('48', 32, 1, 3, 72675) The result was that he came in some places to be regarded as a fiend without feeling, and without consideration for others.
('48', 32, 1, 4, 72799) He quietly pocketed all these epithets and went about his way.
('48', 32, 1, 5, 72862) But as we parted at Agra, his message to me was, “I have neither the heart nor the aptitude for offering apologies.
('48', 32, 1, 6, 72978) I do my duty as I know how and there my task ends.
('48', 32, 1, 7, 73029) You should offer all the necessary apologies for me.” Acharya Kripalani when I first met him in 1915 was already a seasoned warrior.
('48', 32, 1, 8, 73162) He was then earning Rs. 400 per month but was a brahmachari taking only Rs. 40 for himself and sending the balance to Dr. Choithram who was conducting a brahmacharya ashram at Hyderabad.
('48', 32, 1, 9, 73349) He became my most efficient door keeper in Champaran 1 when I was besieged by crowds of eager and pressing ryots.
('48', 32, 1, 10, 73463) In utter disregard of consequences he threw himself in the thick of the non co operation fight and from professor became a khadi hawker and organizer.
('48', 32, 1, 11, 73614) When the call came from Sardar Vallabhbhai, he responded and gave a new lease of life to the Vidyapith.
('48', 32, 1, 12, 73718) And now surrounded by a band of faithful workers he is conducting khadi ashrams in the U.P. with a zeal which any young man may well envy.
('48', 32, 1, 13, 73857) For the sake of his country he has exiled himself from Sind and is equally at home with Biharis as with U.P. men.
('48', 32, 1, 14, 73971) At the pressing instance of the A.I.S.A. he has become its co agent withPandit Jawaharlal Nehru for the U.P. And it was in this capacity that he supervised the tour.
('48', 32, 1, 15, 74137) I am sure that those who came under his lash will forgive him his quick temper.
('48', 32, 1, 16, 74217) I wish we had more workers of the Kripalani type.
('48', 32, 1, 17, 74267) Their quick temper would be forgotten in the quick and sure invigorating change that their solid work will bring about in our enervating surroundings.
('48', 32, 1, 18, 74418) Even the hopes that Acharya Kripalani had to disappoint, I know, sprang from affection of which I had as much abundance in U.P. as in Andhra and elsewhere.
('48', 32, 1, 19, 74574) Indeed the attention received by me and my companions was often embarrassing.
('48', 32, 1, 20, 74652) Where one volunteer was wanted, ten were ready.
('48', 32, 1, 21, 74700) The hospitality was imprudently lavish.
('48', 32, 1, 22, 74740) And I regret to have to confess that we were not always insistent on refusing such as was unnecessary.
('48', 32, 1, 23, 74843) My own experience is that a gentle but firm refusal to accept what is not strictly needed for creature comforts is never mistaken for rudeness.
('48', 32, 1, 24, 74987) My advice to workers is:

('48', 33, 3, 12, 75756) 29. PUBLIC FINANCE AND OUR POVERTY
('48', 33, 4, 13, 75791) Coomarappa, M.A., B.Sc., is a Fellow of the Society of Incorporated Accountants.
('48', 33, 4, 14, 75872) He has travelled abroad to gain practical experience and is now for the time being at any rate, if not permanently, in the Gujarat Vidyapith.
('48', 33, 4, 15, 76014) He has written several informing chapters on public finance and our poverty.
('48', 33, 4, 16, 76091) These being seasonable I propose to publish in instalments in these pages.
('48', 33, 4, 17, 76166) 2 The reader will learn as he proceeds that according to Sjt.
('48', 33, 4, 18, 76228) Coomarappa India spends 93.7 % on debts, military and administrative expenses as against 48.8 % spent by America.
('48', 33, 4, 19, 76342) The money thus spent by India largely goes out of it; what is spent by America remains in it.
('48', 33, 4, 20, 76436) Thus the richest country in the world spends about half of what India the poorest country in the world spends on administration.
('48', 33, 4, 21, 76565) So long as this crushing burden is not removed there is no swaraj whether one knows it by the name Dominion Status or Independence.
('48', 33, 4, 22, 76697) The reader should carefully study these chapters which contain facts rather than arguments.

('48', 34, 1, 2, 77040) 30. TEMPLES FOR ‘UNTOUCHABLES’ Swami Anand who has been leading a valiant fight for the so called untouchables writes: 1
('48', 34, 2, 3, 77161) In the beginning of the movement as I had conceived it on my return from South Africa in 1915, I had thought that it was wholly inconsistent with the movement for removing untouchaability to build separate temples or schools for them.
('48', 34, 2, 4, 77396) But experience taught me that the movement could not proceed upon strict logic and that we Hindus had so much suppressed a third of ourselves that even after the articulate Hindus had with one voice declared for removal the suppressed brethren would for a long time need the helpinghand in a variety of ways.
('48', 34, 2, 5, 77705) After the theoretical lip removal of untouchability, if no special effort was made, the vast bulk of them would not readily take advantage of the removal and the ignorant mass would not tolerate them especially when the latter would be naturally clumsy in their deportment or pardonably forward in the enjoyment of long withheld freedom.
('48', 34, 2, 6, 78043) I am therefore convinced that the two things will have to go hand in hand—perfect freedom to enter ordinary temples and ordinary schools and to use common wells at the same time as erection of model schools and model temples specially designed for the convenience of ‘untouchables’ but open to the others subject always to priority for ‘untouchables’.
('48', 34, 2, 7, 78395) It was along this line of reasoning that I suggested in the brief note for the Calcutta Municipal Gazette that the municipalities could foster removal of untouchability by erecting temples and model schools for the suppressed classes side by side with the attempt to have the existing temples thrown open to these countrymen of ours.
('48', 34, 2, 8, 78729) My note may therefore on no account be taken as an excuse for condoning prohibition against entry into temples, etc.
('48', 34, 2, 9, 78846) It is impossible to exaggerate the importance of the manifesto of the Bombay leaders who have advised the removal of the prohibition against temple entry throughout the Bombay Presidency.
('48', 34, 2, 10, 79034) I have therefore just read with great joy the news that Ramchandra temple in Bombay has been thrown open to the suppressed classes by Sjt.
('48', 34, 2, 11, 79173) Thakordas Nanabhai, a trustee of the temple.
('48', 34, 2, 12, 79218) I hope that there will be no relaxation in the effort initiated in Bombay.
('48', 34, 2, 13, 79293) Young India, 28 11 1929
('48', 34, 3, 14, 79317) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('48', 34, 3, 15, 79354) The correspondent, referring to an article by Gandhiji in the Calcutta Municipal Gazette, hat said that his “plea for building special temples for untouchables is likely to be misconstrued”.
('48', 34, 3, 16, 79545) For Gandhiji’s article in the Gazette, vide “Khaddar and untouchability: Duty of Indian Municipalities”, 12 10 1929.

('48', 35, 1, 2, 79703) 31. PRINCELY STATES
('48', 35, 2, 3, 79723) A gentleman, writing about the many immoral rulers in Central India, asks me why, knowing the facts, I am silent about them.
('48', 35, 2, 4, 79848) Several of the rulers are aged.
('48', 35, 2, 5, 79880) Many have several wives but not content with them they keep many women as half wives or concubines.
('48', 35, 2, 6, 79980) Do I expect anything even from such rulers?
('48', 35, 2, 7, 80024) I expect every human being to be virtuous, because I expect the same thing of myself.
('48', 35, 2, 8, 80110) In this world no one is perfect.
('48', 35, 2, 9, 80143) By trying hard all can become virtuous.
('48', 35, 2, 10, 80183) Some: rulers are immoral, but that is because the subjects are also wanting in morals.
('48', 35, 2, 11, 80270) Therefore, let us not be annoyed with the rulers.
('48', 35, 2, 12, 80320) Rather, when we think of the princely system let us not confuse the issue by mixing up in our deliberations thefaults of individual rulers.
('48', 35, 2, 13, 80460) This, then, is a theoretical appraisal of the aforesaid subject.
('48', 35, 2, 14, 80525) But from this let no one think that according to my belief nothing should be done regarding the princely order or regarding matters like the immorality of the rulers.
('48', 35, 2, 15, 80692) Whatever efforts are made to wipe out social evils in India must have some impact on the rulers as well.
('48', 35, 2, 16, 80797) We have no means of measuring this impact.
('48', 35, 2, 17, 80840) The truth of the matter is that our efforts at social reforms are very feeble.
('48', 35, 2, 18, 80919) So the pace of social betterment is also very slight.
('48', 35, 2, 19, 80973) There can be a special way of dealing with immoral rulers and that is the non co operation of his subjects with his rule.
('48', 35, 2, 20, 81095) It is sad that this kind of awakening or strength is almost absent among the public.
('48', 35, 2, 21, 81180) Not only this; the officials of the ruler, guided by self interest, give full support to the ruler in his misdeeds.
('48', 35, 2, 22, 81296) Lastly, we consider the Indian princely rule.
('48', 35, 2, 23, 81342) As the Emperor so his vassals.
('48', 35, 2, 24, 81373) Our Imperial Government is Satanic.
('48', 35, 2, 25, 81409) Therefore, from 1920 onwards the mighty weapon of non co operation is being wielded.
('48', 35, 2, 26, 81494) When the Imperial Government is replaced by a national government, the rulers also will become virtuous automatically.
('48', 35, 2, 27, 81613) This is the universal law—an ancient tradition.
('48', 35, 2, 28, 81661) An agitation against the Indian rulers today only makes the Imperial Government stronger, because the agitation may also amount to inviting the Imperial Government to suppress the Indian States.
('48', 35, 2, 29, 81856) I hope, after reading this explanation, it would not be difficult to understand my silence about the Indian States.
('48', 35, 2, 30, 81972) This silence of mine is part and parcel of non co operation.

('48', 36, 10, 21, 83243) 34. THE WITCH’S LAST BREATH
('48', 36, 11, 22, 83271) Ramnarayan who is a worker in the cause of the Antyajas writes from Mombasa: 1
('48', 36, 12, 23, 83350) The residents of East Africa deserve congratulations on
('48', 36, 13, 24, 83406) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('48', 36, 13, 25, 83443) The correspondent had given an account of the work he was doing in East Africa.
('48', 37, 0, 1, 83523) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 37, 1, 2, 83564) contributing their share to the fund for the service of the Antyajas.
('48', 37, 1, 3, 83634) People can ask only those persons to contribute who have the means to do so.
('48', 37, 1, 4, 83711) Hence it is not surprising that those who collect funds go so far as East Africa and such other places.
('48', 37, 1, 5, 83815) The glory of the philanthropist lies in giving alms only after examining with discrimination the merits or otherwise of each recipient.
('48', 37, 1, 6, 83951) It is the dharma of the wealthy not to contribute a single pie where the beggar begs merely in order to satisfy his hunger or the wicked does so in order to further his evil deeds.
('48', 37, 1, 7, 84132) Both good and wicked people are bound to approach them.
('48', 37, 1, 8, 84188) Their sense of discrimination is to be measured by their capacity to put these persons to the test.
('48', 37, 1, 9, 84288) On the basis of the help that he received in East Africa, Sjt.
('48', 37, 1, 10, 84351) Ramnarayan has concluded that the witch of untouchability is drawing her last breath.
('48', 37, 1, 11, 84437) To draw such a conclusion merely from the funds received by him is to go too far.
('48', 37, 1, 12, 84519) However, many symptoms bear witness to the fact that the witch is indeed drawing her last breath.
('48', 37, 1, 13, 84617) The fact that due to the efforts of Sjt.
('48', 37, 1, 14, 84658) Jamnalalji, eight famous temples in Jabalpur simultaneously opened their gates to the Antyaja brothers and sisters and that respectable gentlemen took part in it, and that in Bombay Sheth Thakoredas Nanabhai opened the gates of the Ramchandra temple to them suggests an epoch making reform.
('48', 37, 1, 15, 84949) Some who regard themselves as orthodox Hindus are trying to carry on an agitation against these efforts.
('48', 37, 1, 16, 85054) However, if the reformers are not indiscreet and if they do not give up their patience and at the same time do not abandontheir task, if they do not exceed their limits, the opposition of their opponents is bound to die down.
('48', 37, 1, 17, 85280) It is easy to understand the impatience of the Antyaja brethren.
('48', 37, 1, 18, 85345) It is but natural to feel impatient when there are no two opinions about the propriety of one’s rights, and where there is a consciousness of the injustice that is being done to one.
('48', 37, 1, 19, 85528) Nevertheless, where Hindus other than Antyajas are making constant efforts on behalf of reformers, if the Antyajas have forbearance, it is most likely that the desired result will be achieved sooner.
('48', 37, 1, 20, 85728) It is understandable that the Antyajas would have to take some steps in the matter if no Hindus other than their own community lent support to their cause or that support produced no results.
('48', 37, 1, 21, 85920) However, there is complete justification for patience in a situation where ceaseless efforts are being made by reformers and where we can actually see the good results achieved in Jabalpur, Bombay and other places.

('48', 38, 1, 2, 86217) 35. THE NAVAJIVAN TRUST
('48', 38, 2, 3, 86241) The reader will recall that in the year 1919, at a time when a fierce struggle was being conducted against the Rowlatt Act, I accepted the editorship of Young India and Navajivan in deference to the wishes of Sjt.
('48', 38, 2, 4, 86455) Shankerlal Banker, Sjt.
('48', 38, 2, 5, 86479) Umar Sobani, Sjt.
('48', 38, 2, 6, 86497) Jamnadas Dwarkadas and Sjt.
('48', 38, 2, 7, 86525) Indulal Yajnik.
('48', 38, 2, 8, 86541) A printing press was set up because everyone clearly felt that the periodicals could only be published in their own press.
('48', 38, 2, 9, 86664) It was immediately felt that a man of determination and courage was required to run it.
('48', 38, 2, 10, 86752) We supplied the requirement in bits from the Satyagraha Ashram.
('48', 38, 2, 11, 86816) However, if it was to prove its worth and become self supporting, it was necessary to get a worker who would be single minded in his devotion to it and think only of its welfare day and night.
('48', 38, 2, 12, 87009) It was not possible to spare such a person from the Ashram who would lend lustre to this post.
('48', 38, 2, 13, 87104) I thought of Swami Anand and like a soldier he honoured my wishes.
('48', 38, 2, 14, 87171) As a result, the press became self sufficient and Navajivan as an institution handed over Rs. 50,000 to Sardar Vallabhbhai for public service.

('48', 39, 4, 12, 89815) CHHAGANLAL, Since you are not in the Ashram, I do not take the trouble of writing to you every day.
('48', 39, 4, 13, 89915) But I see from your last letter that you have carried with you the burden of the Ashram.
('48', 39, 4, 14, 90004) You should lay it aside.
('48', 39, 4, 15, 90029) You have gone out on Ashram work, leaving your charge to someone else.
('48', 39, 4, 16, 90100) Why, then, should you carry any burden?
('48', 39, 4, 17, 90140) Let things happen as they will.
('48', 39, 4, 18, 90172) We have the example of Janaka constantly before us.
('48', 39, 4, 19, 90224) Gibbon’s history, though beautifully written, is not true history, for it is written with external materials.
('48', 39, 4, 20, 90334) It is based on imperfect events of the hour.
('48', 39, 4, 21, 90379) The Mahabharata, on the other hand, is based on the timeless and imperishable inner experience, and therefore it alone is true history.
('48', 39, 4, 22, 90515) We should not, therefore, regard Janaka’s example as an ancient one, but treat it as belonging to the present time.
('48', 39, 4, 23, 90631) Have faith that Krishna, Arjuna and Yudhishthira are talking about the same things and acting in the same manner today, though not under the same names.
('48', 39, 4, 24, 90784) Is it not through faith that we believe in Gibbon’s historical narrative, too?
('48', 39, 4, 25, 90863) We have, in fact, more reliable evidence to put our faith in the stories of the Mahabharata than we have in Gibbon’s history.
('48', 39, 4, 26, 90989) If we understand this simple and plain truth, many of our problems will be solved in no time.
('48', 39, 4, 27, 91083) Let us, therefore, not regard Janaka’s example as a mere brinjal in a book, but believe it to be as fresh brinjal, to be plucked and eaten, as the ones growing in our field.

('48', 47, 2, 3, 107883) Silence Day, Magshar Sud 1, 1986 [December 2, 1929]
('48', 47, 3, 4, 107935) PRABHUDAS, I did not wish to suggest that one should not write long letters even on one’s birthday.
('48', 47, 3, 5, 108035) Your letter is all right.
('48', 47, 3, 6, 108061) I do send you my blessings.
('48', 47, 3, 7, 108089) The pain is deep.
('48', 47, 3, 8, 108107) But Ramanama is not meant for a boil, which can be cured with poultice.
('48', 47, 3, 9, 108179) Ramanama is meant for making a bridge across the sea, for making paper boats sail, for turning stone into water and water into stone.
('48', 47, 3, 10, 108313) So, you cling to it with faith and devotion.
('48', 47, 3, 11, 108358) Do not worry if you can see no results on the surface.
('48', 47, 3, 12, 108413) You will triumph in the end.
