('48', 47, 3, 15, 108496) You find your own answers or ask again.
('48', 47, 3, 16, 108536) The paper should be such that it does not get torn.
('48', 47, 3, 17, 108588) I do remember one question.
('48', 47, 3, 18, 108616) While uttering Ramanama, I do not concentrate on any idol.
('48', 47, 3, 19, 108675) I do not worship Rama as an idol.
('48', 47, 3, 20, 108709) Have you not seen that we worship the name?
('48', 47, 3, 21, 108753) Tulsidas has said that the name of Rama is greater than Rama himself.
('48', 47, 3, 22, 108823) In other words, the indescribable element which is beyond physical existence is greater than what resides in the body.
('48', 47, 3, 23, 108942) Utter the name of God kind and do charitable deeds.
('48', 47, 3, 24, 108994) The significance is not of Rama the king but of the name of Rama.
('48', 47, 3, 25, 109060) Have you not seen my definition of God?
('48', 47, 3, 26, 109100) Usually I had been saying and writing that God is Truth.
('48', 47, 3, 27, 109157) In the new manual I have deliberately improved upon that definition and Inow say Truth is God.
('48', 47, 3, 28, 109252) I am here thinking of that Truth which transcends even God.
('48', 47, 3, 29, 109312) It is not only at prayer time that I have this realization.
('48', 47, 3, 30, 109372) I may say it is in me while eating and drinking, evacuating, reading, writing this, writing other things, delivering speeches—it is there every moment.
('48', 47, 3, 31, 109524) In spite of that, there is no limit to my imperfections, because the realization is only awareness; it has not permeated my being.
('48', 47, 3, 32, 109655) That may not even happen during this life.
('48', 47, 3, 33, 109698) However, why should I worry about it?
('48', 47, 3, 34, 109736) It is within my power to make an effort.
('48', 47, 3, 35, 109777) The result is in the hands of Satyanarayana.
('48', 47, 3, 36, 109822) This does not give you the complete answer.
('48', 47, 3, 37, 109866) No matter what lustful thoughts come, it is sufficient if you do not succumb to them and are not defeated.
('48', 47, 3, 38, 109973) You just sing and dance to the glory of the Lord.
('48', 47, 3, 39, 110023) Do not feel distressed that lustful thoughts assail you but fight against them.
('48', 47, 3, 40, 110103) The great quality of a Kshatriya is not victory but not flinching from battle.

('48', 47, 3, 42, 110198) Chhaganlal and Kashi have just arrived.

('48', 49, 5, 10, 111976) 45. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, SABARMATI ASHRAM
('48', 49, 6, 11, 112023) December 4, 1929 It might be argued how do an Ashram and the performing of a marriage go together.
('48', 49, 6, 12, 112122) 1 My reply is that the two are not contradictory of each other.
('48', 49, 6, 13, 112186) Those who can exercise control over the self should do so; those who cannot, may marry.
('48', 49, 6, 14, 112274) This is proper.
('48', 49, 6, 15, 112290) None need think that those who practise self control are pure and those who marry are all impure.
('48', 49, 6, 16, 112388) It is possible that a married person may be virtuous and a bachelor a hypocrite.
('48', 49, 6, 17, 112469) This is why we consider marriage desirable, although a nuisance.
('48', 49, 6, 18, 112534) In this marriage we have gone one step further.
('48', 49, 6, 19, 112582) In Man ilal’s marriage we broke the caste barrier; in this we blast the provincial prejudices.
('48', 49, 6, 20, 112677) From Gujarat we have come to Mewar.
('48', 49, 6, 21, 112713) This is a good sign.
('48', 49, 6, 22, 112734) This has added to our responsibility.
('48', 49, 6, 23, 112772) Whichever marriage is performed here, we keep the duty aspect before us and we do it in a religious way.
('48', 49, 6, 24, 112877) We adopt for ourselves a code of conduct.
('48', 49, 6, 25, 112919) Considering the present conditions in these troubled times, if we can master the passion it will indeed be good.
('48', 49, 6, 26, 113032) But we ought not to resort to compulsion.
('48', 49, 6, 27, 113074) If, therefore, a boy or a girl so desires, a partner should be found, and they should be blessed into wedlock.
('48', 49, 6, 28, 113185) This is theduty of the Ashram.
('48', 49, 6, 29, 113216) So far,we have been acting on this premise and the result has not been bad.
('48', 49, 6, 30, 113292) We perform the wedding without pageantry, in a short time, and with pure minds.
('48', 49, 6, 31, 113372) This is a matter of joy.
('48', 49, 6, 32, 113397) This marriage was precluded by uneasiness and anxiety which have now vanished.
('48', 49, 6, 33, 113476) All possible precautions were taken.

('48', 50, 4, 33, 115179) 46. OUR BRETHREN THE TREES 2
('48', 50, 5, 34, 115208) Gandhiji wanted to card some cotton and make slivers before going to bed, even though it was getting late.
('48', 50, 5, 35, 115315) I went to put the bow, etc., ready and, being in a hurry, I asked a local volunteer to fetch me from the garden some babul tree leaves, which one requires for applying to the gut of the bow.
('48', 50, 5, 36, 115506) The boy brought me a large bunch, and as he handed it to me, I was surprised to notice that each little leaf was tightly folded up.
('48', 50, 5, 37, 115638) I took them to Gandhiji’s room.
('48', 50, 5, 38, 115670) “Do you see, Bapu,” I said, “the little leaves have all gone to sleep!” “Of course,” replied Gandhiji, looking up with indignation and pity in his eyes.
('48', 50, 5, 39, 115823) “Trees are living beings just like ourselves.
('48', 50, 5, 40, 115869) They live and breathe, they feed and drink as we do, and like us they need sleep.
('48', 50, 5, 41, 115951) It is a wretched thing to go and tear the leaves off a tree at night when it is resting!
('48', 50, 5, 42, 116040) And why have you
('48', 50, 6, 43, 116057) 1 The following paragraph was addressed to Shankarlal Agrawal.
('48', 50, 6, 44, 116120) 2 Vide “Letter to Mirabehn”, 2 12 1929.
('48', 51, 0, 1, 116160) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 51, 1, 2, 116201) brought such a huge quantity?
('48', 51, 1, 3, 116231) Only a few leaves were necessary.
('48', 51, 1, 4, 116265) Surely you heard what I said at the meeting yesterday about the poor flowers, and how deeply it pains me that people should pluck those masses of delicate blossoms to fling in my face and hang round my neck.
('48', 51, 1, 5, 116473) Was not it thoughtless to send someone out like that to worry and pain a tree at such a late hour when it had folded its leaves in sleep?
('48', 51, 1, 6, 116611) We should feel a more living bond between ourselves and the rest of animate creation.” “Yes, Bapu, I know—I understand,” said I, hanging my head in shame.
('48', 51, 1, 7, 116766) “It was very thoughtless of me, In future I will always go myself, and I will endeavour never again unnecessarily to disturb the peaceful sleep of the trees by plucking at their foliage after dark.” And I felt doubly ashamed of myself, as many and many a time have I gained comfort and guidance from our forest brethren.
('48', 51, 1, 8, 117087) Often have I put my arms round the trunk of an old mighty tree and listened to his hushed words of wisdom and peace.
('48', 51, 1, 9, 117204) How could I have been so heartless !
('48', 51, 1, 10, 117241) Let not the reader call this sentimental twaddle, or accuse me or Mirabai of hopeless inconsistency in that we swallow a camel when we eat vegetables by the cartload and strain at a gnat because we would not care to pluck a leaf from a tree having its night’s rest.
('48', 51, 1, 11, 117507) ‘Even a butcher may be to a certainextent humane.’ Because a man eats mutton, he does not slaughter a herd of sheep when they are asleep.
('48', 51, 1, 12, 117645) The essence of manliness consists in showing the utmost consideration to all life, animal as well as vegetable.
('48', 51, 1, 13, 117757) He who in search of pleasure shows little consideration for others is surely less than man.
('48', 51, 1, 14, 117849) He is thoughtless.
('48', 51, 2, 15, 117868) India has cultivated no small respect for trees and other sentient beings.
('48', 51, 2, 16, 117943) The poet describes Damayanti going from tree to tree in the wood bewailing her lot.
('48', 51, 2, 17, 118027) For her companions, Shakuntala had trees as also the birds and beasts.
('48', 51, 2, 18, 118098) The great poet, Kalidasa, tells us how her separation from them all was painful to her.

('48', 51, 4, 20, 118234) 47. ZAMINDARS AND TALUKDARS
('48', 51, 5, 21, 118262) Nothing during the recent U.P. tour pleased me more than the way in which several young zamindars and talukdars had simplified their lives and fired by patriotic zeal were easing the burden of the ryots.
('48', 51, 5, 22, 118466) I had heard fearful accounts of the alleged atrocities of many zamindars and their mode of levying cesses, legal and illegal, on all conceivable occasions with the result that the ryot was reduced to serfdom pure and simple.
('48', 51, 5, 23, 118691) The discovery therefore of so many young
('48', 51, 6, 24, 118732) 1 Navajivan, 12 1 1930, has the following additional paragraph.
('48', 52, 0, 1, 118796) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 53
('48', 52, 1, 2, 118841) talukdars was a very pleasant surprise to me.
('48', 52, 1, 3, 118887) But the improvement has to go further and be thorough.
('48', 52, 1, 4, 118942) There is yet even among the best of them a wide gulf between themselves and the ryots.
('48', 52, 1, 5, 119029) There is yet a great deal of patronizing and self satisfaction over the little that has been done.
('48', 52, 1, 6, 119128) The fact is that whatever may be done is no more than a belated return to the ryots of their due.
('48', 52, 1, 7, 119226) The hideous caricature of varnashrama is responsible for the air of superiority that the so called Kshatriya assumes and the status of inherited inferiority the poor ryot submissively recognizes as his deserved lot in life.
('48', 52, 1, 8, 119450) If Indian society is to make real progress along peaceful lines, there must be a definite recognition on the part of the moneyed class that the ryot possesses the same soul that they do and that their wealth gives them no superiority over the poor.
('48', 52, 1, 9, 119699) They must regard themselves, even as the Japanese nobles did, as trustees holding their wealth for the good of their wards, the ryots.Then they would take no more than a reasonable amount as commission for their labours.
('48', 52, 1, 10, 119920) At present there is no proportion between the wholly unnecessary pomp and extravagance of the moneyed class and the squalid surroundings and the grinding pauperism of the ryots in whose midst the former are living.
('48', 52, 1, 11, 120135) A model zamindar would therefore at once reduce much of the burden the ryot is now bearing, he would come in intimate touch with the ryots and know their wants and inject hope into them in the place of despair which is killing the very life out of them.
('48', 52, 1, 12, 120389) He will not be satisfied with the ryots’ ignorance of the laws of sanitation and hygiene.
('48', 52, 1, 13, 120479) He will reduce himself to poverty in order that the ryot may have the necessaries of life.
('48', 52, 1, 14, 120570) He will study the economic condition of the ryots under his care, establish schools in which he will educate his own children side by side with those of the ryots.
('48', 52, 1, 15, 120734) He will purify the village well and the village tank.
('48', 52, 1, 16, 120788) He will teach the ryot to sweep his roads and clean his latrines by himself doing this necessary labour.
('48', 52, 1, 17, 120893) He will throw open without reserve his own gardens for the unrestricted use of the ryot.
('48', 52, 1, 18, 120982) He will use as hospital, school, or the like most of the unnecessary buildings which he keeps for his pleasure.
('48', 52, 1, 19, 121094) If only the capitalist class will read the signs of the times, revise their notions of God given right to all they possess, in an incredibly short space of time the seven hundred thousand dung heaps which today pass muster as villages can be turned into abodes of peace, health and comfort.
('48', 52, 1, 20, 121385) I am convinced that the capitalist, if he follows the Samurai of Japan, has nothing really to lose and everything to gain.
('48', 52, 1, 21, 121508) There is no other choice than between voluntary surrender on the part of the capitalist of superfluities and consequent acquisition of the real happiness of all on the one hand, and on the other the impending chaos into which, if the capitalist does
('48', 53, 0, 1, 121758) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 53, 1, 2, 121799) not wake up betimes, awakened but ignorant, famishing millions will plunge the country and which not even the armed force that a powerful Government can bring into play can avert.
('48', 53, 1, 3, 121979) I have hoped that India will successfully avert the disaster.
('48', 53, 1, 4, 122041) The privilege I had of meeting intimately some of the young talukdars in the U.P. has strengthened the hope.

('48', 53, 2, 6, 122173) 48. KHADI AND HONESTY
('48', 53, 3, 7, 122195) C. R. Rajagopalachari sends me an interesting letter, which with the omission of personal references and one or two redundant passages I publish below: 1
('48', 53, 4, 8, 122349) I admit that till now I have been indifferent regarding khadi.
('48', 53, 4, 9, 122412) But I have now realized that khadi men are men who follow truth.
('48', 53, 4, 10, 122477) The day before yesterday I went to Coimbatore khadi depot.
('48', 53, 4, 11, 122536) I had with me notes of the value of Rs. 10,000 .
('48', 53, 4, 12, 122585) which I placed .
('48', 53, 4, 13, 122602) on the table.
('48', 53, 4, 14, 122616) I quite forgot about the money and left the depot.
('48', 53, 4, 15, 122667) After some time, your manager saw the money and in the hot sun came to Podanur .
('48', 53, 4, 16, 122748) handed over the money to me .
('48', 53, 4, 17, 122778) This letter shows how unreasoning and illogical we are.
('48', 53, 4, 18, 122834) Surely there is no necessary connection between honesty and khadi.
('48', 53, 4, 19, 122901) Even rogues must cover themselves and therefore may wear khadi.
('48', 53, 4, 20, 122965) I am sorry also to have to confess that not all the workers in the employ of the A.I.S.A. have always been found to be honest.
('48', 53, 4, 21, 123092) Would that every one of them was incorruptible.
('48', 53, 4, 22, 123140) But alas!
('48', 53, 4, 23, 123150) khadi service like every other service has its black sheep.
('48', 53, 4, 24, 123210) And supposing for the moment that all khadi servants were incorruptible, it is still possible for khadi to be a huge mistake or an economic waste.
('48', 53, 4, 25, 123357) But I know that many have come to khadi not on the strength of its merits but on grounds irrelevant to khadi, and I knew too that some others have left off using khadi not because it is an error but because they have not liked something some khadi men have done or not done.
('48', 53, 4, 26, 123632) Whilst therefore I do not mind the adventitious aid such as the possessor of the ten thousand rupees notes promises to give, khadi to be stable must stand on its own unassailable merits.
('48', 53, 4, 27, 123819) These are fortunately being proved day after day.
('48', 53, 4, 28, 123869) The other reflection the foregoing letter gives rise to is somewhat humiliating.
('48', 53, 4, 29, 123950) Why should anyone run into ecstasies because someone is found to possess the ordinary honesty of not stealing other people’s property?

('48', 54, 2, 7, 124497) 49. “THE STORY OF BARDOLI”
('48', 54, 3, 8, 124524) Mahadev Desai who was the literary secretary of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel during the Bardoli Satyagraha campaign wrote some months ago the history of that great and eventful struggle in Gujarati.
('48', 54, 3, 9, 124719) Sardar Vallabhbhai had intended that an English edition too should be published so that a wider public may be in possession of a faithful record of the events.
('48', 54, 3, 10, 124879) Mahadev Desai had first hand and intimate knowledge of most of the stirring events of those exciting times.
('48', 54, 3, 11, 124987) He has now placed before the public an English edition.
('48', 54, 3, 12, 125043) In view of the impending upheaval during the coming year, the book should be read by every national worker.
('48', 54, 3, 13, 125151) The text covers 323 pages and including the appendices and the index extends to 363 pages.
('48', 54, 3, 14, 125242) It is published by the Navajivan Press at Rs. 2/8 cardboard binding with khadi back.
('48', 54, 3, 15, 125327) It contains a specially prepared map, fine illustrations and a helpful glossary.
('48', 54, 3, 16, 125408) Young India, 5 12 1929
('48', 54, 4, 17, 125431) 50. OUR DELUSION
('48', 54, 5, 18, 125448) Tulsidas says:
('48', 54, 6, 19, 125463) Like the appearance of silver in conch shell And of water in the sun’s rays; Illusions, though ever unreal, Are impossible to remove.
('48', 54, 6, 20, 125597) Every day I experience the profound truth embodied in these lines.
('48', 54, 6, 21, 125664) Any notion—whether good or evil—is hard to remove once it takes possession of one’s head or heart, unless experience destroys it.
('48', 54, 6, 22, 125794) So has the delusion in the form of untouchability taken deep roots among the Hindus.
('48', 54, 6, 23, 125879) Reason tells us that no one is untouchable.
('48', 54, 6, 24, 125923) People have neither a name nor a definition for an untouchable.
('48', 54, 6, 25, 125987) If an untouchable conceals his so called untouchability no one, excepting a few who recognize him, will guess that he is an untouchable.
('48', 54, 6, 26, 126124) That is why several ‘untouchable’ brothers can freely visit temples and other places.
('48', 55, 0, 1, 126210) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 55, 1, 2, 126251) If untouchability were a part of religion an untouchable of one province would be treated as such in every other province.
('48', 55, 1, 3, 126374) In fact, however, the untouchables of Assam are not considered untouchables in Sind.
('48', 55, 1, 4, 126459) The untouchables of Travancore are not treated as such anywhere else.
('48', 55, 1, 5, 126529) Not a trace of the untouchability and unapproac hability prevalent in Travancore is to be seen in other places.
('48', 55, 1, 6, 126641) This delusion of untouchability has assumed monstrous and terrible proportion among the Hindus.
('48', 55, 1, 7, 126737) Shri Jamnalal is striving hard to eradicate it.
('48', 55, 1, 8, 126785) His success in getting the temples thrown open to the untouchables is no mean achievement.
('48', 55, 1, 9, 126876) Events like the opening of the eight temples to the untouchables at Jabalpur and the participation of distinguished citizens, etc., are quite hopeful signs.
('48', 55, 1, 10, 127033) The best way to remove this delusion of untouchability is that those who have overcome it should by their actions convince others still labouring under it that untouchability has no connection with religion.
('48', 55, 1, 11, 127241) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 5 12 1929

('48', 57, 3, 7, 129525) He will give her the work which we have thought about.
('48', 57, 3, 8, 129580) After the talk, I wrote to you yesterday.

('48', 57, 3, 10, 129653) I enclose with this papers which should be filed with you.
('48', 57, 3, 11, 129712) Important changes have been introduced in the Ashram this time.
('48', 57, 3, 12, 129776) Keep a note of them.
('48', 57, 3, 13, 129797) We must have a record of lapses due to carelessness on everyone’s part.
('48', 57, 3, 14, 129869) Say, for instance, someone did not do his work in the kitchen in time; in such a case a note should go to the office.
('48', 57, 3, 15, 129987) Even if no action is taken in the matter, the thing should not remain out of notice of the manager and the chief manager of the department concerned.
('48', 57, 3, 16, 130137) The registers of all adult students, that is, of students who are above 16, should be complete so that we may know from them which of them attended prayers both times on how many days and did or neglected sacrificial spinning on which days.

('48', 57, 3, 20, 130585) The work of the sanitary department must become regular.

('48', 58, 7, 29, 132494) 57. APPEAL TO AHMEDABAD LABOURERS
('48', 58, 8, 30, 132528) December 7, 1929
('48', 58, 9, 31, 132545) Mahatma Gandhi has issued an appeal to the workmen following the award of the Umpire, Diwan Bahadur Krishnalal Mohanlal Jhaveri, in which Mahatma Gandhi says that he is grieved, as they might have been grieved, because the Umpire has not fully accepted their demand.
('48', 58, 9, 32, 132812) Their demand was perfectly proper, but after accepting the principle of arbitration they must accept the decision of the arbitrators or Umpire
('48', 59, 0, 1, 132955) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 59, 1, 2, 132996) whether they like it or not.
('48', 59, 1, 3, 133025) The Umpire has accepted one principle which is of great importance from the viewpoint of workers.
('48', 59, 1, 4, 133123) They have been contending for years that they are not getting even a living wage which they have a right to obtain and from which there can be no reduction.
('48', 59, 1, 5, 133280) The Umpire has accepted this principle.
('48', 59, 1, 6, 133320) He agrees that the figures of expenditure which they have produced are legitimate and in comparison with those figures their wages are less.
('48', 59, 1, 7, 133461) On this ground their demand was bound to be fully accepted.
('48', 59, 1, 8, 133521) But it is their duty to be satisfied with what the Umpire has given.
('48', 59, 1, 9, 133590) This does not, however, mean that they should give up their effort to secure a living wage.
('48', 59, 1, 10, 133682) That effort will continue to be made by all legitimate means and they will make that demand at the first suitable opportunity.
('48', 59, 1, 11, 133809) Meanwhile it is their duty to make good use of the increase in wages which they have got by bettering themselves, by giving up their vices and by increasing their efficiency.
('48', 59, 1, 12, 133984) They should thank the Umpire for the great care with which he has examined their case.
('48', 59, 1, 13, 134071) The Bombay Chronicle, 10 12 1929
('48', 59, 2, 14, 134104) 58. MY NOTES
('48', 59, 3, 15, 134117) GUJARAT VIDYAPITH I would like to draw the attention of readers to the appeal issued by Sardar Vallabhbhai and Kakasaheb Kalelkar on behalf of the Gujarat Vidyapith.
('48', 59, 3, 16, 134283) Gujarat is not ignorant of the services rendered by the Vidyapith and the contribution made by it to the non co operation movement.
('48', 59, 3, 17, 134415) Acharya Gidwani, Acharya Kripalani and now Kakasaheb have nurtured this plant.
('48', 59, 3, 18, 134494) Gujaratis have supplied the required quantities of water to it.
('48', 59, 3, 19, 134558) More water is required now.
('48', 59, 3, 20, 134586) The Vidyapith, instead of pursuing a policy of accumulating wealth and building up capital, has relied on the generosity of the public.
('48', 59, 3, 21, 134722) It is an institution of the people.
('48', 59, 3, 22, 134758) They should water it so long as they wish.
('48', 59, 3, 23, 134801) This is one of the best external methods of preserving the integrity of a public institution.
('48', 59, 3, 24, 134895) Ordinarily, funds are collected from people by going from door to door.
('48', 59, 3, 25, 134967) This time, Sardar Vallabhbhai and Kakasaheb have expressed a new hope.
('48', 59, 3, 26, 135038) They expect the people to contribute to the best of their abilities without expecting a visit to their homes.
('48', 59, 3, 27, 135148) It should not be necessary for the principal organizers to give their time to the collection of funds.
('48', 59, 3, 28, 135251) Gujaratis should send their contributions, according to their capacity, for the institution which they love.
('48', 59, 3, 29, 135360) It is my hope that they will fulfil the expectations of Sardar and Kakasaheb.
('48', 59, 3, 30, 135438) This appeal is addressed not to Gujarat but to Gujaratis.
('48', 59, 3, 31, 135496) That is to say, it is imperative for Gujaratis living outside Gujarat, whether in other provinces, in Burma, Singapore, Japan, East, South or North Africa, Mauritius, Madagascar or other countries also to send in their contributions.

('48', 60, 0, 1, 135767) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 61
('48', 60, 1, 2, 135812) 59. SOME SIGNIFICANT QUESTIONS
('48', 60, 2, 3, 135843) A friend has asked some significant questions with reference to the bombshell that the Viceroy has thrown in our midst, the resulting tumult and the hopes entertained in some quarters.
('48', 60, 2, 4, 136028) These questions must have arisen in the minds of many others too.
('48', 60, 2, 5, 136094) Hence it is necessary to some extent to express my views on them.
('48', 60, 2, 6, 136160) I give below the questions and the replies.
('48', 60, 3, 7, 136204) What is meant by Dominion Status ?
('48', 60, 3, 8, 136239) Does it imply a genuine partnership and an equal status in the British Empire, or does it mean responsible government under the leadership of the British?
('48', 60, 3, 9, 136394) Does it imply the Dominion Status as understood prior to 1919 or the status as defined by the Imperial Conference of 1926?
('48', 60, 3, 10, 136517) The term Dominion Status has no definite connotation.
('48', 60, 3, 11, 136571) If the terminology applicable to living beings can be applied to it, it may be said that it has not even attained maturity yet, and hence it deserves to be protected and can be made very healthy if fed on a proper diet.If the atmosphere is unfavourable, there is a possibility of its becoming pale since it happens to be delicate.
('48', 60, 3, 12, 136902) And it may even be suffocated if it does not get oxygen.
('48', 60, 3, 13, 136959) Hence the health and vitality of that baby depend upon the country where it is nurtured.
('48', 60, 3, 14, 137048) If it happens to come to India, its development will depend upon how we look after it.
('48', 60, 3, 15, 137135) Hence, in my opinion, we have little to do with the definitions given in 1919 and 1926. Its definition will be determined by our ability to obtain it.
('48', 60, 3, 16, 137286) And when its precise connotation has not been defined, every person can interpret it as he chooses.
('48', 60, 3, 17, 137386) My definition is this: Dominion Status implies the fullest equality and a voluntary relationship with the British Government in India which either party can freely break off with or without giving reasons for doing so.
('48', 60, 3, 18, 137605) It does not exist where there is any room whatsoever for the distinction of superior and inferior.
('48', 60, 3, 19, 137704) Dominion Status means independence.
('48', 60, 4, 20, 137740) 2. The Indian States may, of course, be invited to the same Conference as British India.
('48', 60, 4, 21, 137829) But what if the former come in the way of true independence of British India?
('48', 60, 4, 22, 137907) What guarantee is there that the British Government will not side with them and prevent us from progressing by making their treaty with the Indian States a pretext?
('48', 60, 4, 23, 138072) Right up to the present day, the States have been deliberately kept aloof from the political activities of British India; why is this policy being reversed today all of a sudden?
('48', 60, 4, 24, 138251) Even the Butler Committee is opposed to the amalgamation of the Indian States with British India without the former’s consent.
('48', 60, 4, 25, 138378) Why then this sudden reversal of outlook?
('48', 60, 4, 26, 138420) And what about the subjects of the Indian States?
('48', 60, 4, 27, 138470) Have their representatives no place whatsoever in the forthcoming Conference?
('48', 60, 4, 28, 138548) Whether the Indian States intend to do so or not, they will certainly stand in our way if we—that is, the party demanding
('48', 61, 0, 1, 138670) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 61, 1, 2, 138711) swaraj—lack spirit.
('48', 61, 1, 3, 138731) I myself have scented some diplomacy in the bringing of the Indian States to the forefront at this juncture.
('48', 61, 1, 4, 138840) The Empire has earlier used them as pawns in their game.
('48', 61, 1, 5, 138897) It seems that these pawns have been used this time.
('48', 61, 1, 6, 138949) The princes are dependent on the Empire for their very existence.
('48', 61, 1, 7, 139015) Hence they have no alternative but to dance to the tune of the Empire, and if we realized this we shall also know that we shall not be able to derive any advantage by maligning them.
('48', 61, 1, 8, 139198) We should realize their dependence, regard them as merely the limbs of the Empire and be on our guard, and, knowing that in whatever they say or do on such an occasion they merely echo the words or the deeds of the Empire, we should concentrate our attention upon the latter alone.
('48', 61, 1, 9, 139480) I entertain no fears regarding the subjects of the Indian States.
('48', 61, 1, 10, 139546) So long as independence is not secured, many of the evils of the Empirewill be found to be magnified in the Indian States.
('48', 61, 1, 11, 139669) I cannot visualize a form of swaraj in which the Swaraj Party would have bartered away the rights of the people of the Indian States.
('48', 61, 2, 12, 139803) 3. Supposing there is unanimous agreement at the Conference, does Parliament still have the authority to make changes in its decisions?
('48', 61, 2, 13, 139939) It has been authoritatively proclaimed that Parliament continues to maintain its independence in this context and even the political parties in Britain are not in any way committed in this matter.
('48', 61, 2, 14, 140136) Is there not then the possibility of the labours of the forthcoming Conference coming to naught?
('48', 61, 2, 15, 140233) There should be some guarantee regarding this also— and that too before we agree to cooperate.
('48', 61, 2, 16, 140328) This question is an echo of our weakness.
('48', 61, 2, 17, 140370) From the legal standpoint, Parliament is certainly the supreme body.
('48', 61, 2, 18, 140439) It can wipe out the work of the Conference.
('48', 61, 2, 19, 140483) However, there is no need to ask for any guarantee regarding the decision of the Conference, as suggested by the person who has put the question, at a conference which India will be attending by reason of its strength.
('48', 61, 2, 20, 140702) Moreover, I am also of opinion that it does no credit to us to ask for such a guarantee and that no party in Britain has the right to give it.
('48', 61, 3, 21, 140845) 4. Why is such great emphasis laid on the policy of 1917 and the Act of 1919?
('48', 61, 3, 22, 140923) Lord Irwin claims that India will get swaraj as a matter of course according to the policy of 1917. What does the phrase “in the fulness of time” signify?
('48', 61, 3, 23, 141078) Mr. Benn says, “There is no change, in substance or time, until after the Conference has met.’’ 1
('48', 61, 4, 24, 141176) Do they not appear to be threatening words?
('48', 61, 4, 25, 141220) And, in all this, there is no reference whatever to the economic rights—economic independence— of India.
('48', 61, 4, 26, 141325) According to the Congress resolution of 1922, the Indian people are not bound to pay up their national debt.
('48', 61, 4, 27, 141434) Has that resolution been completely set aside?
('48', 61, 4, 28, 141481) Will Haji’s Coastal Reservation Bill 2 also be set aside?
('48', 61, 4, 29, 141539) Foreign banks have usurped many rights;
('48', 61, 5, 30, 141579) 1 The source has the passages in quotes in English.
('48', 61, 5, 31, 141631) 2 To reserve for Indians trade along the coastal ports
('48', 62, 0, 1, 141686) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 63
('48', 62, 1, 2, 141731) shall we ever take these into account ?
('48', 62, 1, 3, 141771) These points are not included in the clarification issued by Lord Irwin; but could we, for that reason, forget them?
('48', 62, 1, 4, 141888) The fact that the Act of 1919 has been stressed gives rise to fear.
('48', 62, 1, 5, 141956) And even if there is nothing to fear in it, it certainly is an ambiguous statement.
('48', 62, 1, 6, 142040) It is for this very reason that the leaders who have signed it have been asked to clarify its meaning.
('48', 62, 1, 7, 142143) I am not unhappy because the economic independence of India has not been mentioned in the official communication issued by Lord Irwin.
('48', 62, 1, 8, 142278) Anything that does not include economic independence cannot be regarded as swaraj at all.
('48', 62, 1, 9, 142368) The Congress resolution of 1922 regarding the debt has not been nullified; it still holds good and its consideration is essential in the scheme of swaraj.
('48', 62, 1, 10, 142523) The same may be said of the Haji Bill and the banks.
('48', 62, 1, 11, 142576) We cannot expect to find the plan for swaraj to be given in the official communication of the Viceroy.
('48', 62, 1, 12, 142679) However, it should certainly be made clear that the Congress Party can attend a conference only on condition that each and every question relating to swaraj can be freely discussed there.
('48', 62, 1, 13, 142867) This has not been clarified in Lord Irwin’s communication and in my opinion it is the dharma not only of the Congress Party but of all other parties also to have this point clarified before attending the Conference.
('48', 62, 1, 14, 143083) Let me finally say this too.
('48', 62, 1, 15, 143112) The Labour Government does have the authority but lacks the strength to utilize that authority to its fullest extent.
('48', 62, 1, 16, 143230) We on our part lack the strength to get our demands accepted.
('48', 62, 1, 17, 143292) Hence I entertain only a meagre hope of two parties which lack strength getting together and doing any great service to India.
('48', 62, 1, 18, 143419) My inner voice tells me that if the British Labour Party really wishes to see India gain her independence, it should muster all its strength at present and then carry on a life and death struggle until this independence is achieved.
('48', 62, 1, 19, 143652) We, on the other hand, should realize our want of strength and keep away from such intricate matters like conferences.
('48', 62, 1, 20, 143771) However, worldly affairs are not carried on in such logical manner.
('48', 62, 1, 21, 143839) Hence, we cannot suddenly turn down a hopeful proposal even if it be one from the weak Labour Party.
('48', 62, 1, 22, 143940) We may attend the Conference, in fact, it should be the dharma of the satyagrahi to do so, provided conditions are granted which would ensure success and an atmosphere is created where we are assured that these will be abided by.
('48', 62, 1, 23, 144170) A satyagrahi will not let go an opportunity, however small it may be, for any possible compromise.
('48', 62, 1, 24, 144269) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 8 12 1929

('48', 64, 1, 2, 145461) 62. LETTER TO VITHALBHAI PATEL
('48', 64, 2, 3, 145492) WARDHA, ON THE GRANT TRUNK EXPRESS, Sunday morning, December 8, 1929
('48', 64, 3, 4, 145561) BHAISHRI.
('48', 64, 3, 5, 145571) 1, On the last day I got a long wire from Motilalji saying that he had received the invitation 2 for the 23rd December and that he had accepted it.
('48', 64, 3, 6, 145719) He also writes that the Viceroy does not wish to meet all the leaders together, but for the present only wants to know the attitude of the Congress.
('48', 64, 3, 7, 145868) That is why he has invited Motilalji.
('48', 64, 3, 8, 145906) If I wished to go with him, the Viceroy would certainly invite me.
('48', 64, 3, 9, 145973) In these circumstances I think it is not at all necessary for me to go.
('48', 64, 3, 10, 146045) 3 For the present it is best that Motilalji alone should meet him.
('48', 64, 3, 11, 146112) In my opinion it will be useless for you or Mr. Jinnah to go.
('48', 64, 3, 12, 146174) I think my going can only do harm.
('48', 64, 4, 13, 146209) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('48', 64, 5, 15, 146277) 63. A LETTER
('48', 64, 6, 16, 146290) WARDHA, December 8, 1929
('48', 64, 7, 17, 146315) DEAR MR. PRESIDENT, I hope the conference will succeed.
('48', 64, 7, 18, 146371) Day by day I am being confirmed in the views I have expressed from time to time regarding the Princely States.
('48', 64, 7, 19, 146482) 1. So long as we have not attained freedom, I think true reform in the Princely States is impossible.
('48', 64, 7, 20, 146584) 2. The evils of the States are never going to be remedied by merely condemning them.
('48', 64, 7, 21, 146669) 3. Nor is real reform going to take place so long as there is no real awakening among the subjects of the States.
('48', 64, 7, 22, 146783) 4. Those who are full of anger can never offer satyagraha.
('48', 64, 7, 23, 146842) Bear in mind these points during your deliberations and give them whatever importance you can.
('48', 64, 8, 24, 146937) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('48', 65, 10, 15, 147680) WARDHA, Silence Day, December 9, 1929
('48', 65, 11, 16, 147718) SISTERS, When I was with you this time, there were so many things to keep me busy that I forgot to talk to you about two matters.
('48', 65, 12, 17, 147848) 1 This was in reply to the addressee’s telegram received on December 9,1929 which read: “Anxiously awaiting your wire for writing to the Viceroy.
('48', 65, 12, 18, 147994) Sapru has consented.” 2 Conveying the contents of this letter, the addressee wrote to the Viceroy on December 11, 1929: “Gandhi now writes to me that he has received a telegram from Motilal .
('48', 65, 12, 19, 148186) that he (Motilal) has already received and accepted an invitation from Your Excellency to meet you on the 23rd of December and that the idea is to discuss the Congress point of view with Your Excellency with Congressmen alone.
('48', 65, 12, 20, 148413) In these circumstances, Gandhi adds that it was wholly unnecessary for me to move in the matter.
('48', 65, 12, 21, 148510) On receipt of this letter, I at once sent a copy of it to Mr. Jinnah and informed him that the arrangement had fallen through.” Vithalbhai Patel: Life and Times, Book II, p.
('48', 66, 0, 1, 148684) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 67
('48', 66, 1, 2, 148729) them came to my notice so late that there was no time then to talk about it.
('48', 66, 1, 3, 148806) The other went out of my mind altogether.
('48', 66, 1, 4, 148848) I shall take up the second matter first.
('48', 66, 1, 5, 148889) Our women do not let themselves be examined by [male] doctors or even be operated upon.
('48', 66, 1, 6, 148977) This is a false sense of shame and has its origin in an impure state of the mind.
('48', 66, 1, 7, 149059) In this matter I prefer the practice in Western countries.
('48', 66, 1, 8, 149118) I do know that at times it has had undesirable consequences.
('48', 66, 1, 9, 149179) When an unscrupulous doctor has a simple minded woman patient whose passion is easily aroused, evil results have followed.
('48', 66, 1, 10, 149302) But this happens all over the world in any conditions.
('48', 66, 1, 11, 149357) That should not deter us from pursuing good and necessary activities.
('48', 66, 1, 12, 149427) We should have confidence in ourselves.
('48', 66, 1, 13, 149467) I, therefore, liked it very much that Santok got herself operated upon by Dr. Haribhai and my belief in her courage was confirmed.
('48', 66, 1, 14, 149598) In Phoenix we had made this a common practice.
('48', 66, 1, 15, 149645) When Devdas was born, a male doctor was in attendance.
('48', 66, 1, 16, 149700) Ba had a complaint of the vaginal canal and required an operation.
('48', 66, 1, 17, 149767) It was performed by a male doctor.
('48', 66, 1, 18, 149802) Ba is very brave but simple about such matters.
('48', 66, 1, 19, 149850) She certainly requires my presence at such times, but that is a small matter.
('48', 66, 1, 20, 149928) Everyone requires a trusted person by his or her side on such occasion, and that is but right.
('48', 66, 1, 21, 150023) My purpose in writing about all this is to explain to you that in the Ashram we should cultivate this type of courage and abandon false shame.
('48', 66, 1, 22, 150166) Hundreds and thousands of women suffer because of such shame.
('48', 66, 1, 23, 150228) We have before us Vidyavati’s example.
('48', 66, 1, 24, 150267) She would not let her private parts be examined even by a woman doctor.
('48', 66, 1, 25, 150339) We wish to cultivate the innocence of Shukadevji.
('48', 66, 1, 26, 150389) We should not, of course, pretend to have it so long as we have not succeeded in acquiring it.
('48', 66, 1, 27, 150484) There are men whose passion is aroused by the mere touch of a woman, and there are, likewise, women who are aroused by the mere touch of a man.
('48', 66, 1, 28, 150628) Such persons should certainly force themselves to live as untouchables, even if that means their continuing to suffer a disease.
('48', 66, 1, 29, 150757) Here I have only suggested that you should give up false shame.
('48', 66, 1, 30, 150821) Those who are afraid of impure feelings being aroused in them by the mere touch of a man should admit that candidly and behave with due regard to the limitations of their nature.
('48', 66, 1, 31, 151000) Such a passionate nature is a kind of disease and a man or woman who suffers from it should avoid the touch of a person of the opposite sex The disease will probably disappear in course of time.
('48', 66, 1, 32, 151195) Read this part of the letter several times and try to understand its meaning.
('48', 66, 1, 33, 151273) If you do not understand it, ask me.
('48', 66, 1, 34, 151310) Valjibhai, too, will explain it if you ask him.
('48', 66, 1, 35, 151358) It is, of course, simple enough.
('48', 66, 1, 36, 151391) The second point arises from Umiya’s wedding.
('48', 66, 1, 37, 151437) Immediately after the wedding, she started wearing ornaments in her ears and nose.
('48', 66, 1, 38, 151520) I did not like this at all.
('48', 66, 1, 39, 151548) The giver and the receiver were both at fault.
('48', 67, 0, 1, 151595) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 67, 1, 2, 151636) What was done was against our practice in the Ashram.
('48', 67, 1, 3, 151690) Umiya could have started wearing ornaments after she had gone to live with her husband, but the poor girl could not wait till then.
('48', 67, 1, 4, 151822) I mention this incident not as a complaint, but in order to draw a lesson from it.
('48', 67, 1, 5, 151905) Let no other girl follow Umiya’s example.
('48', 67, 1, 6, 151947) Poor Umiya, after all, has not been trained in the Ashram.
('48', 67, 1, 7, 152006) Jaisukhlal has not paid sufficient attention to her.
('48', 67, 1, 8, 152059) Her mother is a good natured woman who follows tradition, good or bad.
('48', 67, 1, 9, 152130) Umiya’s fault, therefore, is pardonable.
('48', 67, 1, 10, 152171) I have drawn Umiya’s and her husband’s attention to this matter.
('48', 67, 1, 11, 152236) From him, she has received nothing except a small choodi 1. I have, however, mentioned this matter so that no man or girl who knows the rules of the Ashram may act in this manner.
('48', 67, 1, 12, 152416) I also wish to draw another moral from this.
('48', 67, 1, 13, 152461) Lustful men have degraded woman.
('48', 67, 1, 14, 152494) They have taught her ways of dressing and behaving which might please them.
('48', 67, 1, 15, 152570) They have taught her to adorn herself.
('48', 67, 1, 16, 152609) Woman did not see in all this her slavery and her degradation.
('48', 67, 1, 17, 152672) She, too, was attracted by lustful thoughts and, therefore, consented to get her nose and ears pierced, put on fetters on her feet and became a slave.
('48', 67, 1, 18, 152823) An evil man can easily drag a woman behind him by getting hold of her nose ring or earring.
('48', 67, 1, 19, 152915) It passes my understanding how any thoughtful woman can put on such things which make them helpless.
('48', 67, 1, 20, 153016) Real beauty is of the heart.
('48', 67, 1, 21, 153045) Let every woman in the Ashram save herself from external adornment and resist being pierced in the nose.
('48', 67, 1, 22, 153150) Is it not enough that draught animals are so pierced?
('48', 67, 1, 23, 153204) It is now six o’clock and so I stop here.
('48', 67, 1, 24, 153246) Iremembered you so early in the morning, for I expect much from you.
('48', 67, 2, 25, 153315) Blessings from BAPU

('48', 70, 1, 2, 157178) 71. LETTER TO RAMNIKLAL MODI
('48', 70, 2, 3, 157207) WARDHA, December 10, 1929
('48', 70, 3, 4, 157233) RAMNIKLAL, There is no post from you today.
('48', 70, 3, 5, 157277) The manager of every department should inspect it daily and should note having done so in his notebook.
('48', 70, 3, 6, 157381) You should look into the notebooks when you are free from other work.
('48', 70, 3, 7, 157451) If we want to remain vigilant and keep a watch over ourselves, we should never neglect such proceedings.
('48', 70, 3, 8, 157556) We of all people cannot neglect them, for we have attached so much importance to this thing that we sent away Jagannath from the Ashram.
('48', 70, 3, 9, 157693) We have relieved some others, too, for the same reason.
('48', 70, 3, 10, 157749) I forget the names of these persons.
('48', 70, 3, 11, 157786) If there is laxity in observing rules which are easy to observe and if we tolerate it, the Ashram will not only break up one day but I am sure there will also be a blot on its fair name.
('48', 70, 3, 12, 157973) If deficiencies remain despite our vigilance, the world will forgive us for them.
('48', 70, 3, 13, 158055) But it will have a right to censure us for what may happen through our remissness.
('48', 70, 3, 14, 158138) I have been thinking a great deal these days about such matters.
('48', 70, 3, 15, 158203) I feel extremely concerned and am becoming confirmed in the views which I expressed when I was there.
('48', 70, 3, 16, 158305) That is, those who regularly violate rules which are easy for all to observe should be asked to leave the Ashram or should themselves leave it.
('48', 70, 3, 17, 158449) That will save us from many dangers.
('48', 70, 3, 18, 158486) Our Ashram is not an asylum for the infirm and the crippled.
('48', 70, 3, 19, 158547) There grown up men and women have come together inspired by a certain ideal.
('48', 70, 3, 20, 158624) I exclude from this, but only partially, the women who have been there from the beginning.
('48', 70, 3, 21, 158715) If those who have thus voluntarily come together do not observe the rules which they themselves have made and if we tolerate that, I think we are traitors to dharma and society.
('48', 70, 3, 22, 158893) If all of you in the Ashram do not know, you may know by this that Rajibehn, who lived in the Ashram for some time, died of illness in her village.
('48', 70, 3, 23, 159041) Chandulal had come here and he gave me the news.
('48', 70, 3, 24, 159090) She was guilty of serious lapses, but she had eaten the salt of the Ashram and it is, therefore, our duty to pay her the tribute of remembrance.

('48', 71, 5, 14, 159842) 73. A LETTER
('48', 71, 6, 15, 159855) December 11, 1929 Your diagnosis is not correct.
('48', 71, 6, 16, 159904) The men and women living in the Udyoga Mandir are very happy.
('48', 71, 6, 17, 159966) They can and do laugh freely.
('48', 71, 6, 18, 159996) Visitors have often expressed their happiness at seeing these people so happy.
('48', 71, 6, 19, 160075) The Mandir itself is a club.
('48', 71, 6, 20, 160104) There is no need for us to set up separate bodies for entertainment and recreation.
('48', 71, 6, 21, 160188) We can find greater joy in doing well the work which we are doing.
('48', 71, 6, 22, 160255) It is true, however, that notwithstanding the happiness we seem a little listless.
('48', 71, 6, 23, 160338) But the reason for it lies in the laziness in our blood and the consequent lack of method in our work.
('48', 71, 6, 24, 160441) In comparison with other institutions people notice our activity and praise it.
('48', 71, 6, 25, 160521) But we recognize our failings.
('48', 71, 6, 26, 160552) I am sure that they will gradually disappear.
('48', 71, 6, 27, 160598) In any case do not base your pessimism on the views which I occasionally express.
('48', 71, 6, 28, 160680) It is not for me to praise such virtues as I may see in the Udyoga Mandir.
('48', 71, 6, 29, 160755) On the other hand it is my duty to magnify into mountains the defects I may notice and draw your attention to them.
('48', 71, 6, 30, 160871) We can never see our own faults till we so magnify them.
('48', 71, 6, 31, 160928) I think that the children somewhat lack in courtesy.
('48', 71, 6, 32, 160981) But we need not be upset by this.
('48', 71, 6, 33, 161015) True courtesy will develop on its own from the present lack of courtesy.

('48', 73, 4, 9, 164253) 75. U.P. NATIONAL SERVICE
('48', 73, 5, 10, 164279) It was a happy idea of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru during my recent tour to ask for funds for forming a national service for the province.
('48', 73, 5, 11, 164414) Rs. 12,036 15 9 were collected for the purpose.
('48', 73, 5, 12, 164462) Though the sum is not adequate for the purpose intended, it is a goodly sum as a nucleus.
('48', 73, 5, 13, 164552) The idea of having a national service is not new.
('48', 73, 5, 14, 164602) Ever since 1920 it has been before the country.
('48', 73, 5, 15, 164650) But Pandit Jawaharlal has given it a shape and a habitation.
('48', 73, 5, 16, 164711) National work must suffer so long as we have to depend upon volunteers who give only a part of their time and that too by fits and starts.
('48', 73, 5, 17, 164850) Permanent work requires permanent whole time workers.
('48', 73, 5, 18, 164904) This can best be done by each province establishing its service in accordance with its needs and out of funds collected locally.
('48', 73, 5, 19, 165033) Feeling hampered at every step for want of trained and tried permanent workers, Pandit Jawaharlal seized the opportunity that the tour gave him of getting funds.
('48', 73, 5, 20, 165195) I hope now that no time will be lost in framing rules and inviting applications.Untouchability, Hindu Muslim unity, boycott of foreign cloth, total prohibition, national education, etc., can absorb a large number of permanent workers.
('48', 73, 5, 21, 165430) Indeed our ideal should be to have at least one worker to every one of the seven hundred thousand villages.
('48', 73, 5, 22, 165538) But apart from the A.I.S.A. we have hardly a worker even for every district.
('48', 73, 5, 23, 165615) All the provinces will naturally watch the coming U.P. national service organization.
('48', 73, 5, 24, 165701) Experience teaches that any such service to be truly national and permanent, though a creation of the Congress, must stand outside of its varying politics and must enjoy complete responsible self government.
('48', 73, 6, 25, 165909) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.

('48', 74, 1, 2, 166193) must be able to give an absolute assurance to our workers that they will not be subject to dismissal with the annual change in the elected office bearers of the Congress.

('48', 74, 2, 5, 166478) 76. THE THIRD CLASS CARRIAGE
('48', 74, 3, 6, 166507) I was a third class passenger from Allahabad to Patna on 20th November last.
('48', 74, 3, 7, 166584) I have travelled thousands of miles in third class carriages throughout the length and breadth of India during the last four years, and my experience is that ordeals of this kind are of common occurrence.
('48', 74, 3, 8, 166789) Such a condition of things would be utterly impossible in any well governed country.
('48', 74, 4, 9, 166874) Having become a Mahatma, although I have resumed third class travelling for the past twelve months or more, my experiences of overcrowding that more than resemble Mirabai’s can only date back to 1915 to 1917. These were duly recorded in the Pressat the time I had gone through them.
('48', 74, 4, 10, 167157) I had however flattered myself with the belief that as a consequence of these disclosures, overcrowding had been at least made bearable.
('48', 74, 4, 11, 167294) But I see that I was mistaken.
('48', 74, 4, 12, 167325) The railway management is no respecter of persons so far as non Europeans or un Anglicized Indians are concerned.
('48', 74, 4, 13, 167439) For Europeans and Anglicized Indians there is no doubt more than needed comfort in third class carriages.
('48', 74, 4, 14, 167545) For the 60,l7,78,000 third class passengers who made in 1925 26 payment of Rs. 34,76,45,000 to the railways, they must be content to be ‘packed like sardines’ in boxes.
('48', 74, 4, 15, 167714) Though they pay fares as passengers having wants of the same kind as 1st and 2nd class passengers, they are treated as if they were so many parcels to be thrown in a heap into a luggage van.
('48', 74, 4, 16, 167905) If Mirabai had exercised the privilege of her colour and birth she would either not have gone through the experiences she has, or if she had, her complaint would have been heard in the proper quarters.
('48', 74, 4, 17, 168107) Let the reader and the other concerned ponder over the following instructive figures for 1925 25: Passengers 1st 2nd Inter Inter Third Numbers in thousands 11,69 1,04,87 1,40,09 60,17,78 Income in thousands of rupees 1,20,42 1,89,42 1,59,61 34,76,45
('48', 74, 5, 18, 168357) 1 Only extracts from Mirabehn’s article are reproduced here.
('48', 75, 0, 1, 168418) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 75, 1, 2, 168459) But at present it is of course doubtful whether her article will have any effect on the authorities.
('48', 75, 2, 3, 168560) We ourselves are one of the causes of this disease.
('48', 75, 2, 4, 168612) The sayings ‘Only he can sell his goods who shouts their names’ and ‘Not unless you ask will even mother serve you a helping at a meal’ are as true as they are trite and common.
('48', 75, 2, 5, 168790) Our spirit of tolerance passes all limit, and the result is laziness and painful indifference.
('48', 75, 2, 6, 168885) Many of the difficulties can be removed if our sense of self respect is awakened, if we look upon it as our duty to end discomforts which it is not our duty to submit to, and if we gladly suffer the hardships which follow from our doing this duty.
('48', 75, 2, 7, 169133) Passengers should refuse to go into a carriage whenever they find in it more than the lawfully fixed number.
('48', 75, 2, 8, 169242) They should be prepared to run the risk of missing their train occasionally, if necessary.
('48', 75, 2, 9, 169333) If after the matter has been brought to his notice a railway official does not find for the passengers the room required, I think he can be sued in a court of law.
('48', 75, 2, 10, 169497) Ordinary passengers cannot take that step.
('48', 75, 2, 11, 169540) They would either abuse or fight.
('48', 75, 2, 12, 169574) Action which requires patience, firmness and knowledge is only for the educated and experienced passengers to undertake.
('48', 75, 2, 13, 169695) Whenever they have to face such occasions they ought to take proper steps without fail.
('48', 75, 2, 14, 169783) Young India, 12 12 1929 and Navajivan, 19 1 1930
('48', 75, 3, 15, 169832) 77. AN IMPORTANT AWARD 2
('48', 75, 4, 16, 169857) The award given by the Umpire, Diwan Bahadur Krishnalal Mohanlal Jhaveri, in the matter referred to him by the unofficial permanent arbitration board appointed voluntarily by the Ahmedabad Mill owners’ Association and the Textile Labour Union is, as the reader will recognize from the text printed elsewhere, an important document.
('48', 75, 4, 17, 170189) The Umpire’s judgment is a preparation evidencing a careful study of the facts of the case and is a bold enunciation of the doctrine that when ‘the worker does not get enough wages to enable him to maintain a suitable standard of living’, ‘he can ask his employer to pay him wages which would enable him to do so.’ The contention advanced by labour for the past many years and denied by employers that it is entitled to a living wage has been wholly accepted, as I maintain it was boundto be, by the Umpire.
('48', 75, 4, 18, 170697) It is also worthy of note that he has found as a matter of fact that the average earnings of families of labourers including the lowest paid and the highest paid are not more than Rs. 40 per month and the expenses not less than
('48', 75, 5, 19, 170925) 1 This and the following paragraph are from Navajivan, 19 1 1930. 2Vide “Appeal to Ahmedabad Labourers”, also “Textile Labourers’ Demand”?
('48', 75, 5, 20, 171064) 15 12 1929
('48', 76, 0, 1, 171075) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 77
('48', 76, 1, 2, 171120) Rs. 50 per month.
('48', 76, 1, 3, 171138) Now the matter referred to the Umpire was the demand made by labour for full restoration of the cut of 15% made in 1923 by the mill owners in labour wages.
('48', 76, 1, 4, 171294) The learned Umpire having granted the contention that labour is entitled to a living wage and that as a matter of fact Ahmedabad textile labour is not getting such a wage, it is not easy to understand why the whole of the cut has not been restored.
('48', 76, 1, 5, 171543) The reader will note that even the restoration of the whole cut would not send up the wage to Rs. 50 per month.
('48', 76, 1, 6, 171655) The only explanation I can discover for this discrepancy between the finding on the theory and its actual enforcement in terms of wages is that the Umpire was afraid of his own finding, or that he hesitated to condemn, even by implication, the action of the mill owners in making the cut in 1923, and that too not by arbitration, but by an arbitrary exercise of their power to coerce labour.
('48', 76, 1, 7, 172047) For whilst it is quite true that the condition of the mill industry was not as prosperous as it was in the War period, it was a period of merely less profits, not of loss and encroachment upon capital.
('48', 76, 1, 8, 172249) The question of cut can occur, if at all, only when the wages are so good as to leave a margin after paying for living expenses and when the industry concerned has to face an actual deficit.
('48', 76, 1, 9, 172440) But the men are wedded to the principle of arbitration and therefore they must cheerfully submit to the Umpire’s decision even though they do not get the full restoration of the cut.
('48', 76, 1, 10, 172623) They must thankfully accept what the Diwan Bahadur has allowed, and perseveringly and peacefully work for the balance.
('48', 76, 1, 11, 172742) Indeed there can be no rest for them or the employers so long as the living wage is not actually reached and better housing and other ordinary comforts are not secured.
('48', 76, 1, 12, 172911) But it will be a great gain if strikes become unnecessary and the principle of arbitration is strictly adhered to by both parties.
('48', 76, 1, 13, 173042) In spite therefore of the partial failure of the men, I tender my congratulations to the Diwan Bahadur for the labour of love that he gave to the task that was entrusted to him and for the prompt and impartial manner in which he approached the difficult question referred to him by both the parties.
('48', 76, 2, 14, 173342) Young India, 12 12 1929

('48', 77, 1, 23, 175397) Several evils persist on account of our despondency and ignorance.
('48', 77, 1, 24, 175464) We should have the faith that immorality is atransient thing and it cannot face the dynamic morality of even a few.

('48', 79, 3, 6, 177491) I have also written to Ramsahai and advised him to have a talk with you.
('48', 79, 3, 7, 177564) Show boundless love, keep patience and never lose hope.
('48', 79, 3, 8, 177620) If you do so you are bound to win in the end.
('48', 79, 3, 9, 177666) Never feel easily satisfied with your own work and always be generous in assessing ano ther’s.
('48', 79, 3, 10, 177761) Bear with the imperfect work of an honest worker.
('48', 79, 3, 11, 177811) With the dishonest non co operate.
('48', 79, 3, 12, 177846) Have love for both.
('48', 79, 3, 13, 177866) That is what is meant by samabhava.
('48', 79, 3, 14, 177902) Giving bread to the hungry, but refusing food to one suffering from indigestion, as both these acts are inspired by love for the persons, such an attitude is called samabhava which means treating the ant and the elephant on the same footing..
('48', 79, 3, 15, 178145) Do not proceed on the belief that your new method has succeeded outright.
('48', 79, 3, 16, 178219) The friction will be minimum, if you proceed by persuading and carrying with you those insisting on following the old method.
('48', 79, 3, 17, 178345) Whether the method adopted is old or new, it should be followed faithfully.

('48', 79, 3, 19, 178486) Do not f eel the least embarrassed in doing so.
('48', 79, 3, 20, 178534) If on any points you find my inferences based on insufficient information or mistaken, caution me about them.
('48', 79, 3, 21, 178644) It may be very well to have faith in any principles which I may laydown, but the inferences which I draw from facts can never be a matter of faith, as faith has no place at all in matters belonging entirely to the field of the intellect.
('48', 79, 3, 22, 178882) Do therefore correct me whenever you find me misinformed about facts and hence mistaken in my conclusions.
('48', 79, 3, 23, 178989) If you follow this practice, I shall be able to write to you more freely and guide you better.

('48', 81, 2, 3, 181577) WARDHA, December 14, 1929
('48', 81, 3, 4, 181603) DEAR MOTILALJI, I wired you yesterday in answer to your letter that I shall be with you in Delhi on 22nd.
('48', 81, 3, 5, 181709) I have since discovered that 23rd is a Monday.
('48', 81, 3, 6, 181756) I do not know when the appointment with the Viceroy comes off.
('48', 81, 3, 7, 181819) It must not be in the morning.
('48', 81, 3, 8, 181850) If it is any time in the afternoon, there will be no difficulty.
('48', 81, 3, 9, 181915) I would take silence on Sunday at about that hour.
('48', 81, 3, 10, 181966) But what of our talk before the interview?
('48', 81, 3, 11, 182009) My train reaches there at 11.28 a.m.
('48', 81, 3, 12, 182046) If the interview takes place in the afternoon we would easily have some time on Sunday.
('48', 81, 3, 13, 182134) The other way is for us to meet somewhere on the train and the third is for you to talk and for me, if I have anything to say, to put it down on paper.
('48', 81, 3, 14, 182286) After all I have not much to say.
('48', 81, 3, 15, 182320) At the interview you should lead.
('48', 81, 3, 16, 182354) I do not know what I could say beyond reiterating the four conditions.
('48', 81, 3, 17, 182425) As a matter of fact we go to listen to what H.E. has to say about our conditions.
('48', 81, 3, 18, 182507) Now you will direct me.
('48', 81, 3, 19, 182531) I observe that your professional engagements keep you fully busy.
('48', 81, 3, 20, 182597) I shall look forward to a fair share of the spoils.
('48', 81, 3, 21, 182649) Daridranar ayana’s belly is never full.
('48', 81, 4, 22, 182689) Yours, From a copy: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.
('48', 81, 4, 23, 182734) S.N. 32579/24

('48', 82, 1, 2, 183393) 86. LETTER TO SHIVABHAI PATEL
('48', 82, 2, 3, 183423) WARDHA, December 14, 1929
('48', 82, 3, 4, 183449) BHAI SHIVABHAI, I have your letter.
('48', 82, 3, 5, 183485) The question itself is based on faulty reasoning.
('48', 82, 3, 6, 183535) Work and rules are not two independent things, just as the elephant and the curb are not unconnected with each other.
('48', 82, 3, 7, 183653) An elephant which is not properly controlled can be of no service and is actually a danger.
('48', 82, 3, 8, 183745) Similarly, undisciplined work is also useless.
('48', 82, 3, 9, 183792) Now tell me yourself which of the two is more important.
('48', 82, 3, 10, 183849) That the number of labourers cannot be reduced and that they do not mix with us— both these are defects which it is the duty of all inmates of the Ashram to remove.
('48', 82, 3, 11, 184014) If my view of the matter is correct, a rule should mean that anyone who cannot observe it should leave the Ashram.
('48', 82, 3, 12, 184129) What you write about the kitchen is true.
('48', 82, 3, 13, 184171) I see that our activities are increasing, but I do not feel inclined to check them since it is the same activities which are expanding.
('48', 82, 3, 14, 184307) I think that work has not been properly assigned to Jethalal, Manji and Bhagwanji.
('48', 82, 3, 15, 184390) At present, however, it is not my job to interfere with the running of the Ashram; my duty is to watch things and offer criticism when necessary.
('48', 82, 3, 16, 184536) You are right when you say that the necessity for too many rules means that the secretary is weak.
('48', 82, 3, 17, 184635) The secretary himself knows, and so do we all, that he is weak.
('48', 82, 3, 18, 184699) But he will do nothing wrong knowingly.
('48', 82, 3, 19, 184739) It is enough for me, and should be so for all of us, that he strives to do his best.
('48', 82, 3, 20, 184824) All the questions you have asked are good.
('48', 82, 3, 21, 184867) Discuss them with me when I return, and we shall then do what we can.
('48', 82, 4, 22, 184937) Blessings from BAPU
('48', 82, 5, 23, 184957) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 9497

('48', 83, 1, 4, 185562) Relations lived at distant places even when there were no trains and mail was carried by runners.

('48', 84, 1, 2, 187373) 89. VIDYAPITH’S APPEAL FOR FUNDS
('48', 84, 2, 3, 187406) Those who have in principle approved of the appeal made by Vallabhbhai and Kakasaheb should remember the following Latin proverb: “He who gives in time gives twice.” We have the following parallel saying: “There is a great deal of merit in giving immediately.” We experience every day the truth of the point underlying this saying.
('48', 84, 2, 4, 187738) If a doctor or a vaid does not give timely medical help the patient will suffer and there are even cases in which the latter dies.
('48', 84, 2, 5, 187869) We see every day that if anyone who is bitten by a snake is immediately given medical aid, he can be saved; if not, he dies.
('48', 84, 2, 6, 187994) Although it is our dharma to feed a hungry person, he who does not do so immediately is guilty of violence towards the hungry individual.
('48', 84, 2, 7, 188132) This should be regarded as holding good for all acts of philanthropy.
('48', 84, 2, 8, 188202) There is no generosity in giving alms indiscriminately to anyone who begs.
('48', 84, 2, 9, 188277) This may imply thoughtlessness, foolishness, or even pride.
('48', 84, 2, 10, 188337) However, despite knowingthat the person who begs is a worthy individual and the cause for which he begs is a deserving one, anyone who contributes his share only after the former has approached him wastes public time and forfeits his own prestige, and thereby misuses the worthiest persons belonging to the institution.
('48', 84, 2, 11, 188657) Considering the Vidyapith’s appeal in this light is a form of education for the people.
('48', 84, 2, 12, 188745) This appeal is not addressed to people who do not approve of the Vidyapith.
('48', 84, 2, 13, 188821) Its object is to point out their dharma to those who entertain no doubts regarding its usefulness or the service it has rendered and its object is also to encourage and draw those who are neutral towards it but may contribute if they come to realize its value.
('48', 84, 2, 14, 189082) At this time of public awakening, no one should, as far as possible, stay neutral.
('48', 84, 2, 15, 189165) Those who do not stand by their country in its hour of need also help the cause of the enemy.
('48', 84, 2, 16, 189259) It is the dharma of every individual to make his choice.
('48', 84, 2, 17, 189316) The Vidyapith is an institution for non co operation, that is, one which serves in this time of distress.
('48', 84, 2, 18, 189422) Its additional advantage is that its usefulness will always endure.
('48', 84, 2, 19, 189490) However, it was born in the hour of the struggle in order to assist in it.
('48', 84, 2, 20, 189565) Hence it is my expectation that those who have not arrived at the conclusion that the Vidyapith is a harmful or a useless institution should come to know what it stands for, what its achievements are and what it can achieve in future.
('48', 84, 2, 21, 189800) It is the dharma of such people to send in their contributions after they have known of and have been convinced about it.
('48', 84, 2, 22, 189922) Contributions may be sent to the following addresses; Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj, Treasurer, 395 397, Kalbadevi Road, Bombay 2; Gujarat Vidyapith, Ahmedabad; Provincial Committee,

('48', 85, 2, 4, 190247) 90. A PERPLEXED HUSBAND
('48', 85, 3, 5, 190271) A perplexed husband writes: 1
('48', 85, 4, 6, 190301) I do wish to console him; but in such matters if a person does not himself find consolation, others will hardly be able to give him any.
('48', 85, 4, 7, 190438) However, a person can derive some solace from an intellectual discussion.
('48', 85, 4, 8, 190512) Let us, therefore, analyse the problems faced by this young husband.
('48', 85, 4, 9, 190581) One can see that the power exercised by traditionlies at the root of his problems.
('48', 85, 4, 10, 190664) It seems that in his heart of hearts, the husband desires to exercise the authority vested in him by virtue of his being lord and master.
('48', 85, 4, 11, 190802) If this is not the case, and if the husband regards the wife as a friend, there will be no cause for despair.
('48', 85, 4, 12, 190912) We reason with patience with a friend and, if he is not convinced, we neither feel disappointed nor use force.
('48', 85, 4, 13, 191023) If the husband has a right to entertain any expectations of his wife, will not the latter also entertain some of the former?
('48', 85, 4, 14, 191148) What do many wives who regularly go to temples to have darshan of God do when they do not approve of the modern habits of their reformed husbands?
('48', 85, 4, 15, 191295) They would not even dare to persuade their husbands.
('48', 85, 4, 16, 191348) Hence, I would first of all advise this husband and others in similar predicament deliberately to give up the right of exercising authority over their wives.
('48', 85, 4, 17, 191506) In order to serve and educate their wives, they should suppress all physical desire during the period of education and later patiently explain to the latter that false superstitions, faith in the priests of temples, visits to so called places of worship, etc., are not only futile but may also prove harmful.
('48', 85, 4, 18, 191815) I have not the slightest doubt that if the husband’s love is pure, the wife will surely be convinced.
('48', 85, 4, 19, 191917) Mango trees do not bear fruit quickly.
('48', 85, 4, 20, 191956) If a tree like the mango tree requires to be tended for a number of years, how much tender care will a woman require who is like a tree and who has been kept ignorant for so long?
('48', 85, 4, 21, 192136) It has been my experience that both satisfaction and success lie in such daily care and tending.
('48', 85, 4, 22, 192233) One should not give up one’s efforts if, after having told a person once, the latter is still unconvinced.
('48', 85, 4, 23, 192340) One should have faith that such daily care will finally lead to a change of heart.
('48', 85, 4, 24, 192423) Hence I am unable to advice either
('48', 85, 5, 25, 192458) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('48', 85, 5, 26, 192495) The correspondent had described the feeble understanding of his wife whom he had been forced to marry in early childhood.
('48', 86, 0, 1, 192617) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 87
('48', 86, 1, 2, 192662) that one should put up with one’s lot or abandon one’s wife.
('48', 86, 1, 3, 192723) To try in the above manner to rectify the error made by one’s parents in arranging such a marriage is a truly manly effort.
('48', 86, 1, 4, 192847) It is easier to be happy by abandoning one’s wife; but that is not true happiness; it is not a truly manly effort and hence it is not dharma.
('48', 86, 1, 5, 192989) Anyone who is aware of the poverty stricken state of his country does not, therefore, abandon it but, on the contrary, tries until his death to free his country from the grip of poverty, puts up with many hardships and finds happiness in doing so.
('48', 86, 1, 6, 193237) Once we understand this, we shall behave towards our wives accordingly.
('48', 86, 1, 7, 193309) The gentleman himself admits that there are others who are faced with the same difficulties as himself.
('48', 86, 1, 8, 193413) If all such husbands abandon their wives, what will be the plight of all these women in our country?
('48', 86, 1, 9, 193514) Who will look after them if not their husbands ?
('48', 86, 1, 10, 193563) Perplexed husbands should realize that the incompatibility that is found between husbands and wives today is also a symptom of the present plight of our country and adopt a path accordingly.
('48', 86, 1, 11, 193754) Moreover, by solving such problems, they will readily learn the correct way of solving the difficulties that lie in the way of attaining swaraj and this will be an additional advantage both to themselves and to the country.

('48', 86, 2, 13, 194016) 91. MY NOTES
('48', 86, 3, 14, 194029) TRUTH BOWS BEFORE AUTHORITY
('48', 86, 4, 15, 194057) A young man writes: 1
('48', 86, 5, 16, 194079) This is a good question.
('48', 86, 5, 17, 194104) Peace is possible only where truth is pursued.
('48', 86, 5, 18, 194151) Truth can be returned only by truth.
('48', 86, 5, 19, 194188) Just as a person who sells the most valuable object cannot expect to get something even more valuable in return, similarly, what more than truth can a truthful person expect?
('48', 86, 5, 20, 194363) I do not wish to belittle Harishchandra but it is erroneous to say that he and Dharmaraja 2 had been unhappy.
('48', 86, 5, 21, 194473) They had regarded misery as happiness, so that they welcomed that which we regard as sorrow.
('48', 86, 5, 22, 194566) It is for such reasons that the poet devotee has sung:
('48', 86, 6, 23, 194621) The path of God is the path of the courageous; here cowards have no place.
('48', 86, 7, 24, 194696) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('48', 86, 7, 25, 194733) The correspondent had said that one does not get peace of mind by following the path of truth.
('48', 86, 7, 26, 194828) 2 Yudhishthira, eldest of the Pandava brothers
('48', 87, 0, 1, 194875) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 87, 1, 2, 194916) Just as the sun radiates heat and also sustains life so does truth.
('48', 87, 1, 3, 194984) If the sun stops radiating heat even for a fraction of a: second, this universe will become lifeless; a similar result will follow if the sun in the form of truth ceases to radiate heat even for a moment.
('48', 87, 1, 4, 195189) It is a fact that we come across untruth in the world, but that is like the dross within coming out.
('48', 87, 1, 5, 195290) We should never be oblivious of the fact that crores of individuals by their very nature employ truth.
('48', 87, 1, 6, 195393) My own experience, without exception, suggests that no one has been able to misuse till the end whatever purity there may be in me.
('48', 87, 1, 7, 195525) As against this, those who have come forward to misuse my single minded devotion to truth have suffered loss of prestige and even much else besides.
('48', 87, 1, 8, 195674) I have had to face difficulties for the sake of my adherence to truth in thought, word and deed, but I have never suffered on that account.I have derived only total happiness and peace from it.
('48', 87, 1, 9, 195868) I have put before the world an instance of my untruth.
('48', 87, 1, 10, 195923) So long as it was within me, it was eating me up.
('48', 87, 1, 11, 195973) I gained peace only when I purified myself by ridding myself of it.
('48', 87, 1, 12, 196041) I can also recall many other similar instances in my own life.
('48', 87, 1, 13, 196104) So far as I am aware the world has accepted that the satyagraha in South Africa ended in nothing but triumph.
('48', 87, 1, 14, 196214) It appears that the gentleman who has raised the above question has no knowledge of the events in South Africa.
('48', 87, 1, 15, 196326) The experience of the world as well as my own teaches me that it is incorrect to hold that truth bows before authority.
('48', 87, 1, 16, 196446) On the contrary, the latter has always to remain a servant of the former.

('48', 87, 3, 26, 197412) On looking at the picture it becomes quite obvious that to wash a khadi cap is a very simple matter.
