('48', 88, 3, 13, 198708) 92. TEXTILE LABOURERS’ DEMAND
('48', 88, 4, 14, 198738) I am both grieved and surprised that the Umpire, Sjt.
('48', 88, 4, 15, 198792) Krishnalal Jhaveri, has been unable fully to accept the demands of the textile mill workers.
('48', 88, 4, 16, 198885) I am grieved at their non acceptance, as I continue to hold the opinion that their demands should have been fully accepted and I am surprised as I do not find any reasons for their non acceptance in the verdict of the Umpire.
('48', 88, 4, 17, 199111) However, the Umpire has fully accepted the principle put forward by the Majoor Mahajan, namely, that labourers have the right to receive and demand wages which are needed for their livelihood.
('48', 88, 4, 18, 199304) Moreover, he has also accepted the figures given by the Majoor Mahajan.
('48', 88, 4, 19, 199376) Krishnalal Jhaveri states that the average monthly income of a labourer’s family does not exceed Rs. 4D, while his expenditure does not fall below Rs. 50. He also admits that in the figures of expenditure given by the Majoor Mahajan, some necessary items of expenditure such as those involved in ceremonies concerned with birth and death have not been included.
('48', 88, 4, 20, 199738) Moreover, the Umpire admits that the mills have suffered no loss of capital.
('48', 88, 4, 21, 199815) In my opinion, any amount that has to be withdrawn from the capital should be regarded as a loss.
('48', 88, 4, 22, 199913) No loss is incurred if there is less profit.
('48', 88, 4, 23, 199958) A fall in profits should never be a reason for decrease in labourers’ wages.
('48', 88, 4, 24, 200035) Such a situation can arise only when labourers
('48', 88, 5, 25, 200082) 1 This is not translated here.
('48', 89, 0, 1, 200113) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 89, 1, 2, 200154) become owners in the same manner and to the same extent as shareholders.
('48', 89, 1, 3, 200227) If we are not narrow minded, we shall immediately realize that labourers should have a greater right to ownership than shareholders.
('48', 89, 1, 4, 200360) All that shareholders do is to pay money whereas a labourer contributes the sweat of his brow every day and, if he happens to be a loyal worker, will not desert his work at all.
('48', 89, 1, 5, 200538) A mill can be run without shareholders but it is impossible to run it without labourers.
('48', 89, 1, 6, 200627) Someone may say that as the labourer is not an intelligent person, the mill will be ruined if he becomes its owner.This contention also is without any foundation.
('48', 89, 1, 7, 200790) All shareholders are not intelligent persons.
('48', 89, 1, 8, 200836) No one examines their hearts and their heads.
('48', 89, 1, 9, 200882) Nevertheless, they have a right to vote, and the mills continue to function.
('48', 89, 1, 10, 200959) In my opinion, they will function better if the labourers are given ownership rights.
('48', 89, 1, 11, 201045) The experience of certain multi millionaires in the United States of America who are experimenting on these lines lends support to my views.
('48', 89, 1, 12, 201186) If labourers are given wages which exceed their bare cost of living and provide room for improving or bettering their condition, one can certainly conceive of situations in which they can be reduced.
('48', 89, 1, 13, 201386) Just as it will be regarded as improper to touch the capital of the capitalists, similarly it is improper to touch the wages of the labourers which barely provide them with a livelihood.
('48', 89, 1, 14, 201573) A happy state of affairs will be the one in which an arbitrating body will annually determine the wages sufficient to cover the cost of living in accordance with the price of foodgrains, and just as shareholders receive dividends, labourers should, similarly and in the same proportion, receive an increase in wages every year.
('48', 89, 1, 15, 201901) I would regard it as wholly proper that this increment should vary in proportion to an increase or decrease in dividends.
('48', 89, 1, 16, 202023) However, here I have digressed from the original subject matter.

('48', 104, 2, 3, 230768) WARDHA, December 18, 1929
('48', 104, 3, 4, 230794) RAMNIKLAL, I have been trying to come into close contact with Bhai Madhavji.
('48', 104, 3, 5, 230871) I have formed a good opinion about the couple and have high hopes of them.
('48', 104, 3, 6, 230946) They have been voluntarily observing complete brahmacharya for a year and a half.
('48', 104, 3, 7, 231028) The desire for service has awakened in Madhavji for quite some years.
('48', 104, 3, 8, 231098) He is full of enthusiasm.

('48', 104, 3, 12, 231410) He will require agricultural work for at least some time daily.
('48', 104, 3, 13, 231474) I also believe that he will be able to look after the store.
('48', 104, 3, 14, 231535) And he is bound to know bookkeeping.
('48', 104, 3, 15, 231572) His wife is a fine woman, but how she acquits herself there the future alone will show.
('48', 104, 3, 16, 231660) Chandrakanta and her mother are getting ready.

('48', 104, 3, 18, 231874) I had a letter from Chandrakanta, which I am sending with this to be filed.

('48', 105, 3, 12, 233371) That you nevertheless ask my permission is an act of courtesy on your part and a voluntary limitation of your freedom out of respect for me.

('48', 105, 6, 18, 233775) 112. A MILITARY PROGRAMME 1
('48', 105, 7, 19, 233803) George Joseph has been one of my dearest comrades.
('48', 105, 7, 20, 233854) When I was having rest in Yeravda, he was editor of Young India.
('48', 105, 7, 21, 233919) Before that at my instance he was editor of the now defunct Independent.
('48', 105, 7, 22, 233992) He had sacrificed a lucrative practice for the sake of the country.
('48', 105, 7, 23, 234060) He went to jail for the same cause.
('48', 105, 7, 24, 234096) He is an earnest and honest worker.
('48', 105, 7, 25, 234132) He is therefore entitled to a respectful hearing, the more so when such a man differs from you and rejecting the old recommends with the fervour of a convert the adoption of a new policy.
('48', 105, 7, 26, 234320) George Joseph has done it.
('48', 105, 7, 27, 234347) One of his old associates sends a cutting from a newspaper containing Joseph’s enunciation of his new policy and marks it ‘George Joseph’s confession of faith’.
('48', 105, 7, 28, 234508) Another man, an unknown admirer of George Joseph, copies out from the report the whole of his
('48', 105, 8, 29, 234602) 1 Another article on the subject appeared in Navajivan, 29 12 1929 under the title “Khadi v.
('48', 105, 8, 30, 234695) Khaki”.
('48', 106, 0, 1, 234703) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 107
('48', 106, 1, 2, 234749) criticism of the khadi programme.
('48', 106, 1, 3, 234783) He writes in a most distracted mood and insists that I must take notice of the remarks about khadi.
('48', 106, 1, 4, 234883) There is no cause for distraction, grief or alarm.
('48', 106, 1, 5, 234934) It would be surprising, if, in a great national upheaval, we did not find men honestly recanting old views and enunciating new.
('48', 106, 1, 6, 235062) Change is a condition of progress.
('48', 106, 1, 7, 235097) An honest man cannot afford to observe mechanical consistency when the mind revolts against anything as an error.
('48', 106, 1, 8, 235211) We must therefore patiently try to understand what George Joseph has to say and not hesitate to accept what appeals to our reason even though it may mean a sacrifice of some cherished ideal.
('48', 106, 1, 9, 235402) It is, I hope, in that spirit that I have endeavoured to study Joseph’s speech.
('48', 106, 1, 10, 235482) He condemns khadi, he is ‘quite satisfied that the removal of untouchability is not primarily a problem of statesm anship’.
('48', 106, 1, 11, 235606) His programme in one simple sentence is: ‘Militarize India’.
('48', 106, 1, 12, 235667) Here is an extract from the speech:
('48', 106, 2, 13, 235703) We cannot all become soldiers.
('48', 106, 2, 14, 235734) There is not enough room for us.
('48', 106, 2, 15, 235767) But it should be possible for us to set about the idea of training about 5,000 men every year in this Presidency in urban units.
('48', 106, 2, 16, 235896) The men will go to drill two or three times a week, go out to camp three weeks in the year.
('48', 106, 2, 17, 235988) Such training should be made available not only for the students who are at college but also for men of sufficient social and educationalstatus, the educational standard being the membership of the School Leaving Class.
('48', 106, 2, 18, 236208) If you see in every street such people going about in khaki, there will be a new element in our life.
('48', 106, 2, 19, 236310) This kind of training would make people to stand straight, to think straight and to speak straight.
('48', 106, 2, 20, 236410) It will be a great enrichment of our life.
('48', 106, 2, 21, 236453) My experience teaches me differently.
('48', 106, 2, 22, 236491) I have known men in khaki rolling in gutters instead of standing straight, I have seen a Dyer thinking crooked and speaking not straight but nonsense.
('48', 106, 2, 23, 236642) I have known a commander in chief being unable to think at all, let alone thinking straight.
('48', 106, 2, 24, 236735) Let those who are enamoured of military training have it by all means, but to suggest it ‘as a new constructive programme’ betrays impatience and hasty thinking.
('48', 106, 2, 25, 236897) There is not much danger of ‘the new programme’ taking root in the Indian soil.
('48', 106, 2, 26, 236977) Moreover it is against the new order of things that is coming into being even in the West which has grown weary of the war god.
('48', 106, 2, 27, 237105) The military spirit in the West bids fair to kill the very humanity in man and reduce him to the level of the beast.
('48', 106, 2, 28, 237222) What is wanted and what India has, thank God, learnt in a measure undreamt of before is the spirit of unarmed resistance before which the bayonet runs to rust and gunpowder turns to dust.
('48', 106, 2, 29, 237410) The vision that Joseph puts before us of an armed Government bending a minority to its will by a clatter of arms is a negation of the democratic spirit and progress.
('48', 106, 2, 30, 237576) If that is the promise of the new programme, we have the armed coercion even now
('48', 107, 0, 1, 237657) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 107, 1, 2, 237699) not indeed of a mere minority but of an overwhelming majority.
('48', 107, 1, 3, 237762) What we want, I hope, is a Government not based on coercion even of a minority but on its conversion.
('48', 107, 1, 4, 237864) If it is a change from white military rule to a brown, we hardly need make any fuss.
('48', 107, 1, 5, 237949) At any rate the masses then do not count.
('48', 107, 1, 6, 237991) They will be subject to the same spoliation as now if not even worse.
('48', 107, 1, 7, 238061) When George Joseph has lived down his impatience, I know him to be too honest not to retrace his steps and become the fine democrat that to my great joy I had discovered him to be on the Madras beach in 1919. Let us then turn to what he has to say about khadi:
('48', 107, 2, 8, 238322) As long as I was within the fold of the Congress, the only thing the constructive programme represented was khaddar, removal of ‘untouchability’, and in later years prohibition.
('48', 107, 2, 9, 238500) Now I must frankly tell you that I have come deliberately to the conclusion that not one of these goes to the root of the fundamental need of this nation.
('48', 107, 2, 10, 238655) Khaddar does not.
('48', 107, 2, 11, 238673) I think it will not survive the creator of the movement, Gandhiji.
('48', 107, 2, 12, 238740) I have come to that conclusion, because of the fundamental economic defect which is attached to khaddar.
('48', 107, 2, 13, 238845) It costs far too much to produce and to buy, and is, consequently, unjust to the consumer.
('48', 107, 2, 14, 238936) Khaddar which costs about a rupee a yard will not stand against the cloth produced by the machine industries costing as.
('48', 107, 2, 15, 239057) 6. My experience of khaddar is that it results in injustice to the producer also.
('48', 107, 2, 16, 239139) The women, the spinners, who are at the root of khaddar, working for 10 hours a day, have got to be content with a wage of as.
('48', 107, 2, 17, 239266) 3. I suggest that an industry based on the payment of as.
('48', 107, 2, 18, 239324) has wages to the fundamental producer thereof cannot succeed, because it amounts to sweating of labour.
('48', 107, 2, 19, 239428) The sweating of labour consists essentially in paying to the labourer less than is sufficient for her physical maintenance.
('48', 107, 2, 20, 239552) It is no answer to say that the country is stricken with famine, that there are millions of people without occupation, and to say that for these as.
('48', 107, 2, 21, 239701) 3 is better than no income whatever.
('48', 107, 2, 22, 239738) I refuse to accept that argument.
('48', 107, 2, 23, 239772) That cannot be an argument which can appeal to any human employer of labour, or any statesman with a forward looking view, in reference to the affairs of his country.
('48', 107, 2, 24, 239939) It is no consolation to be told that I shall be right in offering as.
('48', 107, 2, 25, 240009) 3 wages a day, when I know as a matter of economic necessity that the wages would not be sufficient to maintain the worker, much less her family.
('48', 107, 2, 26, 240155) That is to my mind the hopeless ineradicable and inexorable vice that attaches to khaddar.
('48', 107, 2, 27, 240246) That is why today, in spite of 7 or 8 years of labour by Gandhiji, and in spite of lakhs of money poured like water into the organization of the industry, the production of khaddar is infinitely small compared to the magnitude of the problem that has got to be solved, that is, to produce clothing for the whole of India and to put an end to the importation of Rs. 60 crores worth of cloth every year.
('48', 107, 2, 28, 240648) Here George Joseph’s impatience for reform has betrayed him into lapse of memory.
('48', 107, 2, 29, 240730) For he brings no new argument in support of his summary rejection of khadi but quotes as facts what he himself used to refute as fallacies.
('48', 107, 2, 30, 240870) Arguments may be revised on further
('48', 108, 0, 1, 240906) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 109
('48', 108, 1, 2, 240952) consideration, but facts may not be unless they are proved to have been false.: Khadi as conceived for the use of millions does not cost more than foreign cloth for the simple reason that the millions must, if khadi is to be used by them, be their own manufacturers and consumers.
('48', 108, 1, 3, 241233) These pages have shown that in Bardoli, Bijolia and several other places khadi is being so manufactured and consumed even as in millions of homes people cook and eat their own food.
('48', 108, 1, 4, 241415) It is possible to demonstrate, in terms of metal, that rice or bread cooked in a few factories would cost less than they cost today in the millions of homes.
('48', 108, 1, 5, 241573) But nobody on that account would dare suggest that the millions should cease to cook and should send their raw rice and wheat to be cooked in centralized factories.
('48', 108, 1, 6, 241738) Again it is not true to say that women spinners work ten hours per day.
('48', 108, 1, 7, 241810) Whatever spinning they do is done during their spare hours and what they get is not a day’s wage but in the majority of cases a substantial addition to their daily earnings from their daily avocation.
('48', 108, 1, 8, 242011) The earning from spinning is waste turned into wealth and not the price of ‘sweated labour’ as Joseph puts it.
('48', 108, 1, 9, 242122) And let me correct Joseph by saying that no spinner even working for 10 hours per day can earn 3 annas per day.
('48', 108, 1, 10, 242234) Spinning has never been conceived as a full day occupation.
('48', 108, 1, 11, 242294) Lastly it is untrue to say, that “lakhs of money have been poured like water into the organization of the industry”.
('48', 108, 1, 12, 242411) No organization on a nationwide scale has been known to cost less in organizing than this has.
('48', 108, 1, 13, 242506) What is true is that a paltry 25 lakhs have been invested as capital for organizing this great and daily growing cottage industry which brings water to thousands of parched lips.
('48', 108, 1, 14, 242685) Joseph must think cheap of his countrymen when he prophesies that an organization which employs at least 1,500 willing workers in 1,500 villages, an organization which brings daily relief to nearly 1,50,000 women, an organization which commands the self sacrificing labours of a Mithubai Petit, the Naoroji sisters, of a Banker, a Jamnalal, a Rajagopalachari, an Abbas Tyabji, a Venkatappayya, a Pattabhi, a Gangadharrao, a Vallabhbhai, a Lakshmidas, a Rajendraprasad, a Jairamdas, a Mahadev, a Kripalani, a Satis Chandra Das Gupta, a Suresh Banerji, aye a Jawaharlal and a host of others, lawyers, doctors, merchants and laymen too numerous to mention though known to fame, will die after the death of one man.
('48', 108, 1, 15, 243397) It will be a tragic miracle if all these men and women find the morning after my death that khadi was a ‘huge blunder’.
('48', 108, 1, 16, 243517) And the pity of it all is that Joseph does not suggest an alternative.
('48', 108, 1, 17, 243588) Not even if every educated Indian was dressed in khaki and knew how to shoot straight, would the problem of the growing poverty and the forced partial unemployment of millions of the
('48', 109, 0, 1, 243771) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 109, 1, 2, 243813) peasantry be solved without a special programme devised for the purpose.
('48', 109, 1, 3, 243886) For better or worse khadi is that programme till a better is evolved.
('48', 109, 1, 4, 243956) Young India, 19 12 1929
('48', 109, 2, 5, 243980) 113. THE DUTY OF CAPITALISTS
('48', 109, 3, 6, 244009) Ghanshyamdas Birla, presiding the other day at the Maharashtra Merchants’ Conference (Sholapur), delivered a speech that was noteworthy for the freedom with which he expressed his opinions.
('48', 109, 3, 7, 244199) He would have no distinction made between English cloth and other foreign cloth in the matter of protection.
('48', 109, 3, 8, 244308) He said:
('48', 109, 4, 9, 244317) What I want to tell the Government is that while the country would not tolerate any duty based on principle of differentiation 1 even in the interests of the cotton industry, it is vitally essential that an extra uniform ad valorem protective duty should be imposed.
('48', 109, 4, 10, 244584) I maintain that the Bombay cotton industry requires protection not only against imports of cheaper goods but also against imports of finer goods.
('48', 109, 4, 11, 244730) Speaking on the duty of capitalists he presented an ideal which it will be difficult even for a labour man to improve upon.
('48', 109, 4, 12, 244854) Pleading for unity among the merchant class he said:
('48', 109, 5, 13, 244907) But let me make it clear that the unity which I propose for the businessmen should be unity for service and not for exploitation.
('48', 109, 5, 14, 245037) The modern capitalist has been much abused of late.
('48', 109, 5, 15, 245089) In fact, he is being looked upon at present as belonging to a separate class.
('48', 109, 5, 16, 245167) But in the days of yore the situation was something quite different.
('48', 109, 5, 17, 245236) If we analyse the functions of the Vaishya of the ancient times, we find that he was assigned the duty of production and distribution, not for personal gain but for common good.
('48', 109, 5, 18, 245414) All the wealth that he amassed, he held as a trustee for the nation.
('48', 109, 5, 19, 245483) Capitalists, if they are to fulfill their real function, must exist not as exploiters, but as servants of society.
('48', 109, 5, 20, 245598) No Communism or Bolshevism can thrive if we know and discharge our duty.
('48', 109, 5, 21, 245671) If I may say so, it is we who provided a fertile soil for the development of Communism and Bolshevism by relegating our duty to the background.
('48', 109, 5, 22, 245815) If we knew our duty and followed it faithfully, I am sure that we could save society from many evils.
('48', 109, 5, 23, 245917) I have mentioned that our true function is to produce and distribute....
('48', 109, 5, 24, 245990) Let us produce and distribute for the service of the community.
('48', 109, 5, 25, 246054) Let us live and be prepared, if it comes to that, to sacrifice ourselves for the common good.
('48', 109, 6, 26, 246148) Young India, 19 12 1929
('48', 109, 7, 27, 246172) 1 Presumably the reference is to the Cotton Textile Industry (Protection) Bill which was passed by the Legislative Assembly in March 1930.
('48', 110, 0, 1, 246311) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 111
('48', 110, 1, 2, 246357) 114. TO WHOM DOES CONGRESS BELONG?
('48', 110, 2, 3, 246392) During my tour of the U.P. someone asked me a few questions and requested me to give the answers through the columns of the Hindi Navajivan.
('48', 110, 2, 4, 246533) One of them was:
('48', 110, 3, 5, 246550) Is the Congress a joint organization of the Hindus and Muslims?
('48', 110, 3, 6, 246614) If the answer is ‘yes’, can Congress workers who are responsible for Hindu Muslim clashes be called Congressmen and have a following ?
('48', 110, 3, 7, 246749) When such a situation arises what is the man in the street expected to do?
('48', 110, 3, 8, 246824) Congress, of course, belongs to Hindus and Muslims but it is much bigger than that.
('48', 110, 3, 9, 246908) The Congress belongs to every citizen of India—Hindu, Muslim, Parsi, Sikh, Christian, Jew and others.
('48', 110, 3, 10, 247010) Men and women who accept the ideals of the Congress Party can become its members.
('48', 110, 3, 11, 247092) If any Congress member becomes the cause of Hindu Muslim clashes, such a person can be expelled from the Congress.
('48', 110, 3, 12, 247207) He, who, being a Congress member, causes discord between the two communities, is an enemy not only of the Congress but of the country as a whole.
('48', 110, 3, 13, 247353) This is only a bare answer to the above question.
('48', 110, 3, 14, 247403) But when I myself am not satisfied with this much of an answer, how can I expect the questioner to be content with it?
('48', 110, 3, 15, 247522) The sad fact, however, is that hatred between the two communities already exists and there is no need to create it.
('48', 110, 3, 16, 247638) This state of affairs affects Congress also to some extent.
('48', 110, 3, 17, 247698) How can such mutual hatred be removed?
('48', 110, 3, 18, 247737) The questioner must have had this problem in mind though he has not put it into words.
('48', 110, 3, 19, 247824) In order to eschew hatred, purity of mind is necessary.
('48', 110, 3, 20, 247880) Courage should be generated in the minds of both.
('48', 110, 3, 21, 247930) Today we are afraid of each other.
('48', 110, 3, 22, 247965) If this fear could be replaced by mutual trust all hatred and enmity would soon vanish.
('48', 110, 3, 23, 248053) The best way to get over such weakness is not to follow anyone in this matter but to shed fear and suspicion from our own hearts.
('48', 110, 3, 24, 248183) If even a few such men could rise today, then the Congress would come out unscathed.
('48', 110, 3, 25, 248268) Yes, I do realize that there is an endeavour to create such an atmosphere and, knowing this, I cannot give up my own hope and faith.
('48', 110, 3, 26, 248401) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 19 12 1929
('48', 111, 0, 1, 248442) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 111, 1, 2, 248484) 115. LETTER TO RAMNIKLAL MODI
('48', 111, 2, 3, 248514) WARDHA, December 19, 1929
('48', 111, 3, 4, 248540) RAMNIKLAL, I had a letter from Somabhai.
('48', 111, 3, 5, 248581) Since you have made no reference to him, I infer that you have not read the letter.
('48', 111, 3, 6, 248665) Let me know if what he has stated as facts are such.
('48', 111, 3, 7, 248718) You will realize that many questions arise from what he has stated.
('48', 111, 3, 8, 248786) Ask Surendra to write to me and tell me what he had said to Somabhai.
('48', 111, 3, 9, 248856) It is but proper that I should not discuss anything relating to that letter till I have heard from you.
('48', 111, 3, 10, 248960) Dr. Mehta will probably land in Bombay on the 23rd.
('48', 111, 3, 11, 249012) Write to Manilal Kothari about the kitchen and get it vacated and cleaned.
('48', 111, 3, 12, 249087) I do not know where Manilal is at present.
('48', 111, 3, 13, 249130) In any case I am sending from here a wire to him at his Wadhwan address.
('48', 111, 3, 14, 249203) If the key of the kitchen is with you, make a list of his things and put them away in a safe place and then get the kitchen swept and cleaned.
('48', 111, 3, 15, 249346) Chandrakanta will start tomorrow and reach Ahmedabad on Sunday morning.
('48', 111, 3, 16, 249418) She will be accompanied by her parents.
('48', 111, 3, 17, 249458) Her father, too, seems to have the spirit of self sacrifice in him.
('48', 111, 3, 18, 249526) I have, therefore, suggested to him that he himself should accompany Chandrakanta to the Ashram, see the place for himself and live there for a few days, so that I may feel less worried on her account.
('48', 111, 3, 19, 249728) The husband and the wife wish to have separate arrangements for their meals for the present.
('48', 111, 3, 20, 249821) If the mother decides to stay in the Ashram for some time at least, she will certainly take her meals in the common kitchen.
('48', 111, 3, 21, 249946) At present, lodge the husband and the wife in any vacant rooms in Budhabhai’s house.
('48', 111, 3, 22, 250031) Nanibehn is not there, nor Parvatibehn.
('48', 111, 3, 23, 250071) Hence some rooms are bound to be vacant.
('48', 111, 3, 24, 250112) The two may stay in them and cook their meals as they wish.
('48', 111, 3, 25, 250172) Supply them provisions from the store against their names.
('48', 111, 3, 26, 250231) Give them a bill if they ask for it.
('48', 111, 3, 27, 250268) If they do not, keep the amount pending in the department’s account, and consult me about it after I return.
('48', 111, 3, 28, 250377) Chandrakanta will of course stay in the women’s wing.
('48', 111, 3, 29, 250431) The parents are thinking of staying there till my return.
('48', 111, 3, 30, 250489) Do not get confused because I thus give you new information about this in every letter.
('48', 111, 3, 31, 250577) I have no time to narrate the whole case.
('48', 111, 3, 32, 250619) IfI could do that, you would easily understand the indecision of this couple.
('48', 111, 3, 33, 250697) I cannot say positively yet when Madhavji will come.
('48', 111, 3, 34, 250750) If he decides to come after I have left this place, he himself will write to you and let you know the date.
('48', 111, 4, 35, 250858) Blessings from BAPU

('48', 113, 7, 11, 252590) WARDHA, December 20, 1929
('48', 113, 8, 12, 252616) RAMNIKLAL, I have always been indifferent about Dattajayanti 1, etc.
('48', 113, 8, 13, 252685) I am not moved by such things.
('48', 113, 8, 14, 252716) But I do not feel repulsion towards such things either.
('48', 113, 8, 15, 252772) I do not, however, wish that the public should come to know about the temple and that people from outside may even come to worship there, for I visualize the evil consequences which are likely to follow.
('48', 113, 8, 16, 252976) I cannot easily imagine any beneficial results from such a development.
('48', 113, 8, 17, 253048) Those in the Ashram who wish to use the temple for devotional purposes may do so, but I wish that we should not go further than that.
('48', 113, 8, 18, 253182) Let Panditji also read this.
('48', 113, 8, 19, 253211) I, too, would have decided as you did about Premabehn.
('48', 113, 8, 20, 253266) I missed mildness in your decision.
('48', 113, 8, 21, 253302) It is desirable that we should not attend marriages.
('48', 113, 8, 22, 253355) But we have not adopted a rule that no one may attend a marriage at any time.
('48', 113, 8, 23, 253433) Of course, I do feel that we should not spend the Ashram money for such a visit and that we should dissuade those who would listen to us.

('48', 113, 8, 25, 253643) If he and Hasmukhrai have settled the matter between them, the problem is solved.

('48', 114, 1, 5, 254146) I have come to regard Antyajas and the common kitchen as two shields which protect us.

('48', 117, 11, 16, 257934) 128. LETTER TO RAMNIKLAL MODI 3
('48', 117, 12, 17, 257966) WARDHA, December 21, 1929
('48', 117, 13, 18, 257992) RAMNIKLAL, I have not written again about Chi.
('48', 117, 13, 19, 258039) That episode will certainly not be discussed.
('48', 117, 13, 20, 258085) There should be no mention of it just now in the Ashram Samachar also.
('48', 117, 13, 21, 258156) We have to draw from it the proper lesson and therefore have to take every step with caution.
('48', 117, 13, 22, 258250) Whatever may have been.
('48', 117, 13, 23, 258274) ’s error, he needs no persuasion to atone for it, as Chhaganlal Gandhi did.
('48', 117, 13, 24, 258350) The latter’s secret remorse was great.
('48', 117, 13, 25, 258389) But as he was in ignorance as regards his lapse, so was he in regard to atonement.
('48', 117, 13, 26, 258472) I do not think it is so in the case of .

('48', 120, 1, 2, 262111) 133. WHAT SHOULD BE DONE FOR FARMERS?
('48', 120, 2, 3, 262149) A young man who has mentioned his name and wishes to see me but has forgotten to give his address writes: 1
('48', 120, 3, 4, 262257) The desire expressed by the father of this young man is shared by many other parents today.
('48', 120, 3, 5, 262349) Those young men who have been infused with patriotism and who are prepared to undergo any amount of hardship on account of this sentiment will certainly not like toserve the Government or a State after graduation.
('48', 120, 3, 6, 262563) Parents should accept this fact.
('48', 120, 3, 7, 262596) They should give up their insistence upon forcibly guiding along boys and girls who have reached the age of maturity, and young men like the one who has posed the above question should, with humility but with equal firmness, place their ideas before their parents and put them into practice.
('48', 120, 3, 8, 262888) However, how who are ready to do so should also be prepared to renounce their parents, wealth.
('48', 120, 3, 9, 262983) A son or daughter who is looking forward to receiving, or is actually receiving, an inheritance from his or her father has no right to disregard his or her parents’ wishes.
('48', 120, 3, 10, 263156) The question as to what should be done about the poor people or the farmers now takes a subordinate place.
('48', 120, 3, 11, 263263) Anyone who has the strength to give up politely and for the sake of serving the country the shelter afforded by his father will find hundreds of ways of serving the poor farmers.
('48', 120, 3, 12, 263442) One can make a beginning by living like a farmer.
('48', 120, 3, 13, 263492) This naturally suggests to me the spinning wheel.
('48', 120, 3, 14, 263542) But to whomsoever it does not, may not start serving through the spinning wheel.
('48', 120, 3, 15, 263623) If he goes and settles down in any village, a number of ways of serving it in accordance with his capacity will strike him.
('48', 120, 3, 16, 263747) If however, anyone poses the question as to what is to be done there for the sake of one’s livelihood, the answer to it is that all such persons should join an institution like the Charkha Sangh, accept an adequate salary and work there.
('48', 120, 3, 17, 263985) All readers of Navajivan are aware of the fact that hundreds of young men are working in this manner at present.
('48', 120, 3, 18, 264098) Hence the way is dear for all those who truly wish to serve.
('48', 120, 3, 19, 264159) For all those who have the enthusiasm to serve, but not the training to do so, there are available today means whereby they can acquire this knowledge.
('48', 120, 3, 20, 264311) However, very often it is found that there is not the same amount of understanding as the fervour that is found behind the patriotic urge.
('48', 120, 3, 21, 264450) Some young men believe that this fervour is by itself sufficient.
('48', 120, 3, 22, 264516) However, jut as vapour without control is useless or sometimes proves harmful, similarly, such thoughtless fervour is also futile and may even at times prove harmful.
('48', 120, 3, 23, 264683) Those young men who wish to serve the
('48', 120, 4, 24, 264721) 1 The letter is not translated here.

('48', 121, 2, 4, 265000) 134. WOMEN AND ORNAMENTS
('48', 121, 3, 5, 265025) I have never been able to understand our rajas’ and maharajas’ fondness for ornaments.
('48', 121, 3, 6, 265112) Or I may say that the rajas heavily laden with jewellery have reminded me of women.
('48', 121, 3, 7, 265196) I do not wish to malign women by comparing the rajas with them.
('48', 121, 3, 8, 265260) Even women would not appear beautiful to me if they looked like men.
('48', 121, 3, 9, 265329) Every person looks well in his or her rightful place and can make a useful contribution only by remaining there.
('48', 121, 3, 10, 265442) He loses his status if he tries to go above it and we also say that he does likewise if he attempts to climb down from it.
('48', 121, 3, 11, 265565) This is what is meant when it is said that better one’s duty bereft of merit, than another’s well performed.
('48', 121, 3, 12, 265674) 1 However, after having spoken of the ornaments of the rajas, I wish to speak of those of women.
('48', 121, 3, 13, 265771) The former may not even be reading Navajivan.
('48', 121, 3, 14, 265817) Even if they do, they will not pause to ponder over such matters.
('48', 121, 3, 15, 265883) And even if they wish to do so, the Emperor will not permit it.
('48', 121, 3, 16, 265947) These vassals derive their lustre from the latter.
('48', 121, 3, 17, 265998) They are not self luminous; if they give up their ornaments, perhaps they may also have to give up their thrones.
('48', 121, 3, 18, 266112) They themselves say that it will be regarded as an insult to the Emperor if they do not deck themselves with ornaments on State occasions, and the Emperor will be displeased with them.
('48', 121, 3, 19, 266297) Whether they desire it or not, they have no alternative but to possess and wear expensive ornaments and attend such functions.
('48', 121, 3, 20, 266424) Hence there is no point in raising at present the question of the rajas.
('48', 121, 3, 21, 266497) The planets will automatically find their proper places once the sun finds its own.
('48', 121, 3, 22, 266581) These rajas are like the planets.
('48', 121, 3, 23, 266615) They do not at present have any independent powers of doing good or evil.
('48', 121, 3, 24, 266689) They can react independently to what they are told only when they can escape from the Emperor’s clutches or free themselves from his influence.
('48', 121, 3, 25, 266833) But what about women?
('48', 121, 3, 26, 266855) The uplift of women is one of the principal aims of running Navajivan.
('48', 121, 3, 27, 266926) During my tour of the U.P., I was very much irritated at the sight of the ornaments worn by rich and poor women alike.
('48', 121, 3, 28, 267045) At that very time, I read Mr. Brayne’s book.
('48', 121, 3, 29, 267090) I was largely convinced by his criticism of ornaments.
('48', 121, 3, 30, 267145) He has held the men
('48', 121, 4, 31, 267165) 1 Bhagavad Gita, III.
('48', 122, 0, 1, 267187) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 123
('48', 122, 1, 2, 267233) folk too responsible for this fondness for ornaments.
('48', 122, 1, 3, 267287) I believe that men are or were responsible for this; their responsibility may now have decreased, but the women’s responsibility for this fondness is no less.
('48', 122, 1, 4, 267446) I was unable to convince many women to give up their ornaments.
('48', 122, 1, 5, 267510) How and whence did women develop this fondness?
('48', 122, 1, 6, 267558) I do not know its history, hence I have only made some conjectures.
('48', 122, 1, 7, 267626) The ornaments which women wear on their hands and feet are a sign of their bondage.
('48', 122, 1, 8, 267710) Some of the ornaments worn on the feet are so heavy that a woman cannot walk fast, let alone run.
('48', 122, 1, 9, 267808) Some women wear such heavy ornaments on their arms that they prevent them from fully utilizing the latter.
('48', 122, 1, 10, 267915) Hence I regard these ornaments as fetters on the hands and feet.
('48', 122, 1, 11, 267980) I have found that by means of the ornaments which are worn by piercing the nose and ears, the men lead the women as they wish.
('48', 122, 1, 12, 268107) Even a child, by firmly taking hold of a nose or ear ornament of a woman, can render the latter helpless.
('48', 122, 1, 13, 268213) Hence I have looked upon these principal ornaments as mere symbols of slavery.
('48', 122, 1, 14, 268292) I have found even the designs of these ancient ornaments ugly.
('48', 122, 1, 15, 268355) I have beheld no true art in them.
('48', 122, 1, 16, 268390) I have seen and known them as objects which harbour dirt.
('48', 122, 1, 17, 268448) A woman who is loaded with ancient ornaments on her hands, feet, ears, nose and hair cannot even keep these parts of her body clean.
('48', 122, 1, 18, 268581) I have seen layers of dirt collected on those parts.
('48', 122, 1, 19, 268634) Many of these ornaments are not even removable every day.
('48', 122, 1, 20, 268692) When some women gave me their heavy anklets and bangles, they had to call in a goldsmith to have these removed from their hands and feet.
('48', 122, 1, 21, 268830) When these were taken out, they left a good band of dirt on the hands and ankles, and the designs carved on the ornaments were full of layers of dirt.
('48', 122, 1, 22, 268981) These women too felt as if they were rid of an age old burden.
('48', 122, 1, 23, 269044) The modern woman is oblivious of this origin of ornaments and, regarding them as objects which beautify her gets delicate ones made for her.
('48', 122, 1, 24, 269185) She has them made in such a way that they can be readily worn and removed and if she happens to be very wealthy, she has them made of diamonds and pearls instead of gold and silver.
('48', 122, 1, 25, 269367) They may gather less dirt, it may well be the case that they are regarded artistic, but they have no utilitarian value and their capacity to beautify is also imaginary.
('48', 122, 1, 26, 269536) Women of other countries would not wear the ornaments worn by our women.
('48', 122, 1, 27, 269609) Their idea of adorning themsleves is different.
('48', 122, 1, 28, 269657) Ideas of adornment and artistic beauty vary from one country to another; hence we know that in such matters we have no absolute standards of beauty or art.
('48', 122, 1, 29, 269813) Why is it then that many reasonable, educated women still
('48', 123, 0, 1, 269871) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 123, 1, 2, 269913) continue to be fond of ornaments?
('48', 123, 1, 3, 269947) On considering the matter, itseems that as in other matters, here too tradition reigns supreme.
('48', 123, 1, 4, 270043) We do not find reasons for all our actions and do not even stop to consider whether they are proper or otherwise.
('48', 123, 1, 5, 270157) We do them because it is customary to do so and later we like them independently.
('48', 123, 1, 6, 270239) This is called thoughtless life.
('48', 123, 1, 7, 270272) However, why should all those women who are awakened, who have started thinking for themselves, who wish to serve the country, who are taking or wish to take part in the yajna of swaraj, not exercise their discretion with regard to ornaments, etc.?
('48', 123, 1, 8, 270521) If the origin of ornaments is what I have imagined it to be, they are fit to be renounced, however light or beautiful they may be.
('48', 123, 1, 9, 270652) Fetters, though made of gold, diamonds or pearls, are fetters only.
('48', 123, 1, 10, 270720) Whether in a small dark room or in a palace, men and women imprisoned in either will be regarded as prisoners only.
('48', 123, 1, 11, 270836) Moreover, wherein lies the beauty of a woman?
('48', 123, 1, 12, 270882) Does it lie in her ornaments, her mannerisms, her new clothes which she changes daily, or in her heart, thought and action?
('48', 123, 1, 13, 271006) The cobra which has a precious stone on its hood has poison in its fangs.
('48', 123, 1, 14, 271080) Hence, despite the fact that it wears a crown of precious stone, it is not considered worthy of darshan or of being embraced.
('48', 123, 1, 15, 271206) If a woman realizes that this ‘artistic device’ leads to the downfall of countless men, why should she garner these ornaments although they may possess any amount of artistic value?
('48', 123, 1, 16, 271388) This is not a matter of individual freedom, nor is it a question of the rights of an individual; it is merely a wilful act and hence fit to be renounced, because it involves cruelty.
('48', 123, 1, 17, 271571) It is the dharma of every thoughtful and compassionate man and woman to see what effect his or her actions have on others and to desist from them if they are not otherwise proved to be useful and produce a harmful effect.
('48', 123, 1, 18, 271793) Finally, in this poverty stricken land, where the average daily income of a person is seven pice or at the most eight pice, who has the right to wear even the lightest of rings?
('48', 123, 1, 19, 271971) A thoughtful woman who moreover wishes to serve her country, cannot ever touch ornaments.
('48', 123, 1, 20, 272061) Looking at it from the economic standpoint, the gold and silver that we lock up in making ornaments causes threefold harm to the country.
('48', 123, 1, 21, 272199) The first harm is that where there is a shortage of food, we increase it by wearing ornaments.
('48', 123, 1, 22, 272294) It should be borne in mind that our average daily income is seven or eight pice.
('48', 123, 1, 23, 272375) As those whose daily income is a thousand rupees are also included in these calculations, even if we leave the destitutes aside and take into account only thepoorer classes, their income would amount to one or two pice.
('48', 123, 1, 24, 272595) Hence the amount spent on jewellery is something that we have taken
('48', 124, 0, 1, 272663) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 125
('48', 124, 1, 2, 272709) away from the poor.
('48', 124, 1, 3, 272729) The second is that these ornaments do not yield any interest, hence we prevent an increase in the national wealth to that extent.
('48', 124, 1, 4, 272859) The third is that a large portion of these ornaments finally wears off or, in other words, that amount of wealth is lost for ever.
('48', 124, 1, 5, 272990) Just as if an individual throws away some of the gold bars in his possession into the ocean, his wealth will decrease to that extent, almost the same can be said of a woman who invests her money in ornaments.
('48', 124, 1, 6, 273199) I use the word “almost”, as some ornaments are sold in straitened circumstances and hence they may be regarded as having been put to some use.
('48', 124, 1, 7, 273342) The loss that they have suffered through wear and tear before their sale is of course there; moreover, anyone who buys them can never recover their original value when reselling them, and the loss suffered thereby is also there.
('48', 124, 1, 8, 273571) Therefore, any woman who wishes to keep aside ornaments as her own property or as property which may be useful in times of distress should put their equivalent in cash in her name; either her parents or her partents in law should open an account in a bank and give her the pass book.
('48', 124, 1, 9, 273855) Such times may well be far off.
('48', 124, 1, 10, 273887) However, if thoughtful women, who wish to render service, give up their love of ornaments, I would regard this article as having fully served its purpose at least for the time being.
('48', 124, 1, 11, 274070) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 22 12 1929
('48', 124, 2, 12, 274108) 135. MY NOTES
('48', 124, 3, 13, 274122) THE LATE JAIKRISHNA INDRAJI
('48', 124, 4, 14, 274150) A reader of Navajivan writes 1
('48', 124, 5, 15, 274181) I had become acquainted with Sjt.
('48', 124, 5, 16, 274215) Jaikrishna in Porbandar and that very time I was astonished by his diligence in trying to excel himself in his own field and by his simplicity which matched his diligence.
('48', 124, 5, 17, 274387) In trying to discover new plants, he had often roamed the hills of Barda and as a result of his vast experience, he had also written a beautiful book.
('48', 124, 5, 18, 274538) In his own house, too, he had built up a collection which included many botanical specimens and he showed it with pride to anyone who visited him.
('48', 124, 5, 19, 274685) He thought ofnothing but of making discoveries in the field of botany.
('48', 124, 5, 20, 274756) He felt his spiritual well being in this world as well as the next to lie in this only.
('48', 124, 5, 21, 274844) Hence I always regarded him as an ideal student.
('48', 124, 5, 22, 274893) During my tour of Kutch, I
('48', 124, 6, 23, 274920) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('48', 124, 6, 24, 274957) The correspondent had informed Gandhiji of the death of Jaikrishna Indraji.
('48', 125, 0, 1, 275033) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 125, 1, 2, 275075) renewed my acquaintance with him.
('48', 125, 1, 3, 275109) His passion for planting new trees increased rather than decreased with advancing age.
('48', 125, 1, 4, 275196) Men with such single minded devotion to their subject are indeed rare.
('48', 125, 1, 5, 275267) Jaikrishna Indraji was one of them.
('48', 125, 1, 6, 275303) He has now left us after fulfilling his duty; hence his soul is of course at peace.
('48', 125, 1, 7, 275387) Let us all emulate his single mindedness and his self confidence.
('48', 125, 2, 8, 275453) LABOUR AND CAPITAL
('48', 125, 3, 9, 275472) Nowadays labour and capital have formed two distinct camps and it is found that the two are generally opposed to each other.
('48', 125, 3, 10, 275597) A sect has arisen in the world which believes that the capitalist class should not exist at all, or that everyone should belong to the class of owners.
('48', 125, 3, 11, 275749) In my opinion, such a state of affairs will never come about in the world.
('48', 125, 3, 12, 275824) What is possible, and what should happen, is that instead of mutual distrust and enmity, there should be trust and love between them.
('48', 125, 3, 13, 275958) Just as a sect has arisen which aims at destroying the capitalists, today in the West another has arisen which believes that it is possible to create trust and love between the two.
('48', 125, 3, 14, 276140) If such a situation is possible, it is primarily the responsibility of the capitalists to bring it about.
('48', 125, 3, 15, 276246) This is so not only because theirs is the stronger side, but also because it is their class which will have to make the requisite sacrifices.
('48', 125, 3, 16, 276388) Labour has no privileges on its side, or the only privilege that it does enjoy is the one to feel aggrieved, that is to say, to offer satyagraha.
('48', 125, 3, 17, 276534) That, however, is not the special privilege of labour.
('48', 125, 3, 18, 276589) All human beings enjoy it.
('48', 125, 3, 19, 276616) Sheth Ghanshyamdas Birla had recently made a speech in Sholapur 1 in which he has accepted the fact that capitalists should make this type of sacrifice.
('48', 125, 3, 20, 276769) In it, he had clearly stated that it was against the dharma of the mill owners to misuse or make anything in order to earn profits, that their dharma was to produce goods and sell them only in order to serve and benefit the public.
('48', 125, 3, 21, 277001) And he has also expressed the view that if mill owners do not do so, they cannot continue to survive in the long run.
('48', 125, 3, 22, 277119) If all mill owners act in this manner, all disputes will be banished and an atmosphere of trust will be created between them and the labourers and along with it, the two canbe united by a bond of love.
('48', 125, 3, 23, 277321) In the language of the old times, this is known as conduct in accordance with one’s dharma and in modern language it is known as just conduct.
('48', 125, 3, 24, 277464) While judging the matter by these very standards, Sjt.
('48', 125, 3, 25, 277519) Ghanshyamdas has also expressed the opinion that they should not abandon what is important in order to reap a minor benefit or, in other words, if the temptation arises to levy an import duty on foreign cloth other than that manufactured in
('48', 125, 4, 26, 277760) 1 Vide “The Duty of Capitalists”, 19 12 1929.
('48', 126, 0, 1, 277806) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 127
('48', 126, 1, 2, 277852) Britain, they should not yield to it.
('48', 126, 1, 3, 277890) Sheth Ghanshyamdas Birla had delivered this speech as President before the business community of Sholapur; and it has not been reported that anyone raised any objections to it.
('48', 126, 1, 4, 278067) However, it is one thing not to object to such ideas, and quite another to put them into practice.
('48', 126, 1, 5, 278166) What is essential is to act in accordance with such ideas, because even the best of ideas have ultimately no value if they are not put into practice.
('48', 126, 2, 6, 278316) HAJAM OR ‘VALAND’?
('48', 126, 3, 7, 278335) A gentleman from Palitana writes: 1
('48', 126, 4, 8, 278371) The contemptible implication underlying the word hajam is actually directed towards that profession.
('48', 126, 4, 9, 278472) This word is used with reference to persons whose profession is to shave or cut the hair.
('48', 126, 4, 10, 278562) If this word is not approved of, I shall only use the word ‘Valand’ in Navajivan.
('48', 126, 4, 11, 278644) However, it is my confirmed opinion that this is no remedy for the basic problem.
('48', 126, 4, 12, 278726) The real remedy consists in ending the prejudice against those professions which are essential but are concerned with the removal of dirt.
('48', 126, 4, 13, 278865) Thereafter, we can remain indifferent to names that may be used to indicate them.
('48', 126, 4, 14, 278947) What can we do when ‘a boy fondly named Hari dies at an early age’?
('48', 126, 4, 15, 279015) We should not, therefore, look upon the word Hari with contempt.

('48', 128, 1, 2, 282636) 137. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('48', 128, 2, 3, 282664) DELHI, December 23, 1929
('48', 128, 3, 4, 282689) SISTERS, I am writing this in Delhi after the morning prayers.
('48', 128, 3, 5, 282752) It is severe cold, so severe that Mirabehn’s feet have become stiff.
('48', 128, 3, 6, 282821) She has slipped back into bed and is lying near me.
('48', 128, 3, 7, 282873) Lahore, of course, is even colder than Delhi.
('48', 128, 3, 8, 282919) But I do not wish to write to you about the cold.
('48', 128, 3, 9, 282969) I wish to write about our duties.
('48', 128, 3, 10, 283003) Just now I shall say only this, that those among you who are thinking about their selfish desires are bound to fall.
('48', 128, 3, 11, 283120) Those who devote themselves to their duty, when can they have the time to fall?
('48', 128, 3, 12, 283200) It has always been my experience that those who fell had remained, or become, indifferent to truth.
('48', 128, 3, 13, 283300) A sinful actrequires the cover of darkness.
('48', 128, 3, 14, 283344) It is always done in secret.
('48', 128, 3, 15, 283373) We certainly see persons who have abandoned all sense of shame and act sinfully in the open.
('48', 128, 3, 16, 283466) There are even people who regard sin as virtue.
('48', 128, 3, 17, 283514) We are not talking about them.
('48', 128, 3, 18, 283545) One reason why progress in many of our activities is held up is the selfishness I have mentioned above.
('48', 128, 3, 19, 283649) In that selfishness lies the danger of our fall and that of society.
('48', 128, 3, 20, 283718) Think over this, fix your mind on it and let each one examine her life in the light of it.

('48', 130, 3, 15, 287983) December 24, 1929 Mahatma Gandhi while delivering his presidential address at the Suppressed Classes Conference declared: Freedom can never be attained by exploding bombs on an innocent man.

('48', 130, 3, 17, 288214) He said no other power on earth could prove a barrier against the attainment of freedom, but our own weaknesses were our greatest enemy.

('48', 130, 3, 19, 288467) He laid stress on sanitation, education, etc.
('48', 130, 3, 20, 288513) He paid a tribute to Rishi Balmiki, their ancestor and author of the Ramayana, and exhorted the untouchables to follow him.
('48', 130, 3, 21, 288637) Referring to the question of temple entry, Mahatma Gandhi said entering temples by force was not satyagraha.
('48', 130, 3, 22, 288746) They should learn satyagraha from him.
('48', 130, 3, 23, 288785) He cited the example of the satyagraha at Vykom in South India five years back.
('48', 130, 3, 24, 288865) He said compulsion whether by the British or by Indians was a crime.
('48', 130, 3, 25, 288934) They must not compel high caste people for temple entry.
('48', 130, 3, 26, 288991) He said they could not see God by force.
('48', 130, 3, 27, 289032) God was present within their hearts and not in temples and mosques.
('48', 130, 3, 28, 289100) He advised the untouchables patiently to undergo sufferings and pray that high caste cruelty may come to an end.

('48', 131, 2, 6, 289809) 141. NOTES
('48', 131, 3, 7, 289820) A VICIOUS INFERENCE
('48', 131, 4, 8, 289840) The estimated drink and drug bill paid by Madras in 1928 29, according to the statistics collected by Sjt.
('48', 131, 4, 9, 289947) C. Rajagopalachari, was Rs. 16,83,00,000, i.e., seventeen crores in round figures.
('48', 131, 4, 10, 290030) The revenue got out of this was Rs. 5,10,00,000, i.e., a little over five crores.
('48', 131, 4, 11, 290112) The net waste was therefore say 113 crores.
('48', 131, 4, 12, 290156) This is more than the land revenue by over four crores.
('48', 131, 4, 13, 290212) These figures are startling enough to make a reformer think.
('48', 131, 4, 14, 290273) But the worst is yet to follow.
('48', 131, 4, 15, 290305) The same vigilant eye has observed that the drink bill increases year after year as also crime against Abkari 1 laws.
('48', 131, 4, 16, 290423) From these statistics the Madras Government is reported to have drawn this vicious inference: The continued increase of crime against Abkari laws and its appearance in all parts of the Presidency must give pause to any immediate drastic action in the way of cutting of the supply of licit liquor lest the result should prove more serious to the general morality than are the present conditions.
('48', 131, 4, 17, 290818) This is the same as saying that because the crime of thieving is on the increase there should be a progressive relaxation of the laws against thieving.
('48', 131, 4, 18, 290970) The inference is based on the assumption that drinking intoxicating liquors is not a disease or an evil in the same sense as thieving.
('48', 131, 4, 19, 291105) The fact however is that the drink habit has been demonstrated to be a parent of thieving as of many other crimes.
('48', 131, 4, 20, 291220) The proper inference to be drawn from the increasing crime is that the existence of liquor shops is a fatal trap for poor humanity and that therefore the true method is forthwith to declare total prohibition without counting the cost.
('48', 131, 4, 21, 291455) Crime there will still be against the prohibition laws as there is and always has been against laws prohibiting thieving, etc.
('48', 131, 4, 22, 291582) If there is no licensed thieving, there may be no licensed drinking.
('48', 131, 4, 23, 291651) For an unsophisticated mind that is the only inference possible and that is the straight and simple logic.
('48', 131, 4, 24, 291758) A Government whichwants a revenue anyhow to run an expensive foreign administration manufactures logic to suit its evil purpose.
('48', 131, 5, 25, 291887) 1 Excise
('48', 132, 0, 1, 291896) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 133
('48', 132, 1, 2, 291942) “SEVEN MONTHS WITH GANDHIJI”
('48', 132, 2, 3, 291971) This is the title of two volumes brought out by Sjt.
('48', 132, 2, 4, 292024) Krishnadas who was with me as my valued assistant during the stirring non co operation days whilst I was touring through Assam and elsewhere 1. He recorded the events of those days in his diary chiefly meant for his guru, Sjt.
('48', 132, 2, 5, 292251) Satischandra Mukerji who had lent Krishnadas’ services to me when Mahadev was wanted by Pandit Motilalji.
('48', 132, 2, 6, 292357) The volumes are chiefly extracts from that diary and have been before the public for some time.
('48', 132, 2, 7, 292453) Satish Babu having received inquiries from foreign friends as to the authenticity of the facts narrated in the volumes asked me whether I would read the volumes and testify.
('48', 132, 2, 8, 292627) Krishnadas himself was anxious to know my opinion of his volumes.
('48', 132, 2, 9, 292693) I have gone through them.
('48', 132, 2, 10, 292719) And the facts appear to me to be correctly set forth and exhaustively dealt with.
('48', 132, 2, 11, 292801) For the inferences and opinions drawn from and based on the facts I can say nothing.
('48', 132, 2, 12, 292886) We know that different minds applied to the same facts draw different inferences.
('48', 132, 2, 13, 292968) We know too that the same mind by efflux of time and maturer experience draws opposite inferences from the same facts.
('48', 132, 2, 14, 293087) So far as these volumes are concerned, whilst the pen is that of Krishnadas, the directing mind is that of his master and guide Satischandra Mukerji.
('48', 132, 2, 15, 293237) The volumes are the only narrative we have of the seven months with which Krishnadas deals.
('48', 132, 2, 16, 293329) The first volume is published by S. Ganesan, Triplicane, Madras, and the second is published by Babu Ram Binode Sinha, Gandhi Kutir, Dighwara (Bihar).
('48', 132, 2, 17, 293480) Young India, 26 12 1929
('48', 132, 3, 18, 293504) 142. DEFINITE SUGGESTIONS
('48', 132, 4, 19, 293530) During the U.P. tour I received the following letter 2 from Allahabad students: Though I dealt with the matter in one of my addresses to students and though a definite programme has been placed before students in these pages, it is worth while reiterating and perhaps more pointedly the scheme adumbrated before.
('48', 132, 4, 20, 293843) The writers of the letter want to know what they may do after finishing their studies.
('48', 132, 4, 21, 293930) I want to tell them that the grown up students
('48', 132, 5, 22, 293977) 1 In 1921. 2 Not reproduced here.
('48', 132, 5, 23, 294011) The students had complained that Gandhiji’s article “What May Youth Do?”, pp.
('48', 132, 5, 24, 294089) 108 9, was vague, and wanted some definite outline to be clearly chalked out
('48', 133, 0, 1, 294166) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 133, 1, 2, 294208) and therefore all college students should begin village work even whilst they are studying.
('48', 133, 1, 3, 294300) Here is a scheme for such part time workers.
('48', 133, 1, 4, 294345) The students should devote the’ whole of their vacation to village service.
('48', 133, 1, 5, 294421) To this end, instead of taking their walks along beaten paths, they should walk to the villages within easy reach of their institutions and study the condition of the village folk and befriend them.
('48', 133, 1, 6, 294620) This habit will bring them in contact with the villagers who, when the students actually go to stay in their midst, will by reason of the previous occasional contact receive them as friends rather than as strangers to be looked upon with suspicion.
('48', 133, 1, 7, 294869) During the long vacation the students will stay in the villages and offer to conduct classes for adults and to teach the rules of sanitation to the villagers and attend to the ordinary cases of illness.
('48', 133, 1, 8, 295072) They will also introduce the spinning wheel amongst them and teach them the use of every spare minute.
('48', 133, 1, 9, 295175) In order that this may be done students and teachers will have to revise their ideas of the uses of vacation.
('48', 133, 1, 10, 295285) Often do thoughtless teachers prescribe lessons to be done during the vacation.
('48', 133, 1, 11, 295365) This in my opinion is in any case a vicious habit.
('48', 133, 1, 12, 295416) Vacation is just the period when students’ minds should be free from the routine work and be left free for self help and original development.
('48', 133, 1, 13, 295559) The village work I have mentioned is easily the best form of recreation and light instruction.
('48', 133, 1, 14, 295654) It is obviously the best preparation for dedication to exclusive village service after finishing the studies.
('48', 133, 1, 15, 295764) The scheme for full village service does not now need to be elaborately described.
('48', 133, 1, 16, 295847) Whatever was done during the vacation has now to be put on a permanent footing.
('48', 133, 1, 17, 295927) The villagers will also be prepared for a fuller response.
('48', 133, 1, 18, 295986) The village life has to be touched at all points, the economic, the hygienic, the social and the political.
('48', 133, 1, 19, 296094) The immediate solution of the economic distress is undoubtedly the wheel in the vast majority of cases.
('48', 133, 1, 20, 296198) It at once adds to the income of the villagers and keeps them from mischief.
('48', 133, 1, 21, 296275) The hygienic includes insanitation and disease.
('48', 133, 1, 22, 296323) Here the student is expected to work with his own body and labour to dig trenches for burying excreta and other refuse and turning them into manure, for cleaning wells and tanks, for building easy embankments, removing rubbish and generally to make the villages more habitable.
('48', 133, 1, 23, 296601) The village worker has also to touch thesocial side and gently persuade the people to give up bad customs and bad habits, such as untouchability, infant marriages, unequal matches, drink and drug evil and many local superstitions.
('48', 133, 1, 24, 296832) Lastly comes the political part.
('48', 133, 1, 25, 296865) Here the worker will study the political grievances of the villagers and teach them the dignity of freedom, self reliance and self help in everything.
('48', 133, 1, 26, 297016) This makes in my opinion complete adult education.
('48', 133, 1, 27, 297067) But this does not complete the task of the village worker.
('48', 134, 0, 1, 297126) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 135
('48', 134, 1, 2, 297172) He must take care and charge of the little ones and begin their instruction and carry on a night school for adults.
('48', 134, 1, 3, 297288) This literary training is but part of a whole education course and only a means to the larger end described above.
('48', 134, 1, 4, 297403) I claim that the equipment for this service is a large heart and a character above suspicion.
('48', 134, 1, 5, 297497) Given these two conditions every other needed qualification is bound to follow.

('48', 135, 3, 14, 300371) Although all people theoretically admit that Hindi alone can be the national language, yet the requisite love for the Hindi language is not apparent among young men of the provinces where the mother tongue is Hindi.

('48', 140, 6, 19, 313112) We must praise his efforts to come to some agreement.
('48', 140, 6, 20, 313166) But considering his point of view, I cannot lay any blame upon him.

('48', 140, 6, 23, 313478) So thinking about the question from all its aspects, we feel that no good can be had for the country by the Congress sending representatives to the Round Table Conference.
('48', 140, 6, 24, 313650) I hope there will be no amendment to this part of the resolution.
('48', 140, 6, 25, 313716) The second part of the resolution is regarding the change of

('48', 141, 0, 1, 313978) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 141, 1, 2, 314020) creed of the Congress.
('48', 141, 1, 3, 314043) This again is nothing but the logical conclusion of the resolution passed in the Calcutta Congress last year.
('48', 141, 1, 4, 314153) 1 The Madras Congress 2 had set up the ideal of swaraj within the Empire if possible and without it if necessary.
('48', 141, 1, 5, 314267) And by the exigencies of circumstances, we are now compelled to declare that the Congress wants complete independence and fixes it as its “swaraj”.
('48', 141, 1, 6, 314415) The Madras Congress did not actually change the objective of the Congress.
('48', 141, 1, 7, 314490) The Calcutta Congress too did not take up definitely any attitude in regard to this matter.
('48', 141, 1, 8, 314582) But now we are going to change our objective into definite form of complete independence.
('48', 141, 1, 9, 314672) Today, I do not want to say swaraj within Empire is possible at all, and we say clearly that swaraj means complete independence.
('48', 141, 1, 10, 314801) The third part of the resolution deals with how to work up this new creed of complete independence.
('48', 141, 1, 11, 314901) The first step as suggested by the resolution is for boycott of legislatures and local bodies, or in other words we want that the legislatures both provincial and central should be boycotted by Congressmen.
('48', 141, 1, 12, 315108) Not only that, the Congress further wants the boycott of local bodies such as municipalities, local boards, etc.
('48', 141, 1, 13, 315221) It is no doubt a great step.
('48', 141, 1, 14, 315250) But for the attainment of that great ideal of complete independence, we must have to take up such rather drastic steps.
('48', 141, 1, 15, 315370) We must be now prepared for great struggles ahead.
('48', 141, 1, 16, 315421) We must cease to have any more internal difference and dissensions.
('48', 141, 1, 17, 315489) Another thing I want to make clear before you.
('48', 141, 1, 18, 315536) Now that the Nehru Report on the line of Dominion Status will be declared to have lapsed, there cannot and should not be any further fighting over it and I hope the Sikhs and Muslims and all other sections who had one or other grievances against the Nehru Report will see no objection to join the Congress and unite within its fold for the battle of independence.
('48', 141, 1, 19, 315900) Even if you have got unavoidable dissensions, still we should act unitedly within the Congress.
('48', 141, 1, 20, 315996) If Mussalmans cut the throats of Hindus let them cut it.

('48', 141, 1, 23, 316255) I never thought of going to the legislatures and I am glad that the same feelings are being entertained by other leaders regarding these legislative bodies.
('48', 141, 1, 24, 316412) Now it is being widely felt that no good can be brought to the country by taking part in them and today we want to decide to leave them.
('48', 141, 1, 25, 316549) As regards municipalities and local bodies, I

('48', 152, 2, 8, 342613) 156. SPEECH AT SUBJECTS COMMITTEE, A.I.C.C. –II
('48', 152, 3, 9, 342661) December 30, 1929 This Congress congratulates the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee, the Anti Untouchability Committee and the Prohibition Committee on the vigorous prosecution of the work entrusted to them, but notes with regret that the response from the nation has not been as adequate as the Congress had the right to expect.
('48', 152, 3, 10, 342989) Experience gained by these Committees and by the All India Spinners’ Association shows that far more effective work becomes possible through autonomous organizations created for specific activities.
('48', 152, 3, 11, 343188) This Congress, therefore, hereby declares the foregoing Committees to be permanent with complete autonomy and with powers to add to their number, to frame their respective constitutions and to raise funds, provided that they shall follow the general policy of the Congress and further that the Congress reserves to itself full authority to disown any of these bodies when and if they appear to the Congress to be acting contrary to the national interest.
('48', 152, 4, 12, 343643) Mahatmaji then spoke.
('48', 152, 4, 13, 343665) As regards the resolution which has been submitted to you several questions have been asked.

('48', 157, 2, 3, 355189) MR. PRESIDENT AND FRIENDS, I have been asked to give you in English the substance of what I have said.
('48', 157, 2, 4, 355292) In my opinion, it will be a good beginning if our resolutions dealing with the task before the Congress are passed unanimously.
('48', 157, 2, 5, 355420) In appearing before you I have realized my responsibility in the matter to the fullest and my certain conviction is that the Congress will fail in its obvious duty if it does not record this resolution.
('48', 157, 2, 6, 355623) You find the reason for it stated in the resolution itself.
('48', 157, 2, 7, 355683) So long as the Congress creed remains what it is, namely, that we want to attain swaraj, not by any means, but by peaceful and legitimate means, it is our bounden duty to take note’ of anything that happens in India in breach of that condition.
('48', 157, 2, 8, 355928) You might be told, as I dare say you will be told, that when people who do not belong to the Congress organization and are not connected with it in any shape or form do particular acts which may be contrary to our creed, we are in no way and in no sense responsible.
('48', 157, 2, 9, 356195) Those who think like that have, I say in all humility, little sense of the tremendous responsibility that rests on their shoulders; and they have little sense also of the great status that belongs to the Congress.
('48', 157, 2, 10, 356409) We either claim to represent the thirty crores of Hindustan or we do not.
('48', 157, 2, 11, 356483) If we claim to represent them, as I, a humble Congress worker, most certainly do, and asI hope, you also do, then it is our duty to consider ourselves responsible for anything that any single person born in Hindustan may do and it does not matter to me in the slightest whether that person is a reasonable human being or whether he belongs to the C.I.D. I hope that you consider the C.I.D. Indians also to be our kith and kin.
('48', 157, 2, 12, 356910) Every Indian we expect to convert by our deeds to our creed and use his services in the attainment of our goal.
('48', 157, 2, 13, 357022) Not only that, but the resolution states, and I hope you believe it, that such acts do great harm to the national cause.
('48', 157, 2, 14, 357143) I do not wish to take up your time by drawing your attention to the various landmarks in the history of the Congress, which would enable you to prove to your own satisfaction that each bomb outrage has cost India dear.
('48', 157, 2, 15, 357362) You may say, if you wish to, that the reforms that were obtained could not have been obtained without bomb outrages or without violence.
('48', 157, 2, 16, 357499) Let me tell you that every one of these reforms has cost far more than you would care to pay.
('48', 157, 2, 17, 357593) We have paid millions in exchange for mere toys.

('48', 158, 1, 5, 358330) We have a tremendous military burden which is crushing the starving millions who are living in the 700,000 villages of India.
('48', 158, 1, 6, 358456) That military burden is really not due to the necessities of frontier defence, but let me assure you, that burden is due to the fact that thirty crores of people are held bond slaves by a few thousand Englishmen coming all the way from England.
('48', 158, 1, 7, 358701) If we would get rid of this military burden at any stage, it would be a necessity of the case that we hold the lives of those whom we may even consider our enemies as a sacred trust.
('48', 158, 1, 8, 358884) That is the clearest possible implication, in my humble opinion, of the creed of non violence for the political salvation of India, and if you hold with me, then it is not only a matter of courtesy on your part, but it is a matter of duty to tender our congratulations to the Viceroy and Lady Irwin and their party including the servants, and tender congratulations, if you will, to ourselves also.

('48', 160, 3, 14, 364535) 159. SPEECH AT CONGRESS SESSION, LAHORE–II
('48', 160, 4, 15, 364578) December 31, 1929 This Congress endorses the action of the Working Committee in connection with the manifesto signed by party leaders including Congressmen on the Viceregal pronouncement of the 31st October relating to Dominion Status, and appreciates the efforts of the Viceroy towards a settlement of the national movement for swaraj.
('48', 160, 4, 16, 364915) The Congress, however, having considered all that has since happened and the result of the meeting between Mr. M. K. Gandhi, Pandit Motilal Nehru and other leaders and the Viceroy, is of opinion that nothing is to be gained in the existing circumstances by the Congress being represented at the proposed Round Table Conference.

('48', 168, 1, 18, 387675) If, on the other hand, you do not believe their testimony, then you must hound them out of the Congress.
('48', 168, 1, 19, 387780) It is not a sign of courage that one should be ashamed of saying what one feels; but it is a sign of decided courage when a man openly admits the good that even his enemy does.

('48', 168, 1, 21, 388258) Hope begets hope, hope begets courage and hope therefore begets decisive action.

('48', 169, 1, 12, 390153) There is one stock argument, I know, that no matter what you do your places will never remain vacant; but it is not the idea that the places should remain vacant.

('48', 170, 1, 5, 391596) Then there comes the question of civil disobedience.

('48', 170, 1, 7, 391839) I can conceive of freedom and independence being achieved by and on behalf of the starving millions scattered over the length and breadth of India, in the seven hundred thousand villages, by legitimate and peaceful means only.
('48', 170, 1, 8, 392066) Disobedience to be absolutely effective has got to be always civil, that is always non violent; and if you want that civil disobedience should come in the near future you will have to transform yourselves.
('48', 170, 1, 9, 392272) You will then not have jugglery of thought; you will not then deceive yourselves and, unconsciously it may be, deceive the nation also into the belief that the bomb and non violence can run on parallel lines.
('48', 170, 1, 10, 392481) In a place like India where the mightiest organization is pledged to [non ] violence, if you really believe in your own creed, that is to say, if you believe in yourselves, if you believe in your nation, then it is civil disobedience that is wanted; and if it is civil disobedience that is wanted, then, you must observe the strictest discipline, you must see that no passion arises at least amongst ourselves, no ugly demonstrations of the sort that we have seen here and that we saw in the Subjects Committee; we must be calm, cool, collected, courageous, brave; and we must speak to the point, never obstruct.
('48', 170, 1, 11, 393094) It does not matter a bit if every one of my propositions is lost; I must have toleration for those who have moved and supported these amendments.

('48', 177, 4, 10, 403750) AHMEDABAD, [1929] 1
('48', 177, 5, 11, 403770) JAMNADAS, I have committed a great blunder.
('48', 177, 5, 12, 403814) Driven by a particular thought I just said that you should go to Calcutta.
('48', 177, 5, 13, 403889) By all means, go to any place where you can find your peace of mind.
('48', 177, 5, 14, 403958) I have had long arguments with you.
('48', 177, 5, 15, 403994) I have prevented you from doing many things.
('48', 177, 5, 16, 404039) We must give up the habit of indulging so much in arguments.
('48', 177, 5, 17, 404100) In that state of mind I just told you to go to Calcutta if you so wished.
('48', 177, 5, 18, 404174) But I cannot give you such a permission.
('48', 177, 5, 19, 404215) It is one thing if you wish to go and go.
('48', 177, 5, 20, 404257) But it is another if I happily permit you to go.
('48', 177, 5, 21, 404306) Not only am I not in favour of your going to Calcutta, but I am against it.
('48', 177, 5, 22, 404382) Considering my view, take an indepedent decision.
('48', 177, 5, 23, 404432) It would not hurt me in any way.
('48', 177, 5, 24, 404465) My reason for opposing your going to Calcutta is as under : I have believed that there is no other city in India as wicked as Calcutta.
('48', 177, 5, 25, 404601) The atrocities that are perpetrated in Calcutta can hardly be witnessed in any other city of the world.
('48', 177, 5, 26, 404705) This comparison may be somewhat exaggerated.
('48', 177, 5, 27, 404750) My knowledge about other cities is incomplete.
('48', 177, 5, 28, 404797) But I have no doubt at all about the cities of India.
('48', 177, 5, 29, 404851) In Calcutta, thousands of innocent lambs and goats are slaughtered in the name of religion.
('48', 177, 5, 30, 404943) Such a thing is done nowhere else in India.
('48', 177, 5, 31, 404987) Everyone, big and small, the learned and the foolish, are a party to this slaughter.
('48', 177, 5, 32, 405072) No one stops to think about it even for a moment.
('48', 177, 5, 33, 405122) The enlightened Calcutta does not even protest against it.
('48', 177, 5, 34, 405181) And in this so called age of reform, this cruel act is being performed day after day.
('48', 177, 5, 35, 405267) Stand anywhere in the Bhawanipur area of Calcutta early in the morning and you will see flocks of sheep around.
('48', 177, 5, 36, 405379) I have witnessed that sight with my own eyes.

('48', 179, 7, 9, 407356) I have travelled throughout the country in the third class and have mixed with the poor more than anyone else and I have seen with my own eyes how the poor suffer in winter.
('48', 179, 7, 10, 407530) This proposal has been placed before you after the most careful consideration of all the months of the year.
('48', 179, 7, 11, 407639) During the month suggested there is no rain, no malaria or any other epidemic or diseases.
('48', 179, 7, 12, 407730) It may be said that we get railway concession during the Christmas.
('48', 179, 7, 13, 407798) But I think it is immaterial.
('48', 179, 7, 14, 407828) And we hope to be in control of the railways before long.
('48', 179, 7, 15, 407886) (Laughter) Similarly the question that we will not get students as our volunteers seems to be also immaterial, because besides students there are lakhs of people who are non students and I hope these poor men will take part in the Congress.
('48', 179, 7, 16, 408127) The months of February and March are the best months for the poor from the point of view of convenience and cheapness.
('48', 179, 7, 17, 408246) I very much realize the remark that we are Xmas politicians.
('48', 179, 7, 18, 408307) Henceforth: we want to dispose of our business most promptly and I think I need not speak much on this resolution.
