('48', 180, 3, 4, 409065) Mahatmaji then moved the resolution of the Working Committee repudiating the national debt and declaring that at the time of final settlement of India’s national debt a tribunal would be appointed to judge which debt India should pay and would pay according to the decision of that tribunal.
('48', 180, 3, 5, 409357) This Congress is of opinion that the financial burdens directly or indirectly imposed on India by the foreign administration are such as a free India cannot bear and cannot be expected to bear.
('48', 180, 3, 6, 409551) This Congress, whilst reaffirming the resolution passed at the Gaya Congress in 1922, therefore records its opinion for the information of all concerned that every obligation and concession to be inherited by independent India will be strictly subject to investigation by an independent tribunal, and every obligation, every concession, no matter how incurred or given, will be repudiated if it is not found by such tribunal to be just and justifiable.

('48', 181, 3, 13, 412486) [LAHORE, January 1, 1930] 2
('48', 181, 4, 14, 412514) What is the difference between the Non co operation Movement of 1921 and the present movement?
('48', 181, 4, 15, 412609) The present movement is directed towards independence, whereas that of 1921 was directed towards the redress of the Khilafat and Punjab wrongs and the attainment of swaraj within the Empire if possible and without if necessary.
('48', 181, 4, 16, 412837) The boycott is confined this time only to the legislatures, but civil disobedience including the no tax campaign is common to both, as also truth and non violence.
('48', 181, 5, 17, 413001) The civil disobedience will be of the Bardoli type?
('48', 181, 5, 18, 413053) You mean the satyagraha of 1928?
('48', 181, 5, 19, 413086) Yes, somewhat of that type; only in Bardoli the people fought for the redress of a specific local grievance.
('48', 181, 6, 20, 413195) How about the other boycotts?
('48', 181, 6, 21, 413225) It may not be necessary to resort to them if we can place civil

('48', 183, 0, 1, 415383) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 183, 1, 2, 415425) 181. THE CULT OF THE BOMB
('48', 183, 2, 3, 415451) There is so much violence in the atmosphere immediately surrounding us, politically minded part of India, that a bomb thrown here and a bomb thrown there causes little perturbation and probably there is even joy over such an event in the hearts of some.
('48', 183, 2, 4, 415705) If I did not know that this violence was like froth coming to the surface in an agitated liquid, I should probably despair of non violence succeeding in the near future in giving us the freedom which we are all violently minded and non violently minded people yearning for.
('48', 183, 2, 5, 415979) Happily I have a certain belief based upon ceaseless experience during my tour in the heart of India for the past twelve months very nearly, that the vast masses who have become conscious of the fact that they must have freedom are untouched by the spirit of violence.
('48', 183, 2, 6, 416248) In spite therefore of sporadic violent outbursts such as the bomb explosion under the Viceregal train I feel that non violence for our political battle has come to stay.
('48', 183, 2, 7, 416418) It is because of my increasing faith in the efficacy of non violence in political warfare and the possibility of its being practised by masses of people that I propose to reason with those who may not be so much saturated with violence as to be beyond the pale of reason.
('48', 183, 2, 8, 416690) Let us think then for a moment what would have happened if the Viceroy had been seriously injured or killed.
('48', 183, 2, 9, 416799) There certainly would have been no meeting of 23rd ultimo and therefore no certainty as to the course to be adopted by the Congress.
('48', 183, 2, 10, 416932) That surely would have been, to say the least, an undersirable result.
('48', 183, 2, 11, 417003) Fortunatelyfor us the Viceroy and his party escaped unhurt, and with great self possession he went through the day’s routine as if nothing had happened.
('48', 183, 2, 12, 417156) I know that those who have no regard even for the Congress, who hope nothing from it and whose hope lies only through violence, will not be affected by this speculative reasoning.
('48', 183, 2, 13, 417336) But the others, I hope, will not fail to realize the truth of the argument and to put together several important deductions that can be drawn from the hypothetical case put by me.
('48', 183, 2, 14, 417516) Take again the net result of political violence practised in this country.
('48', 183, 2, 15, 417591) Every time violence has occurred we have lost heavily, that is to say, military expenditure has risen.
('48', 183, 2, 16, 417694) As against this, I am willing to put the Morley Minto reforms, the Montagu reforms and the like.
('48', 183, 2, 17, 417791) But an ever widening circle of politicians is now beginning to realize that they have been like toys given to us against heavy economic burden.
('48', 183, 2, 18, 417935) Whilst paltry concessions have been made, a few more Indians have
('48', 184, 0, 1, 418001) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 185
('48', 184, 1, 2, 418047) found employment under Government, the masses in whose name, and for whose sake, we want freedom, have had to bear greater burdens without having any return whatsoever therefor.
('48', 184, 1, 3, 418225) If we would only realize that it is not by terrorizing the foreigner that we shall gain freedom, but by ourselves shedding fear and teaching the villager to shed his own fear that we shall gain true freedom, we would at once perceive that violence is suicidal.
('48', 184, 1, 4, 418486) Then consider its reaction on ourselves.
('48', 184, 1, 5, 418527) From violence done to the foreign ruler, violence to our own people whom we may consider to be obstructing the country’s progress is an easy natural step.
('48', 184, 1, 6, 418682) Whatever may have been the result of violent activities in other countries and without reference to the philosophy of non violence, it does not require much intellectual effort to see that if we resort to violence for ridding society of the many abuses which impede our progress, we shall but add to our difficulties and postpone the day of freedom.
('48', 184, 1, 7, 419032) The people unprepared for reform because unconvinced of their necessity will be maddened with rage over their coercion, and will seek the assistance of the foreigner in order to retaliate.
('48', 184, 1, 8, 419221) Has not this been happening before our eyes for the past many years of which we have still painfully vivid recollections?
('48', 184, 1, 9, 419343) Take now the positive side of the argument.
('48', 184, 1, 10, 419387) When, that is in 1920, non violence came to be part of the Congress creed 1, the Congress became a transformed body as if by magic.
('48', 184, 1, 11, 419519) Mass awakening came no one knows how.
('48', 184, 1, 12, 419557) Even remote villages were stirred.
('48', 184, 1, 13, 419592) Manyabuses seemed to have been swept away.
('48', 184, 1, 14, 419635) The people became conscious of their power.
('48', 184, 1, 15, 419679) They ceased to fear authority.
('48', 184, 1, 16, 419710) The system of begar 2 vanished like mist in Almora and several other parts of India, wherever the people had become awakened to a sense of the power that lay within themselves.
('48', 184, 1, 17, 419887) Such as it was, it was their freedom that they had attained by their own strength.
('48', 184, 1, 18, 419970) It was true swaraj of the masses attained by the masses.
('48', 184, 1, 19, 420027) If the march of non violence had not been interrupted by events culminating in Chauri Chaura, I make bold to say that we would have been today in full possesssion of swaraj.
('48', 184, 1, 20, 420201) No one has been found to dispute this proposition.
('48', 184, 1, 21, 420252) But many have shaken their heads as they have said, ‘But you can’t teach non violence to the masses.
('48', 184, 1, 22, 420353) It is only possible for individuals and that too in rare cases.’ This is, in my opinion, a gross self deception.
('48', 184, 1, 23, 420466) If mankind was not habitually non violent, it would have been self destroyed ages ago.
('48', 184, 1, 24, 420553) But in the duel between forces of violence and non violence the latter
('48', 184, 2, 25, 420624) 1 Vide “Speech on New Congress Creed, Nagpur”, 28 12 1920. 2 Forced unpaid labour
('48', 185, 0, 1, 420706) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 185, 1, 2, 420748) have always come out victorious in the end.
('48', 185, 1, 3, 420792) The truth is that we have not had patience enough to wait and apply ourselves whole heartedly to the spread of non violence among the people as a means for political ends.
('48', 185, 1, 4, 420964) We are now entering upon a new era.
('48', 185, 1, 5, 421000) Our immediate objective and not our distant goal is complete independence.
('48', 185, 1, 6, 421075) Is it not obvious that if we are to evolve the true spirit of independence amongst the millions, we shall only do so through non violence and all it implies?
('48', 185, 1, 7, 421233) It is not enough that we drive out Englishmen by making their lives insecure through secret violence.
('48', 185, 1, 8, 421335) That would lead not to independence but to utter confusion.
('48', 185, 1, 9, 421395) We can establish independence only by adjusting our differences through an appeal to the head and the heart, by evolving organic unity amongst ourselves, not by terrorizing or killing those who, we fancy, may impede our march, but by patient and gentle handling, by converting the opponent, we want to offer mass civil disobedience.
('48', 185, 1, 10, 421728) Everybody owns that it is a certain remedy.
('48', 185, 1, 11, 421772) Everybody understands that ‘civil’ here means strictly non violent, and has it not often been demonstrated that mass civil disobedience is an impossibility without mass non violence and without mass discipline?
('48', 185, 1, 12, 421983) Surely it does not require an appeal to our religious faith to convince us that the necessity of our situation, if nothing else, demands non violence of the limited type I have indicated.
('48', 185, 1, 13, 422171) Let those who are not past reason then cease either secretly or openly to endorse activities such as this latest bomb outrage.
('48', 185, 1, 14, 422298) Rather let them openly and heartily condemn these outrages, sothat our deluded patriots may for want of nourishment to their violent spirit realize the futility of violence and the great harm that violent activity has every time done.
('48', 185, 1, 15, 422533) Young India, 2 1 1930
('48', 185, 2, 16, 422555) 182. HINDI IN THE CONGRESS
('48', 185, 3, 17, 422582) It is our strange misfortune that we are not as familiar with the name “Mahasabha” as we are with the name “Congress”.
('48', 185, 3, 18, 422701) When the name Mahasabha is mentioned some take it to mean the Hindu Mahasabha and others take it for some other organization.
('48', 185, 3, 19, 422827) During my tour of the United Provinces when I used the word Mahasabha for Congress I was told no one would recognize Mahasabha as the Congress.
('48', 185, 3, 20, 422971) This is the influence of habit.
('48', 185, 3, 21, 423003) We have got into the habit of using an English word; therefore when someone uses a Hindi word we find it difficult to understand.
('48', 185, 3, 22, 423133) Therefore, even though it is a rule that only the Hindi language
('48', 186, 0, 1, 423198) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 187
('48', 186, 1, 2, 423244) should be used in the Mahasabha, it is English that is largely used.
('48', 186, 1, 3, 423313) The Mahasabha notices are generally printed in English.
('48', 186, 1, 4, 423369) In the Mahasabha office too English is generally used.
('48', 186, 1, 5, 423424) Correspondence is carried on in English.
('48', 186, 1, 6, 423465) In the lanes of Lajpat Nagar 1 wherever one looked, one found only English signboards.
('48', 186, 1, 7, 423552) All this is lamentable.
('48', 186, 1, 8, 423576) But the remedy for this malady is not rigorous enforcement of the rules.
('48', 186, 1, 9, 423649) The remedy is love for the national language in the masses and the resultant effort.
('48', 186, 1, 10, 423734) If the public wishes, it can insist on all the business of the Mahasabha being transacted in Hindi.
('48', 186, 1, 11, 423834) The fact is, there is neither sufficient awakening nor enthusiasm nor love for their language in the masses.
('48', 186, 1, 12, 423943) There is one great practical difficulty in running the Mahasabha office in Hindi.
('48', 186, 1, 13, 424025) President Jawaharlal Nehru has drawn the attention of the members to it.
('48', 186, 1, 14, 424098) As I have already written last time, 2 in the United Provinces, Bihar and other Hindi speaking provinces there are very few people who are willing to take up this work.
('48', 186, 1, 15, 424267) Those very few who are or who can, are engaged in their own work.
('48', 186, 1, 16, 424333) Be it in the Mahasabha office or in offices elsewhere, very few Hindi speaking people are available for national work.
('48', 186, 1, 17, 424452) In these circumstances it is not surprising that the work of the Mahasabha is done mostly in English only in spite of the rule about the use of the national language.
('48', 186, 1, 18, 424619) Ten years ago all the work was done only in English.
('48', 186, 1, 19, 424672) Now there is considerable change in the desirable direction; even then, much remains to be done.
('48', 186, 1, 20, 424769) All debates and discussions in the Mahasabha should be conducted only in the national language.
('48', 186, 1, 21, 424865) And there should be no need for their English translation.
('48', 186, 1, 22, 424924) Two difficulties crop up in achieving this.
('48', 186, 1, 23, 424968) One is that, members from Bengal, Tamilnad and other such provinces understand very little Hindi and the second is that, the speaker who wants to say something wishes to explain what he means to all.
('48', 186, 1, 24, 425168) If he knows both the languages he gains his end by arguing in both of them.
('48', 186, 1, 25, 425244) To overcome these difficulties there are two ways.
('48', 186, 1, 26, 425295) One is that, when any member begins to speak in English, he and the President should be reminded of this.
('48', 186, 1, 27, 425401) Secondly, the Bengali and Tamil brothers and sisters should declare that they have no need for English.
('48', 186, 1, 28, 425505) Their duty is to learn Hindi or get the sense of the proceedings from their neighbours.
('48', 186, 1, 29, 425593) The change of heart in the Bengali, Tamil and other brethren depends entirely on the love, determination and courtesy of the Hindi speaking people.
('48', 186, 1, 30, 425741) Without courtesy no work can be done.
('48', 186, 1, 31, 425779) Force and compulsion will not secure for Hindi its rightful place.
('48', 186, 1, 32, 425846) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 2 1 1930
('48', 186, 2, 33, 425885) 1 The venue of the Congress session in Lahore 2 Vide “Letter to a Friend”, 2 2 1921.

('48', 187, 6, 14, 426608) 184. LETTER TO MOTILAL NEHRU
('48', 187, 7, 15, 426637) DELHI, January 3, 1930
('48', 187, 8, 16, 426660) DEAR MOTILALJI, In Lahore there was no time to talk or to read the newspaper or to think of anything else but the next hour’s work.
('48', 187, 8, 17, 426792) Here, in Delhi, on a cattle farm five miles away I saw the Hindustan Times and the Kelkar manifesto.
('48', 187, 8, 18, 426893) It struck me immediately that it was absolutely necessary to have from you a brief statement to show why the boycott of Legislatures is an absolute necessity.
('48', 187, 8, 19, 427052) The sooner you issue it to the Press, the better it would be.

('48', 188, 3, 4, 427588) DEAR SUBHAS BABU, You are becoming more and more an enigma to me.
('48', 188, 3, 5, 427654) I want you to live up to the certificate that Deshbandhu once gave me for you.

('48', 188, 3, 12, 428186) But in Lahore you became an obstructionist.

('48', 192, 1, 2, 433714) 191. YOUNG JUDGE
('48', 192, 2, 3, 433731) A young judge has put me the following question: 1
('48', 192, 3, 4, 433782) This question refers to the time when Gujarat was ravaged by floods and a large number of young men and other volunteers were working hard under Sardar Vallabhbhai’s guidance.
('48', 192, 3, 5, 433958) That a man reaps as he sows is an immutable principle which admits of no exception.
('48', 192, 3, 6, 434042) The above extract is an example of how the principle can be misinterpreted.
('48', 192, 3, 7, 434118) Many persons think in this way, and the question deserves consideration because I know that the correspondent has not advanced his plea merely for argument’s sake.
('48', 192, 3, 8, 434282) The maxim “Reap as you sow” is true for all times.
('48', 192, 3, 9, 434333) Holy books in Sanskrit state the same thing, and so does the Bible.
('48', 192, 3, 10, 434401) Nowhere does the maxim imply that we are to inflict on the doer what his deed deserves.
('48', 192, 3, 11, 434489) The present correspondent, however, has put such a construction on the original sentence, and that has led to a terrible misunderstanding of its meaning.
('48', 192, 3, 12, 434643) When we say ‘man reaps as he sows’, we mean that God will bestow on him his due and not that any of us might sit in God’s place and mete out justice to the doer according as he thinks of the latter’s deed.
('48', 192, 3, 13, 434849) If we had the right to judge a man’s deed and reward or punish him as the case may demand, there would be nothing left for anyone to do for anyone else.
('48', 192, 3, 14, 435002) In that case, the idea of service would lose all meaning.
('48', 192, 3, 15, 435060) If that idea should disappear, the world would perish.
('48', 192, 3, 16, 435115) But the fact is that the world has not perished.
('48', 192, 3, 17, 435164) Countless men have been rendering service to one another, correcting one another’s mistakes and even forgiving one another.
('48', 192, 3, 18, 435288) From this we see that the meaning of the great maxim in question is not what the correspondent conceives it to be, but it is what I have suggested above.
('48', 192, 3, 19, 435442) We do not fully know how to judge a man’s action.
('48', 192, 3, 20, 435492) With limited experience, we can only draw an inference about a given action.
('48', 192, 3, 21, 435569) Each one of us often draws a different inference.
('48', 192, 3, 22, 435619) The seven blind men in the fable came each to his own conclusion according to the elephant’s limb that he could feel.
('48', 192, 3, 23, 435737) Thus, though each was true in respect of his own experience of the elephant, all the seven remained ignorant and none could form a correct idea of the elephant.
('48', 192, 3, 24, 435898) Similarly, thejustice we mete out is the justice of the blind and is therefore imperfect.
('48', 192, 3, 25, 435988) Hence, it is our religious duty always to hunger after service and find fulfilment in only serving one another.
('48', 192, 3, 26, 436100) To reward or punish is God’s
('48', 192, 4, 27, 436129) 1 This is not translated here.
('48', 192, 4, 28, 436160) The correspondent had objected to relief work in Gujarat.
('48', 193, 0, 1, 436218) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 193, 1, 2, 436260) exclusive right, for He sees the past, the present and the future.
('48', 193, 1, 3, 436327) There certainly exists some sentient Power that pervades this world, to whose tunes we dance, no matter whether we call the Power God, or Lord, or describe him as a principle, or whether or not we apply any epithet to it.
('48', 193, 1, 4, 436549) That Power alone rewards or punishes us as our actions might deserve.
('48', 193, 1, 5, 436619) In any case, we are not the Power; and so, instead of saying ‘Let us give a man what he deserves’, we say ‘A man gets what he deserves.’ It was from the realization of man’s imperfection that there arose the family of virtues, such as service, generosity, love, forgiveness and non violence.
('48', 193, 1, 6, 436911) We do not, therefore, know whether the calamity suffered by Gujarat was the result of people’s sin or goodness in this life or another.
('48', 193, 1, 7, 437047) But certainly, those who participated in the alleviation of the suffering have done their duty and found self fulfilment to the extent they did so.
('48', 193, 1, 8, 437195) If they had put a wrong construction on the law of karma and kept to their homes with hands folded, they should have shown themselves ignorant of duty.
('48', 193, 1, 9, 437347) I hope the correspondent will now see that his statement was not merely one sided, but was entirely mistaken, and will take care not to commit such a mistake again.
('48', 193, 1, 10, 437512) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 5 1 1930

('48', 200, 6, 20, 449173) 203. STATEMENT TO “ THE NEW YORK WORLD”
('48', 200, 7, 21, 449213) [Before January 9, 1930] 3
('48', 200, 8, 22, 449240) The world should realize that as Congressional representatives, Pandit Motilal Nehru, leader of the Nationalists in the Legislative Assembly, and I could only treat the Viceregal pronouncement about Dominion Status in India as a response to the Calcutta Congress resolution of 1928. 4 We were bound, therefore, in pursuance of that resolution to press for a clear declaration that the proposed Round Table Conference would consider only ways and means of framing a scheme for a Dominion Status constitution and no other.
('48', 200, 8, 23, 449761) This the Viceroy, Lord Irwin, could not do.
('48', 200, 8, 24, 449805) While, therefore, we appreciated his good efforts and his difficulties, we had no course left open but to decline to have Congress represented at the proposed Conference.
('48', 200, 9, 25, 449976) 1 From the contents it appears this letter was written before the one to the addressee dated January 9, 1930; vide “Letter to G. D. Birla”, 9 1 1930. 2 Maganlal Gandhi’s son, Keshav 3 The statement was published in The New York World, 9 1 1930. 4 Vide “Speech on Resolution on Nehru Report, Calcutta Congress”, 28 12 1928.
('48', 201, 0, 1, 450299) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 201, 1, 2, 450341) Conference, so far as Congress was concerned, having miscarried, the independence resolution 1 need frighten nobody.
('48', 201, 1, 3, 450458) I had repeatedly declared that for me, as for all other Congressmen, Dominion Status could mean only virtual independence; that is partnership at will for mutual benefit and to be dissolved at the instance of either partner.
('48', 201, 1, 4, 450683) It only clears the issue, especially after Secretary of State for India, Wedgwood Benn’s unfortunate statement that India already had a Dominion Status in action.
('48', 201, 1, 5, 450846) The real cause for satisfaction to lovers of peace consists in the fact that through the full debate Congress supported methods of non violence and truth, to the exclusion of other methods.
('48', 201, 1, 6, 451036) Civildisobedience is a dynamic expression of non violence.
('48', 201, 1, 7, 451095) It is undoubtedly fraught with great danger and difficulties, but infinitely less so than the present danger of unbridled but secret violence breaking out in many parts of India, owing to understandable and pardonable impatience on the part of many youths.
('48', 201, 1, 8, 451352) Responsibility for initiating civil disobedience rests on me and I am not likely rashly to embark upon it.
('48', 201, 1, 9, 451459) At the same time I must confess that I shall not hesitate to run a certain minimum of risk which is inevitable in any struggle for freedom.
('48', 201, 1, 10, 451599) The risk for prolonging the present agony caused by the realized slavery here is any day much greater than I am ever likely to run.
('48', 201, 1, 11, 451731) The boycott of legislatures is also part of the programme for enforcing the national demand.
('48', 201, 1, 12, 451824) This was a natural corollary to the independence resolution, and I am glad to say it is finding an adequate response from Congressmen.
('48', 201, 1, 13, 451959) A constructive programme such as removal of untouchability, communal union, liquor prohibition, and the boycott of foreign cloth remains.
('48', 201, 1, 14, 452097) These have tremendous social and economic value and also bear great political consequences.
('48', 201, 1, 15, 452189) The Nehru constitution, with its tentative communal solution, naturally lapses.
('48', 201, 1, 16, 452269) Congress, therefore, will concentrate on solving the communal question, not on differential lines, but on strictly national lines.
('48', 201, 1, 17, 452400) There was also a resolution on financial obligations.
('48', 201, 1, 18, 452454) 2 It need not disturb any foreigner who has a legitimate interest in India.
('48', 201, 1, 19, 452530) It should be remembered that there are always, under any foreign Government, obligations incurred and concessions granted that are in no way in the interest of the country concerned, and are indeed often hostile to it.
('48', 201, 1, 20, 452749) These can never be acknowledged by successors who are free to examine every such obligation and concession.
('48', 201, 1, 21, 452857) Congress has offered
('48', 201, 2, 22, 452878) 1 Vide “Speech at Congress Session, Lahore II”, 31 12 1929. 2 Vide “Speech at Subjects Committee, A.I.C.C. II”, 1 1 1930.
('48', 202, 0, 1, 453000) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 203
('48', 202, 1, 2, 453046) investigation of these by an independent tribunal.
('48', 202, 1, 3, 453097) Lastly, the door against a conference purposely convened to satisfy national aspirations, that is, to frame a scheme of independence has been left open.

('48', 202, 2, 5, 453271) 204. NOTES
('48', 202, 3, 6, 453282) THE LATE MAZHAR UL HAQ
('48', 202, 4, 7, 453305) Mazhar ul Haq was a great patriot, a good Mussalman and a philosopher.
('48', 202, 4, 8, 453376) Fond of ease and luxury, when Non co operation came he threw them off as we throw superfluous scales off the skin.
('48', 202, 4, 9, 453491) He grew as fond of the ascetic life as he was of princely life.
('48', 202, 4, 10, 453555) Growing weary of our dissentions, he lived in retirement, doing such unseen services as he could, and praying for the best.
('48', 202, 4, 11, 453679) He was fearless both in speech and action.
('48', 202, 4, 12, 453722) The Sadakat Ashram near Patna is a fruit of his constructive labours.
('48', 202, 4, 13, 453792) Though he did not live in it for long as he had intended, his conception of the Ashram made it possible for the Bihar Vidyapith to find a permanent habitation.
('48', 202, 4, 14, 453952) It may yet prove a cement to bind the two communities together.
('48', 202, 4, 15, 454016) Such a man would be missed at all times; he will be the more missed at this juncture in the history of the country.
('48', 202, 4, 16, 454132) I tender my condolences to Begum Mazhar ul Haq and her family.
('48', 202, 5, 17, 454195) PROHIBITION CAMPAIGN
('48', 202, 6, 18, 454216) At the Temperance Conference in Lahore one of the resolutions adopted was as follows: 1
('48', 202, 7, 19, 454304) It is a matter for sorrow that in a country like India, where drink is almost universally admitted to be a vice, there are respectable newspapers enough to be found to take advertisements for the sake of spirituous liquor whilst their editorial columns favour total prohibition.
('48', 202, 7, 20, 454583) I hope that the resolution of the Conference will move the newspapers concerned to stop taking the offending advertisements.
('48', 202, 7, 21, 454708) There may be the question of contracts made with advertisers.
('48', 202, 7, 22, 454770) Since the proprietors of the newspapers concerned have wronged the nation in taking the advertisements, it is not too much to expect them to part with a portion of the ill gotten profits in paying for such damages as may be necessary for ending contracts before their times.

('48', 203, 0, 1, 455207) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 203, 1, 2, 455249) 205. THE CONGRESS
('48', 203, 2, 3, 455267) PRESIDENT
('48', 203, 3, 4, 455277) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru more than justified the choice of the people.
('48', 203, 3, 5, 455347) His address brief and to the point was bold, extreme in conception but moderate in expression.
('48', 203, 3, 6, 455442) It bore evidence of a man capable of viewing things with complete detachment.
('48', 203, 3, 7, 455520) A confirmed socialist, he wants for his country only what the country can manage.
('48', 203, 3, 8, 455602) He is a practical statesman tempering his ideals to suit his surroundings: But for himself he is an idealist who would ever strive to live up to his ideals.
('48', 203, 3, 9, 455759) As in his address, so in the chair.
('48', 203, 3, 10, 455795) He was strong, yet accommodating.
('48', 203, 3, 11, 455829) His wit came to his rescue on many an awkward occasion.
('48', 203, 3, 12, 455885) He never hesitated when action was required.
('48', 203, 3, 13, 455930) His tireless energy and entire self forgetfulness, his natural simplicity and affability captivated everyone.
('48', 203, 3, 14, 456040) No Government that is at all anxious to do what is right can have any reason to fear Jawaharlal Nehru.
('48', 203, 3, 15, 456143) A wicked Government would soon feel the strength of a stalwart who counts no price too dear to pay for ridding the country of wicked rule.
('48', 203, 3, 16, 456282) The youth of the country has every reason to be proud of their representative, the nation may well rejoice to find in Jawaharlal Nehru such a noble and worthy son.
('48', 203, 3, 17, 456446) May God’s blessings descend upon him and may the nation reach her destination during Jawaharlal’s year of service.
('48', 203, 4, 18, 456561) INDEPENDENCE
('48', 203, 5, 19, 456574) The resolutions 1 of the Congress strictly followed the trend of the Presidential address.
('48', 203, 5, 20, 456665) Let us first consider the central resolution 2. In strict accordance with the Calcutta resolution 3 and owing to a combination of circumstances undesigned by anybody, Dominion Status gave place at the stroke of midnight 31st December 1929 to complete independence as the immediate objective of the Congress.
('48', 203, 5, 21, 456973) Swaraj in article 1 of the Congress constitution is now to mean complete independence.
('48', 203, 5, 22, 457060) It is as well.
('48', 203, 5, 23, 457075) Apart from the Calcutta resolution, Mr. Benn’s statement that India already had
('48', 203, 6, 24, 457155) 1 Vide “Draft Resolutions for A.I.C.C., Lahore”, 26 12 1929. 2 Vide “Speech at Congress Session, Lahore II”, 31 12 1929. 3 Vide “Speech on Resolution on Nehru Report, Calcutta Congress II”, 28 12 1928.
('48', 204, 0, 1, 457357) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 205
('48', 204, 1, 2, 457403) DominionStatus in action made that phrase impossible of acceptance to convey the nation’s meaning.
('48', 204, 1, 3, 457502) If representation, at important functions, of India through representatives chosen by the British Government, means Dominion Status in action, Heaven help India.
('48', 204, 1, 4, 457664) The Congress means something totally different from it.
('48', 204, 1, 5, 457720) For the Congress, Dominion Status meant complete independence plus voluntary partnership with Britain as it might be with any other nation for mutual good.
('48', 204, 1, 6, 457876) Lastly it has been of late loudly whispered that independence was illegal, and a resolution replacing Dominion Status with independence would mean the death of the Congress.
('48', 204, 1, 7, 458050) This threat made it a sacred obligation for the Congress to incorporate complete independence in the Congress creed.
('48', 204, 1, 8, 458167) The Congress would not be worthy to represent the nation if, for fear of consequences, it hesitated to enunciate the nation’s birthright.
('48', 204, 1, 9, 458305) If swaraj was a doubtful word, it becomes unequivocal by becoming purna swaraj.
('48', 204, 2, 10, 458385) ‘PEACEFUL AND LEGITIMATE’
('48', 204, 3, 11, 458411) But the Congress rejected by an overwhelming majority any change in the description of the means.
('48', 204, 3, 12, 458509) They still remain ‘peaceful and legitimate’.
('48', 204, 3, 13, 458554) There were members in the Subjects Committee who suggested that independence would not be vindicated by non violent and truthful means.
('48', 204, 3, 14, 458690) Violence there undoubtedly was in the air.
('48', 204, 3, 15, 458733) But I feel that those who flock to the Congress session year by year have a living faith in non violence as the only possible means for India at least to regain her lost freedom.
('48', 204, 3, 16, 458912) Non violence and truth are the vital need for India if the stupor of the millions is to be removed, if the warring communities are to be welded into one.
('48', 204, 3, 17, 459066) A foreign power must be a necessary factor for any community that will coerce any other or the others into submission to its will.
('48', 204, 3, 18, 459197) But the Congress must perforce remain non violent if it will represent, as it claims to represent, all communities.
('48', 204, 3, 19, 459313) Whether therefore it takes a year or ages to reach political independence, non violence and truth are in my opinion the shortest way to it.
('48', 204, 3, 20, 459453) Complete independence of the Congress is no menace to a single legitimate foreign interest or the presence of a single Englishman who will live as a friend willing to submit to the rules applicable to the whole of independent India.
('48', 204, 3, 21, 459686) This is clear from the condemnation of the bomb resolution and the clause in the central resolution appreciating the efforts of the Viceroy to arrive at a peaceful solution of the national problem.
('48', 204, 3, 22, 459884) Both the bomb resolution and the clause were hotly contested, but the Congress accepted both, the one by a substantial majority ascertainedafter a division and the second by an overwhelming majority.
('48', 204, 3, 23, 460084) I am sure that by passing the resolution and the clause the
('48', 205, 0, 1, 460144) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 205, 1, 2, 460186) nation has conformed to its creed, and risen in the estimation of the world, as it would have denied its creed and lost in the world’s estimation if it had refused to condemn the bomb outrage and perform the common courtesy of recognizing the good even in a representative of a rule which we seek to destroy.
('48', 205, 2, 3, 460495) BOYCOTT OF LEGISLATURES
('48', 205, 3, 4, 460519) To the constructive programme the Congress has added boycott of legislatures.
('48', 205, 3, 5, 460597) This was in my opinion inevitable.
('48', 205, 3, 6, 460632) Those who would have independence have to work outside the legislatures and among the people.
('48', 205, 3, 7, 460726) That no single seat will remain vacant because of Congressmen withdrawing from the legislatures is no reason for opposing the boycott.
('48', 205, 3, 8, 460861) Let those who believe in the legislatures by all means go there.
('48', 205, 3, 9, 460926) It is enough that Congressmen employ themselves otherwise and cease to give those bodies any prestige through their presence there.
('48', 205, 3, 10, 461058) For me the decisive opinion of Pandit Motilalji in favour of boycott was enough to incorporate it in the resolution.
('48', 205, 3, 11, 461175) The programme would have been undoubtedly strengthened if law courts and Government schools were also boycotted.
('48', 205, 3, 12, 461288) But the atmosphere was absent.
('48', 205, 3, 13, 461319) The Congress is not an organization to enunciate theories, but to anticipate national wants and wishes, and forge practical sanctions for their fulfilment.
('48', 205, 3, 14, 461475) Local bodies stand on a different footing.
('48', 205, 3, 15, 461518) They were included in the original draft.
('48', 205, 3, 16, 461560) But as opinion was sharply divided, I did not press for their retention in the boycott clause.
('48', 205, 3, 17, 461655) Let no one however run away with the idea that it is now any Congressman’s duty to seek election to or capture these institutions.
('48', 205, 3, 18, 461786) On the contrary it is the duty of every Congressman to retire from or avoid them, if they take away best workers’ attention from better work or if they mean continuous wrangling, dissensions or worse.
('48', 205, 3, 19, 461987) They are at liberty to remain in them or seek election thereto when they are convinced that by their presence there, they can promote not merely some legitimate interest but national independence.
('48', 205, 4, 20, 462184) CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('48', 205, 5, 21, 462203) The greatest and the most effective sanction however is civil disobedience including non payment of taxes.
('48', 205, 5, 22, 462310) Whilst the task of choosing the time and the method of it has been nominally and properly left to the All India Congress Committee to decide, I know that it is a duty primarily devolving upon me.
('48', 205, 5, 23, 462506) I must confess that I donot see the atmosphere for it today.
('48', 205, 5, 24, 462567) I want to discover a formula whereby sufficient provision can be made for avoiding suspension by reason of Chauri Chaura.
('48', 205, 5, 25, 462689) A time must come when there my be a fight
('48', 206, 0, 1, 462731) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 207
('48', 206, 1, 2, 462777) to the finish with one’s back to the wall.
('48', 206, 1, 3, 462820) With the present temper of many Congressmen, with our internal dissensions, with the communal tension, it is difficult to discover an effective and innocent formula.
('48', 206, 1, 4, 462986) It may be impossible to offer civil disobedience at this stage in the name of the Congress, and it may be necessary to offer individual civil disobedience without the Congress imprimatur and apart from it.
('48', 206, 1, 5, 463192) But just now every thing is in the embryonic state.
('48', 206, 1, 6, 463244) I can only give the impatient patriot the assurance, that I am concentrating all my powers on discovering a workable formula.
('48', 206, 1, 7, 463370) He can help me materially by assisting to promote a non violent atmosphere and to push forward the constructive programme.
('48', 206, 1, 8, 463493) I know that many have refused to see any connection between the constructive programme and civil disobedience.
('48', 206, 1, 9, 463604) But for one who believes in non violence it does not need hard thinking to realize the essential connection between the constructive programme and civil disobedience for swaraj.
('48', 206, 1, 10, 463782) I want the reader to mark the qualification.
('48', 206, 1, 11, 463827) Constructive programme is not essential for local civil disobedience for specific relief as in the case of Bardoli.
('48', 206, 1, 12, 463943) Tangible common grievance restricted to a particular locality is enough.
('48', 206, 1, 13, 464016) But for such an indefinable thing as swaraj people must have previous training in doing things of all India interest.
('48', 206, 1, 14, 464134) Such work must throw together the people and their leaders whom they would trust implicitly.
('48', 206, 1, 15, 464227) Trust begotten in the pursuit of continuous constructive work becomes a tremendous asset at the critical moment.
('48', 206, 1, 16, 464340) Constructive work therefore is for a non violent army what drilling, etc., is for an army designed for bloody warfare.
('48', 206, 1, 17, 464459) Individual civil disobedience among an unprepared people and by leaders not known to or trusted by them is of no avail, and mass civil disobedience is an impossibility.
('48', 206, 1, 18, 464628) The more therefore the progress of the constructive programme, the greater is there the chance for civil disobedience.
('48', 206, 1, 19, 464747) Granted a perfectly non violent atmosphere and a fulfilled constructive programme, I would undertake to lead a mass civil disobedience struggle to a successful issue in the space of a few months.
('48', 206, 2, 20, 464943) ‘IN THE EXISTING CIRCUMSTANCES’
('48', 206, 3, 21, 464975) Whilst thus the central resolution lays down the country’s objective and the methods for its attainment in no uncertain terms, it does not rule out the idea of a conference in every circumstance.
('48', 206, 3, 22, 465171) It merely and most properly says, that ‘in the existing circumstances’ no good purpose can be served by the Congress being representedat the proposed Conference.
('48', 206, 3, 23, 465333) What are then the conceivable circumstances in which the Congress may be represented at such a conference?
('48', 206, 3, 24, 465440) I can mention at least one such circumstance.
('48', 207, 0, 1, 465486) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 207, 1, 2, 465528) British Government invites the Congress to a conference, that is to discuss and frame not any scheme but a scheme definitely of independence Government, and fulfils the other conditions suitable for such a conference, I take it that the Congress leaders will gladly respond.
('48', 207, 1, 3, 465803) Indeed a conference there must be at some stage or other.
('48', 207, 1, 4, 465861) It can take place as the proposed Conference was expected to take place out of Britain’s good grace our land pressure of world opinion, or out of pressure from us as we hope it will be if we develop sufficient strength.
('48', 207, 1, 5, 466081) Whether such a time is to be far or near depends upon how we utilize or waste this year of grace.
('48', 207, 2, 6, 466179) OUR FINANCIAL OBLIGATIONS
('48', 207, 3, 7, 466205) Next in importance and almost part of the central resolution must be deemed the one dealing with our financial obligations.
('48', 207, 3, 8, 466329) 1 Everyone who knows anything of public finance knows how extravagant this Government is and how heavy is the load of debts that is crushing the nation.
('48', 207, 3, 9, 466482) Everyone knows also what concessions have been given to foreigners in utter disregard of the national interest.
('48', 207, 3, 10, 466594) These cannot demand, dare not expect recognition from independent India under the much abused name of vested interests.
('48', 207, 3, 11, 466714) All vested interests are not entitled to protection.
('48', 207, 3, 12, 466767) The keeper of a gambling den or of a brothel has no vested interest.
('48', 207, 3, 13, 466836) Nor has a corporation that gambles away the fortunes of a nation and reduces it to impotence.
('48', 207, 3, 14, 466930) The Congress at Gaya 2 therefore passed a comprehensive resolution repudiating certain debts.
('48', 207, 3, 15, 467024) The last, whilst reaffirming the Gaya resolution, laid down that obligations or concessions pronounced to be unjust and unjustifiable by an independent tribunal shall not be recognized by the independence Government to come.
('48', 207, 3, 16, 467249) No exception can, in my opinion, be possibly taken against such a reasonable proposition.
('48', 207, 3, 17, 467339) To shirk the issue is to invite disaster.
('48', 207, 4, 18, 467381) COMMUNAL QUESTION
('48', 207, 5, 19, 467399) Equally important is the communal resolution 3. Though it was adopted for the sake of the Sikhs, it was necessary other wise too toenunciate the principles underlying it.
('48', 207, 5, 20, 467570) Independent India cannot afford to have communal representation, and yet it must placate all communities if the rule of independence is not based on coercion of minorities.
('48', 207, 5, 21, 467743) But the Congress has now to cultivate a spirit of common nationality and refuse to resort to camouflage or expedience in a matter so vital as the communal question.
('48', 207, 5, 22, 467908) In the Congress we must
('48', 207, 6, 23, 467932) 1 Vide “Speech at Subjects Committee, A.I.C.C. II”, 1 1 1930. 2 In 1922 3 Vide “Speech at Subjects Committee, A.I.C.C. III”, 1 1 1930.
('48', 208, 0, 1, 468067) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 209
('48', 208, 1, 2, 468113) cease to be exclusive Hindus or Mussalmans or Sikhs, Parsis, Christians, Jews.
('48', 208, 1, 3, 468192) Whilst we may staunchly adhere to our respective faiths, we must be in the Congress Indians first and Indians last.
('48', 208, 1, 4, 468308) A good Hindu or a good Mussalman should be a better Hindu or a better Mussalman for being a lover of his country.
('48', 208, 1, 5, 468422) There never can be any conflict between the real interest of one’s country and that of one’s religion.
('48', 208, 1, 6, 468525) Where there appears to be any, there is something wrong with one’s religion, i.e., one’s morals.
('48', 208, 1, 7, 468622) True religion means good thought and good conduct.
('48', 208, 1, 8, 468673) True patriotism also means good thought and good conduct.
('48', 208, 1, 9, 468731) To set up a comparison between two synonymous things is wrong.
('48', 208, 1, 10, 468794) But if the Congress is ever forced to consider a solution based on communalism, the resolution binds it to reject any that does not satisfy the parties concerned.
('48', 208, 1, 11, 468957) In order however that the Congress may never be faced with a situation demanding a communal solution, it should now be joined in large numbers by Mussalmans, Sikhs and others who will have India as one indivisible nation.
('48', 208, 1, 12, 469179) I for one would welcome the Congress passing into Mussalman, Sikh, Parsi, Christian, Jewish hands rather than that it should be in any sense a sectional organization.
('48', 208, 1, 13, 469346) Anyone who has the spirit of service in him can capture the Congress.
('48', 208, 1, 14, 469416) It has the most democratic franchise.
('48', 208, 1, 15, 469454) Its doors are ever open to those who would serve.
('48', 208, 1, 16, 469504) Let all join it and make it a mighty instrument for gaining complete independence for the poorest, the weakest and the most downtrodden.
('48', 208, 1, 17, 469641) I must defer the consideration of other resolutions and the other matters relating to this remarkable Congress to a future issue 1, if not the next.
('48', 208, 1, 18, 469790) Young India, 9 1 1930

('48', 209, 0, 1, 470316) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 209, 1, 2, 470358) 207. JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('48', 209, 2, 3, 470380) Jawaharlal 1 Nehru has proved to be a jewel of India.
('48', 209, 2, 4, 470434) In his address lofty thoughts are couched in sweet and courteous language.
('48', 209, 2, 5, 470509) Several topics have been dealt with thoroughly and yet the address is short.
('48', 209, 2, 6, 470586) The splendour of the soul shines in every sentence.
('48', 209, 2, 7, 470638) The apprehension that lurked in many hearts disappeared after the oration.
('48', 209, 2, 8, 470713) As was the address, so was his deportment.
('48', 209, 2, 9, 470756) During the Congress session he did all his work independently and impartially.
('48', 209, 2, 10, 470835) And since he worked incessantly and strenuously everything was completed on time and without any hitch.
('48', 209, 2, 11, 470939) If under the Presidentship of such a brave and righteous young man we can achieve nothing it will greatly surprise me.
('48', 209, 2, 12, 471058) But if the ranks are unworthy, what can the brave captain do?
('48', 209, 2, 13, 471120) Therefore, we should do some introspection.
('48', 209, 2, 14, 471164) Are we fit to be under the leadership of Jawaharlal Nehru?
('48', 209, 2, 15, 471223) If we are, then the outcome must be propitious.
('48', 209, 2, 16, 471271) Liberty cannot be secured merely by proclaiming it.
('48', 209, 2, 17, 471323) An atmosphere of liberty must be created within us.
('48', 209, 2, 18, 471375) Liberty is one thing, and licence another.
('48', 209, 2, 19, 471418) Many a time we confuse licence for liberty and lose the latter.
('48', 209, 2, 20, 471482) Licence leads one to selfishness whereas liberty guides one to supreme good.
('48', 209, 2, 21, 471559) Licence destroys society, liberty gives it life.
('48', 209, 2, 22, 471608) In licence propriety is sacrificed; in liberty it is fully cherished.
('48', 209, 2, 23, 471678) Under slavery we practise several virtues out of fear; when liberated we practise them ofour own free will.A slave will not steal out of fear, will not quarrel with anyone, will not lie and will appear honest.
('48', 209, 2, 24, 471888) He will be protected from dacoits and others by his master.
('48', 209, 2, 25, 471948) A slave does not exercise his free will in whatever he does.
('48', 209, 2, 26, 472009) A free man’s thoughts and actions are identical.
('48', 209, 2, 27, 472058) Whether for good or for evil he acts of his own free will.
('48', 209, 2, 28, 472117) Therefore, a free man reaps the full benefits of his good actions, and when this happens society progresses from day to day.
('48', 209, 2, 29, 472242) A free man will not fail in his duty of protecting others.
('48', 209, 2, 30, 472301) Therefore, if we have understood true freedom, we will shed communal fear.
('48', 209, 2, 31, 472376) Hindus and Muslims will cease to fear one another.
('48', 209, 2, 32, 472427) If both could shed fear at the same time all the better; but a free spirit should not expect the help of others to cast off fear.
('48', 209, 2, 33, 472557) If the other side violates justice, even then he would not seek the help of a third party.
('48', 209, 2, 34, 472648) He will depend only on his own strength, and if he loses, he will try to augment his own strength.
('48', 209, 2, 35, 472747) To die fighting is itself victory, it is one’s duty.
('48', 209, 2, 36, 472800) To run away from the fight is slavery and humiliation.
('48', 209, 2, 37, 472855) Real freedom is impossible without the spirit of a true Kshatriya.
('48', 209, 2, 38, 472922) Therefore,
('48', 209, 3, 39, 472933) 1 Literally, ‘jawahar’ means jewel
('48', 210, 0, 1, 472968) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 211
('48', 210, 1, 2, 473014) the unique quality of a Kshatriya is considered to be his determination never to shrink from a battle.
('48', 210, 1, 3, 473117) For this reason we too, in everything we do, must never run away from the battlefield.
('48', 210, 1, 4, 473204) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 9 1 1930

('48', 213, 0, 1, 478131) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 213, 1, 2, 478173) 212. DRAFT DECLARATION FOR JANUARY 26 1
('48', 213, 2, 3, 478213) [ January 10, 1930] 2
('48', 213, 3, 4, 478235) We believe that it is the inalienable right of the Indian people, as of any other people, to have freedom and to enjoy the fruits of their toil and have the necessities of life, so that they may have full opportunities of growth.
('48', 213, 3, 5, 478465) We believe also that if any government deprives a people of these rights and oppresses them, the people have a further right to alter it or to abolish it.
('48', 213, 3, 6, 478620) The British Government in India has not only deprived the Indian people of their freedom but has based itself on the exploitation of the masses, and has ruined India economically, politically, culturally and spiritually.
('48', 213, 3, 7, 478841) We believe therefore that India must sever the British connection and attain purna swaraj or complete independence.
('48', 213, 3, 8, 478957) India has been ruined economically.
('48', 213, 3, 9, 478993) The revenue derived from our people is out of all proportion to our income.
('48', 213, 3, 10, 479069) Our average income is seven pice (less than 2 pence) per day.
('48', 213, 3, 11, 479131) The taxes we pay are 2.5 pies per day and of these the land revenue derived from the peasantry is 20% and the salt tax, which falls heaviest on the poor, is 3% of the total.
('48', 213, 3, 12, 479305) Village industries, such as hand spinning, have been destroyed, leaving the peasantry idle for at least four months in the year, and dulling their intellect for want of handicrafts, and nothing has been substituted, as in other countries, for the crafts thus destroyed.
('48', 213, 3, 13, 479575) Customs and currency have been so manipulated as to heap further burdens on the peasantry.
('48', 213, 3, 14, 479666) British manufactured goods constitute the bulk of our imports and customs revenue from these, which ought to have been used to lessen the burden of taxation on the masses, is 44 times lighter in India than it is in Russia and 44 3 times and 24 4 times, respectively, less heavy than it is in the United Statesof America and Germany.
('48', 213, 3, 15, 479999) The arbitrary manipulation of the exchange ratio has resulted in millions being drained away from the country.
('48', 213, 4, 16, 480110) Politically, India’s status has never been so reduced as under the British regime.
('48', 213, 4, 17, 480193) All administrative talent is killed and the masses have
('48', 213, 5, 18, 480249) 1 For the final declaration, vide “Things to Remember for 26th”, 23 1 1930. 2 Vide the preceding item.
('48', 213, 5, 19, 480352) 3 For the correction of these figures, vide “Telegram to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 16 1 1930. 4 ibid 5 All the figures quoted in this paragraph relate to the year 1904. For the changes made by Gandhiji, vide “Telegram to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 17 1 1930.
('48', 214, 0, 1, 480596) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 215
('48', 214, 1, 2, 480642) to be satisfied with petty village offices and clerkships.
('48', 214, 1, 3, 480701) The tallest of us have to bend before foreign authority.
('48', 214, 1, 4, 480758) No reform has given real political power to the people.
('48', 214, 1, 5, 480814) Culturally, the system of education has torn us from our moorings and our training has made us hug the very chains that bind us.
('48', 214, 1, 6, 480943) Spiritually, compulsory disarmament has made us unmanly and the presence of an alien army of occupation, employed with deadly effect to crush in us the spirit of resistance, has made us think that we cannot look after ourselves or put up a defence against foreign aggression, or even defend our homes and families from the attacks of thieves, robbers and miscreants.
('48', 214, 1, 7, 481310) We hold it to be a crime against men and God to submit any longer to a rule that has caused this fourfold disaster to our country.
('48', 214, 1, 8, 481441) We recognize, however, that the most effective way of gaining our freedom is not through violence.
('48', 214, 1, 9, 481540) We will therefore prepare ourselves by withdrawing, so far as we can, all voluntary association from the British Government, and will prepare for civil disobedience, including non payment of taxes.
('48', 214, 1, 10, 481738) We are convinced that if we can but withdraw our voluntary help and stop payment of taxes without doing violence, even under provocation, the end of this inhuman rule is assured.
('48', 214, 1, 11, 481917) We therefore hereby solemnly resolve to carry out the Congress instructions, issued from time to time for the purpose of establishing purna swaraj.

('48', 216, 12, 16, 484454) 218. SPEECH AT GUJARAT VIDYAPITH CONVOCATION January 11, 1930 2
('48', 216, 13, 17, 484518) Narendra Dev just told you, “You are eager to serve the nation.

('48', 219, 4, 16, 491898) As in the past, so in the present also a person wanting to found a village would first look for water.
('48', 219, 4, 17, 492001) If there exists no proper facility to obtain water or it is not possible to create it, he would give up all thought of founding a village at the place.
('48', 219, 4, 18, 492153) In South India we come across dry, though otherwise beautiful, regions where no villages can be founded for want of water.
('48', 219, 4, 19, 492276) Man’s first elementary need is air, for which one does not have to go in search.
('48', 219, 4, 20, 492357) The next is water.
('48', 219, 4, 21, 492376) Though it cannot be obtained as easily as we get air, the getting of water does not involve the amount of labour needed for producing grain.
('48', 219, 4, 22, 492517) However, the water we use has to be as clean as the air or food we take in.
('48', 219, 4, 23, 492593) We all know that the villagers are ignorant of this requirement, or are indifferent to it though they know it.

('48', 220, 1, 2, 493255) and means of keeping the water clean.
('48', 220, 1, 3, 493293) Slowly we should teach the villagers the advantages of keeping water clean and the rules to be observed for doing so.
('48', 220, 1, 4, 493411) We should also get their assistance in this work.
('48', 220, 1, 5, 493461) In several places, it happens that none of the inhabitants comes forward to help though the work is for their own benefit.
('48', 220, 1, 6, 493584) In such circumstances, the only way open to the sevak is to work hard by himself and, by doing single handed as much as he can, to induce in the villagers a feeling of shame for their unhelpful behaviour.
('48', 220, 1, 7, 493789) Let us now go a little into the details of what we might do.
('48', 220, 1, 8, 493850) Many of the villages have only one pond, where the cattle drink and people bathe or wash, cleanse utensils and wash clothes, and people fetch the water for drinking and cooking from the same pond.
('48', 220, 1, 9, 494047) Experts on hygiene have demonstrated through numerous experiments how poisonous germs are born in such water and diseases like choleraresult from drinking it.
('48', 220, 1, 10, 494206) With a little care, it is possible to keep such ponds clean.
('48', 220, 1, 11, 494267) The village pond should be enclosed so that no cattle can approach it.
('48', 220, 1, 12, 494338) Of course there should be a provision for them to drink water.
('48', 220, 1, 13, 494401) For that purpose there should be built a separate drinking trough near the pond as we find done near many of the wells.
('48', 220, 1, 14, 494521) If everyone in the village makes it a point every day to fetch and add to it a potful of water from the pond, the daily requirement of the cattle would be met without much difficulty.
('48', 220, 1, 15, 494705) Never should utensils be cleansed or clothes washed in a pond from which drinking water is drawn.
('48', 220, 1, 16, 494803) There are two ways to ensure this.
('48', 220, 1, 17, 494838) Everyone should do the washing at home with the water fetched for domestic use.
('48', 220, 1, 18, 494918) The other way is to have a water tank just near the pond.
('48', 220, 1, 19, 494976) Everyone should fetch and put into the tank his share of the water needed for this kind of work.
('48', 220, 1, 20, 495073) Then the tank water may be used for washing and cleansing by the village population.
('48', 220, 1, 21, 495158) This would be possible only if there exists among the villagers a spirit of co operation and mutual service.
('48', 220, 1, 22, 495267) If it is not feasible to get the tank and the drinking trough filled through personal labour in the way I have described, this could be done by incurring a little expense on that account.
('48', 220, 1, 23, 495455) As water is bound to get spilt and spread at a washing place, the immediate open space around should be paved so that no mud gets formed there.
('48', 220, 1, 24, 495599) Before any utensil is dipped into the pond of drinking water, it ought to have been cleansed outside the pond.
('48', 220, 1, 25, 495710) Moreover, there should be an arrangement so that the feet of the person fetching water do not have to wade through any part of the pond.
('48', 220, 1, 26, 495847) This is about the villages that have one pond only.
('48', 220, 1, 27, 495899) In some villages there are, or it is possible to have, more than one pond.
('48', 220, 1, 28, 495974) At such a place the pond for drinking water should be set apart for the purpose.

('48', 224, 8, 12, 501190) 227. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA NATIONAL EDUCATIONAL CONFERENCE, AHMEDABAD 2
('48', 224, 9, 13, 501260) January 13, 1930 3
('48', 224, 10, 14, 501279) The Vidyapith owes its origin to the non co operation movement, and, as I said some years ago, the object of the Vidyapith is the attainment of swaraj.
('48', 224, 10, 15, 501431) All those studying in national educational institutions and connected with them must do all the thingsthat the country has to do, and must go through the same discipline as the country has to go through for the attainment of swaraj, so that they may be ready to offer themselves willing sacrifices when the time comes.
('48', 224, 10, 16, 501750) Ours is a movement of self purification.
('48', 224, 10, 17, 501791) There are some who think that morality has nothing to do with politics.
('48', 224, 10, 18, 501863) We do not concern ourselves with the character of our leaders.
('48', 224, 10, 19, 501926) The democracies of Europe and America steer clear of any notion of morality having anything to do with politics.
('48', 224, 10, 20, 502039) Bad characters are often great intellects, and they can manage certain affairs well enough by the force of their intellect.
('48', 224, 10, 21, 502163) The private character of some of the leading men of the House of Commons will not bear examination.
('48', 224, 10, 22, 502263) We too have often
('48', 224, 11, 23, 502281) 1 Vide “Draft Declaration for january 26”, 10 1 1930. 2 Published in Young India, 23 1 1930, under the caption “Not a Policy But Creed” 3 From The Bombay Chronicle, 14 1 1930
('48', 225, 0, 1, 502456) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 225, 1, 2, 502498) carried on our political movement in the same fashion, we did not concern ourselves with the morals of the Congress delegates or leaders.
('48', 225, 1, 3, 502636) But in 1920 we struck an entirely new departure and we declared that since truth and non violence were the sole means to be employed by the Congress to reach its goal, self purification was necessary even in political life.
('48', 225, 1, 4, 502860) Today there is not much open opposition to the idea, though there are many who secretly believe that politics should have nothing to do with morality.
('48', 225, 1, 5, 503011) That is why our progress is so slow and in some respect even nil.
('48', 225, 1, 6, 503077) If we had acted up to our creed of 1920, we should not have taken nine years to arrive even at the present stage.
('48', 225, 1, 7, 503191) If swaraj was not meant to civilize us, and to purify and stabilize our civilization, it would be nothing worth.
('48', 225, 1, 8, 503304) The very essence of our civilization is that we give a paramount place to morality in all our affairs, public or private.
('48', 225, 1, 9, 503426) And as one of the functions of the Vidyapith is to civilize us, the battle of swaraj calls for the greatest sacrifice from the national educational institutions.
('48', 225, 1, 10, 503588) I want you all to realize the implications of our creed.
('48', 225, 1, 11, 503645) If you think that truth and non violence constitute not the creed but the policy of the Congress, I do not know where I should be.
('48', 225, 1, 12, 503776) But if you are convinced that they are your personal creed, I need not expatiate on them.
('48', 225, 1, 13, 503866) The very fact that a person belongs to the Vidyapith should be sufficient guarantee of his truthfulness and non violence.
('48', 225, 1, 14, 503988) The first thing therefore that this national educational conference and those who are attending it should do is to ask themselves whether all their doings have been in consonance with that creed.
('48', 225, 1, 15, 504184) If you have gone about your work, following truth and non violence as a policy, there will come a day when you might be tempted to alter the policy.
('48', 225, 1, 16, 504333) For instance my friends the Ali Brothers accepted truth and non violenceas a policy, and they never made a secret of it.
('48', 225, 1, 17, 504454) They always said that they could not accept them as a creed.
('48', 225, 1, 18, 504515) There are many others of their way of thinking, and they undoubtedly have their place in the service of the country, but for you, students and teachers of national educational institutions, that attitude will not suffice.

('48', 228, 7, 19, 511967) It was easy enough to pass the independence resolution at Lahore.
('48', 228, 7, 20, 512033) It is difficult enough to achieve it even by ‘peaceful and legitimate means’.

('48', 229, 1, 4, 512837) No speeches are therefore necessary.

('48', 229, 1, 7, 513298) It would be good, if the declaration is made by whole cities, whole villages even as happened on that ever memorable 6th of April 1919. It would be well if all the meetings were held at the identical minute in all the places.

('48', 229, 1, 13, 514561) They may also speak to the visitors to such places and wind up the day by attending the celebration.

('48', 243, 1, 12, 547058) I have therefore suggested measures of stern discipline and far from being any the worse, I hope we are the better for it.
('48', 243, 1, 13, 547181) For it is so obvious.
('48', 243, 1, 14, 547203) Take care of the vital thing and other things will take care of themselves.
('48', 243, 1, 15, 547279) Rectify one angle of a square, and the other angles will be automatically right.
('48', 243, 1, 16, 547360) Begin therefore your day with prayer, and make it so soulful that it may remain with you until the evening.
('48', 243, 1, 17, 547468) Close the day with prayer so that you may have a peaceful night free from dreams and nightmares.
('48', 243, 1, 18, 547565) Do not worry about the form of prayer.
('48', 243, 1, 19, 547604) Let it be any form, it should be such as can put us into communion with the divine.
('48', 243, 1, 20, 547688) Only, whatever be the form, let not the spirit wander while the words of prayer run on out of your mouth.
('48', 243, 1, 21, 547794) If what I have said has gone home to you, you will not be at peace until you have compelled your hostel superintendents to interest themselves in your prayer and to make it obligatory.
('48', 243, 1, 22, 547979) Restraint self imposed is no compulsion.
('48', 243, 1, 23, 548020) A man, who chooses the path of freedom from restraint, i.e., of self indulgence, will be a bondslave of passions, whilst the man who binds himself to rules and restraints releases himself.
('48', 243, 1, 24, 548209) All things in the universe, including the sun and the moon and the stars, obey certain laws.
('48', 243, 1, 25, 548302) Without the restraining influence of these laws the world would not go on for a single moment.
('48', 243, 1, 26, 548397) You, whose mission in life is service of your fellowmen, will go to pieces if you do not impose on yourselves some sort of discipline, and prayer is a necessary spiritual discipline.
('48', 243, 1, 27, 548580) It is discipline
('48', 244, 0, 1, 548597) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 245
('48', 244, 1, 2, 548643) and restraint that separates us from the brute.
('48', 244, 1, 3, 548691) If we will be men walking with our heads erect and not walking on all fours, let us understand and put ourselves under voluntary discipline and restraint.

('48', 252, 6, 11, 559793) 255. INTERVIEW TO “THE DAILY EXPRESS”
('48', 252, 7, 12, 559831) AHMEDABAD, January 22, 1930 The great trial of strength in this country is at hand.
('48', 252, 7, 13, 559915) Events now depend entirely on the British Government, for we shall not in any circumstances, now or in the future, participate in any conference unless it is called to consider our complete secession from Great Britain.
('48', 252, 7, 14, 560135) The day has passed when we could accept anything less than that.
('48', 252, 7, 15, 560200) We are engaged, as the world must know, in a struggle for the absolute severance of the present British connection and we shall not rest until that aim has been achieved.
('48', 252, 7, 16, 560371) We have begun now.
('48', 252, 7, 17, 560390) You shall find in every section of the land millions of our men and women in their cottages spinning hour after hour.
('48', 252, 7, 18, 560508) This means a nationwide boycott of foreign spun cloths, and in time must mean the end of British predominance in an industry which is the principal reason for the presence of your British troops in this country.
('48', 252, 8, 19, 560720) Asked to outline the details of his plans for the execution of his crusade of civil disobedience, Gandhiji replied: I am not yet sure of the form it will take.
('48', 252, 8, 20, 560880) I have come here and in my seclusion I hope to evolve a plan of civil resistance which will
('48', 253, 0, 1, 560972) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 253, 1, 2, 561014) not cause destruction or involve bloodshed, but which will be large enough to make the impression I desire.
('48', 253, 1, 3, 561122) That is all I am doing here, otherwise, as you can see, I am spinning.
('48', 253, 2, 4, 561193) He lapsed here into a long theoretical explanation of the necessity for careful preparation.
('48', 253, 2, 5, 561286) He was not certain that the precise moment had arrived which would ensure the success of this first step in the coming revolution, but it would be a guide—the measure of its success would be a guide to him.
('48', 253, 2, 6, 561493) He went on to explain: It is absolutely necessary for the person controlling such a movement to keep himself in tune with the voice of his followers, and therefore he must be as impervious to outside influences as he has to be sensitive to every little thing that goes on within.
('48', 253, 3, 7, 561773) I asked Gandhi if it was not possible that he might yet be able to avoid the extreme measures to which he was proceeding.
('48', 253, 3, 8, 561895) When he replied promptly in the affirmative and said that the slightest gesture from the British Government would work the miracle, I inquired what that gesture in his view should involve.
('48', 253, 3, 9, 562084) He replied: Any real gesture from the British Government and the British people, or any unexpected combination, spontaneous and healthy among ourselves, which would in itself constitute sufficient pressure to compel world attention, and not merely the attention of the British people.
('48', 253, 4, 10, 562369) That meant, of course, combination with extremists, but what kind of gesture from Britain?
('48', 253, 4, 11, 562460) Supposing the British Cabinet were to say tomorrow, ‘We are prepared to consider and further a scheme of Indian independence’, and produce an atmosphere, as it can certainly do, congenial to the framing of such a scheme, that would automatically prevent any further preparation for civil disobedience.
('48', 253, 5, 12, 562762) Does not the proposed Round Table Conference offer you an opportunity for full discussion in this respect?
('48', 253, 5, 13, 562869) He answered with some emphasis: No, not in any shape or form.
('48', 253, 5, 14, 562931) Because the Round Table Conference scheme so far as I have understood it from authentic sources is designed to discuss anything between a form of government infinitely less than the present and Dominion Status.
('48', 253, 5, 15, 563142) There is, for example, this proposition made by responsible ex officials that powers hitherto enjoyed by the people of India, such as they are now, should be taken away, because these critics actually suggest that we have proved ourselves unworthy of the powers.
('48', 253, 5, 16, 563405) Therefore, such a Round Table Conference, where even the capacity of India for full freedom is in question, has no place for me whatever.
('48', 253, 5, 17, 563543) It is entirely out of the question that I should attend.
('48', 253, 5, 18, 563600) I can only attend a conference which is pledged not to consider how much power India should or should not
('48', 254, 0, 1, 563706) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 255
('48', 254, 1, 2, 563752) enjoy, but to consider ways and means of framing a scheme of complete independence.
('48', 254, 1, 3, 563836) This is the only conference I could consider for a moment attending.

('48', 257, 3, 12, 572592) 257. TO ENGLISH FRIENDS
('48', 257, 4, 13, 572616) To the many known and still more unknown English friends, I owe perhaps a word on the eve of what may end in being a life and death struggle.
('48', 257, 4, 14, 572758) In spite of myself I tried to believe in the possibility of self respecting Congressmen attending the proposed Round Table Conference.
('48', 257, 4, 15, 572893) I had my doubts because I knew that the Congress, though it is admittedly the most representative organization in the country, had no adequate power behind it for vindicating its position.
('48', 257, 4, 16, 573082) It could therefore be represented at the Conference, only if it knew that the British Government and people had, either through a generous impulse or through the pressure of world opinion, decided to grant immediate Dominion Status, and that the Conference was to meet in order to discuss not anything the different groups liked but to discover the contents of a Dominion Status constitution.
('48', 257, 4, 17, 573475) The Viceroy made it clear in no uncertain terms that he could give no such assurance.
('48', 257, 4, 18, 573561) Such being the case, consistently with its past declaration and with the national interest of which the Congress claims to be the principal trustee, clearly it could not allow itself to be represented at the Conference.
('48', 257, 4, 19, 573781) But it may be asked: Granting that the Congress could not in the circumstances be expected to send its representatives, where was the necessity for going from Dominion Status to independence?
('48', 257, 4, 20, 573973) The answer is plain.
('48', 257, 4, 21, 573994) Organizations like men, if they are to command respect and grow, must have a sense of honour
('48', 258, 0, 1, 574087) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 259
('48', 258, 1, 2, 574133) andmust fulfil their promises.
('48', 258, 1, 3, 574164) Well, the Congress promised at Calcutta to change the creed to independence if Dominion Status was not forthcoming by the 31st of December 1929. It did not come nor was there any prospect of its coming for certain in the immediate future.
('48', 258, 1, 4, 574403) The Congress therefore had no other course left open, if it was not ‘to commit suicide’, but to declare its immediate objective to be complete independence instead of Dominion Status.
('48', 258, 1, 5, 574587) But what is there intrinsically wrong in wanting independence?
('48', 258, 1, 6, 574650) It is not possible for me to understand this opposition from sober Englishmen to the enunciation of an inalienable right of every nation to be independent except on the supposition that even they, the sober Englishmen, do not want India to be free.
('48', 258, 1, 7, 574899) ‘But you are not fit for independence’, say some.
('48', 258, 1, 8, 574949) Surely it is for us to judge whether we are fit or not.
('48', 258, 1, 9, 575005) And granting that we are not, there is nothing wrong or immoral in our aspiring after independence and in the attempt rendering ourselves fitter day by day.
('48', 258, 1, 10, 575162) We shall never be fit by being taught to feel helpless and to rely upon the British bayonet to keep us from fighting among ourselves or from being devoured by our neighbours.
('48', 258, 1, 11, 575337) If we have to go through the agonies of a civil war or a foreign invasion, it won’t be a new thing in the history of nations that have struggled for freedom.
('48', 258, 1, 12, 575495) England has gone through both the experiences.
('48', 258, 1, 13, 575542) After all freedom is not a hot house growth.
('48', 258, 1, 14, 575587) It is open to those English friends who are sincerely anxious for India’s welfare to assist India in her fight for freedom and on her terms.
('48', 258, 1, 15, 575728) She knows best what she needs.
('48', 258, 1, 16, 575759) Complete independence does not mean arrogant isolation or a superior disdain for all help.
('48', 258, 1, 17, 575850) But it does mean complete severance of the British bondage, be it ever so slight or well concealed.
('48', 258, 1, 18, 575950) The opposition therefore to the demand for immediate independence raises the strongest suspicions about the good intentions of those who have conceived the idea of the Conference.
('48', 258, 1, 19, 576130) It must be clearly understood that the largest nationalist party in India will no longer submit to the position of a dependent nation or to the process of helpless exploitation.
('48', 258, 1, 20, 576308) It will run any risk to be free from the double curse.
('48', 258, 1, 21, 576363) Is it not now intelligible why, notwithstanding its undoubted risks, I am planning some sort of civil disobedience so as to get together all the non violent forces and see if it stems the tide of onrushing violence?
('48', 258, 1, 22, 576579) Hatred and ill will there undoubtedly are in the air.
('48', 258, 1, 23, 576633) They are bound sooner or later to burst into acts of fury if they are not anticipated in time.
('48', 258, 1, 24, 576728) The conviction has deepened in me that civil disobedience alone can stop the bursting of that fury.
('48', 259, 0, 1, 576828) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 259, 1, 2, 576870) nationwants to feel its power more even than to have independence.
('48', 259, 1, 3, 576937) Possession of such power is independence.
('48', 259, 1, 4, 576979) That civil disobedience may resolve itself into violent disobedience is, I am sorry to have to confess, not an unlikely event.
