('48', 260, 0, 1, 579177) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 261
('48', 260, 1, 2, 579223) made on 26th:
('48', 260, 2, 3, 579237) We believe that it is the inalienable right of the Indian people, as of any other people, to have freedom and to enjoy the fruits of their toil and have the necessities of life so that they may have full opportunities of growth.
('48', 260, 2, 4, 579466) We believe also that if any government deprives a people of these rights and oppresses them, the people have a further right to alter it or to abolish it.
('48', 260, 2, 5, 579621) The British Government in India has not only deprived the Indian people of their freedom, but has based itself on the exploitation of the masses, and has ruined India economically, politically, culturally and spiritually.
('48', 260, 2, 6, 579843) We believe therefore that India must sever the British connection and attain purna swaraj or complete independence.
('48', 260, 3, 7, 579959) India has been ruined economically.
('48', 260, 3, 8, 579995) The revenue derived form our people is out of all proportion to our income.
('48', 260, 3, 9, 580071) Our average income is 7 pice (less than two pence) per day, and of the heavy taxes we pay, 20 per cent are raised from the land revenue derived form the peasntry and 3 per cent from the salt tax, which fals most heavily on the poor.
('48', 260, 4, 10, 580304) Village industries, such as hand spinning, have been destroyed, heaving the peasantry idle for at least four months in the year, and dulling their intellect for want of handicrafts, and nothing has been substituted, as in other countries, for the crafts thus destroyed.
('48', 260, 5, 11, 580574) Customs and currency have been so manipulated as to heap further burdens on the peasantry.
('48', 260, 5, 12, 580665) The British manufactured goods constitute the bulk of our imports.
('48', 260, 5, 13, 580732) Customs duties betrary clear partiality for British manufactures, and arevenue from them is used not to lessen the burden on the masses but for sustaining a highly extravagant administration.
('48', 260, 5, 14, 580924) Still more arbitrary has been the manipulation of the exchange ratio which has resulted in millions being drained away form the country.
('48', 260, 6, 15, 581061) Politically, India’s status has never been so reduced as under the British regime.
('48', 260, 6, 16, 581144) No reforms have given real political power to the people.
('48', 260, 6, 17, 581202) The tallest of us have to bend before foreign authority.
('48', 260, 6, 18, 581259) The rights of free expression of opinion and free association have been denied to us, and many of our countrymen are compllled to live in exile abroad and cannot return to their homes.
('48', 260, 6, 19, 581444) All administrative talent is killed, and the masses have to be satisfied with petty village offices and clerkships.
('48', 260, 7, 20, 581560) Culturally, the system of education has torn us from our moorings and our training has made us hug the very chains that bind us.
('48', 260, 8, 21, 581689) Spiritually, compulsory disarmament has made us unmanly, and the presence of an alien army of occupation, employed with deadly effect to crush in us the spirit of resistance, has made us think that we cannot look after ourselves or put up a defence against foreign aggression, or even defend our homes and families form the attacks of thieves, robbers and miscreants.
('48', 260, 8, 22, 582057) We hold it to be a crime against man and God to submit any longer to a rule that has caused this fourfold disaster to our country.
('48', 260, 8, 23, 582188) We recognize, however, that the most effective way of gaining our freedom is not through violence.
('48', 260, 8, 24, 582287) We will therefore prepare ourselves, by withdrawing, so far as we can, all voluntary association from the British Government, and will prepare for civil disobedience, including
('48', 260, 9, 25, 582464) 1 Vide “Telegram to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 17 1 1930.

('48', 261, 3, 7, 582965) A friend writes: 1
('48', 261, 4, 8, 582984) It is very improper of any editor to publish incorrect reports about someone in this manner, without proper investigation and verification.

('48', 261, 4, 12, 583287) I have also been getting visible proof of its success.

('48', 261, 4, 14, 583453) In other words, I said that if people should turn violent under these circumstances the adherents of non violence should endeavour to restrain them.
('48', 261, 4, 15, 583602) As for slavery, I said that if I were compelled to choose to be a witness to slavery or violence, I shall certainly choose to be a witness to violence.

('48', 261, 4, 19, 584035) One lesson has to be learnt from the above letter, namely, when one hears or reads anything unusual about a well known public servant or a public leader, it should never be believed without corroboration from him.

('48', 265, 6, 15, 589070) January 25, 1930
('48', 265, 7, 16, 589087) BHAISHRI ANANDANAND, I have your letter.
('48', 265, 7, 17, 589128) I do not know what agitation Malaviyaji is carrying on.
('48', 265, 7, 18, 589184) But if it is against the Congress he can hold no position in the Anti Untouchability Committee.
('48', 265, 7, 19, 589280) 1 I have no doubt about this.
('48', 265, 7, 20, 589310) Let Jamnalalji trace Malaviyaji’s speech against the Congress and send it to him, and, like a son to his father put to him his doubt about the propriety of his remaining in the Anti Untouchability Committee.
('48', 265, 7, 21, 589518) Malaviyaji is not hurt by such questions, and even if he is, he has a great capacity for suppressing his feelings.
('48', 265, 7, 22, 589633) I had thought that he would never carry on an agitation against the Congress for whatever reason.
('48', 265, 7, 23, 589731) It is necessary to clear this matter at once.
('48', 265, 7, 24, 589777) I have still not understood Rajaji’s suggestion regarding Vallabhbhai and myself touring.
('48', 265, 7, 25, 589867) Boycott of the Assemblies is a necessary but negative and not a very important part of our new programme.
('48', 265, 7, 26, 589973) The important and constructive part is civil disobedience.
('48', 265, 7, 27, 590032) And for that I do not think it necessary for anybody to tour the country.
('48', 265, 7, 28, 590106) On the contrary, those who regard non violence as an essential means for the attainment of independence should avoid touring.
('48', 265, 7, 29, 590232) If you do not follow this, ask me for further clarification, for it is necessary that Jamnalalji, you and others should understand it well.
('48', 265, 7, 30, 590372) The letter up to here was dictated at five o’clock in the morning.

('48', 266, 3, 11, 591029) 269. NAVAJIVAN KARYALAYA
('48', 266, 4, 12, 591054) A full report of the activities of the Navajivan Karyalaya accompanies the present number of Navajivan.
('48', 266, 4, 13, 591158) I invite to it the attention of every lover of the journal.
('48', 266, 4, 14, 591218) The reader will please consider it pardonable if he notices anywhere in the Report a sense of pride resulting from self satisfaction.
('48', 266, 4, 15, 591352) This Karyalaya came into being in circumstances that no one had ever imagined.
('48', 266, 4, 16, 591431) It got the services of Swami Anand, who helped to give the Karyalaya the stability which it now has.
('48', 266, 4, 17, 591532) My purpose in drawing attention to the Report is to show that a business, run with honesty and in a spirit of service but in a businesslike manner, can succeed, and to dispel the illusion that one cannot afford to be entirely honest in business.
('48', 266, 4, 18, 591778) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 26 1 1930

('48', 268, 4, 8, 594581) 273. PREFACE TO “KATHAKUSUMANJALI 1”
('48', 268, 5, 9, 594618) UDYOGA MANDIR, SABARMATI, January 29, 1930 This is a collection of articles by Sjt.
('48', 268, 5, 10, 594702) Valji Desai.
('48', 268, 5, 11, 594715) All readers of Navajivan know by now the labour which preceded the writing of each one of these articles.
('48', 268, 5, 12, 594821) They were not written to serve a journalist’s immediate aim, but were written to serve permanent public good.
('48', 268, 5, 13, 594931) Hence they deserve to be published in book form.
('48', 268, 5, 14, 594980) The subjects dealt with in these articles will be of great help to anyone seeking satsang 2. From the point of view of language, too, their value is no less, for Valji Desai commands a unique style.
('48', 268, 6, 15, 595179) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI
('48', 268, 7, 16, 595206) From a copy of the Gujarati: C.W. 9276. Courtesy: V. G. Desai
('48', 268, 8, 17, 595268) 274. CLEARING THE ISSUE
('48', 268, 9, 18, 595292) I have never sought to delude Indian opinion into the belief that a definition of purpose, however plainly stated, would of itself by the enunciation of a phrase provide a solution for problems which have to be solved before that purpose is fully realized.
('48', 268, 9, 19, 595549) The assertion of a goal, however precise its terms, is of necessity a different thing from the goal’s attainment.
('48', 268, 9, 20, 595663) No sensible traveller would feel that a clear definition of his destination was the same thing as the completion of his journey.
('48', 268, 11, 21, 595792) But though the Conference cannot assume the duty that appertains to His Majesty’s Government, it will be convened for the purpose, hardly less important, of elucidating and harmonizing opinion, and so affording guidance to His Majesty’s Government on whom the responsibilitymust subsequently devolve of drafting proposals for the consideration ofParliament.
('48', 268, 11, 22, 596150) The foregoing titbits from His Excellency the Viceroy’s address
('48', 268, 12, 23, 596214) 1 Literally, ‘a floral tribute in the form of stories’ 2 Company of righteous or religious men
('48', 269, 0, 1, 596309) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 269, 1, 2, 596351) to the Assembly 1 make it as clear as possible that Dominion Status was never to be the immediate objective of the proposed Round Table Conference.
('48', 269, 1, 3, 596499) And why need any of us doubt that even Lord Birkenhead will concede that Dominion Status may be India’s distant goal?
('48', 269, 1, 4, 596617) Where time is of essence, it makes a difference not in degree but in kind.
('48', 269, 1, 5, 596692) And when that difference in kind was discovered at the interview at Delhi 2, there was no meeting ground left between the Viceregal mentality and the Congress mentality.
('48', 269, 1, 6, 596862) The Viceroy would not mind waiting for the grant of Dominion Status till every millionaire was reduced to the level of a wage earner getting seven pice per day.
('48', 269, 1, 7, 597023) The Congress will today, if it had the power, raise every starving peasant to a state in which he can at least get a living even equal to a millionaire’s.
('48', 269, 1, 8, 597178) And when the peasant is fully awakened to a sense of his plight and knows that it is not kismet that has brought him to the helpless state but the existing rule, unaided he will in his impatience abolish all distinctions between constitutional and unconstitutional, even violent and non violent means.
('48', 269, 1, 9, 597480) The Congress expects to guide the peasant in the right direc tion.
('48', 269, 1, 10, 597547) The Viceroy’s speech has cleared another thing.
('48', 269, 1, 11, 597595) We now know why Sir John Simon has made the discovery that the question of Indian princes should be made an integral part of his precious inquiry.
('48', 269, 1, 12, 597742) A pure creation of the British Government, unlike those in British India, bereft even of speech, they are to be pawns in the game of exploitation to be played at the Conference.
('48', 269, 1, 13, 597920) The Conference room will ring with the name of Dominion Status whilst further burdens will be sought to be heaped upon the devoted heads of the starving millions.
('48', 269, 1, 14, 598083) Let those who wish join a game where one party plays with loaded dice.
('48', 269, 1, 15, 598154) His Excellency is offended over the Congress resolution on financial obligations!
('48', 269, 1, 16, 598236) Be it noted that the Congress has referred the examination of the justness or otherwise of these obligations to an impartial tribunal.
('48', 269, 1, 17, 598371) Is it a crime to question the propriety of some of these obligations?
('48', 269, 1, 18, 598441) Lord Irwin’s impatience over that most innocent resolution is typical of the British mentality.
('48', 269, 1, 19, 598537) Thousands of Englishmen honestly believe that all obligations have been incurredvoluntarily and for India’s good, and that it is the height of ungratefulness even to suspect unfairness about any of the transactions of the Secretary of State for India.
('48', 269, 1, 20, 598789) Prominence has been exclusively given in that speech to the
('48', 269, 2, 21, 598849) 1 On January 25 2 On December 23
('48', 270, 0, 1, 598882) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 271
('48', 270, 1, 2, 598928) unity which is impossible of full achievement so long as a foreign rule divides the varied interests and unconsciously or consciously plays one against another for the purpose of perpetuating itself.
('48', 270, 1, 3, 599128) The Congress is well out of the tangle.
('48', 270, 1, 4, 599168) It can afford even to be in a minority if need be.
('48', 270, 1, 5, 599219) But the demonstrations of 26th are an unmistakable proof that the Congress still remains the one body to rule the hearts of the masses.
('48', 270, 1, 6, 599355) Thank God, they have unity in their starvation.
('48', 270, 1, 7, 599403) This Government is wholly impartial in the discharge of its duty of extracting the last pie from the peasantry whether Hindu or Mussalman or any other.
('48', 270, 1, 8, 599555) I make the same ‘childish’ offer (almost) to Lord Irwin that I had the honour of making to Lord Reading.
('48', 270, 1, 9, 599660) 1 Let him and the British Cabinet initiate the following reforms: 1. Total prohibition, 2. Reduction of the ratio to ls.
('48', 270, 1, 10, 599781) 4d., 3. Reduction of the land revenue to at least 50% and making it subject to legislative control, 4. Abolition of the salt tax, 5. Reduction of the military expenditure to at least 50% to begin with, 6. Reduction of the salaries of the higher grade service to one half or less so as to suit the reduced revenue, 7. Protective tariff on foreign cloth, 8. The passage of the Coastal Traffic Reservation Bill, 9. Discharge of all political prisoners save those condemned for murder or the attempt thereat by the ordinary judicial tribunal, withdrawal of all political prosecutions, abrogation of Section 124 A, the Regulation of 1818 and the like, and permission to all the Indian exiles to return, 10. Abolition of C.I.D. or its popular control, 11. Issue of licences to use firearms for self defence subject to popular control.
('48', 270, 1, 11, 600610) This is by no means an exhaustive list of pressing needs.
('48', 270, 1, 12, 600668) 2 But let the Viceroy satisfy these very simple but vital needs of India.He will then hear no talk of civil disobedience, and the Congress will heartily participate in any conference where there is perfect freedom of expression and demand.
('48', 270, 2, 13, 600908) 1 Vide “Letter to Viceroy”, 1 2 1922. 2 These were the terms which Gandhiji communicated to Bomanji who undertook to negotiate with Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald.
('48', 270, 2, 14, 601073) (The History of the Indian National Congress, Vol. I, p.
('48', 271, 0, 1, 601130) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 271, 1, 2, 601172) Our disunion is no bar to these reforms.
('48', 271, 1, 3, 601213) The Congress is not agitating for a shadow.
('48', 271, 1, 4, 601257) Hundreds of thousands of people do not gather to the annual session of the Congress in order to secure independence in mere name, they gather in the hope that the glow of freedom, when it comes, will be felt in the remotest village.
('48', 271, 1, 5, 601490) The greatest evil is undoubtedly the economic pressure and the corroding feeling of inferiority which the people experience in every walk of life.
('48', 271, 1, 6, 601637) We are like Sir Narayan Chandavarkar’s goat whom, when released from airy surroundings to which she was forcibly taken, the deceased Knight saw frisking about on a Poona road being led by her mistress to her dungeon home.
('48', 271, 1, 7, 601859) We refuse to be satisfied with the airy peace, we would rather risk the dark anarchy if perchance thereby we can be released from the grinding pauperism.
('48', 271, 1, 8, 602013) The threat of dire vengeance uttered against civil and criminal resisters is idle and therefore uncalled for.
('48', 271, 1, 9, 602123) There is this in common between both.
('48', 271, 1, 10, 602161) Both have counted the cost.
('48', 271, 1, 11, 602189) They are out for suffering.
('48', 271, 1, 12, 602217) Would that their means were also common.
('48', 271, 1, 13, 602258) Unfortunately instead of being complementary, they neutralize each other.
('48', 271, 1, 14, 602332) I know that the non violent revolutionary like me impedes the progress of the violent revolutionary.
('48', 271, 1, 15, 602433) I wish the latter would realize that he impedes my progress more than I do his, and that I, being a Mahatma, if left unhampered by him, am likely to make greater progress than he can ever hope to make.
('48', 271, 1, 16, 602635) Let him realize too that he has never yet given me a fair chance.
('48', 271, 1, 17, 602701) Some of them no doubt have been most considerate.
('48', 271, 1, 18, 602751) I want full suspension of his activity.
('48', 271, 1, 19, 602791) If it will please him, I am free to admit that I dread him more than I dread Lord Irwin’s wrath.
('48', 271, 1, 20, 602888) His Excellency the Viceroy deserves the thanks of every Congressman for having cleared the atmosphere and let us know exactly where he and we stand.
('48', 271, 1, 21, 603037) Young India, 30 1 1930
('48', 271, 2, 22, 603060) 275. DIFFICULTY OF PRACTICE
('48', 271, 3, 23, 603088) The reader should read Rev.
('48', 271, 3, 24, 603116) B. de Ligt’s letter printed elsewhere in this issue 1. I welcome the letter as of a fellow seeker in the field of ahimsa.
('48', 271, 3, 25, 603238) It is entitled to respectful consideration.
('48', 271, 3, 26, 603282) And such friendly discussion leads to a clearer conception of the possibilities and limitations of non violence.
('48', 271, 3, 27, 603395) In spite of the greatest effort to be detached, no man can altogether undo the effect of his environment or of his up bringing.
('48', 271, 3, 28, 603523) Non violence of two persons occupying different positions will not
('48', 271, 4, 29, 603590) 1 Under the title “Cat and Mouse”
('48', 272, 0, 1, 603624) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 273
('48', 272, 1, 2, 603670) outwardly take the same shape.
('48', 272, 1, 3, 603701) Thus the non violence of a child towards his father would take the shape of conscious and voluntary submission to his violence when he loses his temper.
('48', 272, 1, 4, 603854) But if the child has lost his temper, the father’s submission to the child’s violence would be meaningless.
('48', 272, 1, 5, 603962) The father would take the child to his bosom and instantaneously sterilize the child’s violence.
('48', 272, 1, 6, 604059) In each case it is of course assumed that the outward act is an expression of the inward intention.
('48', 272, 1, 7, 604159) One who having retaliation in his breast submits to violence out of policy is not truly non violent and may even be a hypocrite if he hides his intention.
('48', 272, 1, 8, 604314) It should also be remembered that non violence comes into play only when it comes in contact with violence.
('48', 272, 1, 9, 604422) One who refrains from violence when there is no occasion for its exercise is simply unviolent and has no credit for his inaction.
('48', 272, 1, 10, 604552) Dominion Status ceasing to be a factor, the points raised from that imaginary event now need not be discussed except to say, that the enjoyment by India of Dominion Status would have meant India, then become an equal partner, instead of being ruled by it, dominating the foreign policy of Great Britain.
('48', 272, 1, 11, 604856) My general and hearty approval of the Nehru Report must not be taken to mean endorsement of every word of it.
('48', 272, 1, 12, 604966) My approval need not carry endorsement of the constructive programme for the future governance of free India.
('48', 272, 1, 13, 605076) My non violence would prevent me from fighting my countrymen on the many questions that must arise when India has become free.
('48', 272, 1, 14, 605203) A mere academic discussion can only hamper the present progress of non violence.
('48', 272, 1, 15, 605284) I know however that if I survive the struggle for freedom, I might have to give non violent battle to myown countrymen which may be as stubborn as that in which I am now engaged.
('48', 272, 1, 16, 605463) But the military schemes now being considered by the great Indian leaders are highly likely to appear even to them to be wholly unnecessary, assuming that we have come to our own demonstrably through non violent means deliberately chosen and used.
('48', 272, 1, 17, 605711) My collaboration with my countrymen today is confined to the breaking of our shackles.
('48', 272, 1, 18, 605798) How we would feel and what we shall do after breaking them is more than they or I know.
('48', 272, 1, 19, 605886) It is profitless to speculate whether Tolstoy in my place would have acted differently from me.
('48', 272, 1, 20, 605982) It is enough for me to give the assurance to my friends in Europe, that in no single act of mine have I been consciously guilty of endorsing violence or compromising my creed.
('48', 272, 1, 21, 606158) Even the seeming endorsement of violent action by my participation on the side of Britain in the Boer War and the Zulu revolt was a recognition in the interest of non violence of an inevitable
('48', 273, 0, 1, 606351) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 273, 1, 2, 606393) situation.
('48', 273, 1, 3, 606404) That the participation may nevertheless have been due to my weakness or ignorance of the working of the universal law of non violence is quite possible.
('48', 273, 1, 4, 606557) Only I had no conviction then, nor have any now, of such weakness or ignorance.
('48', 273, 1, 5, 606637) A non violent man will instinctively prefer direct participation to indirect, in a system which is based on violence and to which he has to belong without any choice being left to him.
('48', 273, 1, 6, 606822) I belong to a world which is partly based on violence.
('48', 273, 1, 7, 606877) If I have only a choice between paying for the army of soldiers to kill my neighbours or to be a soldier myself, I would, as I must, consistently with my creed, enlist as a soldier in the hope of controlling the forces of violence and even of converting my comrades.
('48', 273, 1, 8, 607144) National independence is not fiction.
('48', 273, 1, 9, 607182) It is as necessary as individual independence.
('48', 273, 1, 10, 607229) But neither, if it is based on non violence, may ever be a menace to the equal independence of the nation or the individual as the case may be.
('48', 273, 1, 11, 607373) As with individual and national independence, so with the international.
('48', 273, 1, 12, 607446) The legal maxim is equally moral: Sic utere tuo ut alienum non laedas.
('48', 273, 1, 13, 607517) It has been well said that the universe is compressed in the atom.
('48', 273, 1, 14, 607584) There is not one law for the atom and another for the universe.
('48', 273, 1, 15, 607648) Young India, 30 1 1930

('48', 274, 6, 18, 609894) These weddings took place in our Mathur Chaturvedi caste.
('48', 274, 6, 19, 609952) It is the misfortune of our caste that girls of 2, 2_ and 3 years are given in marriage.
('48', 274, 6, 20, 610041) There has been considerable agitation over this.
('48', 274, 6, 21, 610090) The well known leader Shri Radheylal Chaturvedi, who belongs to our caste, tried very hard but these child marriages could not be prevented.
('48', 274, 6, 22, 610231) Last year an eight month old girl and a 15 month old girl were given in marriage.
('48', 274, 6, 23, 610313) One does not know how to reform these people.
('48', 274, 6, 24, 610359) It must be pointed out that we, the Chaturvedi community, consider ourselves the highest Brahmins.
('48', 274, 6, 25, 610458) We consider it a sin to eat food cooked even by other Brahmins.
('48', 274, 6, 26, 610522) What else can the marriages described by Benarsidasji be called than monstrous?
('48', 274, 6, 27, 610602) It is sad that those who perpetrate such marriages continue to be respectable.
('48', 274, 6, 28, 610681) This creates many difficulties in thwarting them; and when scriptures are quoted in their favour, the difficulties multiply.
('48', 274, 6, 29, 610806) However, satyagraha can become a sure means of overcoming all kinds of tyranny.
('48', 274, 6, 30, 610886) Always and under every
('48', 274, 7, 31, 610909) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.

('48', 275, 1, 2, 611118) circumstance we may not have the strength to resort to satyagraha or we may not know how to employ it.
('48', 275, 1, 3, 611221) This is a different matter.
('48', 275, 1, 4, 611249) It points to the limitations of the satyagrahi, not of satyagraha.
('48', 275, 1, 5, 611316) In the above circumstances every person can resort to one method.
('48', 275, 1, 6, 611382) The family in which such marriages are recognized should be boycotted and no help of any kind should be expected of it.
('48', 275, 1, 7, 611502) For example, if a father wishes to get his little daughter married, or if he wishes to sell her, then, in that case, the boys and girls of that house, or at least any one of them who has the courage, must leave the father’s house and should accept no help whatever from him.
('48', 275, 1, 8, 611777) If this is done it will surely have some effect on the father’s heart.
('48', 275, 1, 9, 611848) Even if there is none, those who have left the father’s house will escape from the sin.

('48', 278, 6, 11, 615564) 285. MY NOTES
('48', 278, 7, 12, 615578) THE KHAKHRECHI SATYAGRAHA The Khakhrechi satyagraha was a simple one and on a modest scale.
('48', 278, 7, 13, 615670) The demand put forward by the farmers was actually small, but the satyagraha owed itself to the cultivators’ courage, which was remarkable for Kathiawar and indeed surprising for a principality that lies in a remote corner of the region.
('48', 278, 7, 14, 615908) What deserved the notice of all the States was how the farmers had initiated the satyagraha on their own.
('48', 278, 7, 15, 616014) Their demand was so just that no one could have opposed it.
('48', 278, 7, 16, 616074) The injustice against which the satyagraha was aimed was obvious.
('48', 278, 7, 17, 616140) It was a painful surprise that the Durbar made the cultivators suffer for about six weeks.
('48', 278, 7, 18, 616231) When a batch of satyagrahis arrived there to assist these farmers, it was only doing its duty.
('48', 278, 7, 19, 616326) The satyagrahis deserve compliments for going through their sufferings patiently with no violation of limits of propriety.
('48', 278, 7, 20, 616449) One cannot say that at the end of this satyagraha the prince on his part had showed any grace.
('48', 278, 7, 21, 616544) It is true that the farmers have been pacified by doing them some justice and a promise to do some more.
('48', 278, 7, 22, 616649) If the prince desires congratulations on the point, he might have them.
('48', 278, 7, 23, 616721) But according to my information, the prince’s behaviour towards the volunteer corps lacked grace, decencyand courtesy.
('48', 278, 7, 24, 616840) It does no honour to him that the members of the corps should have been banished from the territory in spite of their modest conduct, and insolently dealt with by the State police.
('48', 278, 7, 25, 617021) It is an unpleasant fact that the victorious end of the satyagraha is not
('48', 279, 0, 1, 617095) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 279, 1, 2, 617137) followed by the sweetness which we should have expected.
('48', 279, 1, 3, 617194) The people of Kathiawar have a right to expect from all the States there courteous conduct towards such public men as Sjt.
('48', 279, 1, 4, 617317) Manilal Kothari and Sjt.
('48', 279, 1, 5, 617342) Fulchand, so well known for their love of peace.
('48', 279, 1, 6, 617391) The princes and the people both have a lesson to learn from this small scale satyagraha.
('48', 279, 2, 7, 617480) CHILD MARRIAGES A Patidar youth writes: 1
('48', 279, 3, 8, 617522) Many others must be in such a plight.
('48', 279, 3, 9, 617560) I would advise all such persons to refuse firmly to get into the bonds of such a marriage and to suffer whatever consequences follow from the refusal.
('48', 279, 3, 10, 617711) Such marriages are a sign of our weak minds.
('48', 279, 3, 11, 617756) This weakness retards our growth socially, economically, politically and spiritually.
('48', 279, 3, 12, 617842) If we should assert our mental strength in one field, its effect cannot but be felt in the others.
('48', 279, 3, 13, 617941) Hence I particularly advise youths in such a plight not to submit themselves, whatever the cost, to evil customs like child marriage which are a bane to the society.
('48', 279, 3, 14, 618107) Let them however show the utmost courtesy in their conduct towards the elders and equally scrupulous regard for truth.
('48', 279, 3, 15, 618226) Courtesy without full regard for truth is no courtesy.
('48', 279, 3, 16, 618281) It is only flattery, it is hypocrisy, and, therefore, truly speaking, it is discourtesy.

('48', 281, 1, 6, 622132) The events have moved fairly fast.
('48', 281, 1, 7, 622167) I see as clearly as never before that the spirit of violence must be dealt with by non violent action if the situation is to be at all saved.
('48', 281, 1, 8, 622309) There is the growing violence of the Government expressing itself in a variety of ways — the subtle exploitation and the necessary prosecutions as a consequence of that exploitation, for instance.
('48', 281, 1, 9, 622506) You will note the extended meaning I have given to violence.
('48', 281, 1, 10, 622567) Greed, pilfering, untruth, crooked diplomacy—all these are phases or signs or results of violent thought and action.
('48', 281, 1, 11, 622684) The reaction of this violence upon the thinking educated people is remarkable and daily growing.
('48', 281, 1, 12, 622781) I have therefore to deal with this double violence.
('48', 281, 1, 13, 622833) To sit still at this juncture is stupid if not cowardly.
('48', 281, 1, 14, 622890) I have made up my mind to run the boldest risks.
('48', 281, 1, 15, 622939) I have arrived at this definite conclusion as a result of deep and prayerful thinking.
('48', 281, 1, 16, 623026) Lahore revealed it all to me.

('48', 281, 1, 19, 623138) How it is to be undertaken and by whom besides me, I have not yet seen quite clearly.
('48', 281, 1, 20, 623224) But the shining cover that overlays the truth is thinning day by day and will presently break.

('48', 283, 1, 2, 625697) 289. LETTER TO PURSHOTTAMDAS THAKURDAS
('48', 283, 2, 3, 625736) SABARMATI, February 2, 1930
('48', 283, 3, 4, 625764) DEAR SIR PURSHOTTAMDAS, There was no need for an apology for writing to me in English.
('48', 283, 3, 5, 625851) My own impression is that the depreciation is largely manipulated and the letter from the India Office is intended to frighten us.
('48', 283, 3, 6, 625982) 1 At the same time when the effect of the Congress resolution comes to be really felt, I know that all the gilt edged securities are bound to suffer heavy depreciation unless the British Government underwrites all losses and is in a position to do so.
('48', 283, 3, 7, 626234) I know that during the South African War even all the Republican notes, which 24 hours before the declaration of war were fully worth their face value, became scraps of paper and I understand that such was the case in :France and Germany during the late War.
('48', 283, 3, 8, 626493) It would not surprise me, if we have to go through the same purgatory.
('48', 283, 3, 9, 626564) The meaning to me of the resolution is that the poor people who have invested their little savings in these securities should not suffer and that the British Government should be made to take over such liabilities as are held by the tribunal referred to in the resolution to be unjust or unjustifiable.
('48', 283, 3, 10, 626867) Lastly, you will agree with me that the interpretation of the resolution as also the momentary depreciation are not of so much importance as what action India is going to take in the near future.
('48', 283, 3, 11, 627063) We are so many and our case is so overwhelmingly justthat, if the other parties instead of belittling the Congress resolution and the Congress efforts were to endorse them, even if by reason of their weakness, they cannot make common cause with the Congress, we
('48', 283, 4, 12, 627325) 1 The addressee had written: “The repudiation of debts as approved of by the Indian National Congress at their Lahore session by their Resolution No.
('48', 283, 4, 13, 627475) 10 has had considerable effect on the securities market both in England and in India as you are perhaps already aware.
('48', 283, 4, 14, 627594) In the course of this week there has been published a letter addressed by the India Office to an investor in London, and I mention this to show what anxiety this Resolution of the Congress has created in the minds of investors in London....
('48', 283, 4, 15, 627835) My principal motive in addressing this letter to you is to draw your attention to the serious depreciation of Indian sterling securities in London since December last.
('48', 283, 4, 16, 628003) There is no doubt that an enormous amount of loss is being encountered by the present holders of Indian Government paper, either rupee or sterling, and it cannot be to the advantage of any school of politicians to make the innocent ones suffer.
('48', 283, 4, 17, 628248) .” Vide also “Speech at Subjects Committee, A.I.C.C. II”, 1 1 1930 & “Some Implications”, 6 2 1930.
('48', 284, 0, 1, 628348) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 285
('48', 284, 1, 2, 628394) should come to our own without much disturbance of the present life in the cities.
('48', 284, 1, 3, 628477) A radical reshaping of the life in the cities which is today related to the false and artificial standard that is set up by the British administrators and that is out of all keeping with the life of the millions is in any case necessary, if the terrible burden of taxation upon the poor is to be removed.
('48', 284, 1, 4, 628782) I hope you are not among those who believe that by a mere change of the constitution the starving ryots will find themselves in a position to pay a larger revenue than they are paying today or even to pay comfortably what they are paying now.
('48', 284, 1, 5, 629025) In my opinion the only meaning of swaraj to these people will be an appreciable reduction in the taxes that they are paying directly and indirectly and fixity of tenure.
('48', 284, 1, 6, 629195) This cannot happen until we, who are partners with the British administrators in the game of the exploitation of the masses, are prepared to change the angle of our vision even as we expect the former to do.
('48', 284, 2, 7, 629403) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI Purshottamdas Thakurdas Papers, File No.

('48', 291, 4, 11, 640333) 304. THE ISSUE
('48', 291, 5, 12, 640348) I gladly publish the foregoing circular letter 1. I have the privilege of knowing Mr. Horace Alexander personally, and I believe him to be a true friend.
('48', 291, 5, 13, 640502) Common courtesy demands utmost frankness at this stage.
('48', 291, 5, 14, 640558) I am as anxious as he and other English friends for honest co operation as between equals.
('48', 291, 5, 15, 640649) But the element of equality is wanting.
('48', 291, 5, 16, 640689) The interview broke on the one single issue of Dominion Status, but not as Mr. Alexander puts it.

('48', 292, 3, 23, 644419) Well might the points suggested by me as for immediate attention 1 raise a storm of indignation in the British Press.

('48', 293, 1, 2, 645089) British imagination pictures to itself an India under Dominion Statusremaining a perpetual El Dorado for the British.
('48', 293, 1, 3, 645207) If Dominion Status is feared, it is because the reality of it would mean ability to undo continuing wrongs and therefore unjust burdens whether in the shape of Government of India loans or guarantees given to the military and the civil services, or favours shown to British manufactures at the expense of India, or concessions granted to the British trader, capitalist or prospector.

('48', 293, 1, 5, 645764) The masses feel that the Congress will remove the burdens which they vaguely feel but cannot describe.
('48', 293, 1, 6, 645867) I venture to claim that in formulating the eleven points, I have somewhat and to the extent of my ability given a concrete shape to their feeling.
('48', 293, 1, 7, 646014) It is not difficult to understand the resentment felt in England over the ‘demands’ nor the hysterics of Sir Malcom Hailey over the idea of repudiating debts in any circumstance whatsoever.

('48', 293, 1, 9, 646286) If he finds the trustee having buttered his own bread at the ward’s expense, he makes the trustee pay for his malpractices or misappropriation or breach of trust or whatever other name by which his selfishness may be described.

('48', 293, 1, 11, 646853) If the stopping of the drain means a revision of the tastes of the city people of this land who live upon the commission they make from their British principals, it means also that the British as a whole will have to revise their tastes by reason of the sudden stoppage of the millions looted from India for their sakes.
('48', 293, 1, 12, 647174) It is clear, that the riches derived from the tillers of the soil are not a voluntary contribution or a contribution compelled for their benefit.
('48', 293, 1, 13, 647320) The villages are not affected by the Pax Britannica so called; for they were untouched even by the invasions of Timur or Nadirshah.
('48', 293, 1, 14, 647452) They will remain untouched by anarchy if it comes.

('48', 294, 1, 7, 648513) Ordered violence hides itself often behind camouflage and hypocrisy as we see them working through the declarations of good intentions, commissions, conferences and the like, or even through measures conceived as tending to the public benefit but in reality to the benefit of the wrongdoer.
('48', 294, 1, 8, 648804) Greed and deceit are often the offspring as they are equally often the parents of violence.
('48', 294, 1, 9, 648896) Naked violence repels like the naked skeleton shorn of flesh, blood and the velvety skin.

('48', 294, 1, 13, 649237) Non violence has to work in the midst of this double violence.
('48', 294, 1, 14, 649300) But if it is the supreme law governing mankind, it must be able to make its way in the face of the heaviest odds.
('48', 294, 1, 15, 649414) Violence such as we have to face may well make us cowards utterly unable to discover the method of working non violence.

('48', 295, 3, 14, 651738) THE FINISHING TOUCH
('48', 295, 4, 15, 651758) It will be remembered that the Broomfield Committee 1, whilst holding that the Bardoli peasants’ complaints were substantially justified, and cancelling the enhanced assessment to the extent of something over 89,379 rupees, still recommended a net increase of Rs. 30,806 over the old assessment.
('48', 295, 4, 16, 652054) But there was a legal flaw about this recommendation.
('48', 295, 4, 17, 652108) Government seem to have rectified the error by revising the assessment in something like 40 villages, and now they are making arrangements for giving full effect to the Broomfield Committee’s recommendations about the rectification of errors in the classification of lands and kindred matters.
('48', 295, 4, 18, 652402) The net result of all this might amount to, in effect, a restoration of the old assessment of the Taluk.
('48', 295, 4, 19, 652507) That would put a finishing touch to the success of that historic struggle.
('48', 295, 4, 20, 652582) No wonder that an English friend, writing to Mahadev Desai about his Story of Bardoli, says, “Lahore made me feel most scepticalof the power of India to work unitedly and effectively for swaraj, but the Story of Bardoli has more than answered my fears.” Though both the Lahore demonstration and the Bardoli struggle were offshoots of the Congress, the difference the English friend noticed is easily explained.
('48', 295, 4, 21, 652993) The Lahore demonstration was the whole
('48', 295, 5, 22, 653032) 1 Comprising R. S. Broomfield and R. M. Maxwell
('48', 296, 0, 1, 653080) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 297
('48', 296, 1, 2, 653126) Congress at its best and its worst.
('48', 296, 1, 3, 653162) It necessarily included every variety of character.
('48', 296, 1, 4, 653214) Moreover it was the yearly deliberative function.
('48', 296, 1, 5, 653264) The Bardoli struggle on the other hand was a Congress body in action.
('48', 296, 1, 6, 653334) It was Congressmen who conceived it.
('48', 296, 1, 7, 653371) The Sardar 1 himself was the President of the Provincial Congress Committee, and he mobilized the whole resources of the Committee for the struggle.
('48', 296, 1, 8, 653520) The forces of violence were hushed in the presence of non violent action.
('48', 296, 1, 9, 653594) It remains to be seen how the all India struggle for independence will shape.
('48', 296, 1, 10, 653672) The law that governed the Bardoli struggle which centred round a local grievance will govern the greater struggle for independence.
('48', 296, 1, 11, 653804) The partakers will have to be strictly non violent; they will have to visualize the grievance of slavery as the Bardoli peasant visualized the grievance of an unjust assessment; they will have to submit to the strictest discipline even as the Bardoli peasants did.

('48', 299, 2, 10, 661038) 310. VARNADHARMA AND DUTY OF LABOUR 1 I
('48', 299, 3, 11, 661078) Questions asked and my answers to them are given below:
('48', 299, 4, 12, 661134) Q : Do you accept the duty of [bread] labour expounded by Tolstoy ?
('48', 299, 4, 13, 661202) A: Yes, certainly.
('48', 299, 5, 14, 661221) Q : Do you expect that every person should do all his work himself ?
('48', 299, 5, 15, 661290) A: I do not expect it and I do not think it practicable; Tolstoy too did not consider this essential.
('48', 299, 5, 16, 661392) Man’s dependence is no less than his independence.
('48', 299, 5, 17, 661443) So long as he remains in society, and remain he must, he has to curtail his independence to fit into that of others, that is, society.
('48', 299, 5, 18, 661578) Therefore it can only be said that each person, as far as it is possible, must do his work himself; that is to say, I may fill a mug for my use, but may not dig a well myself.
('48', 299, 5, 19, 661754) Not to fill the mug is pride; to plan or begin digging a well is stupidity.
('48', 299, 5, 20, 661830) One must, therefore, exercise discretion in deciding whether a task is to be done by oneself or with the help of others.
('48', 299, 6, 21, 661951) Q: Do you wish that all should earn their livelihood by the sweat of the brow ?
('48', 299, 6, 22, 662031) A: Certainly.
('48', 299, 6, 23, 662045) Everyone does not do so and that is why dire poverty has arisen in the world and especially so in India.
('48', 299, 6, 24, 662150) This is also the main cause of ill health and the immense greed for acquisition of wealth.
('48', 299, 6, 25, 662241) If all earned their livelihood by physical work, greed would decrease and much of the power to acquire wealth would weaken automatically.
('48', 299, 6, 26, 662379) If physical labour is done, ill health will almost disappear and the greatest gain will be the complete obliteration of the distinction between high and low in society.
('48', 299, 6, 27, 662548) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 6 2 1930
('48', 299, 7, 28, 662587) 1 Published serially in four consecutive issues of Hindi Navajivan
('48', 300, 0, 1, 662654) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 301
('48', 300, 1, 2, 662700) 311. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU

('48', 302, 1, 2, 665839) 315. A LETTER
('48', 302, 2, 3, 665853) February 8, 1930 Condemning the wicked does not necessarily betray want of moderation.
('48', 302, 2, 4, 665940) The condemnation is not of the wicked but of their wickedness.
('48', 302, 2, 5, 666003) We often criticize the English in strong language, but we never wish ill of them.
('48', 302, 2, 6, 666085) From that we claim that we condemn not the wicked but their wickedness.
('48', 302, 2, 7, 666157) As a matter of fact the word condem nation is wrongly used here.
('48', 302, 2, 8, 666222) There is no condemnation of the crow in calling it black, but there is of the swan in calling it black.
('48', 302, 2, 9, 666326) Saying that Yudhishthira resorted to falsehood on one occasion in his life is not to condemn him, but saying that he was a coward because he did not protect Draupadi when she was being disrobed is condemning him and shows one’s ignorance.
('48', 302, 2, 10, 666565) If you understand this distinction, my meaning, will become clear to you.
('48', 302, 2, 11, 666639) Bowing in respect both to the saintly and the unsaintly may be regarded as an explanatory comment on Chapter XVI of the Gita.
('48', 302, 2, 12, 666765) There the description of the demoniac nature was necessary in order to explain the meaning of the divine nature and show its excellence by contrast.
('48', 302, 3, 13, 666914) From the Gujarati original: Chhaganlal Gandhi Papers.
('48', 302, 3, 14, 666968) Courtesy: Sabarmati Sangrahalaya

('48', 302, 7, 22, 667291) From that, we can claim that the criticism is of wickedness and not that of the wicked.

('48', 303, 4, 8, 668303) 317. MY NOTES
('48', 303, 5, 9, 668317) OUR CARELESSNESS
('48', 303, 6, 10, 668334) A friend writes: 1
('48', 303, 7, 11, 668353) As has been stated above, there is no doubt that smokers transgress limits, and non smokers do not even attempt to prevent the former from smoking, out of shame or fear.
('48', 303, 7, 12, 668523) We no longer have such respect for women that in their presence we would not smoke, would not use obscene language or be guilty of any other discourteous conduct!
('48', 303, 7, 13, 668686) I cannot blame the railway servants in this matter.
('48', 303, 7, 14, 668738) What can they do when passengers themselves are indifferent to their own comforts?
('48', 303, 7, 15, 668821) We should bear in mind that these persons do not take up employment for the service of others.
('48', 303, 7, 16, 668916) Moreover, even in accordance with the law, they have no authority to prevent without reason any passenger from smoking.
('48', 303, 7, 17, 669036) This is because the regulations do not prohibit smoking under all circumstances, but only when one passenger objects to another doing so when the latter happens to be smoking in a compartment which is not meant for smokers.
('48', 303, 7, 18, 669260) How can an officer know whether or not a particular passenger has been asked not to smoke?
('48', 303, 7, 19, 669351) Hence so long as any passenger does not complain, the officer does not have the authority to prevent anyone from smoking.
('48', 303, 7, 20, 669473) Volunteers can render much assistance in this.
('48', 303, 7, 21, 669520) They can politely reason with smokers and, if the latter are not amenable to reason, they can complain to the officer and pull the alarm chain and stop the train.
('48', 303, 7, 22, 669683) But I would not advise them to do this.
('48', 303, 7, 23, 669723) Difficulties are bound to arise in trying all at once to enforce a regulation, enforcement of which has not been attempted since it was made.
('48', 303, 7, 24, 669865) Clashes too will arise.
('48', 303, 7, 25, 669889) Hence, for the present, the task of the volunteers consists in educating public opinion and in explaining to
('48', 303, 8, 26, 669998) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('48', 304, 0, 1, 670035) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 305
('48', 304, 1, 2, 670081) the non smokers their rights and to the smokers their limits.
('48', 304, 1, 3, 670143) When the passengers begin to understand this matter and the smokers realize that many people are inconvenienced by their smoking, it is possible that they will stop doing so.
('48', 304, 1, 4, 670318) Moreover, a satyagrahi volunteer will not as far as possible make anyone obey regulations by getting himpunished.
('48', 304, 1, 5, 670432) By trying to perform the duty of a policeman a reformer often fails to perform his own duty.
('48', 304, 1, 6, 670525) The dharma of a reformer lies in trying to bring about a change of heart in those who violate regulations.
('48', 304, 1, 7, 670632) In the beginning, patience is required for doing this but in the end the result endures and becomes widespread.
('48', 304, 1, 8, 670744) Despite this, where certain ill habits have taken root, the law where it prevails can be helpful in eradicating them.
('48', 304, 1, 9, 670862) This has happened in the past and will also happen in the future; for instance, the task of prohibition can be carried on very speedily if it is given the backing of law.
('48', 304, 1, 10, 671033) Those who are addicted to smoking have formed such an evil habit that they would seldom listen to anyone however courteously they may be approached.
('48', 304, 1, 11, 671182) For the enthusiastic volunteer, therefore, this is a fine occasion for testing his own forbearance and courtesy.
('48', 304, 1, 12, 671295) In doing so, the volunteers can also utilize this fine occasion for cultivating among the people respect towards women.
('48', 304, 1, 13, 671415) And, an attempt can be made to prevent those who create public nuisance just as those addicted to smoking keep doing so on all occasions without any consideration for the feelings of others.

('48', 305, 5, 12, 673416) 319. SPINNING WHEEL WITH TWO SPINDLES 3
('48', 305, 6, 13, 673456) I, too, believe that the speed of spinning can be much increased if the sliver is of a good quality.
('48', 305, 6, 14, 673557) I am a slow spinner.
('48', 305, 6, 15, 673578) Hitherto I could spin in an hour 160 rounds of 20 counts.
('48', 305, 6, 16, 673636) As the slivers I am at present using are good I am able to spin 200 rounds per hour without effort.
('48', 305, 6, 17, 673736) Good slivers are obtained when cotton pods are plucked by hand and are free from impurities, the cotton wool is ginned by hand so neatly that no seeds get crushed and mixed with the cotton and, finally, such cotton is carded carefully.

('48', 306, 0, 1, 674368) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 307
('48', 306, 1, 2, 674414) 320. VILLAGE ROADS 1
('48', 306, 2, 3, 674435) We have seen how to remove dung hills and prevent harm being done to the village health and to produce from it manure worth its weight in gold.
('48', 306, 2, 4, 674579) 2 We also saw how to increase village income without much hardship by not using cow dung for making dung cakes for fuel, but instead by producing manure from it.
('48', 306, 2, 5, 674741) Moreover we discussed how village health might be protected by cleaning wells and ponds and maintaining them clean.
('48', 306, 3, 6, 674857) Now let us consider village roads.
('48', 306, 3, 7, 674892) One glance at them tells us how tortuous they are.
('48', 306, 3, 8, 674943) They look like heaps of dust just levelled.
('48', 306, 3, 9, 674987) Great hardship is caused to men walking along the roads, as also to cattle drawing cart loads over them.
('48', 306, 3, 10, 675092) For use on such roads we have to build heavy carts with heavy wheels, with the result that the bullock is unnecessarily required to draw a double load.
('48', 306, 3, 11, 675244) To the hardship of the journey over roads full of dust heaps, we add the expense involved in having to draw heavy carts.
('48', 306, 3, 12, 675365) If the roads are metalled, the bullock would draw double the load ordinarily carried, the carts would be less expensive and the health of villagers would improve.
('48', 306, 3, 13, 675528) The present state of things illustrates the proverb, “Butter is given away with whey and, moreover, the giver is branded a slattern.” On these roads so much mud is formed in the rainy season that it gets highly difficult to drive the cart through it, and men have either to swim or walk waist deep in water.
('48', 306, 3, 14, 675836) And in addition, people get the gift of all kinds of diseases.
('48', 306, 3, 15, 675899) Where the village is an extended dung hill, where no one takes care of wells and ponds, where roads are what they were in Grandfather Adam’s days, how can the state of children be any better?
('48', 306, 3, 16, 676091) The behaviour of children, their culture—everything is bound to reflect the conditions of the village life.
('48', 306, 3, 17, 676199) A look at the children will show that they are cared for no better than the roads.
('48', 306, 3, 18, 676282) To speak of this now, however, would be to digress.
('48', 306, 3, 19, 676334) What, then, is to be done for these roads?
('48', 306, 3, 20, 676377) If the spirit of co operation prevails among the inhabitants, with no cost or with a little expense on account of gravel, etc., villagers can buildmetalled roads and add to the wealth of the village.
('48', 306, 3, 21, 676577) Moreover, both the young and the old would get true education free of charge through such co operative activity.
('48', 306, 3, 22, 676690) As far as possible, villagers should employ no labourers for any work.
('48', 306, 3, 23, 676761) The village inhabitants are mostly peasants
('48', 306, 4, 24, 676805) 1 This appeared in the supplement Shikshan ane Sahitya.
('48', 306, 4, 25, 676861) 2 Vide “Cowdung Cakes or Manure?”, 17 11 1929. 3 Vide “Wells and Ponds”, 12 1 1930.
('48', 307, 0, 1, 676945) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 307, 1, 2, 676987) and hence their own labourers.
('48', 307, 1, 3, 677018) When necessary they may ask their neighbours to help them.
('48', 307, 1, 4, 677077) By giving a little of their time to the roads daily, the village people would soon set their roads right.
('48', 307, 1, 5, 677183) To be able to do this, they should prepare a map of the village streets and also of the approach roads leading to neighbouring villages.
('48', 307, 1, 6, 677320) Then they should arrange a programme of work according to their capacity so that, men, women and children, all might participate to some extent.
('48', 307, 1, 7, 677465) The present state of our culture embraces family life only.
('48', 307, 1, 8, 677525) The improvement of villages depends upon an extension of the family feeling to the whole village.
('48', 307, 1, 9, 677623) The look of our villages would be a measure of our culture.
('48', 307, 1, 10, 677683) Just as every member in a family joins in keeping the home clean, every family should be prepared to do the same for the village.
('48', 307, 1, 11, 677813) Not until this is done can the village people live happily and become self reliant.
('48', 307, 1, 12, 677897) Today, however, we look up for everything to the Government—for clearing dung hills, for making the roads and keeping them in repair, for cleansing wells and ponds, for children’s education, for protection against wild animals, for protection of our property, etc.
('48', 307, 1, 13, 678162) This attitude of the mind has crippled and disabled us.
('48', 307, 1, 14, 678218) This helplessness goes on ever increasing and adds to the burden of taxes.
('48', 307, 1, 15, 678293) If all the villagers regard themselves answerable for the cleanliness, the neatness and the safety of the place they live in, most of the necessary improvement would take place immediately and almost without cost.
('48', 307, 1, 16, 678507) Moreover, with increased facilities for travel and transport and with improved health, the economic condition of the village would also improve.
('48', 307, 1, 17, 678652) Some application of intellect is certainly needed for cleaning the roads.
('48', 307, 1, 18, 678726) I have already spoken of the road map.
('48', 307, 1, 19, 678765) All the villages do not have the same kind of facilities for building good metalled roads.
('48', 307, 1, 20, 678856) Some villages may have stone, but in several regions of Bihar no amount of search would find any stone.
('48', 307, 1, 21, 678960) What ways should be adopted to make strong roads is left to the volunteers contemplated in this series of articles.
('48', 307, 1, 22, 679076) Let him go and examine the neighbourhood.
('48', 307, 1, 23, 679118) Let him see if there is anything worth learning from Government methods in the matter.
('48', 307, 1, 24, 679205) One could certainly adopt such Government methods for making strong roads as are suitable.
('48', 307, 1, 25, 679296) At times we might come across village elders who have much practical knowledge of suchmatters.
('48', 307, 1, 26, 679391) The village worker should have no hesitation in finding and using such talent in the countryside.
('48', 307, 1, 27, 679489) As in other matters, so in this one of making strong roads, let the village worker make a beginning by setting an example with his own personal labour.

('48', 309, 1, 2, 681205) 323. LETTER TO MANILAL KOTHARI
('48', 309, 2, 3, 681236) February 9, 1930
('48', 309, 3, 4, 681253) BHAISHRI MANILAL, .
('48', 309, 3, 5, 681273) 1 Shankerlal is not here at present.
('48', 309, 3, 6, 681310) It is within his authority to call for the figures you have asked for.
('48', 309, 3, 7, 681381) I have sent your letter to the Charkha Sangh office and asked for the figures.
('48', 309, 3, 8, 681460) But I am afraid you are unnecessarily prejudiced against Harjivan 2. Harjivan is an experienced man.
('48', 309, 3, 9, 681561) He has won the confidence of all his superiors.
('48', 309, 3, 10, 681609) He is a capable and self sacrificing worker.
('48', 309, 3, 11, 681654) He cannot take more profit and put it in a safe.
('48', 309, 3, 12, 681703) He keeps accurate accounts.
('48', 309, 3, 13, 681731) The Charkha Sangh has not accepted the policy of taking limited profit on all varieties of cloth, but has adopted the policy of limited profit on the total stock and permitted more profit on some special varieties of cloth because on some other varieties it takes even less than the permitted limited profit.
('48', 309, 3, 14, 682040) For instance, there should be no objection to taking 100 per cent profit on khadi lace, while on dhoti no profit need be taken or very little if at all.
('48', 309, 3, 15, 682193) Some things may even be sold at loss.
('48', 309, 3, 16, 682231) Business can be carried on only in this way.
('48', 309, 3, 17, 682276) Kashmiri items are made for luxury loving people like you and me, while the khadi sold in the general market is for persons who do not know patriotism but are forced to adopt simplicity.
('48', 309, 3, 18, 682463) Hence some of the things are sold even at a loss.

('48', 313, 3, 15, 690197) The points were mentioned in order to prevent the misconception that the Viceroy’s speech had given rise to.

('48', 313, 3, 19, 690564) Mere withdrawal of the English is not independence.
('48', 313, 3, 20, 690616) It means the consciousness in the average villager that he is the maker of his own destiny, he is his own legislator through his chosen representatives.
('48', 313, 3, 21, 690769) The eleven points are some of the vital tests of the villager’s authority.
('48', 313, 3, 22, 690844) The very letter of the Bezwada barrister shows how necessary it was to clear the issue.
('48', 313, 3, 23, 690932) By mentioning the eleven points I have given a body in part to the elusive word independence.
('48', 313, 3, 24, 691026) I should be prepared to reconsider my attitude towards the legislatures if the legislators can accomplish the things covered by the eleven points.
('48', 313, 3, 25, 691173) And if they are covered, I should have no hesitation in advising Congress representation at the Conference where independence could be made the basis.For I do conceive the possibility of a conference even for discussingan Independence Constitution.

('48', 314, 2, 13, 692847) 330. TREATMENT OF SMALLPOX
('48', 314, 3, 14, 692874) Friends have pressed me to publish the modes of the treatment of smallpox patients.
('48', 314, 3, 15, 692958) The Udyoga Mandir has not escaped the infection.
('48', 314, 3, 16, 693007) There have been in all seven cases in the Mandir.
('48', 314, 3, 17, 693057) One has proved fatal.
('48', 314, 3, 18, 693079) It is possible to say that that case was not treated like the rest.
('48', 314, 3, 19, 693147) It was an early case, and I feel guilty of having shown want of firmness.
('48', 314, 3, 20, 693221) Contrary to my conviction, the girl remained without hydropathic treatment and was permitted even to take solid food.
('48', 314, 3, 21, 693339) The treatment adopted in the cases that have recovered or that I hope will recover was: l.
('48', 314, 3, 22, 693430) Complete rest; 2. Free ventilation; 3. Light received through a red medium; 4. No solid food, and milk diluted with equal quantity of water when there was no fever; otherwise orange juice or dried grapes juice; 5 Occasional opening medicine and regular enema; 6. Wet sheet pack.
('48', 314, 3, 23, 693709) Rolling the patient in a sheet wrung out of cold water and put between blankets till perspiration.
('48', 314, 3, 24, 693808) During the 1915 epidemic I had two very serious cases of
('48', 315, 0, 1, 693865) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 315, 1, 2, 693907) confluent smallpox.
('48', 315, 1, 3, 693927) I knew nothing then of red light treatment.
('48', 315, 1, 4, 693971) In the 1916 cases the boys were given a bath daily with hot water in which neem leaves were boiled.
('48', 315, 1, 5, 694071) This was regarded by me somewhat a substitute for Condy’s fluid.
('48', 315, 1, 6, 694136) After convalescence the boys were stronger than before.
('48', 315, 1, 7, 694192) The treatment given in a book called Why Vaccinate by Harold W. Whiston, price 6d., published in Macclesfield by Claye, Brown and Claye is copied below.
('48', 315, 1, 8, 694345) 1 The book can be also had from the National Anti Vaccination League, 50 Parliament Street, London, S.W. I have no doubt that more people die of fright than of disease itself.
('48', 315, 1, 9, 694521) I notice this fright even in my children who, poor things, have been taught from childhood to dread the disease.
('48', 315, 1, 10, 694634) There is no reason whatsoever that smallpox is any more fatal than many other diseases.
('48', 315, 1, 11, 694722) Smallpox yields to nature’s treatment just as well as any other illness.
('48', 315, 1, 12, 694795) It is nature’s way of purging the body of latent poison.
('48', 315, 1, 13, 694852) In order to drive away the fright and to prevent simple people from rushing to the vaccination depot, I give the most salient passages from the book to show how unnecessary, even dangerous and filthy the practice of vaccination is.

('48', 317, 3, 15, 700176) 5. Is ‘soul’ something apart from ‘life’?
('48', 317, 3, 16, 700218) The answers are: 1. Man is a special creation of God precisely to the extent that he is distinct from the rest of His creation.
('48', 317, 3, 17, 700346) 2. The ‘Inner Voice’ may mean a message from God or from the Devil, for both are wrestling in the human breast.
('48', 317, 3, 18, 700458) Acts determine the nature of the voice.
('48', 317, 3, 19, 700498) 3. The most defenceless mouse struggles for liberty against his born enemy the cat who is armed to the teeth.
('48', 317, 3, 20, 700608) The mouse does not court ‘force’.
('48', 317, 3, 21, 700642) It is his nature to struggle though he knows that he will be worsted in the unequal contest.
('48', 317, 3, 22, 700735) It is only reserved for man to act less than the mouse, if it is also reserved for him to act infinitely better than the mouse by recognizing the inner power within him which has
('48', 317, 4, 23, 700914) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.

('48', 318, 1, 2, 701140) been known repeatedly to defy all the physical forces arrayed against it.

('48', 318, 1, 4, 701402) 4. Soul force begins when man recognizes that body force, be it ever so great, is nothing compared to the force of the soul within, which pervades not only him but all creation.

('48', 318, 2, 10, 701978) 332. VARNADHARMA AND DUTY OF LABOUR–II
('48', 318, 3, 11, 702017) QUESTION: Is not the division of labour under varnashrama dharma sufficient for the development and welfare of humanity?
('48', 318, 3, 12, 702138) Which do you value more—varnadharma or duty of labour?
('48', 318, 4, 13, 702193) ANSWER: The purport of this question is that varnadharma and duty of labour are incompatible obligations.
('48', 318, 4, 14, 702299) In fact they are not.
('48', 318, 4, 15, 702321) Both are concurrent and imperative.
('48', 318, 4, 16, 702357) Varnadharma pertains to the society and duty of labour pertains to the individual.
('48', 318, 4, 17, 702440) The sages divided society into four sections for its welfare and thereby attempted to root out rivalry which is fatal to society.
('48', 318, 4, 18, 702570) Therefore they made one varna responsible for the growth of knowledge in society, the second responsible for the protection of life and property in society, the third for trade in society, and the fourth for service to society.
('48', 318, 4, 19, 702798) All the four functions were and are equally essential; therefore there was no reason to consider one high and the other low.
('48', 318, 4, 20, 702923) Adverting to the equilibrium of scales Maharshi Vyas has indeed said that each individual by performing the duties of his own varna acquires fitness for salvation; whereas mutual rivalry and distinctions of high and low bring about ruin.
('48', 318, 4, 21, 703161) Varnadharma does not in the least imply that any Varian is exempt from manual labour.
('48', 318, 4, 22, 703247) The duty of labour is incumbent on every person belonging to every varna.
('48', 318, 4, 23, 703321) The Brahmin also had to approach his guru with firewood in his hands, that is to say, he also had to go into the forest and glean firewood and tend cattle.
('48', 318, 4, 24, 703477) This work he did for himself and his family, not for society.
('48', 318, 4, 25, 703539) Only children and cripples were exempt from such manual work.
('48', 319, 0, 1, 703601) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 319, 1, 2, 703643) The doctrine of manual labour for a living which Tolstoy has expounded is a corollary of the duty of labour.
('48', 319, 1, 3, 703752) Tolstoy felt that if everyone had to do manual work then it means that man must earn his bread by manual labour, never by mental work.
('48', 319, 1, 4, 703887) In varnadharma the work of each varna was for the welfare of society.
('48', 319, 1, 5, 703957) Livelihood was not the motive.
('48', 319, 1, 6, 703988) Gain or no gain, the Kshatriya had to defend the people.
('48', 319, 1, 7, 704045) The Brahmin had to impart knowledge whether he received alms or not.
('48', 319, 1, 8, 704114) The Vaishya had to farm and tend cattle whether he earned money or not.
('48', 319, 1, 9, 704186) But Tolstoy’s doctrine that every person must do manual work for a living is perfectly true.
('48', 319, 1, 10, 704279) We come across distressing disparities in the world today because this universal duty has beenneglected or forgotten.Disparitics will always be there, but like the several leaves of a tree they will look beautiful and pleasant.
('48', 319, 1, 11, 704507) In the pure varnadharma disparity is no doubt there, and when it was in its pure form, it was pleasing, peaceful and pretty.
('48', 319, 1, 12, 704632) But when several people use their talents for amassing wealth, distrassing disparities are created.
('48', 319, 1, 13, 704732) Just as, if a teacher (Brahmin), a soldier (Kshatriya), a businessman (Vaishya) and a carpenter (Shudra) follow their professions for amassing wealth, not for the welfare of society, then varnadharma is destroyed.
('48', 319, 1, 14, 704946) Because in matters of duty there can be no room for amassing In society there is need for lawyers doctors, soldiers and others.
('48', 319, 1, 15, 705074) But when they work for selfish ends they no longer are protectors of society but become parasites on sockt.
('48', 319, 1, 16, 705182) The Gita III, 10 has expounded a great principle where it says: Together with sacrifice did the Lord of beings create, of old, mankind, declaring: “By this shall ye increase; may this be to you the giver of all your desires.:’ Now we can clearly comprehend the etymology of the word yajna.
('48', 319, 1, 17, 705472) The meaning of yajna is manual work and this is the first and foremost act of worship of God.
('48', 319, 1, 18, 705566) He has given us bodies.
('48', 319, 1, 19, 705590) Without food the body cannot exit and without labour food cannot be produced.
('48', 319, 1, 20, 705668) That is why manual labour has become a universal duty.
('48', 319, 1, 21, 705723) This duty of labour is not Tolstoy’s alone but of the whole world.
('48', 319, 1, 22, 705790) Ignorance of this great yajna has led to the worship of mammon in the world and intelligent people have used their talents to exploit others.
('48', 319, 1, 23, 705932) It is clear that God is not covetous.
('48', 319, 1, 24, 705970) Being all powerful, He creates every day only as much food as is sufficient for every human being or living creature.
('48', 319, 1, 25, 706088) Not knowing this great truth, several people indulge in all kinds of luxuries and thereby starve many others.
('48', 319, 1, 26, 706198) If they could give up this greed and work for their living, and eat enough to meet their needs, the poverty that we find today will vanish.
('48', 319, 1, 27, 706338) I hope the
('48', 320, 0, 1, 706349) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 321
('48', 320, 1, 2, 706395) interrogator would now see that varnadharma and duty of labour are concurrent, complementary and essential.
('48', 320, 1, 3, 706503) [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 13 2 1930

('48', 326, 2, 5, 716222) 343. ‘NEVER FAILETH’
('48', 326, 4, 6, 716243) ‘HATE DISSOLVES IN THE PRESENCE OF LOVE.’
('48', 326, 5, 7, 716285) In the opinion of the Working Committee civil disobedience should be initiated and controlled by those who believe in non violence for the purpose of achieving purna swaraj as an article of faith, and as the Congress contains in its organization not merely such men and women, but also those who accept non violence as a policy essential in the existing circumstances in the country, the Working Committee welcomes the proposal of Mahatma Gandhi and authorizes him and those working with him who believe in non violence as an article of faith to the extent above indicated to start civil disobedience as and when they desire and in the manner and to the extent they decide.
('48', 326, 5, 8, 716959) The Working Committee trusts that when the campaign is actually in action all Congressmen and others will extend to the civil resisters their full co operation in every way possible, and that they will observe and preserve complete non violence notwithstanding any provocation that may be offered.
('48', 326, 5, 9, 717257) The Working Committee further hopes that in the event of a mass movement taking place, all those who are rendering voluntary co operation to the Government, such as lawyers, and those who are receiving so called benefits from it, such as students, will withdraw their co operation or renounce benefits as the case may be, and throw themselves into the final struggle for freedom.
('48', 326, 5, 10, 717637) The Working Committee trusts, that in the event of the leaders being arrested and imprisoned, those who are left behind and have the spirit of sacrifice and service in them, will carry on the Congress organization, and guide the movement to the best of their ability.
('48', 326, 5, 11, 717905) This resolution 2 of the Working Committee gives me my charter of freedom if it also binds me in the tightest chains.
('48', 326, 5, 12, 718023) It is the formula of which I have been in search these long and weary months.
('48', 326, 5, 13, 718101) For me the resolution is not so much a political as a religious effort.
('48', 326, 5, 14, 718173) My difficulty was fundamental.
('48', 326, 5, 15, 718204) I saw that I could not work out ahimsa through an organization holding a variety of mentalities.
('48', 326, 5, 16, 718301) It could not be subject to the decision of majorities.
('48', 326, 5, 17, 718356) To be consistent with itself, it might have to be inconsistent with the whole world.
('48', 326, 5, 18, 718441) A person who has a choice before him is ever exposed to temptation.
('48', 326, 5, 19, 718509) The instinct of those therefore, with whom non violence is
('48', 326, 6, 20, 718568) 1 Patanjali’s Yogadarshanam, ii.
('48', 326, 6, 21, 718601) 35 2 Adopted on February 15, 1930 at Ahmedabad
('48', 327, 0, 1, 718648) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 327, 1, 2, 718690) a policy, when tempted by violence, may fail them.
('48', 327, 1, 3, 718741) That of those who have no remedy but non violence open to them can never fail them if they have non violence in them in reality.
('48', 327, 1, 4, 718870) Hence the necessity for freedom from Congress control.
('48', 327, 1, 5, 718925) And I was thankful that the members of the Working Committee saw the utter correctness of my position.
('48', 327, 1, 6, 719028) It is to be hoped, that no one will misunderstand the position.
('48', 327, 1, 7, 719092) Here there is no question of superiority.
('48', 327, 1, 8, 719134) Those, who hold non violence for the attainment of freedom as an article of faith, are in no way superior to those with whom it is a mere policy, even as there is no such inequality between brown men and yellow men.
('48', 327, 1, 9, 719350) Each acts according to his lights.
('48', 327, 1, 10, 719385) The responsibility devolving on me is the greatest I have ever undertaken.
('48', 327, 1, 11, 719460) It was irresistible.
('48', 327, 1, 12, 719481) But all will be well, if it is ahimsa that is guiding me.
('48', 327, 1, 13, 719539) For the seer who knew what he gave to the world has said, ‘Hate dissolves in the presence of ahimsa.’ The true rendering of the word in English is love or charity.
('48', 327, 1, 14, 719703) And does not the Bible say: Love worketh no ill to his neighbour, Believeth all things, Hopeth all things, Never faileth.
('48', 327, 2, 15, 719825) Civil disobedience is sometimes a peremptory demand of love.
('48', 327, 2, 16, 719886) Dangerous it undoubtedly is, but no more than the encircling violence.
('48', 327, 2, 17, 719957) Civil disobedience is the only non violent escape from its soul destroying heat.
('48', 327, 2, 18, 720038) The danger lies only in one direction, in the outbreak of violence side by the side with civil disobedience.
('48', 327, 2, 19, 720147) If it does I know now the way; not the retracing as at the time of Bardoli.
('48', 327, 2, 20, 720223) The struggle, in freedom’s battle, of non violence against violence, no matter from what quarter the latter comes, must continue till a single representative is left alive.
('48', 327, 2, 21, 720396) More no man can do, to do less would be tantamount to want of faith.
('48', 327, 2, 22, 720465) Young India, 20 2 1930
('48', 327, 3, 23, 720488) 344. SOME QUESTIONS
('48', 327, 4, 24, 720508) With reference to the imminent civil disobedience some pertinent questions have been put by friends as well as critics.
('48', 327, 4, 25, 720628) These need answering.
('48', 327, 5, 26, 720650) Q. Surely you are not so impatient as to start your campaign without letting the authorities know your plans and giving them an opportunity of meeting you and arresting you?
('48', 327, 5, 27, 720824) A. Those who know my past should know that I hold it to be
('48', 327, 6, 28, 720883) 1 I Corinthians, xiii

('48', 328, 1, 2, 720951) contrary to satyagraha to do anything secretly or impatiently.

('48', 328, 2, 5, 721168) Q. Did you not say even at Lahore that the country was not prepared for civil disobedience, especially no tax campaign on a mass scale?
('48', 328, 2, 6, 721304) A. I am not even now sure that it is.
('48', 328, 2, 7, 721342) But it has become clear to me as never before that the unpreparedness in the sense that a non violent atmosphere is wanting will, as time goes by, very likely increase as it has been increasing all these years.
('48', 328, 2, 8, 721553) Young men are impatient.
('48', 328, 2, 9, 721578) I know definitely many stayed their violent designs because in 1921 the Congress had decided to offer civil disobedience.
('48', 328, 2, 10, 721700) That school has been more active than before because of my repeated declarations that the country was not prepared for civil disobedience.
('48', 328, 2, 11, 721839) I feel then that if non violence is an active force, as I know it is, it should work even in the face of the most violent atmosphere.
('48', 328, 2, 12, 721973) One difficulty in the way was that the Congress claiming to represent the whole nation could not very well offer civil disobedience and disown responsibility for violence especially by Congressmen.
('48', 328, 2, 13, 722171) I have procured discharge from that limitation by taking over the responsibility for launching on civil disobedience.
('48', 328, 2, 14, 722289) I represent no one but myself and at the most those whom I may enroll for the campaign.

('48', 328, 2, 16, 722522) It is true that I may not shirk responsibility indirectly for any violence that may break out on the part of the nation and in the course of the campaign.

('48', 328, 2, 18, 722918) For instance I give my co operation by paying taxes direct or indirect.
('48', 328, 2, 19, 722990) The very salt I eat compels my voluntary co operation.
('48', 328, 2, 20, 723045) Moreover it has dawned on me never so plainly as now that if my non violence has suffered the greatest incarnation of violence which the British imperialistic rule is, it must suffer the crude and ineffective violence of the impatient patriots who know not that by their ineffectiveness they are but helping that imperialistic rule and enabling it to consolidate the very thing they seek to destroy.
('48', 328, 2, 21, 723445) I see now as clearly as daylight that my non violence working as it has done against the British misrule has shaken it somewhat.

('48', 329, 1, 4, 724000) It is indeed ‘the last throw of a gambler’.

('48', 329, 1, 6, 724081) In my passion for finding the truth and in relentlessly following out my faith in non violence, I have counted no stake too great.
('48', 329, 1, 7, 724212) In doing so I have erred, if at all, in the company of the most distinguished scientist of any age and any clime.

('48', 329, 2, 11, 724499) I do not want independence at the cost even of the weakest minority, let alone the powerful Mussalman and the no less powerful Sikh.
('48', 329, 2, 12, 724632) The Lahore Congress resolution on unity 1 finally sums up all its previous effort in that behalf.
