('48', 331, 1, 2, 729141) 345. ‘BUCCAANEERING COMMISSION’ 1
('48', 331, 2, 3, 729175) As the public have a short memory, I reproduce below the two Congress resolutions which have been defended by Professor Coomarappa and which have been so misrepresented here and abroad: GAYA CONGRESS RESOLUTION (1922)
('48', 331, 3, 4, 729393) Whereas by reason of unjustifiable military expenditure and other extravagance, the Government has brought the national indebtedness to a limit beyond recovery, and whereas the Government still pursues the same policy of extravagance under cover of the authority of the so called representative assemblies constituted without the suffrage of a majority or any substantial fraction of the voters and despite their declared repudiation of the authority of such assemblies to represent the people: And whereas if the Government is permitted to continue this policy, it will become impossible for the people of India ever to carry on their own affairs with due regard to the honour and happiness of the people, and it has therefore become necessary to stop the career of irresponsibility: This Congress hereby repudiates the authority of the legislatures that have been or may be formed by the Government in spite of the national boycott of the said institutions in future to raise loans or to incur any liabilities on behalf of the nation, and notifies to the world that on the attainment of swarajya the people of India, though holding themselves liable for all debts and liabilities rightly or wrongly incurred hitherto by the Government, will not hold themselves bound to repay any loans or discharge any liabilities incurred on and after this date on the authority or sanction of the so called legislatures brought into existence in spite of the national boycott.
('48', 331, 3, 5, 730858) LAHORE CONGRESS RESOLUTION 2 (1929) The Gaya resolution is surely innocuous and even charitable at the expense of posterity, in that it makes the people liable for the then existing debts whether ‘rightly or wrongly incurred’.
('48', 331, 3, 6, 731085) The Lahore resolution undoes the mistake, and adopts the honourable and usual method of submitting all accounts, past, present and future when the time comes, to the scrutiny of an impartial tribunal.
('48', 331, 3, 7, 731286) What happens when an institution or a business passes from one steward to another?
('48', 331, 4, 8, 731369) 1 In this article to which Gandhiji appended his comments, J. C. Coomarappa had explained how the people of India had been burdened with debts by the British Government to the tune of over £200 million—all by unjust transactions—and had invited the readers’ attention to the resolution on the subject passed at the Gaya and Lahore Congresses.
('48', 331, 4, 9, 731712) 2 Not reproduced here.
('48', 332, 0, 1, 731735) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 333
('48', 332, 1, 2, 731781) Does not the outgoing steward render accounts to the incoming one?
('48', 332, 1, 3, 731848) Are not those accounts subject to scrutiny?
('48', 332, 1, 4, 731892) The future national Government will betray its trust at the very threshold of its career, if it fails to perform the obvious duty of submitting to the strictest scrutiny all the obligations it may take over.
('48', 332, 1, 5, 732100) If Great Britain and India are then solvent, no investor need fear the loss of a penny or a pice.

('48', 332, 3, 13, 732801) ‘NO SURRENDER’
('48', 332, 4, 14, 732816) Here are the choicest bits from Northcliffe House just received: .
('48', 332, 4, 15, 732883) Politicians must for ever drop their gibberish about Dominion Home Rule for the Eastern Empire.
('48', 332, 4, 16, 732979) Those of them who persist in toying with so fatal a policy must be remorselessly driven from public life.
('48', 332, 4, 17, 733085) The retention of India is more important to the welfare of Great Britain than tariffs or any other political question.
('48', 332, 4, 18, 733204) That country may fairly be described as the very keystone of the Empire.
('48', 332, 4, 19, 733277) Its trade is vital to our people.
('48', 332, 4, 20, 733311) The total loss of the Indian market would mean bankruptcy for Lancashire and misery for her industrial workers.
('48', 332, 4, 21, 733423) In the last year for which figures are available British exports to India were £; 83,900,000 in value (one ninth of our total exports), and there is no other country or territory, British or foreign, which takes anything like that amount of British goods.
('48', 332, 4, 22, 733679) This trade it is the deliberate purpose of the revolutionaries to destroy if they get the chance.
('48', 332, 4, 23, 733777) British investments in India reach the enormous figure of £1,000,000,000, according to evidence given before the Simon Commi ssion.
('48', 332, 4, 24, 733909) Again, it is the declared intention of the revolutionaries to repudiate the Indian debt and to confiscate the plantations and factories which British capital has created on Indian soil.
('48', 332, 4, 25, 734095) From the loss of such a sum Great Britain could never recover.
('48', 332, 4, 26, 734158) The policy of surrender in India has got to slop.
('48', 332, 4, 27, 734208) There are two courses, and only two.
('48', 332, 4, 28, 734245) The first is to get out and hand over the country to the Princes, who would pretty quickly settle the Hindu lawyers of the All India Congress.
('48', 332, 4, 29, 734388) The second is to stay in India and govern.
('48', 332, 4, 30, 734431) That second course is the one which this country will take.

('48', 334, 1, 2, 736939) 347. VARNADHARMA AND DUTY OF LABOUR III
('48', 334, 2, 3, 736979) Q. It is of course good to find the virtues of all the four varnas in any one individual but can the majority of human beings acquire them all and is it proper to place this ideal before society?
('48', 334, 2, 4, 737175) A. Many virtues and functions are common to all varnas and ought to be so; but it is neither necessary nor possible for everyone to have all the virtues of all the varnas.
('48', 334, 3, 5, 737347) Q. If Tolstoy’s duty of labour is universally accepted will it not be difficult for poets like Kabir and Rabindra to live in this world?
('48', 334, 3, 6, 737484) And would this not be a misfortune for the world?
('48', 334, 3, 7, 737534) A. Acceptance of the duty of labour is not a denial of Kabir and Rabindranath; on the other hand it is capable of making the poetry of both more forceful and radiant.
('48', 334, 3, 8, 737701) Manual labour does not weaken the mental faculty; on the contrary it nourishes it.
('48', 334, 3, 9, 737784) The difference merely is that the votary of manual labour will never earn a living by only writing poetry nor will he give up manual labour altogether.
('48', 334, 3, 10, 737936) Kabir was of course an advocate of manual labour.
('48', 334, 3, 11, 737986) He never earned a penny by composing religious songs and hymns.
('48', 334, 3, 12, 738050) He earned his living as a weaver of cloth.
('48', 334, 3, 13, 738093) Propagation of religion and morality had become his nature or hobby.
('48', 334, 3, 14, 738162) Rabindranath is a great poet of this age because he does not earn his living by writing poetry.
('48', 334, 3, 15, 738258) Whatever he earns by writing poetry is all donated to his institution.
('48', 334, 3, 16, 738329) He lives by the income from his estates.
('48', 334, 3, 17, 738370) I do not know how far he believes in the duty of labour; this I do know that he certainly does not despise it.
('48', 334, 3, 18, 738481) We learn from history that ancient poets or sages had accepted the duty of labour even if it might have been implicitly.
('48', 334, 3, 19, 738602) As a result their benedictions are with us even today.
('48', 334, 4, 20, 738657) Q. According to the doctrine of the duty of labour, Jesus, Buddha and Tolstoy himself are blameworthy.
('48', 334, 4, 21, 738760) Tolstoy’s wife herself has said that beyond writing books he could do nothing else.
('48', 334, 4, 22, 738844) He might have learnt carpentry and some other manual work only to become a laughing stock; but this does not satisfy Tolstoy’s concept of the duty of labour.
('48', 334, 4, 23, 739002) Is it not therefore necessary to examine it very carefully?
('48', 334, 5, 24, 739062) A. This view takes no note of history.
('48', 334, 5, 25, 739101) Jesus was a carpenter.
('48', 334, 5, 26, 739124) He never used his intellect to earn his livelihood.
('48', 334, 5, 27, 739176) We do not know how much manual work Buddha did before he attained wisdom.
('48', 334, 5, 28, 739250) Yes, we know this much, that he did not propagate religion for securing his livelihood.
('48', 334, 5, 29, 739338) He lived on charity.
('48', 334, 5, 30, 739359) That could not militate against the duty of labour.
('48', 334, 5, 31, 739411) A roving ascetic has to do a lot of manual work.
('48', 334, 5, 32, 739460) Now, to come to Tostoy, what his wife has said is true but it is not the whole truth.
('48', 334, 5, 33, 739546) After the change in his outlook Tostoy never took for himself the income from his books.
('48', 334, 5, 34, 739635) Although he had property worth millions, he lived like a guest in his own house.
('48', 334, 5, 35, 739716) After the attainment of wisdom,
('48', 335, 0, 1, 739748) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 335, 1, 2, 739790) he worked eight hours a day and earned his wages.
('48', 335, 1, 3, 739840) Sometimes he worked in the field and sometimes he made shoes at home.
('48', 335, 1, 4, 739910) Although he did not earn much by doing such work, still he earned enough to feed himself.
('48', 335, 1, 5, 740000) Tolstoy strove hard to practise what hepreached.
('48', 335, 1, 6, 740049) This was characteristic of him.
('48', 335, 1, 7, 740081) The sum and substance of all this discussion is that the duty which the ancients observed themselves and which the majority in the world discharges even today has been presented to the world in an explicit manner by him.
('48', 335, 1, 8, 740302) In fact this doctrine was not Tolstoy’s original idea; it was thought of by a great Russian writer by name Bondoref.
('48', 335, 1, 9, 740419) Tolstoy endorsed it and proclaimed it to the world.

('48', 337, 5, 18, 743819) 352. LETTER TO KISHORELAL MASHRUWALA
('48', 337, 6, 19, 743856) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 22, 1930
('48', 337, 7, 20, 743893) KISHORELAL, All the three types of people mentioned by you can join this struggle.
('48', 337, 7, 21, 743976) But discussing these distinctions in Navajivan at present is likely to confuse people’s minds.
('48', 337, 7, 22, 744071) I think everyone has understood the broad meaning of the Working Committee’s resolution.
('48', 337, 7, 23, 744160) Almost all men and women here have sent in their names.
('48', 337, 7, 24, 744216) All of them cannot understand the distinctions suggested by you.
('48', 337, 7, 25, 744281) But I think they all have faith in non violence and understand that no Englishman should be harmed or permitted to be harmed in any way.
('48', 337, 7, 26, 744418) They believe in non violence not as an expedient but as a creed.
('48', 337, 7, 27, 744483) Who can say how far their ahimsa will endure when the testing time comes?
('48', 337, 7, 28, 744557) What can we say even about you and me?
('48', 337, 7, 29, 744596) Peter who was as hard as stone turned out to be soft as wax at the moment of crisis.
('48', 337, 7, 30, 744681) And those two women who were only guided by their faith remained as firm as rock.
('48', 337, 7, 31, 744763) If you have any questions pertaining to the articles I am writing these days, do place them before me.
('48', 337, 7, 32, 744866) Read the rules about satyagraha carefully and
('48', 338, 0, 1, 744912) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 339
('48', 338, 1, 2, 744958) let me know if you notice any omission in them.
('48', 338, 1, 3, 745006) And now for the monthly periods.
('48', 338, 1, 4, 745039) A couple of women who had not during their periods joined others for meals for fear of criticism followed Mirabehn’s example and joined.
('48', 338, 1, 5, 745176) That gave rise to some discussion.
('48', 338, 1, 6, 745211) The matter had been settled earlier.
('48', 338, 1, 7, 745248) It had been agreed that any woman who, like Mirabehn, wished to join others for meals during her periods could do so.
('48', 338, 1, 8, 745366) She must observe three rules: she should not enter the kitchen for the four days of menses; even from outside the kitchen she should not look at the food being cooked or at the water used for cooking; she should not touch the cooked food.
('48', 338, 1, 9, 745605) This decision was arrived at after correspondence with Nathji through Panditji.
('48', 338, 1, 10, 745685) But a couple of women were in panic after a woman in menses had joined at the meals.
('48', 338, 1, 11, 745770) Therefore, benefiting from Nathji’s presence the conditions necessary for preserving the sacredness of mantras have been ascertained and clarified.
('48', 338, 1, 12, 745918) We have among theinmates some persons who practise mantras and such persons also constantly visit the Ashram.
('48', 338, 1, 13, 746028) I believe that it is the duty of the Ashram for the sake of such persons to observe as fully as possible the conditions for preserving the sacredness of the mantras.
('48', 338, 1, 14, 746194) If I can understand the purpose of the conditions better, I shall help in their still stricter observance.
('48', 338, 1, 15, 746301) I had asked Ramniklal to get one or two points clarified by Nathji.
('48', 338, 1, 16, 746369) But he does not seem to have been able to do so.
('48', 338, 1, 17, 746418) Is milk polluted by the look or touch of a woman in menses?
('48', 338, 1, 18, 746478) From the papers I have with me it seems that it is polluted by touch.
('48', 338, 1, 19, 746548) In Nath’s opinion, even if a person practising mantras does not know that a particular sample of milk has been touched by a woman in menses, the fact of the touch itself has the power of nullifying the effect of the mantra, to some extent at least.
('48', 338, 1, 20, 746797) This means that a person practising mantras should practically live without milk, because whether in the Ashram or outside, particularly outside, women in menses do happen to look at milk.
('48', 338, 1, 21, 746986) We can think of hundreds of ways of milk being polluted by look.
('48', 338, 1, 22, 747051) Hence the question of milk needs to be carefully considered.
('48', 338, 1, 23, 747112) I understand that uncooked grain is not polluted either by touch or look.
('48', 338, 1, 24, 747186) Is it not the same with regard to ghee and oil?
('48', 338, 1, 25, 747234) At what stage can look or touch affect water?
('48', 338, 1, 26, 747280) For I understand that the water meant for cooking is affected both by look and touch.
('48', 338, 1, 27, 747366) Nath says from experience that cooked food is affected both by the look and the touch of the woman in menses.
('48', 338, 1, 28, 747476) But he is not able to explain the reason.
('48', 338, 1, 29, 747518) Have you thought about the reason?
('48', 338, 1, 30, 747553) If you have, send me your opinion on it and also on the other questions above after discussing them with Nathji or independently if you can.

('48', 339, 6, 12, 748233) 354. SOME RULES OF SATYAGRAHA 1
('48', 339, 7, 13, 748265) Satyagraha literally means insistence on truth.
('48', 339, 7, 14, 748313) This insistence arms the votary with matchless power.
('48', 339, 7, 15, 748367) This power or force is connoted by the word satyagraha.
('48', 339, 7, 16, 748423) Satyagraha, to be genuine, may be offered against parents, against one’s wife or one’s children, against rulers, against fellow citizens, even against the whole world.
('48', 339, 7, 17, 748591) Such a universal force necessarily makes no distinction between kinsmen and strangers, young and old, man and woman, friend and foe.
('48', 339, 7, 18, 748724) The force to be so applied can never be physical.
('48', 339, 7, 19, 748774) There is in it no room for violence.
('48', 339, 7, 20, 748811) The only force of universal application can, therefore, be that of ahimsa or love.
('48', 339, 7, 21, 748894) In other words it is soul force.
('48', 339, 7, 22, 748927) Love does not burn others, it burns itself.
('48', 339, 7, 23, 748971) Therefore, a satyagrahi, i.e., a civil resister will joyfully suffer even unto death.
('48', 339, 7, 24, 749057) It follows, therefore, that a civil resister, whilst he will strain every nerve to compass the end of the existing rule, will do no intentional injury in thought, word or deed to the person of a single Englishman.
('48', 339, 7, 25, 749271) This necessarily brief explanation of satyagraha will perhaps enable the reader to understand and appreciate the following rules:
('48', 339, 8, 26, 749401) AS AN INDIVIDUAL
('48', 339, 9, 27, 749418) 1. A satyagrahi, i.e., a civil resister will harbour no anger.
('48', 339, 9, 28, 749481) 2. He will suffer the anger of the opponent.
('48', 339, 10, 29, 749526) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 23 2 1930.
('48', 340, 0, 1, 749592) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 341
('48', 340, 1, 2, 749638) 3. In so doing he will put up with assaults from the opponent, never retaliate; but he will not submit, out of fear of punishment or the like, to any order given in anger.
('48', 340, 1, 3, 749810) 4. When any person in authority seeks to arrest a civil resister, he will voluntarily submit to the arrest, and he will not resist the attachment or removal of his own property, if any, when it is sought to be confiscated by authorities.
('48', 340, 1, 4, 750048) 5. If a civil resister has any property in his possession as a trustee, he will refuse to surrender it, even though in defending it he might lose his life.
('48', 340, 1, 5, 750204) He will, however, never retaliate.
('48', 340, 1, 6, 750239) 6. Non retaliation excludes swearing and cursing.
('48', 340, 1, 7, 750289) 7. Therefore a civil resister will never insult his opponent, and therefore also not take part in many of the newly coined cries which are contrary to the spirit of ahimsa.
('48', 340, 1, 8, 750462) 8. A civil resister will not salute the Union Jack, nor will he insult it or officials, English or Indian.
('48', 340, 1, 9, 750569) 9. In the course of the struggle if anyone insults an official or commits an assault upon him, a civil resister will protect such official or officials from the insult or attack even at the risk of his life.
('48', 340, 2, 10, 750777) AS A PRISONER 10. As a prisoner, a civil resister will behave courteously towards prison officials, and will observe all such discipline of the prison as is not contrary to self respect; as for instance, whilst he will salaam officials in the usual manner, he will not perform any humiliating gyrations and refuse to shout ‘Victory to Sarkar 1’ or the like.
('48', 340, 2, 11, 751135) He will take cleanly cooked and cleanly served food, which is not contrary to his religion, and will refuse to take food insultingly served or served in unclean vessels.
('48', 340, 2, 12, 751305) 11. A civil resister will make no distinction between an ordinary prisoner and himself, will in no way regard himself as superior to the rest, nor will he ask for any conveniences that may not be necessary for keeping his body in good health and condition.
('48', 340, 2, 13, 751562) He is entitled to ask for such conveniences as may be required for his physical or spiritual well being.
('48', 340, 2, 14, 751667) 12. A civil resister may not fast for want of conveniences whose deprivation does not involve any injury to one’s self respect.
('48', 340, 3, 15, 751795) AS A UNIT
('48', 340, 4, 16, 751805) 13. A civil resister will joyfully obey all the orders issued by the leader of the corps, whether they please him or not.
('48', 340, 5, 17, 751927) 1 Government
('48', 341, 0, 1, 751940) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 341, 1, 2, 751982) 14. He will carry out orders in the first instance even though they appear to him insulting, inimical or foolish, and then appeal to higher authority.
('48', 341, 1, 3, 752133) He is free before joining to determine the fitness of the corps to satisfy him, but after he has joined it, it becomes a duty to submit to its discipline irksome or otherwise.
('48', 341, 1, 4, 752309) If the sum total of the energy of the corps appears to a member to be improper or immoral, he has a right to sever his connection, but being within it, he has no right to commit a breach of its discipline.
('48', 341, 1, 5, 752515) 15. No civil resister is to expect maintenance for his dependents.
('48', 341, 1, 6, 752582) It would be an accident if any such provision is made.
('48', 341, 1, 7, 752637) A civil resister entrusts his dependents to the care of God.
('48', 341, 1, 8, 752698) Even in ordinary warfare wherein hundreds of thousands give themselves up to it, they are able to make no previous provision.
('48', 341, 1, 9, 752824) How much more,then, should such be the case in satyagraha?
('48', 341, 1, 10, 752883) It is the universal experience that in such times hardly anybody is left to starve.
('48', 341, 2, 11, 752967) IN COMMUNAL FIGHTS
('48', 341, 3, 12, 752986) 16. No civil resister will intentionally become a cause of communal quarrels.
('48', 341, 3, 13, 753064) 17. In the event of any such outbreak, he will not take sides, but he will assist only that party which is demonstrably in the right.
('48', 341, 3, 14, 753198) Being a Hindu he will be generous towards Mussalmans and others, and will sacrifice himself in the attempt to save non Hindus from a Hindu attack.
('48', 341, 3, 15, 753345) And if the attack is from the other side, he will not participate in any retaliation but will give his life in protecting Hindus.
('48', 341, 3, 16, 753475) 18. He will, to the best of his ability, avoid every occasion that may give rise to communal quarrels.
('48', 341, 3, 17, 753578) 19. If there is a procession of satyagrahis they will do nothing that would wound the religious susceptibilities of any community, and they will not take part in any other processions that are likely to wound such susceptibilities.
('48', 341, 3, 18, 753810) Young India, 27 2 1930
('48', 341, 4, 19, 753833) 355. TO CONTRIBUTORS AND CORRESPONDENTS
('48', 341, 5, 20, 753873) An article with the caption “Plight of Women” 1 was published on p.
('48', 341, 5, 21, 753941) 125 of Navajivan, dated December 15, 1929. I was taken in by the correspondent having given names, addresses and other details.
('48', 341, 5, 22, 754069) I took the writer to be entirely truthful.
('48', 341, 5, 23, 754112) Now, from the facts supplied to me in this matter, I find that the letter was full of exaggeration and was
('48', 341, 6, 24, 754219) 1Vide “Plight of Women”, 15 12 1929.
('48', 342, 0, 1, 754256) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 343
('48', 342, 1, 2, 754302) libellous.
('48', 342, 1, 3, 754313) The truth has been so twisted in the presentation that the chief actor in the incident comes out as cruelty incarnate.
('48', 342, 1, 4, 754432) The information now reaching me puts the whole incident in a different light.
('48', 342, 1, 5, 754510) However, I do not desire to go into the details of the case.
('48', 342, 1, 6, 754571) My aim in writing this is to request correspondents to give facts only.
('48', 342, 1, 7, 754643) Exaggeration does not help improvement in any way or anywhere.
('48', 342, 1, 8, 754706) I advise the correspondent who wrote the original letter to apologize to the person whom he has slandered for the exaggeration he has made.
('48', 342, 1, 9, 754846) If he still desires to adhere to his statement, he should write to me permitting me to send his letter to the persons concerned.
('48', 342, 1, 10, 754975) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 23 2 1930

('48', 345, 8, 20, 759013) 364. WHEN I AM ARRESTED
('48', 345, 9, 21, 759037) It must be taken for granted that, when civil disobedience is started, my arrest is a certainty.
('48', 345, 9, 22, 759134) It is, therefore, necessary to consider what should be done when the event takes place.
('48', 345, 9, 23, 759222) On the eve of my arrest in 1922 2 I had warned co workers
('48', 345, 10, 24, 759280) 1 From the postmark 2 Vide “Message to the Public”, 9 3 1922 & “Message to the Country”, 18 3 1924.
('48', 346, 0, 1, 759380) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 347
('48', 346, 1, 2, 759426) against any demonstration of any kind save that of mute, complete non violence, and had insisted that constructive work which alone could organize the country for civil disobedience should be prosecuted with the utmost zeal.
('48', 346, 1, 3, 759651) The first part of the instructions was, thanks be to God, literally and completely carried out —so completely that it has enabled an English noble contemptuously to say, ‘Not a dog barked.’ For me when I learnt in the jail that the country had remained absolutely non violent, it was a demonstration that the preaching of non violence had had its effect and that the Bardoli decision 1 was the wisest thing to do.
('48', 346, 1, 4, 760065) It would be foolish to speculate what might have happened if ‘dogs’ had barked and violence had been let loose on my arrest.
('48', 346, 1, 5, 760190) One thing, however, I can say, that in that event there would have been no independence resolution at Lahore, and no Gandhi with his confidence in the power of non violence left to contemplate taking the boldest risks imaginable.
('48', 346, 1, 6, 760420) Let us, however, think of the immediate future.
('48', 346, 1, 7, 760468) This time on my arrest there is to be no mute, passive non violence, but non violence of the activest type should be set in motion, so that not a single believer in non violence as an article of faith for the purpose of achieving India’s goal should find himself free or alive at the end of the effort to submit any longer to the existing slavery.
('48', 346, 1, 8, 760816) It would be, therefore, the duty of everyone to take up such civil disobedience or civil resistance as may be advised and conducted by my successor, or as might be taken up by the Congress.
('48', 346, 1, 9, 761006) I must confess, that at the present moment, I have no all India successor in view.
('48', 346, 1, 10, 761089) But I have sufficient faith in the co workers and in the mission itself to know that circumstances will give the successor.
('48', 346, 1, 11, 761213) This peremptory condition must be patent to all that he must be an out and out believer in the efficacy of non violence for the purpose intended.

('48', 348, 1, 2, 765096) 365. SALT AND CANCER
('48', 348, 2, 3, 765117) I gladly publish this letter 1. I have glanced at the literature.
('48', 348, 2, 4, 765183) As an ardent food reformer I have lived without any salt for over six years.
('48', 348, 2, 5, 765260) Even now I take very little salt internally.
('48', 348, 2, 6, 765305) But even a food reformer like me has many other uses of salt.
('48', 348, 2, 7, 765367) To cure a cold, a hot salt water nasal douche is effective.
('48', 348, 2, 8, 765427) As a tooth powder, finely powderedsalt is precious.
('48', 348, 2, 9, 765479) The way to teach people moderation in salt is not to tax that otherwise most valuable commodity.
('48', 348, 2, 10, 765576) And above all what is true of well fed or overfed people, who can provide for themselves every variety of condiment and salt charged foods that the earth can produce or the ingenuity of man can manufacture, may not be true of millions who are semi starved and live on rice or stale unleavened cakes.
('48', 348, 2, 11, 765876) Who can say with certainty that these do not need much more salt than they get?
('48', 348, 2, 12, 765956) At any rate there are doctors who do say that India’s millions need more salt than they eat, and that her cattle too need much more than the poor farmers can afford to give them.

('48', 348, 3, 14, 766158) 366. SALT TAX
('48', 348, 4, 15, 766172) A paragraph appeared in the Press that I would advise non payment of the salt tax to begin with.
('48', 348, 4, 16, 766269) The manufacturer of the canard did not know, perhaps, that the salt tax was so ingeniously devised that it would not yield to easy non payment.
('48', 348, 4, 17, 766413) Nevertheless there was this truth in it, that I was contemplating some method of attacking this nefarious monopoly.
('48', 348, 4, 18, 766529) The garbled report has however resulted in most valuable information having been supplied to me by known and unknown writers.
('48', 348, 4, 19, 766655) Among the publications thus received is the monograph issued by the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce on salt.
('48', 348, 4, 20, 766774) It is a valuable publication giving an authentic history of the process of killing by wicked methods salt manufacture in Bengal and dumping down Liverpool salt on a soil which could produce good salt for only a little labour.
('48', 348, 4, 21, 767000) This history of the evolution of the salt tax furnishes by itself complete condemnation of the British Government.
('48', 348, 4, 22, 767115) Next to air and water, salt is perhaps the greatest necessity of
('48', 348, 5, 23, 767180) 1 From Frederick T. Marwood, not reproduced here.

('48', 349, 1, 2, 767427) It is the only condiment of the poor.
('48', 349, 1, 3, 767465) Cattle cannot live without salt.
('48', 349, 1, 4, 767498) Salt is a necessary article in many manufactures.
('48', 349, 1, 5, 767548) It is also a rich manure.
('48', 349, 1, 6, 767574) There is no article like salt outside water by taxing which the State can reach even the starving millions, the sick, the maimed and the utterly helpless.
('48', 349, 1, 7, 767729) The tax constitutes therefore the most inhuman poll tax that ingenuity of man can devise.

('48', 349, 1, 9, 767860) is according to Government publications as low as 10 pies, and the tax, say, twenty annas, i.e., 240 pies.
('48', 349, 1, 10, 767967) This means 2,400 per cent on sale price!
('48', 349, 1, 11, 768008) What this means to the poor can hardly beimagined by us.
('48', 349, 1, 12, 768065) Salt production like cotton growing has been centralized for the sake of sustaining the inhuman monopoly.
('48', 349, 1, 13, 768171) The necessary consequence of the wilful destruction of the spinning wheel was destruction of cottage cultivation of cotton.
('48', 349, 1, 14, 768295) The necessary consequence of salt monopoly was the destruction, i.e., closing down of salt works in thousands of places where the poor people manufactured their own salt.
('48', 349, 1, 15, 768466) A correspondent writes to me from Konkan, saying that if the people had freedom, they could pick up salt from the deposits made by the receding tides on the bountiful coast.
('48', 349, 1, 16, 768640) But he sorrowfully adds that officers turn the salt over into the sea as fast as nature deposits it.
('48', 349, 1, 17, 768741) He adds however, that those who can successfully evade the salt police do help themselves to this sea salt.
('48', 349, 1, 18, 768849) Gujarat workers report the existence of many places where, but for the prohibition, people can get their salt as easily as they can dig out earth for many household purposes.
('48', 349, 1, 19, 769024) Bengal free can today manufacture all the salt she can ever need.
('48', 349, 1, 20, 769090) And yet she is forced to import all the salt she eats.
('48', 349, 1, 21, 769145) Here is what a retired salt officer writes without disclosing his name: Under the law the manufacture of salt includes every process by which salt is separated from brine or earth or any other liquid or solid substance and also every process for the purification or refinement of salt.
('48', 349, 1, 22, 769431) Contraband salt means salt or salt earth which has not paid duty.
('48', 349, 1, 23, 769497) 1. Manufacture, removal, or transport of salt without licence; 2. The excavation, collection, or removal of natural salt or salt earth; 3. And possession or sale of contraband salt are punishable with a fine up to Rs. 500 or imprisonment up to six months or both.
('48', 349, 1, 24, 769761) The whole western littoral of the Bombay Presidency from Cambay to Ratnagiri; the whole coast of Kathiawar and the southern coast of Sind is a huge natural salt work, and natural salt and salt earth from which salt can be easily prepared is in every creek.

('48', 352, 5, 18, 776689) Postage and railage will be reduced.
('48', 352, 5, 19, 776726) The promises are admirable, but extravagant and hardly likely to be fulfilled by the mere fact of India gaining independence.

('48', 354, 1, 2, 779580) 370. KHADDAR FRANCHISE
('48', 354, 2, 3, 779603) The clause in the Congress constitution requiring Congressmen to wear hand spun and hand woven garments on pain of being debarred from voting at meetings continues to cause trouble.
('48', 354, 2, 4, 779785) A correspondent writes: These Congress members, though they are clad top to toe in foreign and Indian mill made garments, do not hesitate to say when questioned that to the best of their ability and knowledge they are dressed in khaddar garments.
('48', 354, 2, 5, 780032) In the face of Pandit Motilalji’s decision at Calcutta the chairmen at Congress Committee meetings feel obliged to accept such Statements though they are manifestly false.
('48', 354, 2, 6, 780204) Honest men who when challenged admit that they are not dressed in khaddar are debarred.
('48', 354, 2, 7, 780292) Can you not show a way out, or cannot the Working Committee provide a remedy?
('48', 354, 2, 8, 780370) The remedy that comes to me on the spur of the moment is that the chairmen at such meetings should firmly rule out of order those who are manifestly clad in any but khaddar garments.
('48', 354, 2, 9, 780553) Pandit Motilalji’s decision was given, I imagine, to obviate a difficulty.
('48', 354, 2, 10, 780628) It establishes no precedent, and he will himself refuse to be bound by a decision which was neither serious nor considered.
('48', 354, 2, 11, 780752) On the eve of the great struggle that we are about to enter upon, it behoves all Congressmen to carry out the Congress constitution honestly.
('48', 354, 2, 12, 780894) Those who do not like the khaddar clause are free to agitate for its repeal but they are in honour bound to give effect to it while it forms part of the constitution.
('48', 354, 2, 13, 781061) Another correspondent asks questions which present no difficulty.
('48', 354, 2, 14, 781127) The following answers obviate the necessity of copying the questions: 1. No one at the time of becoming a four anna member is obliged to wear khaddar.
('48', 354, 2, 15, 781278) The idea behind the wording of the clause was first to enlist everyone who would subscribe to the 1st article and pay 4 annas or the required quantity of self spun yarn and then to induce him to wear khaddar.
('48', 354, 2, 16, 781487) 2. Those who are entitled to vote at meetings must be habitual wearers of khaddar.
('48', 354, 2, 17, 781570) It is not enough therefore to wear khaddar only for the purpose of attending Congress functions.
('48', 354, 2, 18, 781667) But the practice has grown up of not making any further inquiry when a person attending any meeting is found to be wearing khaddar.
('48', 354, 2, 19, 781799) 3. Those who are partly dressed in khaddar cannot be considered khaddar clad.
('48', 354, 2, 20, 781877) 4. Mill made cloth is not khaddar.
('48', 354, 2, 21, 781912) Young India, 27 2 1930

('48', 356, 1, 2, 784270) 373. VARNADHARMA AND DUTY OF LABOUR IV
('48', 356, 2, 3, 784309) Q. Tolstoy has written “Money and slavery are one and the same thing.
('48', 356, 2, 4, 784379) Their object is the same and their outcome is also alike.
('48', 356, 2, 5, 784437) Money is a new and frightful image of slavery and like the ancient personal bondage, it degrades and depraves the slave as well as the master.
('48', 356, 2, 6, 784580) That is not all.
('48', 356, 2, 7, 784597) It is worse; because it destroys the human affection which subsisted between master and slave in the ancient form of personal slavery.”
('48', 356, 3, 8, 784733) Do you support this view?
('48', 356, 3, 9, 784759) Can money never become a harmless medium of exchange?
('48', 356, 3, 10, 784813) If so, how?
('48', 356, 3, 11, 784825) and if not, why not?
('48', 356, 4, 12, 784846) A. I am not aware that Tolstoy wrote what the questioner quotes as the former’s statement.
('48', 356, 4, 13, 784937) Slavery and money do not belong to the same class and therefore they cannot be compared.
('48', 356, 4, 14, 785026) Slavery is a status and always abhorrent.
('48', 356, 4, 15, 785068) Money is only a medium for one’s dealings with the world.
('48', 356, 4, 16, 785126) However powerful a medium it may be, it is just as likely to be beneficial as to be harmful.
('48', 356, 4, 17, 785219) This same can be said of many other material things.
('48', 356, 4, 18, 785272) Under every circumstance and in some form or other, the need for money will surely exist.
('48', 356, 4, 19, 785362) Slavery never was and never could be necessary.
('48', 356, 4, 20, 785410) We must understand the meaning of money here.
('48', 356, 4, 21, 785456) When I barter grain for shoes, then, as the grain is the medium of exchange for shoes, it becomes money.
('48', 356, 4, 22, 785561) But because barter by grain becomes difficult for a large number of people, a bit of metal or paper is used to represent it.
('48', 356, 4, 23, 785686) This metal or paper is money.
('48', 356, 4, 24, 785716) There can be no objection to this.
('48', 356, 4, 25, 785751) But when a person hoards such paper, metal or grain beyond his needs, it leads to evil.
('48', 356, 4, 26, 785839) It is therefore clear that money by itself is not harmful, but greed for it is harmful.
('48', 356, 4, 27, 785927) As opposed to this, slavery is a sign of greed.
('48', 356, 4, 28, 785975) It is wrong and greedy to make a man a slave, but possession of money becomes wrong only when it is held in excess.
('48', 356, 4, 29, 786091) However, the man who believes in varanadharma is contented and therefore will not be greedy of wealth.
('48', 356, 4, 30, 786194) And the man who believes in the duty of labour will never make another a slave, [From Hindi] Hindi Navajivan, 27 2 1930

('48', 360, 1, 2, 791030) 379. TWO LETTERS A young man writes: 1
('48', 360, 2, 3, 791069) Not all parents are like this.
('48', 360, 2, 4, 791100) Here is a letter 2 that a mother wrote to her son at the Gujarat Vidyapith, who was wanting to join the satyagraha movement.
('48', 360, 2, 5, 791225) This mother deserves congratulations.
('48', 360, 2, 6, 791263) If India has many such mothers, our struggle will end successfully and quickly.
('48', 360, 2, 7, 791343) Fortunately, the number of such parents is well on the increase.
('48', 360, 2, 8, 791408) There are two well to do girls whose parents, too, have given them full encouragement and put no restrictions on their self disciplined freedom.
('48', 360, 2, 9, 791553) I have intentionally used here the adjective “self disciplined” before “freedom” to suggest that freedom can be either self disciplined or self willed.
('48', 360, 2, 10, 791705) Where there is opposition to one’s good intentions, as in the case of this young man, from one’s father or teacher, one should, if one is an adult son or daughter over sixteen years of age, first humbly try to persuade the elders concerned, and then respectfully disobey their order or their will.
('48', 360, 2, 11, 792003) That is the clear duty of the son or the daughter in a situation like this.
('48', 360, 2, 12, 792079) If the son’s description of his father in the letter above is true and if the latter recognizes himself as the father referred to, I would request him to honour the khadi he wears, give his blessings to the son and encourage him in his idea of self sacrifice.
('48', 360, 2, 13, 792339) The father should also discard both tea and the thermos.
('48', 360, 2, 14, 792396) Tea is never a necessity of life, and a thing like a thermos has no place in his poor home.
('48', 360, 2, 15, 792488) I have no prejudice against such foreign articles as are needed for maintaining one’s health or for similar uses.
('48', 360, 2, 16, 792602) However, to decide what is essential is a matter to which considerable thought should always be given.
('48', 360, 2, 17, 792705) It is not enough to wear khadi.
('48', 360, 2, 18, 792737) The wearer should also realize that khadi symbolizes the spirit of patriotism and modesty.
('48', 360, 2, 19, 792828) Wearing khadi does not give one the licence to enjoy all kinds of liberty, but is the first step in the direction of self restraint and a sign of our desire to curtail other unnecessary freedoms.
('48', 360, 2, 20, 793024) I shall show here a cheap, indigenous way of preserving the temperature of hot water or any similar drink.
('48', 360, 2, 21, 793131) If hot water or a similar drink is put in a vessel that can be closed tight, and if the vessel is then wrapped up on all sides in a woollen blanket or in cotton and kept inside a chest or box, the drink will preserve its temperature for twenty four hours.

('48', 361, 1, 2, 793759) 380. LETTER TO LORD IRWIN
('48', 361, 2, 3, 793785) SATYAGRHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 2, 1930 DEAR FRIEND, Before embarking on civil disobedience and taking the risk I have dreaded to take all these years, I would fain approach you and find a way out.
('48', 361, 2, 4, 793986) My personal faith is absolutely clear.
('48', 361, 2, 5, 794025) I cannot intentionally hurt anything that lives, much less fellow human beings, even though they may do the greatest wrong to me and mine.
('48', 361, 2, 6, 794164) Whilst, therefore, I hold the British rule to be a curse, I do not intend harm to a single Englishman or to any legitimate interest he may have in India.
('48', 361, 2, 7, 794318) I must not be misunderstood.
('48', 361, 2, 8, 794347) Though I hold the British rule in India to be a curse, I do not, therefore, consider Englishmenin general to be worse than any other people on earth I have the privilege of claiming many Englishmen as dearest friends.
('48', 361, 2, 9, 794565) Indeed much that I have learnt of the evil of British rule is due to the writings of frank and courageous Englishmen who have not hesitated to tell the unpalatable truth about that rule.
('48', 361, 2, 10, 794752) And why do I regard the British rule as a curse?
('48', 361, 2, 11, 794801) It has impoverished the dumb millions by a system of progressive exploitation and by a ruinously expensive military and civil administration which the country can never afford.
('48', 361, 2, 12, 794978) It has reduced us politically to serfdom.
('48', 361, 2, 13, 795020) It has sapped the foundations of our culture.
('48', 361, 2, 14, 795066) And, by the policy of cruel disarmament, it has degraded us spiritually.
('48', 361, 2, 15, 795139) Lacking the inward strength, we have been reduced, by all but universal disarmament, to a state bordering on cowardly helplessness.
('48', 361, 2, 16, 795271) In common with many of my countrymen, I had hugged the fond hope that the proposed Round Table Conference might furnish a solution.
('48', 361, 2, 17, 795403) But, when you said plainly that you could not give any assurance that you or the British Cabinet would pledge yourselves to support a scheme of full Dominion Status, the Round Table Conference could not possibly furnish the solution for which vocal India is consciously, and the dumb millions are unconsciously, thirsting.
('48', 361, 2, 18, 795726) Needless to say there never was any question of Parliament’s verdict being anticipated.
('48', 361, 2, 19, 795814) Instances are not wanting of the British Cabinet, in anticipation of the Parliamentary verdict, having pledged itself to a particular policy.
('48', 362, 0, 1, 795956) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 363
('48', 362, 1, 2, 796002) The Delhi interview 1 having miscarried, there was no option for Pandit Motilal Nehru and me but to take steps to carry out the solemn resolution of the Congress arrived at in Calcutta at its Session in 1928. 2
('48', 362, 2, 3, 796213) But the Resolution of Independence 3 should cause no alarm, if the word Dominion Status mentioned in your announcement had been used in its accepted sense.
('48', 362, 2, 4, 796369) For, has it not been admitted by responsible British statesmen that Dominion Status is virtual Independence?
('48', 362, 2, 5, 796478) What, however, I fear is that there never has been any intention of granting such Dominion Status to India in the immediate future.
('48', 362, 2, 6, 796610) But this is all past history.
('48', 362, 2, 7, 796640) Since the announcement many events have happened which show unmistakably the trend of British policy.
('48', 362, 2, 8, 796742) It seems as clear as daylight that responsible British statesmen do not contemplate any alteration in British policy that might adversely affect Britain’s commerce with India or require an impartial and close scrutiny of Britain’s transactions with India.
('48', 362, 2, 9, 796998) If nothing is done to end the process of exploitation India must be bled with an ever increasing speed.
('48', 362, 2, 10, 797102) The Finance Member regards as a settled fact the 1/6 ratio which by a stroke of the pen drains India of a few crores.
('48', 362, 2, 11, 797220) And when a serious attempt is being made through a civil form of direct action, to unsettle this fact, among many others, even you cannot help appealing to the wealthy landed classes to help you to crush that attempt in the name of an order that grinds India to atoms.
('48', 362, 2, 12, 797489) Unless those who work in the name of the nation understand and keep before all concerned the motive that lies behind the craving for independence, there is every danger of independence coming to us so changed as to be of no value to those toiling voiceless millions for whom it is sought and for whom it is worth taking.
('48', 362, 2, 13, 797810) It is for that reason that I have been recently telling the public what independence should really mean.
('48', 362, 2, 14, 797915) Let me put before you some of the salient points.
('48', 362, 2, 15, 797965) The terrific pressure of land revenue, which furnishes a large part of the total, must undergo considerable modification in an independent India.
('48', 362, 2, 16, 798111) Even the much vaunted permanent settlement benefits the few rich zamindars, not the ryots.
('48', 362, 2, 17, 798202) The ryot has remained as helpless as ever.
('48', 362, 2, 18, 798245) He is a mere tenant at will.
('48', 362, 2, 19, 798274) Not only, then, has the
('48', 362, 3, 20, 798298) 1 Which took place on December 23, 1929. 2 Vide “Speech on Resolution on Nehru Report, Calcutta Congress I”, 26 12 1928. 3 The resolution referred to is the Congress resolution passed at Lahore in 1929. Vide “Speech at Subjects Committee, A.I.C.C.”, 27 12 1929.
('48', 363, 0, 1, 798560) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 363, 1, 2, 798602) land revenue to be considerably reduced, but the whole revenue system has to be so revised as to make the ryot’s good its primary concern.
('48', 363, 1, 3, 798741) But the British system seems to be designed to crush the very life out of him.
('48', 363, 1, 4, 798820) Even the salt he must use to live is so taxed as to make the burden fall heaviest on him, if only because of the heartless impartiality of it incidence.
('48', 363, 1, 5, 798973) The tax shows itself still more burdensome on the poor man when it is remembered that salt is the one thing he must eat more than the rich man both individually and collectively.
('48', 363, 1, 6, 799152) The drink and drug revenue, too, is derived from the poor.
('48', 363, 1, 7, 799211) It saps the foundations both of their health and morals.
('48', 363, 1, 8, 799268) It is defended under the false plea of individual freedom, but, in reality, is maintained for its own sake.
('48', 363, 1, 9, 799376) The ingenuity of the authors of the reforms of 1919 transferred this revenue to the so called responsible part of dyarchy, so as to throw the burden of prohibition on it, thus, from the very beginning, rendering it powerless for good.

('48', 363, 1, 11, 799953) The tale of India’s ruination is not complete without reference to the liabilities incurred in her name.
('48', 363, 1, 12, 800058) Sufficient has been recently said about these in the public Press.
('48', 363, 1, 13, 800125) It must be the duty of a free India to subject all the liabilities to the strictest investigation, and repudiate those that may be adjudged by an impartial tribunal to be unjust and unfair.
('48', 363, 1, 14, 800315) The iniquities sampled above are maintained in order to carry on a foreign administration, demonstrably the most expensive in the world.
('48', 363, 1, 15, 800452) Take your own salary.
('48', 363, 1, 16, 800474) It is over Rs. 21,000 per month, besides many other indirect additions.
('48', 363, 1, 17, 800546) The British Prime Minister gets £ 5,000 per year, i.e., over Rs. 5,400 per month at the present rate of exchange.
('48', 363, 1, 18, 800660) You are getting over Rs. 700 per day against India’s average income of less than annas 2 per day.
('48', 363, 1, 19, 800758) The Prime Minister gets Rs. 180 per day against Great Britain’s average income of nearly Rs. 2 per day.
('48', 363, 1, 20, 800862) Thus you are getting much over five thousand times India’s average income.
('48', 363, 1, 21, 800937) The British Prime Minister is getting only ninety times Britain’s average income.
('48', 363, 1, 22, 801019) On bended knees I ask you to ponder over this phenomenon.
('48', 363, 1, 23, 801077) I have taken a personal illustration to drive home a painful truth.
('48', 363, 1, 24, 801145) I have too great a regard for you as a man to wish to hurt your feelings.
('48', 363, 1, 25, 801219) I know that you do not need the salary you get.
('48', 363, 1, 26, 801267) Probably the whole of your salary goes for charity.
('48', 363, 1, 27, 801319) But a system that provides for such an arrangement deserves to be summarily scrapped.
('48', 363, 1, 28, 801405) What is true of the Viceregal salary is true generally of the whole administration.
('48', 364, 0, 1, 801489) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 365
('48', 364, 1, 2, 801535) A radical cutting down of the revenue, therefore, depends upon an equally radical reduction in the expenses of the administration.
('48', 364, 1, 3, 801666) This means a transformation of the scheme of government.
('48', 364, 1, 4, 801723) This transformation is impossible without independence.
('48', 364, 1, 5, 801779) Hence, in my opinion, the spontaneous demonstration of 26th January, in which hundreds of thousands of villagers instinctively participated.
('48', 364, 1, 6, 801920) To them independence means deliverance from the killing weight.
('48', 364, 1, 7, 801984) Not one of the great British political parties, it seems to me, is prepared to give up the Indian spoils to which Great Britain helps herself from day to day, often, in spite of the unanimous opposition of Indian opinion.
('48', 364, 1, 8, 802206) Nevertheless, if India is to live as a nation, if the slow death by starvation of her people is to stop, some remedy must be found for immediate relief.
('48', 364, 1, 9, 802359) The proposed Conference is certainly not the remedy.
('48', 364, 1, 10, 802412) It is not a matter of carrying conviction by argument.
('48', 364, 1, 11, 802467) The matter resolves itself into one of matching forces.
('48', 364, 1, 12, 802523) Conviction or no conviction, Great Britain would defend her Indian commerce and interests by all the forces at her command.
('48', 364, 1, 13, 802647) India must consequently evolve force enough to free herself from that embrace of death.
('48', 364, 1, 14, 802735) It is common cause that, however disorganized and, for the time being, insignificant it may be, the party of violence is gaining ground and making itself felt.
('48', 364, 1, 15, 802895) Its end is the same as mine.
('48', 364, 1, 16, 802924) But I am convinced that it cannot bring the desired relief to the dumb millions.
('48', 364, 1, 17, 803005) And the conviction is growing deeper and deeper in me that nothing but unadulterated non violence can check the organized violence of the British Government.
('48', 364, 1, 18, 803163) Many think that non violence is not an active force.
('48', 364, 1, 19, 803216) My experience, limited though it undoubtedly is, shows that non violence can be an intensely active force.
('48', 364, 1, 20, 803323) It is my purpose to set in motion that force as well against the organized violent force of the British rule as [against] the unorganized violent force of the growing party of violence.
('48', 364, 1, 21, 803509) To sit still would be to give rein to both the forces above mentioned.
('48', 364, 1, 22, 803580) Having an unquestioning and immovable faith in the efficacy of non violence as I know it, it would be sinful on my part to wait any longer.
('48', 364, 1, 23, 803720) This non violence will be expressed through civil disobedience, for the moment confined to the inmates of the Satyagraha Ashram, but ultimately designed to cover all those who choose to join the movement with its obvious limitations.
('48', 364, 1, 24, 803954) I know that in embarking on non violence I shall be running what might fairly be termed a mad risk.
('48', 364, 1, 25, 804054) But the victories of truth have never been won without risks, often of the gravest character.
('48', 364, 1, 26, 804148) Conversion of a nation that has consciously or unconsciously preyed
('48', 365, 0, 1, 804216) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 365, 1, 2, 804258) upon another, far more numerous, far more ancient and no less cultured than itself, is worth any amount of risk.
('48', 365, 1, 3, 804371) I have deliberately used the word “conversion”.
('48', 365, 1, 4, 804419) For my ambition is no less than to convert the British people through non violence, and thus make them see the wrong they have done to India.
('48', 365, 1, 5, 804561) I do not seek to harm your people.

('48', 367, 1, 2, 809501) understand fully the meaning of the saptapadi vow and preserve it in practice in your life.
('48', 367, 1, 3, 809593) In this vow, the bride and the bridegroom promise to be each other’s friends; but their friendship is real only if they try to remedy each other’s defects and to strengthen their own virtues.
('48', 367, 1, 4, 809785) The cause of the attachment and aversion we see in the world is people’s habit of observing one another’s defects.
('48', 367, 1, 5, 809900) Those whoseonly aim is enjoyment in life are bound to be filled with such feelings.
('48', 367, 1, 6, 809984) I should, therefore, like to see a bond of friendship between husband and wife, instead of one of sensual enjoyment.
('48', 367, 1, 7, 810101) I know that it is difficult to cultivate such a relationship, but nothing is too difficult for determined effort.
('48', 367, 1, 8, 810215) The vow requires the bride to say that the bridegroom is her guru and her god.

('48', 367, 1, 10, 810427) I intend to omit the words ‘guru’ and ‘god’ in future, because it is not right that a husband should regard himself as a guru or god.
('48', 367, 1, 11, 810561) Anyone who serves another does become a guru or god without his claiming to be one.

('48', 370, 1, 2, 816742) 385. LETTER TO MANMOHANDAS P. GANDHI March 3, 1930 BHAISHRI MANMOHANDAS, I got both the books sent by you.
('48', 370, 1, 3, 816849) You already see that I have been using the book on the subject of salt.
('48', 370, 1, 4, 816921) If you have this further information, send it to me; if you don’t have it, please get it for me.
('48', 370, 1, 5, 817018) What is the expenditure incurred on the collection of the salt tax?
('48', 370, 1, 6, 817086) Some say it is eight per cent and some that it is twenty per cent.Compare the percentage of expenditure on this tax with the percentage of expenditure on other taxes.
('48', 370, 1, 7, 817253) If you have a copy of the latest Administration Report on salt, send it to me.
('48', 370, 1, 8, 817332) If you have no spare copy, I will return it to you.
('48', 370, 1, 9, 817384) Send me any other information which you think will be useful to me.
('48', 370, 1, 10, 817452) Now about your book on cotton.
('48', 370, 1, 11, 817483) I have been reading it.
('48', 370, 1, 12, 817507) But I may point out two errors just now.
('48', 370, 1, 13, 817548) You say that formerly weaving and spinning were probably independent professions and not subsidiary occupations.
('48', 370, 1, 14, 817661) Weaving and spinning are two independent activities.
('48', 370, 1, 15, 817714) Weaving was (chiefly) an independent profession and is so even today.
('48', 370, 1, 16, 817784) That spinning, on the other hand, has always been (chiefly) a subsidiary occupation we can prove with thousands of instances even today.
('48', 370, 1, 17, 817921) The individuals were alive when the movement for the revival of spinning started in 1919. This is an important distinction, and so you must have seen that your error is a serious one.
('48', 370, 1, 18, 818105) This error will continue to be made in the absence of personal knowledge of the facts.
('48', 370, 1, 19, 818192) Even writers who have gone deeper than you have committed it.
('48', 370, 1, 20, 818254) But that defence will not serve an humble student.
('48', 370, 1, 21, 818305) The second error is this.
('48', 370, 1, 22, 818331) Writing about the Mogul period you say that there were then such frequent and widespread massacres that no profession could flourish.
('48', 370, 1, 23, 818465) There are two errors in this view.
('48', 370, 1, 24, 818500) Such massacres were never widespread.
('48', 370, 1, 25, 818538) Before Akbar, no Muslim ruler had entered villages.
('48', 370, 1, 26, 818590) The massacres always took place in cities and there, too, they had little effect on the artisan classes.
('48', 370, 1, 27, 818695) Even today we see these classes going on with their occupations under this anarchical rule.
('48', 370, 1, 28, 818787) Formerly, the government touched the lives of only those who were connected with the administrative machinery.
('48', 370, 1, 29, 818898) It is only in the present age that governments have become eager to extend their grip over entire populations.
('48', 370, 1, 30, 819009) And, among them all, the British Government has acquired the utmost efficiency in this.
('48', 370, 1, 31, 819097) It is this efficiency which is ruining us, for British rule is inspired by no philanthropic motives.

('48', 373, 1, 2, 822688) 390. PENAL SECTIONS OF THE SALT ACT The following sections 1 copied or abridged from the Bombay Salt Act and the Indian Salt Act will show the design underlying their operation.
('48', 373, 1, 3, 822866) The Bombay Act is a refined reproduction of the India Act of 1882. Most of the penal sections of the Bombay Act show a stiffening of the original which evidently experience of administration had shown to be necessary.
('48', 373, 1, 4, 823084) Only one section has been taken from the central Act.
('48', 373, 1, 5, 823138) The reader will not fail to notice a strange section which makes “cowardice” on the part of the salt revenue officers a crime punishable with imprisonment extending to three months.
('48', 373, 1, 6, 823320) The word “cowardice” is not defined.
('48', 373, 1, 7, 823357) But the reader with an imagination will have no difficulty in understanding what cowardice can possibly meanin the administration of an Act which takes in its sweep millions of human beings, men and women, young and old, cripples and healthy.
('48', 373, 1, 8, 823600) Young India, 6 3 1930
('48', 373, 2, 9, 823622) 391. PUBLIC DEBT ANALYSED Sjt.
('48', 373, 2, 10, 823653) Haridas Muzumdar has prepared a note on Public Debt.
('48', 373, 2, 11, 823706) I give below the following condensation 2 which will assist the reader to know what this debt is.
('48', 373, 2, 12, 823804) Young India, 6 3 1930
('48', 373, 3, 13, 823826) 392. ABOUT THAT LETTER My letter to the Viceroy went on the 2nd instant as anticipated by the newspapers.
('48', 373, 3, 14, 823932) Forecasts have been published of its contents which are largely untrue.
('48', 373, 3, 15, 824004) I wish these correspondents and the news agencies will, instead of making the publication of news a matter merely of making money, think of the public good.
('48', 373, 3, 16, 824161) If there had been anything to give to the public, surely Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru would have given it.
('48', 373, 3, 17, 824263) But it was thought advisable to wait for an acknowledgement from Delhi before publishing the letter.
('48', 373, 3, 18, 824364) I am not intent on a fight.
('48', 373, 3, 19, 824392) I am leaving no stone unturned to avoid it.

('48', 374, 1, 3, 825304) I know that mine is a voice in the wilderness, though I speak with the authority of an unbroken experience of practical journalism for over twenty years, if successful conducting of four weeklies 1 can be regarded as such.Be that as it may, the imminent fight includes among the points of attack this slavish habit of copying everything English.

('48', 374, 1, 9, 826197) On the eve of battle therefore I would warn fellow journalists against copying the English method of obtaining and publishing news.
('48', 374, 1, 10, 826329) Let them study my original method which was introduced long before I became a Mahatma and before I had acquired any status of importance in the public life of India.
('48', 374, 1, 11, 826495) It was a hard struggle, but I found in the field of journalism as in many others that the strictest honesty and fair dealing was undoubtedly the best policy.
('48', 374, 1, 12, 826653) Any shorter cut is longer at least by double the length sought to be saved.
('48', 374, 1, 13, 826729) For there must be a retracing.
('48', 374, 1, 14, 826760) I say all this not for the sake of reading a lesson to fellow journalists but for the sake of the struggle in which I would value the co operation of journalists whether they approve of or oppose my methods of political warfare.
('48', 374, 1, 15, 826989) Let them not add to the risks I am already taking.
('48', 374, 1, 16, 827040) The rule I would like them to observe is never to publish any news without having it checked by someone connected with me and having authority.

('48', 374, 1, 18, 827367) The messenger selected was a young English friend Reginald Reynolds who came to India some months ago and who has identified himself completely with the Indian cause.
('48', 374, 1, 19, 827534) For me the sending of the letter was a religious act as the whole struggle is.
('48', 374, 1, 20, 827613) And I selected an English friend as my messenger, because I wanted to forge a further check upon myself against any intentional act that would hurt a single Englishman.
('48', 374, 1, 21, 827782) If I have any sense of honour in me, this choice should prove an automatic restraint even upon unconscious error.
('48', 374, 1, 22, 827896) It pleases me also to have the unselfish and unsolicited association of a cultured, well read,

('48', 375, 4, 16, 829141) The system of education is responsible for the lack of character wherever it shows itself.
('48', 375, 4, 17, 829232) The remedy now is not to seek my opinion or assistance, but for the teachers to make common cause with the students and lead them to victory.
('48', 375, 4, 18, 829374) The latter know the tragic history of their own nation, they know how the other nations have gained their liberty.
('48', 375, 4, 19, 829489) It is impossible to restrain them from working for the freedom of their own country.

('48', 376, 2, 8, 831416) 394. THE PUBLIC DEBT Thanks to the Congress resolution on public debts, important literature on the subject is springing into being.
('48', 376, 2, 9, 831549) The Bombay Chronicle is rendering a service by publishing the informing series of articles by ‘Politicus’ on this subject.
('48', 376, 2, 10, 831672) Financial problems are always a dry subject requiring concentration and some previous study.
('48', 376, 2, 11, 831765) It is for our learned economists to put these problems in an interesting manner capable of being understood by the public.
('48', 376, 2, 12, 831888) The series by ‘Politicus’ is an attempt in that direction.
('48', 376, 2, 13, 831947) I am not however sure that the presentation of his subject cannot be made simpler even if that should require a fuller treatment.
('48', 376, 2, 14, 832077) I pick up from the series two things for the reader’s consideration.
('48', 376, 2, 15, 832146) After examining all available figures, ‘Politicus’ concludes that:
('48', 376, 3, 16, 832213) the aggregate burden of all kinds of Public Debt, owed by all sorts of authorities and incurred for no matter what purpose or in what form, will be not much short of Rs. 1,200 crores at the present moment.
('48', 376, 3, 17, 832419) This is about half of India’s total annual wealth in material goods of all kinds.
('48', 376, 3, 18, 832501) And that wealth barely suffices to give only one meal a day of the coarsest kind to every human being in the land and that too if we exclude all other needs of human life.
('48', 376, 3, 19, 832673) If this statement is true, it constitutes a black record of crime against India.
('48', 376, 3, 20, 832754) It shows that the debts are largely unproductive.
('48', 376, 3, 21, 832804) If these obligations were healthy, our wealth should have so increased as to give more than enough to every one of us to eat.
('48', 376, 3, 22, 832930) Having summed up the total debt, ‘Politicus’ examines the ethics of the obligations and sums up thus:
('48', 376, 4, 23, 833032) The fact, however, must be repeated that, hitherto, the debt has been contracted by the Government without consulting the people of India; that the latter have no power to vote the borrowing programme or the debt charges, even under the reforms of 1919 20; and that any condition precedent to the recognition of our political majority, even in the form of a full Dominion Status, which will serve as an encumbrance for all time to come on the people of India, without their explicit consent or confirmation, must, in law as well as conscience, be held to be void.
('48', 376, 4, 24, 833596) The trustee liquidating or dissolving the
('48', 377, 0, 1, 833638) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 377, 1, 2, 833680) trust is entitled, of course, to a full statement of accounts regarding his management of the trust, so that no unexpected claims or counter claims be urged against him subsequently by the beneficiaries coming into their own.
('48', 377, 1, 3, 833906) But that is no reason why the trustee should be permitted to insist, on the occasion of dissolving the trust, that all his claims against the trust estate shall be passed and adopted, without examination, by the erstwhile beneficiaries under his trust.
('48', 377, 1, 4, 834159) The Congress resolution means no more than this, save that it suggests also an unexceptionable machinery for a due examination of these transactions.
('48', 377, 1, 5, 834309) But they have the power to impose their will, we have not yet generated strength to resist that will.
('48', 377, 1, 6, 834411) Or Sir Malcolm Hailey would not be able to say as he is reported to have said.

('48', 378, 2, 14, 837776) 396. OBSCENE LITERATURE No country and no language is free from obscene literature.
('48', 378, 2, 15, 837860) As long as there are self indulging and immoral people in the world, obscene literature will continue to be produced and read.
('48', 378, 2, 16, 837987) But when such literature is disseminated through newspapers of good standing, and under the guise of art or service, it is truly horrible.
('48', 378, 2, 17, 838126) I have received this kind of obscene literature from the Marwari community.
('48', 378, 2, 18, 838202) I have also received a copy of the statement published on behalf of respectable Marwaris.
('48', 378, 2, 19, 838292) The statement seeks to rouse the Marwari community and calls upon it to boycott literature which goes under the name of art but in reality has money as its end.
('48', 378, 2, 20, 838453) What provoked the statement was the Marwari number of a monthly called Chand.
('48', 378, 2, 21, 838531) I could not read all of it, nor do I wish to do so, but whatever I could read was so obscene and loathsome that no man who has any sense or who has the good of society at heart would ever publish such things.
('48', 378, 2, 22, 838740) To publish such things in the name of reform is unnecessary and harmful.
('48', 378, 2, 23, 838813) People who sing filthy songs such as are published in Chand do not read newspapers.
('48', 378, 2, 24, 838897) Its readership can only be of two types: the
('48', 379, 0, 1, 838942) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 379, 1, 2, 838984) educated debauchees who wish to satisfy their lust by any means, and innocent men who, though so far free from the ways of vice, are so impressionable that they may be corrupted.
('48', 379, 1, 3, 839163) For such people obscene literature is fatal.
('48', 379, 1, 4, 839208) This is also the experience of all.
('48', 379, 1, 5, 839244) I hope that the effect of the statement issued by these distinguished Marwari gentlemen will be felt by the editor of Chand and his associates, and that they will withdraw this number of Chand and will refrain in future from publishing such obscene literature.
('48', 379, 1, 6, 839505) A greater duty as regards this is that of the Marwari community and of society in general.
('48', 379, 1, 7, 839596) It should never buy nor even read such obscene literature.
('48', 379, 1, 8, 839655) Editors of Hindi papers have a twofold responsibility.
('48', 379, 1, 9, 839710) Since we want to make Hindi the national language, it becomes their duty to protect this language.
('48', 379, 1, 10, 839809) One like myself who worships the national language would expect only books with lofty ideas.
('48', 379, 1, 11, 839902) Therefore, if it is possible, the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan should appoint a language committee whose function it would be to scrutinize every new book for its language, thought, etc.
('48', 379, 1, 12, 840083) The committee should then prepare lists of books adjudged best and those adjudged obscene, and it should popularize the goodbooks and boycott the obscene ones.
('48', 379, 1, 13, 840243) Such a committee can only be successful if its members are well versed in literature and are will ing to devote themselves whole heartedly to the service of literature.

('48', 382, 4, 14, 845442) 405. STATEMENT ON ARREST OF VALLABHBHAI PATEL March 7, 1930 It is a good omen for us that Sardar Vallabhbhai has been arrested and sentenced.
('48', 382, 4, 15, 845584) It remains to be seen what use we make of this happy beginning.

('48', 388, 1, 2, 856727) 414. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, SABARMATI ASHRAM [Before March 9, 1930] 1
('48', 388, 2, 3, 856800) How can I go back on the principles I have held dear all my life, when I find that it is these principles that are being put to the test?
('48', 388, 2, 4, 856938) I have no doubt in my mind that vaccination is a filthy process, that it is harmful in the end and that it is little short of taking beef.
('48', 388, 2, 5, 857077) I may be entirely mistaken.
('48', 388, 2, 6, 857105) But holding the views that I do, how can I recant them?
('48', 388, 2, 7, 857161) Because I see child after child passing away?
('48', 388, 2, 8, 857207) 2 No, not even if the whole of the Ashram were to be swept away, may I insist on vaccination and pocket my principle.
('48', 388, 2, 9, 857325) What would my love of truth and my adherence to principle mean if they were to vanish at the slightest touch of reality?
('48', 388, 2, 10, 857446) 3 But God is putting me through a greater test.
('48', 388, 2, 11, 857494) On the eve of what is to be the final test of our strength, God is warning me through the messenger of death.
('48', 388, 2, 12, 857604) I have tried hydropathy and earth treatment with success in numerous cases.
('48', 388, 2, 13, 857680) Never has the treatment failed as it seems to have done during the month.
('48', 388, 2, 14, 857754) But does that mean that I must therefore lose faith in the treatment and faith in God?
('48', 388, 2, 15, 857841) Even so my faith in the efficacy of non violence may be put to the severest test.
('48', 388, 2, 16, 857923) I may have to see not three but hundreds and thousands being done to death during the campaign I am about to launch.
('48', 388, 2, 17, 858040) Shall my heart quail before that catastrophe, or will I persevere in my faith?
('48', 388, 2, 18, 858119) No, I want you, everyone, to understand that this epidemic is not a scourge, but a trial and preparation, a tribulation sent to steel our hearts and to chain us more strongly and firmly to faith in God.
('48', 388, 2, 19, 858322) And would not my faith in the Gita be a mockery if three deaths were to unhinge me?
('48', 388, 2, 20, 858406) It is as clear to me as daylight that life and death are but phases of the same thing, the reverse and obverse of the same coin.
('48', 388, 2, 21, 858535) In fact tribulations and death seem to me to present a phase far richer than happiness of life.
('48', 388, 2, 22, 858631) What is life worth without trials and tribulations which are the salt of life?
('48', 388, 2, 23, 858710) The history of mankind would have been a blank sheet without these individuals.
('48', 388, 2, 24, 858790) What is Ramayana but a record of the trials, privations and penances of Rama and Sita?
('48', 388, 2, 25, 858877) The life of Rama, after the recovery of Sita, full ofhappiness as it was, does not occupy even a hundredth part of the epic.
('48', 388, 2, 26, 859002) I want you all to treasure death and suffe ring more than life, and to appreciate their cleansing and purifying character.
('48', 388, 2, 27, 859125) Young India, 12 3 1930
