('48', 389, 1, 2, 859333) 415. THE FINAL TEST The letter 1 to the Viceroy was despatched from here on Sunday.
('48', 389, 1, 3, 859417) It reached him on Tuesday.
('48', 389, 1, 4, 859444) As proposed therein, it was given to the Press on Thursday for publication after awaiting the Viceroy’s telegram.
('48', 389, 1, 5, 859558) The reader will find in this issue a translation of the letter.
('48', 389, 1, 6, 859622) God willing, I hope to start the march at daybreak on Wednesday.
('48', 389, 1, 7, 859687) Workers from Surat side tell me that there are many facilities there for easy manufacture of salt.
('48', 389, 1, 8, 859786) Moreover, as they say, complete peace is likely to be preserved there and, along with it, help from the general public is also very probable.
('48', 389, 1, 9, 859928) In the district of Surat, again, the choice has fallen on Jalalpur taluka for the marching corps to enter.
('48', 389, 1, 10, 860035) In 1921, when the struggle for swaraj was launched at Bardoli, the Jalalpur taluka had applied for being chosen for the honour and I still have several sweet memories of my experience of the place.
('48', 389, 1, 11, 860233) Even today the constructive programme there is in a flourishing state.
('48', 389, 1, 12, 860304) The taluka has many facilities for the manufacture of salt.
('48', 389, 1, 13, 860364) The people of the place are full of enthusiasm and in every way ready to participate in the struggle.
('48', 389, 1, 14, 860466) This is Sardar Vallabhbhai’s view, and he has, therefore, selected Jalalpur taluka for offering civil disobedience against the salt law.
('48', 389, 1, 15, 860603) Whether my co workers or I shall be able to proceed so far in our march, that is, whether Government will let us reach there, is a question.
('48', 389, 1, 16, 860744) I believe we shall not be so allowed.
('48', 389, 1, 17, 860782) Even then, I expect, Jalalpur taluka will take full part in the struggle.
('48', 389, 1, 18, 860856) The Sardar is quite sure that it will.
('48', 389, 1, 19, 860895) But I shall not be satisfied with that.
('48', 389, 1, 20, 860935) I hope the whole of Gujarat will join this time.
('48', 389, 1, 21, 860984) If Gujarat takes the initiative, I have no doubt that the whole of India will rise up.
('48', 389, 1, 22, 861071) When a great awakening takes place among a people, there is always the fear of violence breaking out.
('48', 389, 1, 23, 861173) This non violent war is not free from that fear.
('48', 389, 1, 24, 861222) No one is pained at the outbreak of violence where no question of violence or non violence arises.
('48', 389, 1, 25, 861321) Many even welcome it.
('48', 389, 1, 26, 861343) But in this struggle we have a large number whose duty it would beto prevent, and not welcome, the outbreak of violence.
('48', 389, 1, 27, 861464) Deterred by the fear of violence, I had been holding back civil disobedience and trying till now to dissuade the people from launching it.
('48', 389, 1, 28, 861603) But I am now ready to take the ultimate step even at the risk of a violent outbreak, because I find that there is no other way in which I might prepare the people for the struggle.
('48', 389, 1, 29, 861784) Looking at the other side, I find that the Government’s organized violence goes on increasing day by day and the group wanting to meet violence with violence is becoming correspondingly stronger.
('48', 389, 1, 30, 861980) Hence, if non violence has the power to
('48', 389, 2, 31, 862020) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Irwin”, 2 3 1930.
('48', 390, 0, 1, 862061) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 391
('48', 390, 1, 2, 862107) check violence or if I am truly non violent, I must be able to find a non violent way to restrain the double violence which I have mentioned.
('48', 390, 1, 3, 862249) That way, I believe, is the way I am now adopting.
('48', 390, 1, 4, 862300) And if I am mistaken, I have no doubt that I ought to cease obstructing the progress of the people any more.
('48', 390, 1, 5, 862409) I do clearly see that I would put my non violence to shame if I remained content with working only for khadi.
('48', 390, 1, 6, 862519) There is no doubt in my mind that the power of non violence is a million times greater than that of khadi.
('48', 390, 1, 7, 862626) Nor do I in any way doubt that khadi is an essential element of the non violent way to win swaraj and that without khadi, there can be no swaraj.
('48', 390, 1, 8, 862772) I have no doubt also that unless khadi had made the progress it has I should not have had the self confidence to adopt the way I am now preparing to take.
('48', 390, 1, 9, 862927) But it is clear that there should now be some other action besides the manufacture of khadi.
('48', 390, 1, 10, 863020) There is need of greater awakening among the people even for giving more impetus to the khadi movement.
('48', 390, 1, 11, 863124) If we are able to rouse the people and also maintain non violence, there is no doubt that swaraj will be ours here and now.
('48', 390, 1, 12, 863248) Having thus considered the matter I am taking the plunge.
('48', 390, 1, 13, 863306) The reader will observe that this reasoning occurred to me after I had first seen the way.
('48', 390, 1, 14, 863397) It is my belief that great things are achieved by man in obedience to the prompting of the inner voice.
('48', 390, 1, 15, 863501) It is another matter whether the inner voice is from God or Satan.
('48', 390, 1, 16, 863568) It has been my experience, with regard to myself and many others, that after one has heard the inner voice, one finds arguments in support of it.
('48', 390, 1, 17, 863714) It is clear as daylight that I ought to get out of the way if this inner voice is wrong or devilish.
('48', 390, 1, 18, 863815) I believe the inner voice to be divine and hence the only way open to me is to follow the way shown by the light within and demonstrate its success or die in the attempt.
('48', 390, 1, 19, 863986) I, therefore, look upon this struggle as the final test.
('48', 390, 1, 20, 864043) Those who join it may join on this understanding only.
('48', 390, 1, 21, 864098) If countless multitudes join the struggle and if peace is preserved, we shall win swaraj sooner than we imagine.
('48', 390, 1, 22, 864211) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 9 3 1930

('48', 391, 2, 3, 864691) Wednesday, the 12th Aslali Thursday, the 13th Morning Bareja Evening Navagam Friday, the 14th Morning Vasana Evening Matar Saturday, the 15th Morning Dabhan Evening Nadiad Sunday, the 16th Morning Boriavi Evening Anand Monday, the 17th Morning Napa Evening Borsad Tuesday, the 18th Morning Raas Evening Badalpur I request the mahajans and the workers of the respective places to bear in mind the following.
('48', 391, 2, 4, 865098) The satyagrahi party is expected to reach each place by 8 o’clock in the morning and to sit down for lunch between 10.00 and 10.30 a.m.
('48', 391, 2, 5, 865234) It may be half past nine by the time the party reaches Aslali on the first day.
('48', 391, 2, 6, 865314) No rooms will be needed for rest at noon or night, but a clean, shaded place will be enough.
('48', 391, 2, 7, 865407) In the absence of such a shaded place, it will be enough to have a bamboo and grass covering.
('48', 391, 2, 8, 865501) Both bamboo and grass can be put to use again.
('48', 391, 2, 9, 865548) It is assumed that the village people will provide us food.
('48', 391, 2, 10, 865608) If provisions are supplied the party will cook its own meal.
('48', 391, 2, 11, 865669) The food supplied, whether cooked or uncooked, should be the simplest possible.
('48', 391, 2, 12, 865749) Nothing more than rotli or rotla or kedgeree with vegetables and milk or curds, will be required.
('48', 391, 2, 13, 865847) Sweets, even if prepared, will be declined.
('48', 391, 2, 14, 865891) Vegetables should be merely boiled, and no oil, spices and chillies, whether green or dry, whole or crushed, should be added or used in the cooking.
('48', 391, 2, 15, 866040) This is my advice for preparing a meal:
('48', 391, 3, 16, 866080) Morning, before departure: Rab and dhebra; the rab should be left to the party itself to prepare.
('48', 391, 3, 17, 866178) Midday: Bhakhri, vegetable and milk or butter milk.
('48', 391, 3, 18, 866230) Evening, before the march is resumed: Roasted gram, rice.
('48', 391, 3, 19, 866288) Night:Kedgeree with vegetable and butter milk or milk.
('48', 392, 0, 1, 866343) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 393
('48', 392, 1, 2, 866389) The ghee for all the meals together should not exceed three tolas per head: One tola in the rab, one served separately to be smeared on the bhakhri, and one to be put into the kedgeree.
('48', 392, 1, 3, 866575) For me goat’s milk, if available, in the morning, at noon and at night, and raisins or dates and three lemons will do.
('48', 392, 1, 4, 866694) I hope that the village people will incur no expenses whatever, except for the simple food items named above.
('48', 392, 1, 5, 866804) I look forward to meeting the people of each village and its neighbourhood.
('48', 392, 1, 6, 866880) Everyone in the party will be carrying his own bedding, so that the village people will have to provide nothing except a clean place for resting in.
('48', 392, 1, 7, 867029) The people should incur no expense on account of betel leaves, betel nuts or tea for the party.
('48', 392, 1, 8, 867125) I shall be happy if every village maintains complete cleanliness and fixes beforehand an enclosed place for the satyagrahis to answer calls of nature.
('48', 392, 1, 9, 867276) If the villagers do not already use khadi, it is clear that they should now start using it.
('48', 392, 1, 10, 867368) It is desirable that information under the following heads should be kept ready for each village: 1. Population: Number of women, men, Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Parsis, etc.
('48', 392, 1, 11, 867545) 2. Number of untouchables.
('48', 392, 1, 12, 867572) 3. If there is a school in the village, the number of boys and girls attending it.
('48', 392, 1, 13, 867655) 4. Number of spinning wheels.
('48', 392, 1, 14, 867685) 5. The monthly sale of khadi.
('48', 392, 1, 15, 867715) 6. Number of people wearing khadi exclusively.
('48', 392, 1, 16, 867762) 7. Salt consumed per head; salt used for cattle, etc.
('48', 392, 1, 17, 867816) 8. Number of cows and buffaloes in the village.
('48', 392, 1, 18, 867864) 9. The amount of land revenue paid; at what rate per acre.
('48', 392, 1, 19, 867923) 10. The area of the common grazing ground if any.
('48', 392, 1, 20, 867973) 11. Do the people drink?
('48', 392, 1, 21, 867998) How far is the liquor shop from the village?
('48', 392, 1, 22, 868043) 12. Educational and other special facilities, if any, for the untouchables.
('48', 392, 1, 23, 868119) It will be good if this information is written out on a sheet of paper neatly and handed to me immediately on our arrival.

('48', 393, 1, 2, 868320) 417. LETTER TO MANIBEHN PATEL March 9, 1930 CHI.
('48', 393, 1, 3, 868369) MANI, I was waiting every day to hear from you.
('48', 393, 1, 4, 868417) Not a day passed on which I did not remember you, but I quite understand your feeling that I neglect you.
('48', 393, 1, 5, 868523) My pitiable condition is responsible for it.
('48', 393, 1, 6, 868568) I have no time even to raise my head to look at anybody.
('48', 393, 1, 7, 868625) I was content with knowing where you were and what you were about.
('48', 393, 1, 8, 868692) Father did not leave any instructions for you.
('48', 393, 1, 9, 868739) He had no idea [he would be arrested].
('48', 393, 1, 10, 868778) You should live in any place where you will be happy and at peace.
('48', 393, 1, 11, 868845) 1 You can certainly go to jail when the time comes.
('48', 393, 1, 12, 868897) Mahadev has written about it.
('48', 393, 1, 13, 868927) I understand why you like to live in the Ashram.
('48', 393, 1, 14, 868976) But I think your attitude is not proper.
('48', 393, 1, 15, 869017) Compulsion in such matters however is out of the question.
('48', 393, 1, 16, 869076) So I will say nothing more about it.
('48', 393, 1, 17, 869113) I only wish that you should be at ease, no matter where you live.
('48', 393, 1, 18, 869179) I expect to be arrested before Tuesday.
('48', 393, 1, 19, 869219) Be brave and improve your health.
('48', 393, 1, 20, 869253) Blessings from BAPU SMT.

('48', 394, 1, 2, 869825) 419. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING, SABARMATI ASHRAM 1
('48', 394, 2, 3, 869875) March 10, 1930 I am glad that you have been coming to our prayer in such large numbers, and generally I would say, ‘May your tribe increase.’ But I must utter a few words of warning.
('48', 394, 2, 4, 870058) If it is mere curiosity that draws you here, you had better not come at all.
('48', 394, 2, 5, 870135) If it is the prayer that attracts you, you are quite welcome, but in that case this sudden inroad cannot be accounted for.
('48', 394, 2, 6, 870258) But I presume you come both for the prayer and for understanding the significance of the campaign I am about to launch.
('48', 394, 2, 7, 870378) As for the prayer, I assure you that mere utterance, parrot wise, of the name of God is of no avail.
('48', 394, 2, 8, 870479) All your trouble in coming this long distance from the town would be wasted and the quiet of our prayers would be disturbed.
('48', 394, 2, 9, 870604) If therefore your desire to take part in the prayer is genuine, you must be prepared to fulfil a condition which alone can prove your bona fides, and that is that you come here dressed in khadi.
('48', 394, 2, 10, 870799) You may or may not admit the many claims made on behalf of khadi, but one thing is now practically universally admitted, that khadi unites the wearer to the poorest of the land.
('48', 394, 2, 11, 870977) And I may tell you that but for the progress that khadi has made in recent years I should not have been able to launch this campaign.
('48', 394, 2, 12, 871111) It is the spread of khadi that infuses in me the hope that the message of non violence has spread to the masses, for I have always associatednon violence with khadi.
('48', 394, 2, 13, 871277) A believer in violence may wear khadi, but he would do so in order to exploit it.
('48', 394, 2, 14, 871359) As for the other desire that also prompts you to come here, you know that the march begins on Wednesday morning.
('48', 394, 2, 15, 871472) Everyone is on the tiptoe of expectation, and before anything has happened the thing has attracted world wide attention.
('48', 394, 2, 16, 871593) Now I should like to analyse the thing for you and to implore you to appreciate its implications.
('48', 394, 2, 17, 871691) Though the battle is to begin in a couple of days, how is it that you can come here quite fearlessly?
('48', 394, 2, 18, 871793) I do not think anyone of you would be here if you had to face rifleshots or bombs.
('48', 394, 2, 19, 871876) But you have no fear of rifleshots or bombs.
('48', 394, 2, 20, 871921) Supposing I had announced that I was going to launch a violent campaign (not necessarily with men armed with rifles, but even with sticks or stones), do you think the Government would have left me free until now?
('48', 394, 2, 21, 872134) Can you show me an
('48', 394, 3, 22, 872153) 1 This is a condensed summary of Gandhiji’s speech made at the end of the prayer meeting, which was attended by about 2,000 people.
('48', 395, 0, 1, 872285) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 395, 1, 2, 872327) example in history (be it England, America or Russia) where the State has tolerated violent defiance of authority for a single day?
('48', 395, 1, 3, 872459) But here you know that the Government is puzzled and perplexed.
('48', 395, 1, 4, 872523) And you have come here because you have been familiarized by now with the idea of seeking voluntary imprisonment.
('48', 395, 1, 5, 872637) Then I would ask you to proceed a step further.
('48', 395, 1, 6, 872685) Supposing ten men in each of the 700,000 villages in India come forward to manufacture salt and to disobey the Salt Act, what do you think can this Government do?
('48', 395, 1, 7, 872848) Even the worst autocrat you can imagine would not dare to blow regiments of peaceful civil resisters out of a cannon’s mouth.
('48', 395, 1, 8, 872974) If only you will bestir yourselves just a little, I assure you we should be able to tire this Government out in a very short time.
('48', 395, 1, 9, 873105) I want you, therefore, to understand the meaning of this struggle and to do your part in it.
('48', 395, 1, 10, 873198) If it is only curiosity that moves you to walk this long distance, you had better not waste your time and mine.
('48', 395, 1, 11, 873310) If you come here to bless us and our movement, the blessings must take some concrete shape.
('48', 395, 1, 12, 873402) I don’t want any money from you.
('48', 395, 1, 13, 873435) I am hoping that it may be possible to fight this battle with the least possible money.
('48', 395, 1, 14, 873523) At the time of Kheda Satyagraha in 1918 I had to refuse several offers for raising contributions.
('48', 395, 1, 15, 873621) In Bardoli an appeal was made and there was a spontaneous response, but much of the money was saved and is now being utilized for constructive work.
('48', 395, 1, 16, 873770) So I do not want you to contribute any money just now.
('48', 395, 1, 17, 873825) That you will do unasked when our suffering has reached that stage which cannot but compel your sympathy.
('48', 395, 1, 18, 873931) But I want you to take your courage in both hands and contribute in men towards the struggle which promises to be fierce and prolonged.
('48', 395, 1, 19, 874067) I certainly expect the city of Ahmedabad, the Ahmedabad of Vallabhbhai, who is already in jail, to furnish an unlimited supply of volunteers to keep the stream unbroken, in case batch after batch happens to be arrested and marched to jail.
('48', 395, 1, 20, 874307) That is the least I expect of you.
('48', 395, 1, 21, 874342) May God give you the strength to rise to the occasion.
('48', 395, 1, 22, 874397) Young India, 12 3 1930

('48', 396, 1, 2, 874789) 421. INTERVIEW TO H. D. RAJAH 1
('48', 396, 2, 3, 874821) [On or before March 11, 1930]
('48', 396, 3, 4, 874851) I had a prolonged interview with Gandhiji regarding the coming struggle and the part youths are to play.
('48', 396, 3, 5, 874956) Gandhi said: I begin the struggle in right earnest on 12th morning.
('48', 396, 3, 6, 875024) This struggle must be continued to the successful end.
('48', 396, 3, 7, 875079) Either we shall be effaced out of the earth or we shall spring up as an independent nation enjoying full freedom.
('48', 396, 3, 8, 875193) We shall face the bullets with our backs to the wall.
('48', 396, 3, 9, 875247) In our fight, we shall be engaged in active civil disobedience campaign and fill the prisons with men and women, but there will be no retreat at any cost.
('48', 396, 3, 10, 875402) I hope to return to Ashram triumphant in our struggle for India achieving her independence.
('48', 396, 4, 11, 875494) Questioned by me as a to what the people should do when he is arrested, Gandhiji said: Yes, I expect arrest at any moment.
('48', 396, 4, 12, 875617) But the fight should continue.
('48', 396, 4, 13, 875648) The Congress Committees, Provincial, District or Taluka, should organize the campaign.
('48', 396, 5, 14, 875735) What part can the Youth Leagues play in this fight?
('48', 396, 5, 15, 875787) The Youth Leagues should organize volunteers and offer them to the Congress Committees which decide on a course of action.
('48', 396, 5, 16, 875910) If any Congress Committee of a particular place fails to do the work, the Youth League would take up the work and do it.
('48', 396, 6, 17, 876031) The Bombay Chronicle, 12 3 1930
('48', 396, 7, 18, 876063) 422. INTERVIEW TO “THE MANCHESTER GUARDIAN”

('48', 396, 9, 20, 876157) I don’t believe that the slightest good for India can come of the Round Table Conference in London.
('48', 396, 9, 21, 876257) I would like to spare the world the melancholy spectacle of Indians fighting against Indians in a foreign country, but this is what the Conference would lead to, as it seems to be composed at present.
('48', 396, 9, 22, 876458) I shall waste no time.
('48', 396, 9, 23, 876481) I expect my movement to be successful.
('48', 396, 9, 24, 876520) I hope that my movement will not lead to deeds of violence, but even in this case there can be no going back for me.
('48', 396, 9, 25, 876637) Yet I supported the Nehru Report once; but many things have

('48', 397, 1, 3, 876899) I admit that this may be my last chance, and if I do not seize it, it may never come again.
('48', 397, 1, 4, 876991) The revolutionary and, of course, violent movement has gained ground heavily.
('48', 397, 1, 5, 877069) The need for the speediest action is absolutely clear.

('48', 397, 2, 9, 877412) 423. ON RECORDING OF MESSAGE 1
('48', 397, 3, 10, 877443) [On or before March 11, 1930] If there is truth in my message, then whether I am inside or outside the jail, people are bound to pay heed to it.
('48', 397, 3, 11, 877588) But if there is no truth in it, then in spite of all your efforts, and even with the help of gramophone, you would not be able to carry it to the people.
('48', 397, 3, 12, 877742) If the satyagraha we are going to start is really satyagraha, that is to say, if it means an insistence on truth, and if we are prepared to go ahead on the basis of truth and non violence, it is bound to succeed, whether people hear my words or not, and whether my voice reaches their ears or not.
('48', 397, 3, 13, 878040) Therefore, a record like this is neither necessary nor likely to be of any help.
('48', 397, 3, 14, 878121) At the Feet of Mahatma Gandhi, pp.
('48', 397, 4, 15, 878156) 424. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 2
('48', 397, 5, 16, 878184) [On or before March 11, 1930]
('48', 397, 6, 17, 878214) Q. What sort of Government do you want?
('48', 397, 7, 18, 878254) A. I want a Government that would obey and carry out the wishes of the people.
('48', 397, 8, 19, 878333) Q. You want a democracy?
('48', 397, 8, 20, 878358) A. I am not interested in words, and I never worry myself about the form of government.
('48', 397, 9, 21, 878446) Q. But don’t you mind methods?
('48', 397, 9, 22, 878477) A. I do mind them very much indeed, but I don’t mind the form.
('48', 397, 10, 23, 878540) 1 Rajendra Prasad had suggested that a message of Gandhiji might be recorded so that it could be played after his arrest.
('48', 397, 10, 24, 878662) This was Gandhiji’s reply.
('48', 397, 10, 25, 878689) 2 These were reported by Mahadev Desai under the heading “Talks before the Trek”.
('48', 398, 0, 1, 878771) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 399
('48', 398, 1, 2, 878817) Q. Then you would not mind a monarchy?
('48', 398, 2, 3, 878856) A. I said form and machinery do not much matter to me.
('48', 398, 3, 4, 878911) Q. Well, then, tell me what form your democracy will take.
('48', 398, 4, 5, 878970) A. I do not know; the method alone interests me, and by method I mean the agency through which the wishes of the people are reached.
('48', 398, 4, 6, 879103) There are only two methods; one is that of fraud and force; the other is that of non violence and truth.
('48', 398, 4, 7, 879208) Force always includes fraud, non violence always excludes it.
('48', 398, 5, 8, 879270) Q. Can’t you have fraud with non violence?
('48', 398, 6, 9, 879313) Impossible.
('48', 398, 6, 10, 879325) Fraud itself is a species of violence.
('48', 398, 7, 11, 879364) Q. Well, I have seen fraud associated with non violence.
('48', 398, 7, 12, 879421) China is reputed to be one of the most peaceful countries in the world, and if I were to tell you about the frauds there, you would be shocked.
('48', 398, 8, 13, 879565) A. I repeat, words do not capture my imagination.
('48', 398, 8, 14, 879615) As a people, the Chinese are one of the most peaceful in the world, but that peace cannot be real and voluntary if there is fraud in it.
('48', 398, 8, 15, 879752) If I harbour ill will in my breast but do not express it in acts, I am still violent.
('48', 398, 8, 16, 879838) By non violence or peace I mean the peace which comes through inner strength.
('48', 398, 8, 17, 879916) If I have that peace, that non violence, I won’t have any hate in me.
('48', 398, 8, 18, 879986) Violence does not necessarily mean bodily harm.
('48', 398, 8, 19, 880034) What I want to impress on everyone is that I do not want India to reach her goal through questionable means.
('48', 398, 8, 20, 880143) Whether that is possible or not is another question.
('48', 398, 8, 21, 880196) It is sufficient for my present purpose if the person who thinks out the plan and leads the people is absolutely above board and has non violence and truth in him.
('48', 398, 8, 22, 880360) Non violence works organically, not mechanically.
('48', 398, 8, 23, 880410) It was for that reason that I asked for unrestricted authority from the Working Committee of the Congress to work out my plan of non violence.
('48', 398, 9, 24, 880553) Q. Don’t you think, Gandhiji, boycott of foreign goods would be more potent than civil disobedience?
('48', 398, 10, 25, 880654) A. Years ago I heard that futile cry and I replaced it by one for the boycott of foreign cloth.
('48', 398, 10, 26, 880750) It made some impression, but that of boycott of foreign goods made none at all.
('48', 398, 11, 27, 880830) Q. My impression is that in Bengal boycott of British goods was tried with success, but no other province took it up.
('48', 398, 12, 28, 880948) It fizzled out.
('48', 398, 12, 29, 880964) The mills in Ahmedabad and Bombay defrauded the nation by sending spurious cloth; and when genuine mill cloth was sent, exorbitant prices were charged.
('48', 398, 13, 30, 881116) Q. That is what I mean to say.
('48', 398, 13, 31, 881147) The thing was not tried seriously.
('48', 398, 14, 32, 881182) A. If it was not, it means that the people did not want to.
('48', 398, 14, 33, 881242) So far as I am concerned, I never believed in it and so I could never back it.
('48', 399, 0, 1, 881321) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 399, 1, 2, 881363) Q. But would it not be easier to handle foreign cloth boycott than civil disobedience?
('48', 399, 2, 3, 881450) It is far more difficult.
('48', 399, 2, 4, 881476) In one case you want the co operation of 300 million people.
('48', 399, 2, 5, 881537) In the other, even if you have an army of ten thousand defiant men and women, your work is done.
('48', 399, 3, 6, 881634) Q. Why?
('48', 399, 3, 7, 881642) They can be all clapped in jail and nothing more will happen thereafter.
('48', 399, 4, 8, 881715) A. Let them try the experiment.
('48', 399, 4, 9, 881747) They would have to hang these men before they could dismiss them from their minds.
('48', 399, 4, 10, 881830) If these men are trusty and true their very presence will worry the Government unto death.
('48', 399, 5, 11, 881921) Q. Will they worry Government even in prison?
('48', 399, 6, 12, 881967) A. For one thing they can’t keep them there for any length of time.
('48', 399, 6, 13, 882035) The fact is that we never had even 5,000 full civil resisters in 1921. Every political prisoner is not necessarily a civil resister.
('48', 399, 7, 14, 882168) Q. Will not your movement lead to violence?
('48', 399, 8, 15, 882212) A. It may, though I am trying my best to prevent any outbreak of violence.
('48', 399, 8, 16, 882287) Today there is greater risk of violence, in the absence of any safety valve in the shape of a movement of non violence like the one I am contemplating.
('48', 399, 9, 17, 882439) Q. Yes, I have heard you say that you are launching this campaign for the very purpose of stopping violence.
('48', 399, 10, 18, 882548) A. It is one argument, but that is not the most conclusive argument.
('48', 399, 10, 19, 882617) The other and most conclusive argument for me is that if non violence has to prove its worth, it must prove its worth today.
('48', 399, 10, 20, 882742) It must cease to be the passive or even impotent instrument that it has come to be looked upon [as] in certain quarters.
('48', 399, 10, 21, 882863) And when it is exercised in the most effective way, it must act in spite of the most fatal outward obstructions.
('48', 399, 10, 22, 882976) In fact non violence by its very nature must neutralize all outward obstruction.
('48', 399, 10, 23, 883057) On the contrary, inward obstacles in the shape of fraud, hatred, and ill will would be fatal to the movement.
('48', 399, 10, 24, 883167) Up to now I used to say: “Let me get control over the forces of violence.” It is growing upon me now that it is only by setting the force of non violence in motion that I can get those elements under control.
('48', 399, 10, 25, 883376) But I hear people say, “History will have to repeat itself in India.” Let it repeat itself, if it must.
('48', 399, 10, 26, 883480) I for one must not postponethe movement unless I am to be guilty of the charge of cowardice.
('48', 399, 10, 27, 883573) I must fight unto death the system based on violence and thus bring under control the force of political violence.
('48', 399, 10, 28, 883688) When real organic non violence is set to work, the masses also will react manfully.
('48', 400, 0, 1, 883772) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 401
('48', 400, 1, 2, 883818) Q. But after you are removed the movement will no longer be in your control?
('48', 400, 2, 3, 883895) A. In South Africa the movement was not in my control during the latter part of it, when it gained considerable momentum without any action on my part.
('48', 400, 2, 4, 884047) Thousands joined the movement instinctively.
('48', 400, 2, 5, 884092) I had not even seen the faces of them, much less known them.
('48', 400, 2, 6, 884153) They joined because they felt that they must.
('48', 400, 2, 7, 884199) They had possibly only heard my name, but they saw in the twinkling of an eye that it was a movement for their liberation; they knew that there was a man prepared to fight the £3 tax and they took the plunge.
('48', 400, 2, 8, 884408) And against what odds?
('48', 400, 2, 9, 884431) Their mines were converted into jails; the men who oppressed them day and night were appointed warders over them.
('48', 400, 2, 10, 884545) They knew that there would be hell let loose on them.
('48', 400, 2, 11, 884599) And yet they did not waver or falter.
('48', 400, 2, 12, 884637) It was a perfect miracle.
('48', 400, 3, 13, 884663) Q. But would not the movement add to the already numerous divisions existing in the country?
('48', 400, 4, 14, 884756) A. I have no such fear.
('48', 400, 4, 15, 884780) The forces of disunion can be kept under control, even as the forces of violence.
('48', 400, 4, 16, 884862) You may say that there is fear elsewhere.
('48', 400, 4, 17, 884904) The party of violence may not respond to my advances and the masses might behave unthinkingly.
('48', 400, 4, 18, 884999) I am an optimist and have an abiding faith in human nature.
('48', 400, 4, 19, 885059) The party of violence will give me fair play and the masses will act rightly by instinct.
('48', 400, 4, 20, 885149) It is possible that I may be living in a fool’s paradise.
('48', 400, 4, 21, 885207) But no general can possibly provide for all contingencies.
('48', 400, 4, 22, 885266) For me it is the opportunity of a lifetime.
('48', 400, 4, 23, 885310) The movement is none of my seeking.
('48', 400, 4, 24, 885346) Almost in spite of myself I was irresistibly drawn to Calcutta.
('48', 400, 4, 25, 885410) I entered into a compromise to which I was driven.
('48', 400, 4, 26, 885461) The period of two years I changed to one, simply because it did not involve any moral principle.
('48', 400, 4, 27, 885558) In Lahore I had to conceive and frame practically every resolution.
('48', 400, 4, 28, 885626) There I saw the forces of violence and non violence in full play, acting side by side; and I found that non violence ultimately triumphed over violence.
('48', 400, 5, 29, 885779) Q. You said some time ago that the time was not ripe for civil disobedience.
('48', 400, 5, 30, 885856) What has happened between that time and today that has helped you to alter your view?
('48', 400, 6, 31, 885942) A. I am quite positive that it is fully ripe.
('48', 400, 6, 32, 885988) The reason I will tell you.
('48', 400, 6, 33, 886016) Nothing has happened externally, but the internal conflict in me, which was the only barrier, has ceased; and I am absolutely certain now that the campaign had been long overdue.
('48', 400, 6, 34, 886195) I might have started it long before this.
('48', 400, 7, 35, 886237) Q. And what was that internal conflict?
('48', 400, 8, 36, 886277) A. You know I have always been guided solely by my attitude towards non violence, but I did not know then how to translate that attitude into action in the face of growing violence.
('48', 400, 8, 37, 886459) But now I see as
('48', 401, 0, 1, 886476) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 401, 1, 2, 886518) clearly as daylight that, pursuing the course that I have adopted, I minimize the risk I am taking.
('48', 401, 2, 3, 886618) Q. Are you sure that the salt campaign will lead you to jail?
('48', 401, 3, 4, 886680) A. I have not a shadow of doubt that it will.
('48', 401, 3, 5, 886726) How long exactly it will take is more than I can say, but I feel that it will be much sooner than most people would be inclined to think.
('48', 401, 3, 6, 886864) I expect a crisis to be soon reached which would lead to a proper Conference—not a Round Table Conference, but a Square Table, one where everybody attending it would know his bearings.
('48', 401, 3, 7, 887049) The exact lineaments of that Conference I cannot at present depict, but it will be a Conference between equals met to lay their heads together to devise ways and means for the establishment of an Independent Constitution in India.
('48', 401, 4, 8, 887280) Q. Were you not responsible for allowing the Viceregal negotiations to come to an abrupt end?
('48', 401, 5, 9, 887374) A. I know that is the impression in certain quarters; the public blamed me for a time, but now it has come to understand the true position.

('48', 401, 9, 17, 888063) A. If the scheme was such as to come into operation at a future time, I should rule it out.

('48', 401, 9, 19, 888212) The public might know more about it some day.

('48', 408, 2, 22, 904530) 433. THE FOURFOLD CURSE
('48', 408, 3, 23, 904554) The moral influence of British rule on personal character, on the position of women, in stimulation of public spirit, in the attitude to children and the poor and infirm, far outweighs the great material burdens imposed by it.

('48', 411, 2, 6, 911318) 435. WHAT IT IS NOT Maulana Shaukat Ali is reported to have said that the independence movement is a movement not for swaraj but for Hindu Raj and against Mussalmans, that therefore the latter should leave it alone.

('48', 413, 2, 14, 917875) 436. A NEW ORIENTATION The discussion that has raged round the eleven points mentioned in my article 1 on the Viceregal address to the Assembly and my reference to some of them in my letter to the Viceroy shows how necessary it was to bring them out.
('48', 413, 2, 15, 918126) Critics have said that these points fall far below even Dominon Status, not to speak of Independence.
('48', 413, 2, 16, 918228) They could not have carefully read my article ormy letter.
('48', 413, 2, 17, 918287) If they will re read them, they will find it stated therein that the conceding of those points was a preliminary to a conference about Independence.
('48', 413, 2, 18, 918436) Whilst therefore there is no substance in the criticism levelled against my presentation of the case, I am free to admit that I have endeavoured to give a new orientation to the national demand.
('48', 413, 2, 19, 918631) Just as it was necessary in 1921 to keep the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs separate from swaraj and I used to say then that for me to have their
('48', 413, 3, 20, 918777) 1 Vide “Clearing the Issue” 30 1 1930.
('48', 414, 0, 1, 918816) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 415
('48', 414, 1, 2, 918862) redress purely through our effort was tantamount to swaraj, so has it become necessary for me on the eve of battle to lay stress on the eleven points and even to say that they are swaraj.
('48', 414, 1, 3, 919050) For if they are not included in swaraj, it can have no meaning for the nation; and if we generate sufficient strength to gain those points, we have strength enough to gain an Independence Constitution.
('48', 414, 1, 4, 919252) Let me illustrate my point.
('48', 414, 1, 5, 919280) There is the proposal for protecting the mill industry and at the same time of Imperial Preference.
('48', 414, 1, 6, 919380) I call this a dangerous trap, especially when the expression Dominion Status is being bandied about in connection with the proposed Round Table Conference.
('48', 414, 1, 7, 919536) If against the grant of Dominion Status or even Independence a stipulation is made that there should always be preference for British cloth, Dominion Status or Independence will have no meaning either for the millions or for the indigenous mills.
('48', 414, 1, 8, 919783) There can never be preference for things British when India is capable of manufacturing them to the full extent of the demand thereof within her own borders.
('48', 414, 1, 9, 919941) She may share foreign trade with others; she dare not share her inland trade with anybody so long as she is able to cope with it herself.
('48', 414, 1, 10, 920079) Indeed she is entitled and it is her duty to protect growing industries against even a friendly England or any other friendly power.
('48', 414, 1, 11, 920212) It would be wrong and unpatriotic for the mill owners to fall into the trap laid for them.

('48', 415, 0, 1, 921601) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 415, 1, 2, 921643) This is the most expeditious plan, if Independence is to be achieved through peaceful means.
('48', 415, 1, 3, 921736) Satyagraha works only in this manner.
('48', 415, 1, 4, 921774) It arms people with power not to seize power but to convert the usurper to their own view till at last the usurper retires or sheds the vices of a usurper and becomes a mere instrument of service of those whom he has wronged.

('48', 416, 3, 16, 925150) 438. PARTING MESSAGE AT CHANDOLA 1
('48', 416, 4, 17, 925185) March 12, 1930 Your surpassing love for me has drawn you thus far.
('48', 416, 4, 18, 925252) I appreciate your affection for me which has been so vividly demonstrated by you .
('48', 416, 4, 19, 925335) There were rumours of my arrest last night.God is great, mysterious indeed are His ways.

('48', 417, 2, 6, 926954) Well, the technique is the same even though the organization is different.
('48', 417, 2, 7, 927029) Soul force is the weapon common to both.
('48', 417, 2, 8, 927070) In South Africa, however, there were 3,000 persons, here we are only 79. ('48', 417, 2, 9, 927377) The march in South Africa was attended by greater hardships than the present one.

('48', 417, 3, 11, 927491) 440. SPEECH AT ASLALI [March 12, 1930] Do not be content with merely wearing khadi and plying the spinning wheel, thinking that you have done all that you could do.
('48', 417, 3, 12, 927656) Take the case of your own village: For a population of 1,700, 850 maunds of salt will be required.
('48', 417, 3, 13, 927755) For 200 bullocks, 300 maunds of salt will be required.
('48', 417, 3, 14, 927810) That is, a total of 1,150 maunds of salt will be required.
('48', 417, 3, 15, 927869) The Government levies a tax of Rs. 1 4 on one pukka maund of salt.
('48', 417, 3, 16, 927936) Hence, on 1,150 maunds, which is equal to 575 pukka maunds, you pay a tax of Rs. 720. A bullock must be given two maunds of salt.
('48', 417, 3, 17, 928066) In addition, there are 800 cows, buffaloes and calves in your village.
('48', 417, 3, 18, 928137) If you give them salt, or if the tanner uses salt for treating hides, or if you use salt as manure, you would be paying that amount of tax in excess of Rs. 720. Can your village afford to pay this amount in taxes every year ?
('48', 417, 3, 19, 928363) In India, the average income of an individual is calculated at 7 pice or, in other words, hundreds of thousands of persons do not earn even a single pice and either die of starvation or live by begging.
('48', 417, 3, 20, 928566) Even they cannot do without salt.
('48', 417, 3, 21, 928600) What will be the plight of such persons if they can get no salt or get it at too high a price?
('48', 417, 3, 22, 928695) Salt, which sells at 9 pice a maund in the Punjab, salt of which
('48', 418, 0, 1, 928760) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 419
('48', 418, 1, 2, 928806) heaps and heaps are being made on the coast of Kathiawar and Gujarat, cannot be had by the poor at less than Re.
('48', 418, 1, 3, 928919) 1 8 0 a maund.
('48', 418, 1, 4, 928934) What curses the Government may not be inviting upon itself from the poor for hiring men to throw this salt into mud!
('48', 418, 1, 5, 929051) The poor destitute villagers do not have the strength to get this tax repealed.
('48', 418, 1, 6, 929131) We want to develop this strength.
('48', 418, 1, 7, 929165) A democratic State is one which has authority to abolish a tax which does not deserve to be paid.
('48', 418, 1, 8, 929263) It is one in which the people can determine when a certain thing should or should not be paid.
('48', 418, 1, 9, 929358) We, however, do not possess such authority.
('48', 418, 1, 10, 929402) Likewise, even our supposedly great representatives do not have it.
('48', 418, 1, 11, 929470) In the Central Legislative Assembly, Pandit Malaviya said that the manner inwhich Sardar Vallabhbhai was arrested could not be called just ; that it was unjust and high handed.
('48', 418, 1, 12, 929647) And this resolution was supported by Mr. Jinnah.
('48', 418, 1, 13, 929696) To this the Government official replied that their magistrate had acted in a manner which befitted a loyal subject, if he had acted otherwise, he would have been regarded as a traitor.
('48', 418, 1, 14, 929881) If, however, that is the case, this bearded person (Abbas Saheb) and I should also be arrested, because I on my part openly make speeches about preparing salt.
('48', 418, 1, 15, 930041) We want to establish a government which will be unable to arrest a single individual against the wishes of the people, which cannot extract ghee worth even a quarter pice from us, cannot take away our carts, cannot extort money from us.
('48', 418, 1, 16, 930278) There are two ways of establishing such a government: that of the big stick or violence and that of non violence or civil disobedience.
('48', 418, 1, 17, 930414) We have chosen the second alternative, regarding it as our dharma.
('48', 418, 1, 18, 930481) And it is because of this that we have set out to prepare salt after serving notice on the Government to that effect.
('48', 418, 1, 19, 930599) I can understand there being a tax on such things as the hookah, bidis and liquor.
('48', 418, 1, 20, 930682) And if I were an emperor, I would levy with your permission a tax of one pie on every bidi.
('48', 418, 1, 21, 930774) And if bidis are found too expensive, those addicted to them may give them up.
('48', 418, 1, 22, 930853) But should one levy a tax on salt?
('48', 418, 1, 23, 930888) Such taxes should now be repealed.
('48', 418, 1, 24, 930923) We should make a resolve that we shall prepare salt, eat it, sell it to the people and, while doing so, court imprisonment, if necessary.
('48', 418, 1, 25, 931061) If, out of Gujarat’s population of 90 lakhs, we leave out women and children, and the remaining 30 lakhs get ready to violate the salt tax, the Government does not have enough accommodation in jails to house so many people.
('48', 418, 1, 26, 931285) Of course, the Government can also beat up and shoot down those who violate the law.
('48', 418, 1, 27, 931370) But the governments of today are unable to go to this extent.
('48', 419, 0, 1, 931432) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 419, 1, 2, 931474) We, however, are determined to let the Government kill us if it wishes.
('48', 419, 1, 3, 931546) The salt tax must be repealed now.
('48', 419, 1, 4, 931581) The fact that a sea of humanity had gathered and showered blessings upon us—for a distance of seven miles from the Ashram to the Chandola lake —a sight for the gods to see—that is a good omen.
('48', 419, 1, 5, 931774) And, if we climb even one step, we shall readily be able to climb the other steps leading to the palace of Independence.

('48', 423, 4, 12, 939454) 450. SPEECH AT BAREJA March 13, 1930 This is our second halt after the march began.
('48', 423, 4, 13, 939538) As at our first halt, here too I was given the required information about this village.
('48', 423, 4, 14, 939626) I was pained to read it.
('48', 423, 4, 15, 939651) It is strange that a place so near Ahmedabad has zeroes against the columns for consumption of khadi, the number of habitual khadi rearers and spinning wheels at work.
('48', 423, 4, 16, 939819) During my tours of North and South India, I used to follow a rule, namely, that the barber cutting my hair should be a khadi wearer.
('48', 423, 4, 17, 939952) But here you keep yourselves far away from such a thing as khadi.
('48', 423, 4, 18, 940018) Khadi is the foundation of our freedom struggle.
('48', 423, 4, 19, 940067) All like khadi, but people are nowadays deterred by the fear that those wearing khadi will have to go to jail and die.
('48', 423, 4, 20, 940186) Bareja has not a single khadi wearer, which is indeed a very painful fact.
('48', 423, 4, 21, 940261) There is a khadi store here and you can certainly remove this blot.
('48', 423, 4, 22, 940329) We do not disown our mother because she is fat or ugly to look at and adopt another woman, more beautiful, to fill her place.

('48', 424, 2, 22, 942510) 451. SPEECH AT NAVAGAM March 13, 1930 As I enter the Kheda District, memories—some sweet, some bitter—fill the mind.
('48', 424, 2, 23, 942627) It was while working in the Kheda District that I became one with the lives of people.
('48', 424, 2, 24, 942714) I have seen nearly all the villages here.

('48', 433, 1, 2, 961422) 460. SPEECH AT NADIAD March 15, 1930 I have visited Nadiad often and made many speeches here, but never before did I see such a huge mass of men.
('48', 433, 1, 3, 961568) Bound by the chains of slavery, we are being crushed at present, and we want to shake them off.
('48', 433, 1, 4, 961664) I am sure you have come here today not for my sake or for the sake of my troop of eighty, but because you hunger for complete freedom.
('48', 433, 1, 5, 961799) Since I left Ahmedabad, on my way here large numbers have showered their blessings on me and my mission.
('48', 433, 1, 6, 961904) The showers have swelled into a flood, as it were.

('48', 434, 5, 20, 964776) For my part, every moment I experience the truth that though many we are all one.
('48', 434, 5, 21, 964858) He does not reveal Himself in the same form in all of us, or rather the hearts of all of us not being alike we do not see Him in the same form— just as in mirrors of different colours and shapes a thing is reflected in different colours and shapes.
('48', 434, 5, 22, 965107) From this it follows that the sin of one is the sin of all.
('48', 434, 5, 23, 965167) And hence it is not up to us to destroy the evil doer.

('48', 436, 1, 2, 968785) 463. THE DEPARTURE Thousands of Ahmedabad citizens, both men and women, kept vigil on the night of the 11th.
('48', 436, 1, 3, 968894) Thousands flocked to the Ashram.
('48', 436, 1, 4, 968927) One heard rumours all through the night.
('48', 436, 1, 5, 968968) “Here is some news,” someone with a grave face twice whispered into my ear!
('48', 436, 1, 6, 969044) “Reliable news has been received that a special train is arriving this evening and will take you away to be borne to Mandalay.” As it is the same to me whether I am in jail or outside, the news had no effect on me and I went to bed in perfect peace.
('48', 436, 1, 7, 969294) But the sight of the mill workers and mill owners around me could not but make me happy.
('48', 436, 1, 8, 969383) Though eagerly expected, “they” did not come, and at the appointed hour and minute God gave us the send off.
('48', 436, 1, 9, 969492) We walked on between rows of people who had come to see us set out, the rows extending to as far as the Chandola lake.
('48', 436, 1, 10, 969611) I cannever forget the scene.
('48', 436, 1, 11, 969640) For me, this was the form in which God’s blessing descended on me.
('48', 436, 1, 12, 969707) In the face of such a spectacle, how could I believe that there was no prospect of success in this struggle?
('48', 436, 1, 13, 969816) Both the rich and the poor were present in proportion to their numbers in the population.
('48', 436, 1, 14, 969906) If the spectacle has any meaning, it is this, at any rate, that all people want freedom and they want it through peaceful means.
('48', 436, 1, 15, 970035) In the eyes of men lining the road from the Ashram to Ellis Bridge I saw not poison but nectar.
('48', 436, 1, 16, 970131) I saw in their eyes no anger against British rule or rulers, but I saw there the joy born of the confidence that complete freedom was now at hand.
('48', 436, 1, 17, 970278) The authorities on their part had acted wisely.
('48', 436, 1, 18, 970326) Not one policeman was to be seen.
('48', 436, 1, 19, 970360) What business could the police have where people had come together for a festive occasion?
('48', 436, 1, 20, 970451) What would the police do there?
('48', 436, 1, 21, 970483) May the self confidence displayed by the citizens of Ahmedabad last for ever!
('48', 436, 1, 22, 970561) Let that confidence spread all over the country, and complete freedom will be ours without much effort.
('48', 436, 1, 23, 970665) If such freedom is our birthright, how much time should we need to win that right?
('48', 436, 1, 24, 970748) To breathe is my birthright, and breathing therefore proceeds with ease.
('48', 436, 1, 25, 970821) It is the long history of slavery that has given us the illusion that slavery is our natural state.
('48', 436, 1, 26, 970921) The truth is that it is not the natural state of any man whatever.
('48', 436, 1, 27, 970988) If three hundred million men and women are determined to win freedom, you may take it that it is theirs.
('48', 436, 1, 28, 971093) The scene on the 12th was a sign of that determination.
('48', 436, 1, 29, 971149) But I am not a man to be easily taken in by appearances.
('48', 436, 1, 30, 971206) All over the world, the common mass of men move like sheep following one another.
('48', 436, 1, 31, 971288) It was so on the 12th too.
('48', 436, 1, 32, 971315) Many had come out just because others had done so.
('48', 436, 1, 33, 971366) For many others, this coming out for the
('48', 437, 0, 1, 971407) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 437, 1, 2, 971449) festival was the beginning and the end of their self sacrifice.
('48', 437, 1, 3, 971513) If that was the truth, their coming out was no sign of the approach of freedom.
('48', 437, 1, 4, 971593) If a hundred thousand men oppress three hundred million and the latter come together to struggle to get rid of the oppression, they will win their freedom from slavery with very little effort and sacrifice.
('48', 437, 1, 5, 971800) But some sacrifice there has to be.
('48', 437, 1, 6, 971836) Winning freedom is not child’s play.
('48', 437, 1, 7, 971873) It requires the labour of thoughtful men, so that if the three hundred million would not become khadi wearers, at any rate three million must come forward to offer civil disobedience.
('48', 437, 1, 8, 972057) If many join in this sacrifice for swaraj they would share the labour.
('48', 437, 1, 9, 972128) If the number of such people is small, they will have to bear a greater burden, for the labour needed for winning freedom will always be the same.
('48', 437, 1, 10, 972275) The only question therefore, is who should bear this burden and how.
('48', 437, 1, 11, 972344) The immediate burden of bringing success to the present march falls on the Gujaratis.
('48', 437, 1, 12, 972430) Bringing success to the march does not mean only providing regular meals and rendering other services to the party.
('48', 437, 1, 13, 972546) The mahajans at the various places are doing that with love.
('48', 437, 1, 14, 972607) To bring success to the march means men and women coming out in large numbers to join the struggle.
('48', 437, 1, 15, 972707) People should get ready for civil disobedience of the salt law as soon as the marching party reaches Jalalpur.
('48', 437, 1, 16, 972818) Every village should get ready its own quota of civil law breakers so that at the proper time they plunge into the fight.
('48', 437, 1, 17, 972940) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 16 3 1930
('48', 437, 2, 18, 972977) 464. “BHAGAVAD GITA” OR “ANASAKTIYOGA”
('48', 437, 3, 19, 973016) It is more than forty years since I have been reading, pondering and following the Gita.
('48', 437, 3, 20, 973105) Friends expressed a desire that I should put before the Gujaratis my understanding of that work.
('48', 437, 3, 21, 973202) I embarked on translating it.
('48', 437, 3, 22, 973232) From the point of view of scholarship my qualifications for attempting the translation would seem to be nil, but as one following its teaching I may be considered to be fairly well qualified.
('48', 437, 3, 23, 973424) The translation has now been published.
('48', 437, 3, 24, 973464) Many editions of the Gita carry the Sanskrit text also.
('48', 437, 3, 25, 973520) It has been intentionally left out in this one.
('48', 437, 3, 26, 973568) I would like it if all knew Sanskrit, but all will never learn Sanskrit.
('48', 437, 3, 27, 973641) Moreover, many cheap editions with Sanskrit are available.
('48', 437, 3, 28, 973700) I, therefore, decided to leave out the Sanskrit text and reduce both the size and the price.
('48', 437, 3, 29, 973793) This edition has 19 pages of introduction and 187 pages of translation so that it can be easily carried in one’s pocket.
('48', 437, 3, 30, 973914) Ten thousand copies have been printed.
('48', 437, 3, 31, 973953) My aspiration is that every Gujarati will read this Gita, ponder it and practise its teaching.
('48', 437, 3, 32, 974048) An easy way to ponder it is to try and understand the meaning without
('48', 438, 0, 1, 974118) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 439
('48', 438, 1, 2, 974164) referring to the Sanskrit text and then to conduct oneself accordingly.
('48', 438, 1, 3, 974236) For example, those who interpret the teaching of the Gita to mean that one ought to kill the wicked without making a distinction between one’s kinsmen and others, should kill their parents or other relatives if they are wicked.
('48', 438, 1, 4, 974464) In practice, they will not be able to do so.
('48', 438, 1, 5, 974509) Naturally, then, it would occur to the reader that where destruction is prescribed the work contemplates some other form of destruction.Almost every page of the Gita advises us not to make a distinction between our own people and others.
('48', 438, 1, 6, 974747) How is this to be done?
('48', 438, 1, 7, 974771) Reflection will lead us to the conclusion that we should perform all our acts in a spirit of non attachment.
('48', 438, 1, 8, 974880) In the very first chapter we find Arjuna facing the troublesome question of one’s own people and others.
('48', 438, 1, 9, 974985) In every chapter the Gita brings out how such a distinction is false and harmful.
('48', 438, 1, 10, 975067) I have called the Gita Anasaktiyoga.
('48', 438, 1, 11, 975104) The interested reader will be able to learn from the work what that is, how non attachment is to be cultivated, what its characteristics are, etc.
('48', 438, 1, 12, 975251) Trying as I do to live according to the teaching of the Gita, I could not avoid the present struggle.
('48', 438, 1, 13, 975353) As a friend says in his telegram to me, this is a holy war for me.
('48', 438, 1, 14, 975420) It is a happy augury for me that this book is being published just as the holy war is entering its last phase in the form of the present struggle.
('48', 438, 2, 15, 975567) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 16 3 1930

('48', 445, 6, 24, 987317) 481. SPEECH AT ANAND March 17, 1930 You have just heard Panditji sing that the path of love is like a flame.
('48', 445, 6, 25, 987426) A satygrahi’s path is the path of love, not one of enmity.
('48', 445, 7, 26, 987485) 1 From the reference to the illness of Sumangal Prakash, who was left behind at Anand where Gandhiji was present on March 17, 1930; vide also “Letter to Kapilrai Mehta”, 3 4 1930.
('48', 446, 0, 1, 987665) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 447
('48', 446, 1, 2, 987711) should be the ambition of a satyagrahi to win over even the most hard hearted of enemies through love.
('48', 446, 1, 3, 987814) How can one demonstrate that there is nothing but love underlying civil disobedience?
('48', 446, 1, 4, 987900) Pritam must have had a direct experience of this, as a result of which this bhajan poured forth from his heart.
('48', 446, 1, 5, 988012) Ill feeling perhaps could be compared to fire.
('48', 446, 1, 6, 988059) How could that be said of love?
('48', 446, 1, 7, 988091) Whereas ill feeling burns others, love burns oneself and purifies the other person.
('48', 446, 1, 8, 988175) When love assumes this intense form, it may well appear to some as fire, but you may be sure that in the end it will make its cooling effect known.
('48', 446, 1, 9, 988323) This band of satyagrahis which has set out is not staging a play; its effect will not be merely temporary; even through death, it will prove true to its pledge—if death becomes necessary.
('48', 446, 1, 10, 988511) The Government will, in the end, have to admit that these persons practising satyagraha were devotees of truth and non violence.
('48', 446, 1, 11, 988640) Nothing will be better than if this band of satyagrahis perishes.
('48', 446, 1, 12, 988706) If the satyagrahis meet with death, it will put a seal upon their claim.
('48', 446, 1, 13, 988779) None of us can assert today whether we have the strength to die a satyagrahi’s death.
('48', 446, 1, 14, 988865) To stab someone in the abdomen in a fit of rage or to die harbouring anger in heart, but keeping up an appearance of non violence through shame is not to die a satyagrahi’s death.
('48', 446, 1, 15, 989045) Not only should there be no anger within one’s heart at the time of death, but on the contrary, one should feel and pray: ‘May good befall him who kills me !’ When anyone meets death in such a manner, I would call it a satyagrahi’s death and only in such a death would the dying person be considered to have been true to his pledge.
('48', 446, 1, 16, 989378) Even with regard to myself I cannot give anyassurance today.
('48', 446, 1, 17, 989439) It is only others who can judge a person by this test after his death.
('48', 446, 1, 18, 989510) Here in Anand, you have Narsinhbhai’s hut.

('48', 446, 1, 24, 989961) I know how to do that.
('48', 446, 1, 25, 989984) This struggle is not one based on money.
('48', 446, 1, 26, 990025) It is going to be carried on without it.
('48', 446, 1, 27, 990066) In a trice this morning, the yarn merchants of Bombay presented me with Rs. 2,501. The Diamond Association has sent me Rs. 2,000. Moreover, if I make even a feeble appeal for funds, Gujarat and India would shower money upon me; I would be buried under its weight and would be

('48', 449, 2, 5, 996002) 482. TALK TO VOLUNTEERS 1
('48', 449, 3, 6, 996028) March 17, 1930 Ours is a sacred pilgrimage and we should be able to account for every minute of our time.
('48', 449, 3, 7, 996134) Let those who cannot finish their quota or do not find time to spin or to write up their diaries see me.
('48', 449, 3, 8, 996239) I shall discuss the thing with them.
('48', 449, 3, 9, 996276) There must be something wrong about their time table and I should help them to readjust it.
('48', 449, 3, 10, 996368) We should be resourceful enough to do all our daily duties without the march coming in our way.
('48', 449, 3, 11, 996464) I dare say we are not hardy enough for a strenuous trek, and I am, therefore, providing for a weekly day of rest.
('48', 449, 3, 12, 996578) But I should listen to no proposal for the relaxation of the regular discipline of the Ashram.
('48', 449, 3, 13, 996673) I repeat that ours is a sacred pilgrimage, and self examination and self purification are essentials which we cannot do without.
('48', 449, 3, 14, 996802) The diary is a great help in this matter.
('48', 449, 3, 15, 996844) This regular spinning, counting the yards spun each day, the daily diary—all these things were thought out by me in the Yeravda Jail, and for us whose ambition it is to lay the foundation of the edifice of swaraj, inasmuch as ours will be the first sacrificial offering, it should be as unsullied as possible.
('48', 449, 3, 16, 997154) Those who follow us may dispense with the rigid discipline we are going through, but for us there is no escape.
('48', 449, 3, 17, 997266) That rigorous self discipline will generate in us a force which will enable us to retain what we have won.
('48', 449, 3, 18, 997373) It is the natural result of active non violence and should stand us in good stead after swaraj.
('48', 449, 3, 19, 997469) It is hardly likely that when we are imprisoned, we shall all be kept together.
('48', 449, 3, 20, 997549) Therefore if our life is well regulated from now, we should not have the slightest difficulty in going regularly through our daily task.

('48', 450, 3, 4, 997854) It is possible that what you say is true.
('48', 450, 3, 5, 997896) If you regard the rules burdensome, they are so.
('48', 450, 3, 6, 997945) However, in this matter, the condition was laid down before we set out that only those who were prepared to shoulder this burden should join the march.
('48', 450, 3, 7, 998097) Hence, these rules cannot now be relaxed.
('48', 450, 3, 8, 998139) It is only through total adherence to these rules that any massive strength can be generated.
('48', 450, 3, 9, 998233) The inner, spiritual rules have a greater effect than the external and material factors.
('48', 450, 3, 10, 998322) Such is the idea behind this march.
('48', 450, 3, 11, 998358) In this struggle we are attempting to eradicate the pervading violence by means of non violence and in it we need humility as much as determination and courage.
('48', 450, 3, 12, 998519) So long as we are arrogant, so long as we try to progress through our own efforts, we are bound to fail.
('48', 450, 3, 13, 998624) So long as the elephant relied on his own strength, it did him no good.
('48', 450, 3, 14, 998696) This demonstrates a fundamental principle.
('48', 450, 3, 15, 998739) Do we not find that those amongst us who appeared to be weak are hale and hearty today, while those who appeared to be strong are bed ridden?
('48', 450, 3, 16, 998881) When a man gives up his arrogance and becomes humble like dust, only then is the power of non violence awakened in him and the divine strength becomes his.
('48', 450, 3, 17, 999037) Hence we should all become fully devoted to our duties.
('48', 450, 3, 18, 999093) We should pray to God that He alone do everything.
('48', 450, 3, 19, 999144) In this manner, if the eighty persons who have set out become like ciphers, our task will certainly be accomplished.

('48', 450, 4, 21, 999298) 484. A GREAT SEER NAPA, March 18, 1930 Kavi Rajchandra was born in a place called Vavania in Kathiawar.
('48', 450, 4, 22, 999402) I came in touch with him in 1891, the day of my return from London, at Dr. P. J. Mehta’s residence in Bombay.
('48', 450, 4, 23, 999512) Kavi, as I used to call him, was nearly related to Dr. Mehta.
('48', 450, 4, 24, 999574) He was introduced to me as a shatavadhani, i.e., one who can remember a hundred things at a time.
('48', 450, 4, 25, 999672) Kavi was quite young at the time, not much older
('48', 450, 5, 26, 999721) 1 This has been extracted from “Dharma Yatra”.
('48', 450, 5, 27, 999768) 2 This speech was delivered after one of the satyagrahis had had an attack of smallpox and had to be left behind at Anand, where Gandhiji was on March 16 and 17.

('48', 451, 1, 2, 999972) than I was then, i.e., 21 years.
('48', 451, 1, 3, 1000005) He had, however, given up all public exhibition of his powers and was given to purely religious pursuits.
('48', 451, 1, 4, 1000111) I was much struck by his simplicity and independence of judgment.
('48', 451, 1, 5, 1000177) He was free from all touch of blind orthodoxy.
('48', 451, 1, 6, 1000224) What struck me perhaps more was his combining business with religion in practice.
('48', 451, 1, 7, 1000306) A student of the philosophy of religion, he tried to practise what he believed.
('48', 451, 1, 8, 1000386) Himself a Jain, his toleration of the other creeds was remarkable.
('48', 451, 1, 9, 1000453) He had a chance of going to England for studies, but he would not go.
('48', 451, 1, 10, 1000523) He would not learn English.
('48', 451, 1, 11, 1000551) His schooling was quite elementary.
('48', 451, 1, 12, 1000587) But he was a genius.
('48', 451, 1, 13, 1000608) He knew Sanskrit, Magadhi and, I believe, Pali.
('48', 451, 1, 14, 1000656) He was a voracious reader of religious literature and had acquired through Gujarati sources a knowledge, enough for his purpose, of Islam, Christianity and Zoroastrianism.
('48', 451, 1, 15, 1000828) Such was the man who captivated my heart in religious matters as no other man has till now.
('48', 451, 1, 16, 1000920) I have said elsewhere that in moulding my inner life Tolstoy and Ruskin vied with Kavi.
('48', 451, 1, 17, 1001008) But Kavi’s influence was undoubtedly deeper if only because I had come in closest personal touch with him.
('48', 451, 1, 18, 1001115) His judgment appealed to my moral sense in the vast majority of cases.
('48', 451, 1, 19, 1001186) The bedrock of his faith was unquestionably ahimsa.
('48', 451, 1, 20, 1001238) His ahimsa was not of the crude type we witness today among its so called votaries who confine their attention merely to the saving of aged cattle and insect life.
('48', 451, 1, 21, 1001402) His ahimsa, if it included the tiniest insect, also covered the whole of humanity.
('48', 451, 1, 22, 1001485) Yet I never could regard Kavi as a perfect man.
('48', 451, 1, 23, 1001533) But of all the men I knew he appeared to me to be nearer perfection than the rest.
('48', 451, 1, 24, 1001616) he died all too young (thirty three years) when he felt that he was surely going to see truth face to face.
('48', 451, 1, 25, 1001724) He has had many worshippers but not as many followers.
('48', 451, 1, 26, 1001779) His writings, largely consisting or soulful letters to inquirers, have been collected and published.
('48', 451, 1, 27, 1001880) An attempt is being made to have them translated in Hindi.
('48', 451, 1, 28, 1001939) I know that they would bear an English translation.
('48', 451, 1, 29, 1001991) They are largely based on inward experience.

('48', 452, 5, 11, 1002873) 487. SPEECH AT BORSAD March 18, 1930 At one time I was wholly loyal to the Empire and taught others to be loyal.
('48', 452, 5, 12, 1002986) I sang “God Save the King” with zest and taught my friends and relations to do so.
('48', 452, 5, 13, 1003069) Finally, however, the scales fell from my eyes, and the spell broke.
('48', 452, 5, 14, 1003138) I realized that the Empire did not deserve loyalty.
('48', 452, 5, 15, 1003190) I felt that it deserved sedition.
('48', 452, 5, 16, 1003224) Hence I have made sedition my dharma.
('48', 452, 5, 17, 1003262) I try to explain it to others that while sedition is our dharma, to be loyal is a sin.
('48', 452, 5, 18, 1003349) To be loyal to this Government, that is to say to wish it well, is as good as wishing ill of the crores of people of India.
('48', 452, 5, 19, 1003473) We get nothing in return for the crores of rupees that are squeezed out of the country; if we get anything, it is the rags from Lancashire.
('48', 452, 5, 20, 1003613) To approve the policy of this Government is to commit treason against the poor.
('48', 452, 5, 21, 1003693) You should free yourselves from this latter offence.
('48', 452, 5, 22, 1003746) I believe I have done so.
('48', 452, 5, 23, 1003772) Hence I have become ready to wage a peaceful war against this Government.
('48', 452, 5, 24, 1003846) I am commencing it by violating the salt law.
('48', 452, 5, 25, 1003892) It is for this purpose that I am undertaking this march.
('48', 452, 5, 26, 1003949) At every place, thousands of men and women have conferred their blessings upon it.
('48', 452, 5, 27, 1004032) These blessings are not showered on me but on the struggle.
('48', 452, 5, 28, 1004092) Our patience has been severely tried.
('48', 452, 5, 29, 1004130) We must free ourselves
('48', 452, 6, 30, 1004153) 1 Gangabehn Vaidya 2 Narandas Gandhi

('48', 453, 1, 2, 1004232) from the yoke of this Government and we are prepared to undergo any hardships that we may have to suffer in order to secure swaraj.
('48', 453, 1, 3, 1004364) It is our duty as well as our right to secure swaraj.
('48', 453, 1, 4, 1004418) I regard this as a religious movement since sedition is our dharma.

('48', 453, 1, 9, 1004757) Today we are defying the salt law.
('48', 453, 1, 10, 1004792) Tomorrow we shall have to consign other laws to the waste paper basket.
('48', 453, 1, 11, 1004864) Doing so we shall practise such severe non co operation that finally it will not be possible for the administration to be carried on at all.
('48', 453, 1, 12, 1005005) Let the Government then, to carry on its rule, use guns against us, send us to prison, hang us.
('48', 453, 1, 13, 1005101) But how many can be given such punishment?

('48', 453, 1, 17, 1005401) Man does not have the strength to fight circumstances; the latter mould his actions.
('48', 453, 1, 18, 1005486) Hence I do not feel that they are to be blamed for this.
('48', 453, 1, 19, 1005543) But I find their policy so bitter, that I would destroy it today if I could.

('48', 453, 1, 22, 1005802) I am fully convinced that there is nothing base in it.
('48', 453, 1, 23, 1005857) I act exactly as I believe.
('48', 453, 1, 24, 1005885) No one has been able to reply to the complaint I have registered before God and mentioned in my letter to the Viceroy.
('48', 453, 1, 25, 1006004) No one says that the salt tax is just.
('48', 453, 1, 26, 1006043) No one says that the expenditure on the army and the administration is justified.
('48', 453, 1, 27, 1006125) No one holds that the policy of collecting land revenue is justifiable, nor indeed that it is proper to extort 20 to 25 crores of rupees from the people after making drunkards and opium addicts of them and breaking up their homes.
('48', 453, 1, 28, 1006356) Both foreigners and British officers testify to the fact that all this is true.
('48', 453, 1, 29, 1006436) However, what can be done about it?
('48', 453, 1, 30, 1006472) Money is required.
('48', 453, 1, 31, 1006491) For what purpose is it required?
('48', 453, 1, 32, 1006524) In order to repress the people.
('48', 453, 1, 33, 1006556) Recently the Government has appointed all police officers above the rank of constables as officers dealing with salt.
('48', 453, 1, 34, 1006674) As a result of the authority vested in him, even a policeman can arrest me and perpetrate any indignity on me that he likes; if he fails to arrest me he would be guilty of the offence of cowardice.
('48', 453, 1, 35, 1006872) Here we find this offence of cowardice which does not exist in any other Act of the Government.

('48', 454, 1, 2, 1007014) Any constable who sees us making salt, who sees us heating a pan of salt water, can arrest us, snatch away the pan and throw away the water.
('48', 454, 1, 3, 1007155) What can he feel in throwing away the salt?
('48', 454, 1, 4, 1007199) In Lansundra near Kapadvanj there is a mound of salt, which has been covered with dust.

('48', 454, 1, 8, 1007399) If you feel that I should be grateful to you for the purse you have presented to me, I should say I am grateful.
('48', 454, 1, 9, 1007512) But my hunger will not be satisfied with money.
('48', 454, 1, 10, 1007560) I desire that all of you men and women should enrol yourselves in this sacrificial movement.
('48', 454, 1, 11, 1007653) It is my cherished desire that all students studying in this high school who are above the age of fifteen, and all teachers too, should enrol themselves.
('48', 454, 1, 12, 1007807) Wherever revolutions have taken place, that is, in Japan, China, Egypt, Italy, Ireland and in England, students and teachers have played a prominent role.
('48', 454, 1, 13, 1007962) In Europe, war broke out on the 4th of August in 1914, and when I reached England on the 6th of that same month, I found that students had left colleges and marched out with arms.
('48', 454, 1, 14, 1008142) Here, in this righteous war, truth, non violence and forgiveness are the weapons.
('48', 454, 1, 15, 1008224) The consequence of using such weapons can only be beneficial, and it is the duty of every student and teacher to take part in such a struggle.
('48', 454, 1, 16, 1008367) At a time when the final struggle is being waged in order to free India from slavery, any student or teacher who takes shelter in his home or in the school will be regarded as having acted as a traitor to his country.
('48', 454, 1, 17, 1008585) Will you be engaged in learning poems by heart or in doing sums at a time when a person like Sardar is behind the bars?
('48', 454, 1, 18, 1008705) Just as when a house is on fire everyone comes out to extinguish it, similarly you should all come out to put an end to these sufferings of our country.
('48', 454, 1, 19, 1008858) Those who say that Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Jews and others have not united speak an untruth.
('48', 454, 1, 20, 1008956) This salt tax applies equally to all.
('48', 454, 1, 21, 1008994) If it is the case that whereas Hindus have to pay this tax, Muslims can get themselves exempted from it, they may very well do so.
('48', 454, 1, 22, 1009125) If anyone can save himself in this manner, I shall have to modify my dharma.
('48', 454, 1, 23, 1009202) I am prepared to get this tax abolished even if I have to prostrate myself on the ground in order to do so.
('48', 454, 1, 24, 1009310) Why should not everyone unite in order to have that tax abolished from which even a buffalo and a cow cannot escape?
('48', 454, 1, 25, 1009427) My prostrating myself on the ground for the sake of removing the hardships of crores of people was of no avail.
('48', 454, 1, 26, 1009539) I have spared no efforts in drafting appeals.
('48', 454, 1, 27, 1009585) Everyone knows that I know how to use polite language.
('48', 454, 1, 28, 1009640) However, I have become a revolutionary when politeness and persuasion proved infructuous.
('48', 454, 1, 29, 1009730) I find peace in

('48', 455, 1, 3, 1009866) In a revolution which is calm, peaceful and truthful, you should get yourselves enrolled regardless of the religion to which you belong.
('48', 455, 1, 4, 1010003) If you enlist yourselves with sincerity and if you can keep up your courage, the salt tax will have been abolished, this administration will have come to an end and all the hardships enumerated in the letter to the Viceroy as well as those which have not been so enumerated will have to cease.

('48', 456, 1, 2, 1011797) 489. SPEECH AT RAS March 19, 1930 Today we have entered the taluka in which Sardar Vallabhbhai was arrested and sentenced to prison and in which he had carried on such a vigorous struggle in 1924 that the Government had finally to admit its error and mete out justice that should not have required a struggle.
('48', 456, 1, 3, 1012107) It is as if Sardar was sentenced to prison as a reward for having served you!
('48', 456, 1, 4, 1012185) The question now is what you can do to serve the cause for which he has been sent to jail and what I should do.
('48', 456, 1, 5, 1012297) Some of the Headmen and Matadars have handed in their resignations.
('48', 456, 1, 6, 1012365) I congratulate them.
('48', 456, 1, 7, 1012386) However, there are still many who cannot abandon the line.
('48', 456, 1, 8, 1012445) I have not come across a single person who has accepted the post of a Headman for the sake of the salary attached to it.
('48', 456, 1, 9, 1012566) Headmen have the privilege of perpetrating indignities on the people or it may be said that they have the right to participate in the indignities perpetrated on the people.
('48', 456, 1, 10, 1012739) The improper reason for their clinging to their posts is that this privilege satisfies their base self interest or assists them in their work.
('48', 456, 1, 11, 1012882) But how much longer will you keep on doing your part in squeezing these villages?
('48', 456, 1, 12, 1012964) Have not your eyes yet been opened to the robbery that is being committed by the Government?
('48', 456, 1, 13, 1013057) The Headman, the Talati and the Ravania are the representatives of the Government in the villages, and it is through these persons that the latter carries on its administration.
('48', 456, 1, 14, 1013235) A village which is afraid of a handful of men and continues to act in a manner contrary to its own wishes, neither enhances the prestige of the Headman, the Talati or the Ravania nor that of the villagers themselves.
('48', 456, 1, 15, 1013452) Sardar was making great efforts to end this indignity.
('48', 456, 1, 16, 1013507) Sardar neither made speeches nor came here to foment trouble.
('48', 456, 1, 17, 1013569) Neither the Magistrate nor you had expected any sort of trouble.
('48', 456, 1, 18, 1013634) The task for which Sardar had approached you was not a secret to anyone.
('48', 456, 1, 19, 1013707) A satyagrahi has no secrets.
('48', 456, 1, 20, 1013736) Even a child can see how a satyagrahi stands, sits, eats and drinks.
('48', 456, 1, 21, 1013805) It can also examine the latter’s accounts.
('48', 456, 1, 22, 1013848) What secret can a satyagrahi like Sardar have?
('48', 456, 1, 23, 1013895) He had come here to clear the way for me.
('48', 456, 1, 24, 1013937) He had not come here to convey the message regarding salt.
('48', 456, 1, 25, 1013996) We had both so planned that it would be through me and those whom I took along with me that the salt law would be violated.
('48', 456, 1, 26, 1014120) You do not know many of the persons who are accompanying me.
('48', 456, 1, 27, 1014181) They are all public workers devoted to Sardar.
