('48', 459, 3, 6, 1019500) 491. NOTES
('48', 459, 4, 7, 1019511) SALT TAX
('48', 459, 5, 8, 1019520) Fifteen villagers of Bhangore and Matla in 24 Parganas District have been fined eight annas each by the Sub Divisional Officer of Alipore on a charge of illicit manufacture of salt.
('48', 459, 5, 9, 1019702) The men pleaded guilty and throwing themselves at the mercy of the Court, submitted they were too poor to buy salt and were manufacturing it for their own consumption.
('48', 459, 5, 10, 1019870) This seasonable item is from the public Press.
('48', 459, 5, 11, 1019917) Eight annas fine for poor people is no joke.
('48', 459, 5, 12, 1019962) The magistrate might have discharged the men with a caution or he might, as magistrates have done before now, have paid the fine from his own pocket, if he felt that he was bound to impose a penalty.
('48', 459, 5, 13, 1020162) It is likely of course that in that case, he might have laid himself open to the charge of cowardice under the Salt Act.
('48', 459, 5, 14, 1020283) Be that as it may, the fact that the men “threw themselves at the mercy of the court,” and “submitted that they were too poor to buy salt,” and that the magistrate rejected the plea of the villagers, is eloquent testimony in favour of the civil disobedience campaign.
('48', 459, 5, 15, 1020551) No milder agitation would have answered the purpose.
('48', 459, 5, 16, 1020604) Moreover, the salt tax is but a sample from the mountain of such grievances, from which it is the duty of every Indian who knows the wrongs being done to India to strain every nerve to free her.
('48', 459, 6, 17, 1020799) HOW TO BREAK IT
('48', 459, 7, 18, 1020815) A correspondent writes to say that there is no salt tax in Portuguese India, that Daman is quite near Pardi, that salt is sold at 2 annas per maund in Daman, and that any quantity may be imported from Daman and payment of tax refused on passing the British border.
('48', 459, 7, 19, 1021080) A similar suggestion has come too from Kathiawar.
('48', 459, 7, 20, 1021130) There also there is no tax, though there is the State monopoly which makes the salt dearer than the cost price.
('48', 459, 7, 21, 1021242) Nevertheless it is much cheaper than in the British territory.
('48', 459, 7, 22, 1021305) Thus a maund (cutcha) costs, I understand, Rs. 1 4 in Ranpur whereas the same quantity outside Ranpur will cost probably no more than 10 annas, if that.
('48', 459, 7, 23, 1021458) Anyway, when the instructions for civil disobedience on a mass scale are issued, there is no doubt that the salt law is the easiest to break.
('48', 459, 7, 24, 1021600) The Government is naturally preparing to combat the civillaw
('48', 460, 0, 1, 1021661) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 461
('48', 460, 1, 2, 1021707) breakers after its usual fashion.
('48', 460, 1, 3, 1021741) Every police officer above the rank of a constable in the Bombay Presidency except in Sind and Aden has been appointed a salt officer.
('48', 460, 1, 4, 1021876) These men, armed with new powers, may be fully expected to give a good account of themselves.
('48', 460, 1, 5, 1021970) And when they have stained their hands with innocent blood, there will be no doubt the usual inquiry followed by a repeal of the Salt Act.
('48', 460, 1, 6, 1022109) But this time the object of civil disobedience is double—the repeal of the tax and the repeal of the British bondage of which the salt tax is but an offshoot.
('48', 460, 1, 7, 1022268) No inquiry merely into the Salt Act followed by its repeal can stop the campaign of civil disobedience.
('48', 460, 1, 8, 1022372) It behoves all who want the repeal of the salt tax to join the agitation at least to that extent, unless they would have the tax rather than success of civil disobedience even for a specific grievance.
('48', 460, 2, 9, 1022574) SOMETHING ADDED, NOTHING DEDUCTED
('48', 460, 3, 10, 1022608) It has been said that I have now abandoned my first love and that I have given up Hindu Muslim unity, removal of untouchability and khaddar as conditions of swaraj.
('48', 460, 3, 11, 1022773) This is a mischievous suggestion.
('48', 460, 3, 12, 1022807) The fact is that I have given up nothing.
('48', 460, 3, 13, 1022849) Many new things have been added.
('48', 460, 3, 14, 1022882) Hence have I called the recent presentation a new orientation.
('48', 460, 3, 15, 1022945) There will be no swaraj without the old conditions being fulfilled.
('48', 460, 3, 16, 1023013) But there will be none if some more conditions are not also fulfilled.
('48', 460, 3, 17, 1023084) They might have been neglected altogether at the time of formulating the constitution.
('48', 460, 3, 18, 1023171) Now they form an integral part of any scheme of swaraj if it is conceived in the interest of the masses.
('48', 460, 3, 19, 1023276) Again civil disobedience is being offered irrespective of the full fruition of the various points; for it, being in substitution for an armed rebellion, can go on side by side with the prosecution of the amplified constructive programme— even as an armed man will be fighting, whilst the civil population may be engaged in various other national pursuits, suspending them to the extent necessary for supporting the armed man.
('48', 460, 3, 20, 1023702) There is no danger of any one of the conditions of swaraj being neglected or given up as those who are engaged in civil disobedience are irrevocably committed to them.
('48', 460, 3, 21, 1023870) The question therefore is, who are guiding the civil disobedience movement?
('48', 460, 3, 22, 1023946) It is well if they are pure nationalists not directly or indirectly fostering communalism.
('48', 460, 3, 23, 1024037) Civil disobedience is the method whereby the nation is to generate the strength to reach her formulated goal.

('48', 461, 3, 13, 1025279) 492. THE CHOICE BEFORE STUDENTS It has been often said that the money spent on national education in general and the Gujarat Vidyapith in particular has been so much waste.
('48', 461, 3, 14, 1025452) In my opinion the Gujarat Vidyapith by its supreme sacrifice has more than justified its existence, the hopes entertained by its authors and the grants made to it by donors.
('48', 461, 3, 15, 1025626) For the Vidyapith has suspended its literary activities save for boys under 16 who are already under training there.
('48', 461, 3, 16, 1025743) The teachers and students of over 15 years of age have offered their services as volunteers and nearly forty students with the teachers are already in the field.
('48', 461, 3, 17, 1025905) A class for giving fifteen days’ emergency training in connection with satyagraha has been opened for the sake of those who may need such training.
('48', 461, 3, 18, 1026053) I congratulate the students and the teachers on the promptitude with which they have acted.
('48', 461, 3, 19, 1026145) I may state that twenty of these are with me on the march.
('48', 461, 3, 20, 1026204) They are divided into two parties, both preceding the 80 pilgrims to make preparations in advance and assisting the villagers.
('48', 461, 3, 21, 1026331) They are under orders not to offer civil resistance till the 80 are arrested and immediately to replace them as soon as they are arrested.
('48', 461, 3, 22, 1026470) I am sure that every national educational institution will copy the noble example of the Gujarat Vidyapith which was the first to come into being in response to the call of non co operationin 1920. And I hope that the Government and aided institutions will also copy the example.
('48', 461, 3, 23, 1026750) Every revolution of modern times has found students in the forefront.
('48', 461, 3, 24, 1026820) This, because it is peaceful, ought not to offer less attraction to the students.
('48', 461, 3, 25, 1026902) The motto of the Gujarat Vidyapith is: .
('48', 461, 3, 26, 1026943) It means:
('48', 462, 0, 1, 1026953) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 463
('48', 462, 1, 2, 1026999) That is knowledge which is designed for salvation.
('48', 462, 1, 3, 1027050) On the principle that the greater includes the less, national independence or material freedom is included in the spiritual.
('48', 462, 1, 4, 1027175) The knowledge gained in educational institutions must therefore at least teach the way and lead to such freedom.
('48', 462, 1, 5, 1027288) The most superficial observer will not fail to notice that the daily routine of the satyagrahi pilgrims constitutes by itself a perfect education.
('48', 462, 1, 6, 1027435) It is not a company of violent rebels who are moving about creating ravages and letting loose every passion; it is a band of self restrained men who have declared non violent rebellion against organized tyranny and who seek to secure freedom from it by severe self suffering, spreading on their march the message of freedom through non violence and truth.
('48', 462, 1, 7, 1027791) No father need feel the slightest anxiety about dedicating his son or daughter to what is after all the truest education that can be conceived in the existing circumstances of the country.
('48', 462, 1, 8, 1027980) Let me distinguish between the call of 1920 and the present call.
('48', 462, 1, 9, 1028046) The call of 1920 was for emptying Government institutions and bringing into being national ones.
('48', 462, 1, 10, 1028143) It was a call for preparation.
('48', 462, 1, 11, 1028174) Today the call is for engaging in the final conflict, i.
('48', 462, 1, 12, 1028231) e., for mass civil disobedience.
('48', 462, 1, 13, 1028264) This may or may not come.
('48', 462, 1, 14, 1028290) It will not come if those who have been hitherto the loudest in their cry for liberty have no action in them.
('48', 462, 1, 15, 1028400) If the salt loses its savour, wherewith shall it be salted?
('48', 462, 1, 16, 1028460) The students are expected to precipitate a crisis not by empty meaningless cries but by mute, dignified, unchallengeable action worthy of students.
('48', 462, 1, 17, 1028608) It may again be that the students have no faith in self sacrifice, and less in non violence.
('48', 462, 1, 18, 1028701) Then naturally they will not and need not come out.
('48', 462, 1, 19, 1028753) They may then, like the revolutionaries, whose letter is reproduced in another column, wait and see what non violence in action can do.
('48', 462, 1, 20, 1028889) It will be sportsmanlike for them either to give themselves whole heartedly to this non violent revolt or to remain neutral, and (if they like) critical, observers of the developing events.
('48', 462, 1, 21, 1029079) They will disturb and harm the movement, if they will act as they choose and without fitting in with the plan of the authors or even in defiance of them.
('48', 462, 1, 22, 1029233) This I know, that if civil disobedience is not developed to the fullest extent possible now, it may not be for another generation.
('48', 462, 1, 23, 1029364) The choice before the students is clear.
('48', 462, 1, 24, 1029405) Let them make it.The awakening of the past ten years has not left them unmoved.
('48', 462, 1, 25, 1029485) Let them take the final plunge.

('48', 464, 2, 9, 1033093) 495. SWARAJ AND RAMARAJYA No matter in how many ways swaraj may have been defined, no matter how many interpretations I myself may have given it, to me its only meaning which is eternally valid is Ramarajya.
('48', 464, 2, 10, 1033301) If the word Ramarajya offends anyone, then I shall call it ‘Dharmarajya’.
('48', 464, 2, 11, 1033375) The sense of the word Ramarajya is this that under such a rule the poor will be fully protected, everything will be done with justice, and the voice of the people will always be respected.
('48', 464, 2, 12, 1033564) But in order to attain Ramarajya all must help.
('48', 464, 2, 13, 1033612) But in order to achieve this khadi alone is the universal and constructive instrument.
('48', 464, 2, 14, 1033699) But in order toincrease the power of the people something else with a wider appeal was needed.
('48', 464, 2, 15, 1033794) That something is salt tax.
('48', 464, 2, 16, 1033822) Both the poor and the rich use salt equally and because a tax is levied on this universally useful thing, one that is necessary for everyone, one and all can offer civil disobedience against the salt tax law and thus strengthen their power.
('48', 464, 2, 17, 1034063) The power that we shall gain by this sort of civil disobedience will, because of its civil and peaceable nature, help us in securing Ramarajya.
('48', 464, 2, 18, 1034207) There are many other taxes like the salt tax which weigh heavily on the people and in resisting which people can get a good training, and their strength can increase.
('48', 464, 2, 19, 1034374) Ramarajya, by such means, will become easy to establish.
('48', 464, 2, 20, 1034431) No one can predict when we shall attain full Ramarajya.
('48', 464, 2, 21, 1034487) But it is the duty of every one of us to contemplate it day and night.
('48', 464, 2, 22, 1034558) And true contemplation is that in which proper methods also have been used for the establishment of Ramarajya.
('48', 464, 2, 23, 1034669) It should be remembered that in order to establish Ramarajya no

('48', 468, 5, 17, 1042264) [AMOD , March 22, 1930] 2 Q. What part do you expect the youth movement to play in the present struggle?
('48', 468, 5, 18, 1042369) A. The Youth League can do a great deal.
('48', 468, 5, 19, 1042410) They can supply recruits in large numbers in the civil disobedience campaign.
('48', 468, 5, 20, 1042488) They can, moreover, help to carry the message of independence to every nook and corner of the land.
('48', 468, 5, 21, 1042588) They can usefully picket foreign cloth and liquor shops.
('48', 468, 6, 22, 1042645) 1 Mir Alam; vide “My Reward”, 22 2 1908. 2 According to the source this was published in the Vanguard, 22 3 1930. Gandhiji, however, arrived in Amod on the evening of the 22nd.

('48', 469, 1, 2, 1042864) Those of its members who are unable to participate actively in the present campaign can render good service in the realm ofsocial reforming, popularizing khaddar and swadeshi articles, in pushing forward prohibition propaganda, etc.
('48', 469, 1, 3, 1043097) Indeed at this juncture great things are expected from the youth of the country and I have no doubt they will fully rise to the occasion.
('48', 469, 1, 4, 1043235) Q. Will you advise students to leave schools and colleges immediately?
('48', 469, 1, 5, 1043306) A. Yes.
('48', 469, 1, 6, 1043314) I wish to point out that the present appeal to the students differs from that of 1921. In the latter case, the students were asked to quit their Government controlled educational institutions and join national educational institutions.
('48', 469, 1, 7, 1043550) The present call is: Suspend your studies and join in the fight for freedom.
('48', 469, 1, 8, 1043627) When victory is won and you happen to be alive, you will resume your studies in schools of our own Government.
('48', 469, 1, 9, 1043738) For to my mind it is a fight to the finish.
('48', 469, 1, 10, 1043782) The greatest service that the youth can now render is to empty schools and colleges and swell the ranks of satyagrahi volunteers.
('48', 469, 1, 11, 1043912) Q. Would you advise Youth Leagues to call out even those students whose examinations are a month or even a week ahead?
('48', 469, 1, 12, 1044031) A. Yes.
('48', 469, 1, 13, 1044039) If the students themselves feel the call they should come out at once.
('48', 469, 1, 14, 1044110) As I said, I consider it a fight to the finish.
('48', 469, 1, 15, 1044158) If they have not the faith, they won’t do it.
('48', 469, 1, 16, 1044204) Q. Would you approve of the suggestion mooted in Youth League circles that the houses of “blackleg” M.L.C.’s who have not resigned their seats and those of selected other officials be picketed, and they be harassed in other ways as much as possible?
('48', 469, 1, 17, 1044454) A. I should say no.
('48', 469, 1, 18, 1044474) During the N.C.O. 1 days three specific instances of this type came to my notice.
('48', 469, 1, 19, 1044556) They did no good.
('48', 469, 1, 20, 1044574) I know they did harm.
('48', 469, 1, 21, 1044596) Q. Would you suggest any method by which the Muslims could be still more attracted to the Congress fold and protected from the pernicious propaganda of communalists?
('48', 469, 1, 22, 1044762) ‘ A. The best way to increase Muslim interest in the Congress is for Congressmen to serve them.
('48', 469, 1, 23, 1044858) Convince them that the Congress is as much theirs as anybody else’s.
('48', 469, 1, 24, 1044927) My present programme—the breaking of the salt laws—should appeal to all the communities in India, for it affects them all alike.
('48', 469, 1, 25, 1045056) I am an optimist.
('48', 469, 1, 26, 1045074) I have no doubt that soon the Congress will stand higher in the affections of the Muslims than it ever did before.
('48', 469, 1, 27, 1045189) The masses are sound at heart.
('48', 469, 1, 28, 1045220) They only require a correct and courageous lead.I repeat that the best way of winning over the Mussalmans is by seeking occasions

('48', 470, 1, 4, 1045632) A. If I am not arrested till I reach Jalalpur, I expect that the Provinces will be free to start civil disobedience soon after I have committed the breach of Salt Act.

('48', 474, 3, 4, 1052191) 513. DRAFT RESOLUTION FOR A.I.C.C. [March 25, 1930] 1
('48', 474, 4, 5, 1052245) This meeting of A.I.C.C. endorses the resolution 2 passed by the Working Committee giving full authority to Gandhiji in the matter of civil disobedience and congratulates him and his companions and the country on the march begun by him on 12th instant, 3 in pursuit of his plan of civil disobedience.
('48', 474, 4, 6, 1052546) The Committee hopes that the whole country will respond to the action taken by G. and his band in a manner befitting the occasion .
('48', 474, 4, 7, 1052678) The A.I.C.C. hereby authorizes the Provincial C.C.s to undertake such civil disobedience as to them may seem proper and in the manner that may appear to them to be most suitable.
('48', 474, 4, 8, 1052857) The committee, however, hopes that so far as is possible the Provinces shall concentrate on a civil breach of the Salt laws.
('48', 474, 4, 9, 1052982) The committee trusts that whilst preparations may be fully made civil disobedience for Poorna Swaraj shall not start till Gandhiji has reached his destination, actually committed a breach of the Salt laws and given the word to the other Provinces through this committee or he has been earlier arrested.
('48', 474, 4, 10, 1053285) In the purview of the A.I.C.C. time has arrived for all educational institutions whether Government owned, aided or national to suspend their literary activities and devote their whole attention to the compaign for liberty.
('48', 474, 4, 11, 1053509) The A.I.C.C. congratulates Sardar Vallabhbhai, Sjt.
('48', 474, 4, 12, 1053561) Sen Gupta on their arrest and notes with satisfaction that their arrestinstead of weakening has strengthened the national resolve to reach the goal without any delay.

('48', 481, 1, 2, 1068192) 519. MOUNTAIN IN LABOUR The mountain was in labour in Rangoon and it brought forth a ridiculous mouse.
('48', 481, 1, 3, 1068295) A powerful Government put a distinguished son of India, who was suffering from a dangerous illness, under the strain of an utterly unnecessary prosecution, and spent public money.
('48', 481, 1, 4, 1068475) The ostensible reason was that Sjt.
('48', 481, 1, 5, 1068511) Sen Gupta had delivered, whilst he was passing through Burma, two speeches the like of which are delivered every day from a thousand platforms all over the country without being noticed by the Government.
('48', 481, 1, 6, 1068716) The prosecution could find no witness who was affected by the “seditious” performance.
('48', 481, 1, 7, 1068803) The magistrate was apologetic for having to deliver the judgment he did.
('48', 481, 1, 8, 1068876) Had he been in an environment of freedom he would have discharged the distinguished prisoner and reprimanded the Government for bringing a frivolous complaint before him.
('48', 481, 1, 9, 1069047) Sen Gupta is none the worse for the prosecution.
('48', 481, 1, 10, 1069096) It has enhanced his popularity, and his resolute refusal to defend himself or to answer any questions has furnished an additional proof of the courage for which he has always been known.
('48', 481, 1, 11, 1069283) But this judgment has a deeper meaning.
('48', 481, 1, 12, 1069323) If Sardar Vallabhbhai was really guilty of the crime imputed to him, he deserved a severer punishment; if Sjt.
('48', 481, 1, 13, 1069434) Sen Gupta was guilty of sedition he deserved exemplary punishment, not mere ten days.
('48', 481, 1, 14, 1069520) If disaffection is a crime and the section has any reality about it, I who have made of sedition a religion should have been tried and heavily punished long ago.
('48', 481, 1, 15, 1069682) Let no one think that lighter punishments are being awarded or I am being left alone because the Government is afraid of anything.
('48', 481, 1, 16, 1069813) The real reason is deeper and perhaps creditable to the Government.
('48', 481, 1, 17, 1069881) They are ashamed of punishing people for holding opinions and publicly expressing them.
('48', 481, 1, 18, 1069969) They are sensitive to the world opinion rising against them for such conduct.
('48', 481, 1, 19, 1070047) The Rangoon magistrate felt constrained to say that inasmuch as there was in Sjt.
('48', 481, 1, 20, 1070129) Sen Gupta’s speech no incitement to violence, he saw no reason to award a penalty befitting the crime of sedition.
('48', 481, 1, 21, 1070244) Section 124A is really concerned with violence.
('48', 481, 1, 22, 1070292) The authors of the section probably never conceived the possibility of anybody harbouring sedition and yet having no trace of violence in him.
('48', 481, 1, 23, 1070435) This reluctance or evenincapacity to punish heavily or even to prosecute in the absence of violence is an eloquent tribute to non violence.
('48', 481, 1, 24, 1070575) He who runs may see that if the campaign that has hitherto remained wholly untainted by violence retains its character, victory in the near future is a certainty.
('48', 481, 1, 25, 1070738) Not only will the salt tax go, but the other difficulties in our progress towards swaraj will also vanish like smoke, in the pure air of non violence.
('48', 481, 1, 26, 1070889) Young India, 27 3 1930
('48', 482, 0, 1, 1070912) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 483
('48', 482, 1, 2, 1070958) 520. ‘RENDER UNTO CAESAR’ An unknown English friend has thought it worth while cabling to me that in launching upon civil disobedience I am going against the teaching of Jesus: “Render unto Caesar that which is Caesar’s”.
('48', 482, 1, 3, 1071180) Another, an Indian Christian, writes from the Punjab somewhat in the same fashion and, forsaking charity, pours abuse upon my devoted head for my action.
('48', 482, 1, 4, 1071334) He says further that whereas he considered me to be a good man formerly, he is now utterly undeceived.
('48', 482, 1, 5, 1071437) I can reassure this friend that civil disobedience is no new thing with me.
('48', 482, 1, 6, 1071513) I began to preach and practise it in 1906. His regard for me therefore was evidently from ignorance, if his present dislike of me is wise.
('48', 482, 1, 7, 1071652) But I have learnt from the New Testament, as also from other sources, that if one wishes to walk in the fear of God, one should be indifferent about popular praise or blame.
('48', 482, 1, 8, 1071826) Now for the question.
('48', 482, 1, 9, 1071848) As I hold my conduct to be in utter agreement with universal religion and as I hold the New Testament teaching in great esteem, I should not like it to be justly said of me that I was going against the teaching of Jesus.
('48', 482, 1, 10, 1072069) “Render unto Caesar” was quoted against me before too.
('48', 482, 1, 11, 1072124) I have not read into the celebrated verse the meaning that my critics have sought to put into it.
('48', 482, 1, 12, 1072222) Jesus evaded the direct question put to him because it was a trap.
('48', 482, 1, 13, 1072289) He was in no way bound to answer it.
('48', 482, 1, 14, 1072326) He therefore asked to see the coin for taxes.
('48', 482, 1, 15, 1072372) And then said with withering scorn, “How can you who traffic in Caesar’s coins and thus receive what to you are benefits of Caesar’s rule refuse to pay taxes?” Jesus’s whole preaching and practice point unmistakably to non co operation, which necessarily includes nonpayment of taxes.
('48', 482, 1, 16, 1072657) Jesus never recognized man’s authority as against God’s.
('48', 482, 1, 17, 1072714) He who disregarded the whole host of priesthood, which was in those days superior to kinghood, would not have hesitated to defy the might of emperors had he found it necessary.
('48', 482, 1, 18, 1072891) And did he not treat with supreme disdain the whole of the farcical trial through which he was made to pass?
('48', 482, 1, 19, 1073000) Lastly, let me warn honest friends against running into the trap of literalism.
('48', 482, 1, 20, 1073080) The “letter” surely “killeth”, it is the “spirit” that “giveth life”.
('48', 482, 1, 21, 1073150) In the present case I find no difficulty in reading into the text a satisfactory meaning.
('48', 482, 1, 22, 1073240) But it would matter little to me that some text should confound me, if there was no mistaking the spirit of the whole teaching of a book respected as among the world’s religious scriptures.
('48', 482, 1, 23, 1073430) Young India, 27 3 1930
('48', 483, 0, 1, 1073453) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 483, 1, 2, 1073495) 521. DUTY OF DISLOYALTY There is no halfway house between active loyalty and active disloyalty.
('48', 483, 1, 3, 1073591) There is much truth in the late Justice Stephen’s remark that a man to prove himself not guilty of disaffection must prove himself to be actively affectionate.
('48', 483, 1, 4, 1073751) In these days of democracy there is no such thing as active loyalty to a, person.
('48', 483, 1, 5, 1073833) You are therefore loyal or disloyal to institutions.
('48', 483, 1, 6, 1073886) When therefore you are disloyal you seek not to destroy persons but institutions.
('48', 483, 1, 7, 1073968) The present State is an institution which, if one knows it, can never evoke loyalty.
('48', 483, 1, 8, 1074053) It is corrupt.
('48', 483, 1, 9, 1074068) Many of its laws governing the conduct of persons are positively inhuman.
('48', 483, 1, 10, 1074142) Their administration is worse.
('48', 483, 1, 11, 1074173) Often the will of one person is the law.
('48', 483, 1, 12, 1074214) It may safely be said that there are as many rulers as there are districts in this country.
('48', 483, 1, 13, 1074306) These, called Collectors, combine in their own persons the executive as well as the judicial functions.
('48', 483, 1, 14, 1074410) Though their acts are supposed to be governed by laws in themselves highly defective, these rulers are often capricious and regulated by nothing but their own whims and fancies.
('48', 483, 1, 15, 1074588) They represent not the interests of the people but those of their foreign masters or principals.
('48', 483, 1, 16, 1074685) These (nearly three hundred) men form an almost secret corporation, the most powerful in the world.
('48', 483, 1, 17, 1074785) They are required to find a fixed minimum of revenue, they have therefore often been found to be most unscrupulous in their dealings with the people.
('48', 483, 1, 18, 1074935) This system of government is confessedly based upon a merciless exploitation of unnumbered millions of the inhabitants of India.
('48', 483, 1, 19, 1075064) From the village Headmen to their personal assistants these satraps have created a class of subordinates who, whilst they cringe before their foreign masters, in their constant dealings with the people act so irresponsibly and so harshly as to demoralize them and by a system of terrorism render them incapable of resisting corruption.
('48', 483, 1, 20, 1075400) It is then the duty of those who have realized the awful evil of the system of Indian Government to be disloyal to it and actively and openly to preach disloyalty.
('48', 483, 1, 21, 1075564) Indeed, loyalty to a State so corrupt is a sin, disloyalty a virtue.
('48', 483, 1, 22, 1075633) The spectacle of three hundred million people being cowed down by living in the dread of three hundred men is demoralizing alike for the despots as for the victims.
('48', 483, 1, 23, 1075798) It is the duty of those who have realized the evil nature of the system however attractive some of its features may, torn from their context, appear to be, to destroy it without delay.
('48', 483, 1, 24, 1075983) It is their clear duty to run any risk to achieve the end.
('48', 483, 1, 25, 1076042) But it must be equally clear that it would be cowardly for three hundred million people to seek to destroy the three hundred authors or administrators of the system.
('48', 483, 1, 26, 1076208) It is a sign of gross ignorance to
('48', 484, 0, 1, 1076243) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 485
('48', 484, 1, 2, 1076289) devise means of destroying these administrators or their hirelings.
('48', 484, 1, 3, 1076357) Moreover they are but creatures of circumstances.
('48', 484, 1, 4, 1076407) The purest man entering the system will be affected by it and will be instrumental in propagating the evil.
('48', 484, 1, 5, 1076515) The remedy therefore naturally is not being enraged against the administrators and therefore hurting them, but to non co operate with the system by withdrawing all the voluntary assistance possible and refusing all its so called benefits.
('48', 484, 1, 6, 1076754) A little reflection will show that civil disobedience is a necessary part of non co operation.
('48', 484, 1, 7, 1076849) You assist an administration most effectively by obeying its orders and decrees.
('48', 484, 1, 8, 1076930) An evil administration never deserves such allegiance.
('48', 484, 1, 9, 1076985) Allegiance to it means partaking of the evil.
('48', 484, 1, 10, 1077031) A good man will therefore resist an evil system or administration with his whole soul.
('48', 484, 1, 11, 1077118) Disobedience of the law of an evil State is therefore a duty.
('48', 484, 1, 12, 1077180) Violent disobedience deals with men who can be replaced.
('48', 484, 1, 13, 1077237) It leaves the evil itself untouched and often accentuates it.
('48', 484, 1, 14, 1077299) Non violent, i.e., civil, disobedience is the only and the most successful remedy and is obligatory upon him who would dissociate himself from evil.
('48', 484, 1, 15, 1077448) There is danger in civil disobedience only because it is still only a partially tried remedy and has always to be tried in an atmosphere surcharged with violence.
('48', 484, 1, 16, 1077611) For when tyranny is rampant much rage is generated among the victims.
('48', 484, 1, 17, 1077681) It remains latent because of their weakness and bursts in all its fury on the slightest pretext.
('48', 484, 1, 18, 1077778) Civil disobedience is a sovereign method of transmuting this undisciplined life destroying latent energy into disciplined life saving energy whose use ensures absolute success.
('48', 484, 1, 19, 1077955) The attendant risk is nothing compared to the result promised.
('48', 484, 1, 20, 1078018) When the world has become familiar with its use and when it has had a series of demonstrations of its successful working, there will be less risk in civil disobedience than there is in aviation, in spite of that science having reached a high stage of development.

('48', 485, 2, 13, 1079964) 523. SOME SUGGESTIONS The resolution passed by the A.I.C.C. at its Ahmedabad meeting throws the burden on me of giving the signal for starting civil disobedience all over the country, assuming that I am kept free till I reach Dandi.
('48', 485, 2, 14, 1080197) The reason is obvious.
('48', 485, 2, 15, 1080220) The A.I.C.C. wishes to take every reasonable precaution against mishaps.
('48', 485, 2, 16, 1080293) In the event of my arrest, it would be dangerous to stop the movement.
('48', 485, 2, 17, 1080364) Before my arrest, the A.I.C.C. will not anticipate me.
('48', 485, 2, 18, 1080419) So far as I can judge now, the workers may assume that the date for making an all India start will be the 6th of April.
('48', 485, 2, 19, 1080539) It is the day of commencement of the national week.
('48', 485, 2, 20, 1080591) It is the day of satyagraha that in 1919 witnessed a mass awakening unknown before.
('48', 485, 2, 21, 1080675) The seven days that followed witnessed some dark deeds on our part and culminated in the inhuman Jallianwala massacre.
('48', 485, 2, 22, 1080794) If all goes well I should reach Dandi on April 5th.
('48', 485, 2, 23, 1080846) April 6th therefore appears to me to be the most natural day for commencing satyagraha.
('48', 485, 2, 24, 1080934) But the workers, while they may make preparations, must await the final word.
('48', 485, 2, 25, 1081012) The release of the embargo however does not mean that every province or every district is bound at once to commence civil disobedience although it may not be ready and although its First Servant does not feel the inner urge.
('48', 485, 2, 26, 1081237) He will refuse to be hustled into action if he has no confidence in himself or in his immediate surroundings.
('48', 485, 2, 27, 1081347) No one will be blamed for inaction, but blame will most decidedly descend upon the shoulders of him who instead of controlling the surroundings is carried away by them.
('48', 486, 0, 1, 1081516) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 487
('48', 486, 1, 2, 1081562) What we all are after is mass civil disobedience.
('48', 486, 1, 3, 1081612) It cannot be made.
('48', 486, 1, 4, 1081631) It must be spontaneous, if it is to deserve the name and if it is to be successful.
('48', 486, 1, 5, 1081715) And there certainly will be no mass response where the ground has not been previously tilled, manured and watered.
('48', 486, 1, 6, 1081830) The greatest precaution has to be taken everywhere against an outbreak of violence.
('48', 486, 1, 7, 1081914) Whilst it is true, as I have said, that civil resistance this time will continue even though violence may break out, it is equally true that violence on our part will harm the struggle and retard its progress.
('48', 486, 1, 8, 1082124) Two opposite forces can never work concurrently so as to help each other.
('48', 486, 1, 9, 1082198) The plan of civil disobedience has been conceived to neutralize and ultimately entirely to displace violence and enthrone non violence in its stead, to replace hatred by love, to replace strife by concord.
('48', 486, 1, 10, 1082404) The meaning then of not suspending the fight in spite of any outbreak of violence simply is that votaries of non violence will allow themselves, will even seek, to be consumed in the flames if any should rise.
('48', 486, 1, 11, 1082614) They will not care to remain helpless witnesses either of the organized violence of the Government or of the sporadic violence of an enraged group or nation.
('48', 486, 1, 12, 1082772) The workers will therefore take, in each province, all precautions humanly possible and then plunge into the fight even though in so doing they run the greatest risks imaginable.
('48', 486, 1, 13, 1082951) It follows that everywhere there will be willing submission to the judgment of those who may be in their own provinces known for their belief in non violence as an article of faith for the purpose of gaining Purna Swaraj.
('48', 486, 1, 14, 1083173) There has been talk of disobeying other laws.

('48', 487, 3, 20, 1086285) SCARCITY OF KHADDAR There is naturally nowadays a run on khaddar and letters are being received at the A.I.S.A. office that there is going to be shortage of khaddar in the near future.
('48', 487, 3, 21, 1086470) This is as it should be.
('48', 487, 3, 22, 1086495) The remedy is for full khaddarites to cut down their requirements, for converts to buy only what they need and for all to help to manufacture more khaddar.
('48', 487, 3, 23, 1086651) Just as there never can be scarcity of bread if there is an ensured supply of wheat, so need there be no scarcity of khaddar if there is an ensured supply of cotton.
('48', 487, 3, 24, 1086817) There is no danger of the supply of the cotton running out.
('48', 487, 3, 25, 1086877) The tragedy consists in the people needlessly believing that khaddar cannot be manufactured in our
('48', 488, 0, 1, 1086976) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 489
('48', 488, 1, 2, 1087022) villages and streets as food is prepared in every home.

('48', 488, 1, 13, 1088291) Mirabai became head of the sanitary department as other women took up other departments in order to relieve the men joining me in the march.

('48', 492, 1, 2, 1096472) 530. SPEECH AT MANGAROL March 27, 1930 Let us be under no delusion.
('48', 492, 1, 3, 1096540) As long as we accept the presence of God’s hand behind all things, we may keep up our courage and self confidence and believe the abolition of salt tax a certainty.
('48', 492, 1, 4, 1096705) So far we had been untrue to our salt, but now we must be true to it.
('48', 492, 1, 5, 1096775) It was only on the 12th that we started talking about breaking the salt law.
('48', 492, 1, 6, 1096852) But we have been speaking of two or three other things since 1920. If you remember, according to the Bezwada Congress programme, we were to have two million spinning wheels working and to boycott all foreign cloth.
('48', 492, 1, 7, 1097067) How much of that have we accomplished?
('48', 492, 1, 8, 1097106) This is a painful, shameful thing.
('48', 492, 1, 9, 1097141) The same can be said about the drink habit.
('48', 492, 1, 10, 1097185) Liquor is being freely consumed.
('48', 492, 1, 11, 1097218) In regard to these two, we believe that we shall be able to enforce them only when we have captured power.
('48', 492, 1, 12, 1097325) But take it from me that the power to remove this Government will drop into our hands when we do away with the evils of foreign cloth and liquor.
('48', 492, 1, 13, 1097471) If we mean to work, here is work for us.
('48', 492, 1, 14, 1097512) All men in this village eat salt; let them manufacture salt for their own use.
('48', 492, 1, 15, 1097591) Even children should openly steal salt, as it were.
('48', 492, 1, 16, 1097643) Let us burn foreign cloth and buy khadi to wear in its place, or manufacture it with our own hands.
('48', 492, 1, 17, 1097743) At the same time, we should see the licence holders running liquor booths and persuade them to close the booths.
('48', 492, 1, 18, 1097856) We shall then enjoy fighting for swaraj and become really interested in swaraj.
('48', 492, 1, 19, 1097936) We shall win it only when we do all these things.
('48', 492, 1, 20, 1097986) The fight may start even before the 6th of next month.
('48', 492, 1, 21, 1098041) It only awaits my arrest.
('48', 492, 1, 22, 1098067) No sooner do they arrest me than you should start making salt.
('48', 492, 1, 23, 1098130) When I am arrested, you may do with only a loin cloth but wear no foreign cloth at all.
('48', 492, 1, 24, 1098218) I repeat even today my old slogan: swaraj hangs by the hand spun yarn and the khadi woven from it.
('48', 492, 1, 25, 1098317) [From Gujarati] Prajabandhu, 30 3 1930

('48', 493, 2, 11, 1099175) 532. SPEECH AT RAYMA 1
('48', 493, 3, 12, 1099198) March 28, 1930 I cannot live in a district where salt cannot be prepared.
('48', 493, 3, 13, 1099272) So although I am conscious of the affection you have all shown me I have to proceed to Dandi.
('48', 493, 3, 14, 1099366) Although I find it difficult to leave this district, I must go to Dandi and break the law.
('48', 493, 3, 15, 1099457) If on the 12th we can oppose this tax with the blessings of all, Hindus, Muslims, Christians and Parsis, we may take the law as abolished.
('48', 493, 3, 16, 1099596) All of you, Hindus and Muslims, should unite and start making large quantities of salt on the 6th.
('48', 493, 3, 17, 1099695) If the Government chooses to do so, it can even levy a tax on the mud that is dug out of the ground; so why should we pay this tax that it levies on salt?
('48', 493, 3, 18, 1099850) Just as poor women go about selling babul twigs which we use for cleaning our teeth, let us all set forthand sell salt to everyone.
('48', 493, 3, 19, 1099982) Shall we not even do this much for the poor millions?
('48', 493, 3, 20, 1100036) History has no instance of a tax as cruel as the salt tax.
('48', 493, 3, 21, 1100095) However, we shall not secure swaraj as soon as the salt duty is abolished.
('48', 493, 3, 22, 1100170) We have to become alert and do other things.
('48', 493, 3, 23, 1100215) We have to get rid of foreign cloth.
('48', 493, 3, 24, 1100252) It is not enough that we wear khadi made in the Punjab.
('48', 493, 3, 25, 1100308) Every one of us should spin for himself and have cloth made out of that yarn.
('48', 493, 3, 26, 1100386) It is our stupidity that we do not all—from children to old men —engage ourselves in this simple and beautiful task.
('48', 493, 3, 27, 1100503) This bespeaks disloyalty towards our country.
('48', 493, 3, 28, 1100549) We can win swaraj immediately by getting rid of foreign cloth and liquor.
('48', 493, 3, 29, 1100623) After having won independence for India, we shall carry out our tasks from the seat of office.
('48', 493, 3, 30, 1100718) Hence by participating in this salt satyagraha and by accomplishing these two other objectives—the latter by those who cannot participate in the struggle itself—you should demonstrate the fact that the Broach district is wholly engaged in India’s freedom struggle.

('48', 494, 4, 13, 1101596) 534. SPEECH AT UMRACHHI 3
('48', 494, 5, 14, 1101622) March 28, 1930 If a man wishes to undertake a march at the age of sixty one, he should go to the Himalayas, so that he can at least attain moksha, at least have darshan of God.
('48', 494, 5, 15, 1101799) But I have learnt an opposite dharma.
('48', 494, 5, 16, 1101837) I want to have this darshan through this march only.
('48', 494, 5, 17, 1101890) After having had darshan of you, I beg you also to participate in it.
('48', 494, 5, 18, 1101960) This is so because so long as we do not succeed in overthrowing the Satanic Government that exists in the country, we are all participants in it.
('48', 494, 5, 19, 1102106) Such participants will not attain moksha even if they go to Dhaulagiri.
('48', 494, 5, 20, 1102178) The darshan of God is fraught with difficulties.
('48', 494, 5, 21, 1102227) He dwells in the hearts of thirty crores of people.
('48', 494, 5, 22, 1102279) If you wish to catch a glimpse of Him there, you should establish total identification with their hearts.
('48', 494, 5, 23, 1102385) These thirty crores include all the skeletons of Orissa, Muslims, Parsis, Christians, Sikhs, men and women.
('48', 494, 5, 24, 1102493) We shall continue to be atheists and not believers so long as we do not achieve this unity with every section of the community.
('48', 494, 5, 25, 1102621) Hence I thought to myself that even at the age of sixty one, I must not rest in peace.
('48', 494, 5, 26, 1102708) How can there be any rest for me so long as this Empire is not destroyed?
('48', 494, 5, 27, 1102782) Until today I held my peace; I used to listen to and suffer hosts of friends.
('48', 494, 5, 28, 1102860) I was afraid lest people take to the wrong path.
('48', 494, 5, 29, 1102909) What if people did not listen to me?
('48', 494, 5, 30, 1102946) I felt, however, that I was a coward.
('48', 494, 5, 31, 1102984) This was a weakness of my spirit.
('48', 494, 5, 32, 1103018) What right did I have to distrust people?

('48', 495, 1, 2, 1103320) 535. SPEECH AT BHATGAM 1
('48', 495, 2, 3, 1103345) March 29, 1930 I have been asked to deliver a sermon.
('48', 495, 2, 4, 1103399) I have little fitness for the task.
('48', 495, 2, 5, 1103435) But tonight I propose to make a confession and turn the searchlight inward.
('48', 495, 2, 6, 1103511) You may call this introspection a sermon if you like.
('48', 495, 2, 7, 1103565) India in general and you in particular are acquainted with one part of my nature.
('48', 495, 2, 8, 1103647) Moreover, more than in any other part of Gujarat, in this district are concentrated workers who have come in closest touch with me.
('48', 495, 2, 9, 1103779) They know this habit of mine from personal experience.
('48', 495, 2, 10, 1103834) I am plain spoken.
('48', 495, 2, 11, 1103853) I have not hesitated to describe the mountain high faults of the Government in appropriate language.
('48', 495, 2, 12, 1103954) And I have not hesitated often to picture as mountain high our faults appearing to us as trifling.
('48', 495, 2, 13, 1104053) You know, the common rule is to see our own big lapses as tiny nothings.
('48', 495, 2, 14, 1104126) And when we do realize our blemishes somewhat, we at once pass them on to the broad shoulders of God and say He will take care of them; and then with safety thus assured we proceed from lapse to lapse.
('48', 495, 2, 15, 1104328) But as you know I have disregarded this rule for years.
('48', 495, 2, 16, 1104384) So doing, I have hurt the feelings of many friends and even lost some of them.
('48', 495, 2, 17, 1104463) Tonight I have to repeat the painful operation.
('48', 495, 3, 18, 1104511) I have already told the group of people who are accompanying me that this is the last week of our march.
('48', 495, 3, 19, 1104616) As we shall reach our destination next Saturday, we shall not have to march any further.
('48', 495, 3, 20, 1104705) But we shall be faced with another task.
('48', 495, 3, 21, 1104746) During this last week we shall have to go through Surat district.
('48', 495, 3, 22, 1104812) Only this morning at prayer time I was telling my companions that as we had entered the district in which we were to offer civil disobedience, we should insist on greater purification and intenser dedication.
('48', 495, 3, 23, 1105021) I warned them that as the district was more organized and contained many intimate co workers, there wasevery likelihood of our being pampered.
('48', 495, 3, 24, 1105164) I warned them against succumbing to their pampering.
('48', 495, 3, 25, 1105217) We are not angels.
('48', 495, 3, 26, 1105236) We are very weak, easily tempted.
('48', 495, 3, 27, 1105270) There are many lapses to our debit.
('48', 495, 3, 28, 1105306) God is great.
('48', 495, 3, 29, 1105320) Even today

('48', 498, 3, 30, 1113228) 536. LIMITS OF BOYCOTT In my speeches during this march I have said quite a lot about boycott.
('48', 498, 3, 31, 1113323) I have no idea how the newspapers have reported those parts of my speeches.
('48', 498, 3, 32, 1113399) It is necessary to consider and lay down the limits of boycott here as the subject is an important one.
('48', 498, 3, 33, 1113503) As this struggle is a sacred, truthful and non violent one, that is to say, as it is a religious struggle, it is absolutely essential that no mistake should be made consciously or otherwise.

('48', 499, 1, 2, 1113891) but harm it.
('48', 499, 1, 3, 1113904) Boycott has been working in two ways: one is directed against the Government officials and the other against those who do not respect public opinion—for instance, Headmen and such other persons.
('48', 499, 1, 4, 1114099) It is necessary, indeed it is our duty, not to bow to the official when he visits our village and not to go and pay homage to him.
('48', 499, 1, 5, 1114230) Non co operation implies that we should not attend to this official’s needs and provide no facilities to him.
('48', 499, 1, 6, 1114340) A bullock cart owner should not put his cart at his disposal.
('48', 499, 1, 7, 1114402) The potter should not fetch drinking water for him, the grocer should not provide him with any provisions, and the Headman should not give him a mattress belonging either to the village or to himself.
('48', 499, 1, 8, 1114603) This is so because the official expects these facilities by virtue of his office.
('48', 499, 1, 9, 1114685) The purpose behind not providing these facilities is not to impose any hardship on him but to put an end to his authority and it may also involve an element of civil disobedience.
('48', 499, 1, 10, 1114865) What if the official is dying of hunger or suffering pain and no one is there to attend on him?
('48', 499, 1, 11, 1114961) At such a time, even at the cost of personal inconvenience, we should serve him.
('48', 499, 1, 12, 1115042) For instance, if his car breaks down, and he is in need of food, we should provide him food and not expect any money in return if he does not happen to have any.
('48', 499, 1, 13, 1115204) Supposing he is suddently taken ill and there is no one to attend on him, we should nurse him with as much care as we would show in nursing our own relatives.
('48', 499, 1, 14, 1115363) We bear him no ill will as a human being.
('48', 499, 1, 15, 1115405) We hate his administration.
('48', 499, 1, 16, 1115433) The Government has not so far become insane, as it has not had to put up with much inconvenience in carrying on the administra tion.
('48', 499, 1, 17, 1115566) However, once it is really inconvenienced, there is every possibility of its becoming so and transgressing all bounds.It is possible that when this does take place, its officials will be ordered forcibly to exact anything they need from the public.
('48', 499, 1, 18, 1115815) At such a time full use could be made of boycott as explained above.
('48', 499, 1, 19, 1115884) At such a time we realize that boycott is surely our dharma.
('48', 499, 1, 20, 1115945) The official assumes that by virtue of his office the people are obliged to provide all facilities for him.
('48', 499, 1, 21, 1116053) People would be said to have set themselves free only when they can disprove this belief and in the process put up with any hardships that they may have to face.
('48', 499, 1, 22, 1116215) They will be said to have triumphed when they do not yield to such force.
('48', 499, 1, 23, 1116289) Today boycott can be regarded as being extremely simple.
('48', 499, 1, 24, 1116346) However, even when Government officials receive permission to commit robbery and the people, despite the fact that they have been rendered penniless, do not voluntarily give even a twig to be used as a toothbrush, they will be
('48', 500, 0, 1, 1116573) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 501
('48', 500, 1, 2, 1116619) regarded as having carried out their duty of boycott.
('48', 500, 1, 3, 1116673) However, it should be borne in mind that even when this does occur, if the official is placed in a difficult situation and the authorities do not come to his rescue, we should attend to his needs.
('48', 500, 1, 4, 1116870) This should be considered an occasion for practising the same towards a friend and an enemy.
('48', 500, 1, 5, 1116963) For a satyagrahi there are no enemies in this world, he cannot have any, he should not regard anyone as such.
('48', 500, 1, 6, 1117073) He would boycott even his own son or father if either of these two happened to be an official.
('48', 500, 1, 7, 1117168) For a satyagrahi, there should be no distinction between his own relatives and those holding no such relationship.
('48', 500, 1, 8, 1117283) He would never do to others what he would not do to his own relatives.
('48', 500, 1, 9, 1117354) Let us now take the case of a Headman.
('48', 500, 1, 10, 1117393) Although the entire village wants him to resign, he does not have the courage to do so, or he does not wish to do so out of self interest.
('48', 500, 1, 11, 1117532) He should not be boycotted on this ground.
('48', 500, 1, 12, 1117575) Such boycott would amount to coercion.
('48', 500, 1, 13, 1117614) Compelling the Headman to resign would amount to making him forcibly perform a meritorious deed.
('48', 500, 1, 14, 1117711) But there can be no use of force, so far as our dharma is concerned.
('48', 500, 1, 15, 1117780) A democratic form of government can never be established by getting anyone to do something by force.
('48', 500, 1, 16, 1117881) To use such force on this nation which is half dead would be a great sin and, considering the matter solely from the point of view of expediency, we shall see that we shall never be able to serve our purpose by the use of such force.
('48', 500, 1, 17, 1118115) Whether we succeed or not, such force is nothing but violence.
('48', 500, 1, 18, 1118178) Whether the Headman resigns or not is for him to choose.
('48', 500, 1, 19, 1118235) It would be a good thing if he did so yielding to public opinion, but force cannot be used against him if he does not resign.But he cannot exercise his authority; he cannot make the people do anything whatsoever for him by virtue of his authority.
('48', 500, 1, 20, 1118483) He has a dual role to play: he is an official and he is a villager.
('48', 500, 1, 21, 1118551) He will not get any services as an official; as a villager he has a right to get provisions, etc., which he wants.
('48', 500, 1, 22, 1118666) To refuse him these amounts to compelling him to resign.
('48', 500, 1, 23, 1118723) A satyagrahi cannot do so.
('48', 500, 1, 24, 1118750) The people have a right to carry on a limited social boycott of those who defy public opinion and at times it becomes their duty to do so.
('48', 500, 1, 25, 1118889) Society should not honour a Headman who clings to his office for selfish reasons; in other words, although it would meet its daily requirements, it would sever all other connections with him; people would not attend marriages in his home, decline invitations to dinners from him and although they would share his sorrows, they would refuse to share in his enjoyments.
('48', 500, 1, 26, 1119257) There should be neither bitterness, nor ill will nor violence in such boycott.
('48', 500, 1, 27, 1119336) What should we do if the Headman happens to be our own brother?
('48', 500, 1, 28, 1119400) We should give him the treatment that we would expect from society for ourselves.
('48', 501, 0, 1, 1119482) 502 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 501, 1, 2, 1119524) We have now considered three types of boycott: 1. boycott of officials because of their office; 2. boycott through use of force of such persons as Headmen; and 3. limited boycott of such persons as the Headmen who refuse to respect public opinion.
('48', 501, 1, 3, 1119772) The first type of boycott deserves to be practised; it is our dharma to do so.
('48', 501, 1, 4, 1119851) Only those who have courage should practise it.
('48', 501, 1, 5, 1119899) It is well to remember that such boycott may result in occasions when we shall have to put up with extreme hardships.
('48', 501, 1, 6, 1120017) At present the Congress does not ask for such boycott.
('48', 501, 1, 7, 1120072) This latter has already begun in certain parts of Gujarat as the Gujaratis are used to it and have developed a good ability to practise it.
('48', 501, 1, 8, 1120212) It is the special dharma of Gujarat to do so in view of Sardar Vallabhbhai’s imprisonment.
('48', 501, 1, 9, 1120303) However, those who cannot continue to carry it on at the critical hour should not do so as there is no harm in their not practising it.
('48', 501, 1, 10, 1120439) It will be harmful, however, if it is given up once it has begun.
('48', 501, 1, 11, 1120505) The second type of boycott involving the use of force is always to be eschewed, as it involves violence, and there is every possibility of its doing great harm to the people.
('48', 501, 1, 12, 1120680) The third, that is, limited boycott, is well worth practising.
('48', 501, 1, 13, 1120743) In every task which the satyagrahi undertakes, he has himself to bear suffering but he must never make the opponent suffer.
('48', 501, 1, 14, 1120867) The former is helpless if in the course of his own suffering or hispractising his dharma, the opponent has to suffer or put up with inconvenience.
('48', 501, 1, 15, 1121014) At present what I ask of the people is civil disobedience of the salt law.
('48', 501, 1, 16, 1121089) If nothing more can be done, let everyone sit quiet but it will be both dangerous and harmful if they retreat after having taken a step forward.

('48', 502, 1, 4, 1122043) Let us examine the office of Headman from this standpoint.
('48', 502, 1, 5, 1122102) I did not understand its implications before as clearly as I do now.
('48', 502, 1, 6, 1122171) The Headman is the policeman or the Headman.
('48', 502, 1, 7, 1122216) It is through him that the Government collects the revenue and it is through him that it exercises its authority.
('48', 502, 1, 8, 1122330) Mamlatdars and other officers would become ineffective without him.
('48', 502, 1, 9, 1122398) It is not just anyone who is appointed a Headman, but only one who carries weight in the village.
('48', 502, 1, 10, 1122496) A register of such persons is maintained in Government offices and they are known as Matadars.
('48', 502, 1, 11, 1122591) It is from among these persons that Headmen are appointed by rotation for a period of five years.
('48', 502, 1, 12, 1122689) The Government pays a certain sum annually to these Matadars, amounting to about four or five rupees as allowance.
('48', 502, 1, 13, 1122804) A Headman gets a sum of thirty to fifty rupees every year as nazarana 1. I use the word nazarana.
('48', 502, 1, 14, 1122902) No one regards it as salary.
('48', 502, 1, 15, 1122931) The amount received by the Headman is not of any great consequence to him, as ordinarily he is a well to do person.
('48', 502, 1, 16, 1123047) While considering what term should be used for this amount given tohim, I called it nazarana.
('48', 502, 1, 17, 1123141) The Amir of Afghanistan also receives a nazarana.
('48', 502, 1, 18, 1123191) However, I am aware that there is a great deal of difference between the nazarana received by the Amir and that given to the Headman.
('48', 502, 1, 19, 1123325) While the former consists of a large sum, the latter is a small one.
('48', 502, 1, 20, 1123394) There are other differences also.
('48', 502, 1, 21, 1123428) Nevertheless, the purpose underlying both these payments is to gain a hold upon the recipients.
('48', 502, 1, 22, 1123524) Why do Headmen and Matadars get committed in this manner?
('48', 502, 1, 23, 1123582) It is certainly not for the purpose of enjoying an empty office, but because the office will enhance their prestige and because they can use their status in order to get money out of it.
('48', 502, 1, 24, 1123769) This cannot be done with honesty.
('48', 502, 1, 25, 1123803) It necessarily involves dishonesty.
('48', 502, 1, 26, 1123839) Hence, the office of Headman implies that by accepting this office the person concerned ceases to be the village mahajan and protector, and preys upon the villagers.
('48', 502, 1, 27, 1124005) It is not my intention to say that all Headmen are like this.
('48', 502, 1, 28, 1124067) But this is a conclusion I have reached after talking to a large number of Headmen.
('48', 502, 1, 29, 1124151) Such Headmanship and Matadarship should be given up not for the sake of Sardar or swaraj, but rather for the sake of one’s dharma and morality.
('48', 502, 1, 30, 1124295) These two classes of persons can make a significant contribution to the movement for self purification that is on in the country at the moment.
('48', 502, 1, 31, 1124439) Others may advance the excuse that they have to earn their livelihood, but this does not apply in the case of these Headmen and Matadars.
('48', 502, 1, 32, 1124577) For them, it is like giving up titles.

('48', 506, 2, 10, 1132333) 541. SPEECH AT DELAD 1
('48', 506, 3, 11, 1132356) March 30, 1930 As has been said in the Gita, that which tastes bitter at first but is finally sweet is wholesome.
('48', 506, 3, 12, 1132470) Hence, although I was agitated yesterday and still am, I have not lost my peace; the fiery words of love which I had directed towards my friends, companions and the assembly were not regarded by them as such.
('48', 506, 3, 13, 1132679) Instead of the dazzling lights of yesterday I see small, dim lights of hurricane lanterns.
('48', 506, 3, 14, 1132770) Yesterday I did not find the outer and inner peace which I find in today’s assembly.
('48', 506, 3, 15, 1132855) There was an artificiality in yesterday’s lights.
('48', 506, 3, 16, 1132905) Ifound no affinity between those lights and our rural life.
('48', 506, 3, 17, 1132965) Such lights are a consequence of contact with cities, but vast numbers of villages are hundreds of miles removed from cities or railway lines.
('48', 506, 3, 18, 1133108) Our idea is to serve such villages.
('48', 506, 3, 19, 1133144) You do not even know those villages.
('48', 506, 3, 20, 1133181) Perhaps there are no such villages in Gujarat.

('48', 506, 3, 22, 1133269) It is only a fraction of India.

('48', 510, 7, 10, 1141155) 547. SPEECH AT CHHAPRABHATHA April 1, 1930 Every day people tell me, “Today you will certainly be arrested.” However, the tiger does not appear!
('48', 510, 7, 11, 1141300) The newspapers claim that I have become impatient at the Government not arresting me.
('48', 510, 7, 12, 1141386) This is partially true as it had been decided that while Sardar should remain free, I should court arrest.
('48', 510, 7, 13, 1141493) However, now that Sardar is in prison, I shall remain free.
('48', 510, 7, 14, 1141553) If we wish to secure the release of Vallabhbhai, we can only do so by carrying on this struggle.
('48', 510, 7, 15, 1141650) Choryasi took full advantage of the last fight of Sardar, so you must make your full contribution to this movement.
('48', 510, 7, 16, 1141766) The Government has acted on the principle that all places will get the rainfall of swaraj in equal measure.
('48', 510, 7, 17, 1141874) We certainly have the strength to secure his release.
('48', 510, 7, 18, 1141928) If we were determined, we might say, from a superficial glance at the villages, that swaraj was round the corner.
('48', 510, 7, 19, 1142042) I am not however a person who will thus deceive himself.
('48', 510, 7, 20, 1142099) For the present I am trying to gauge the situation.
('48', 510, 7, 21, 1142151) On inquiring about spinning wheels I found a single one here.
('48', 510, 7, 22, 1142213) If matters are in such a state, we cannot secure Sardar’s release.
('48', 510, 7, 23, 1142280) We have to go forward in all directions.
('48', 510, 7, 24, 1142321) At present we have set out to get the salt tax abolished.
('48', 510, 7, 25, 1142379) We shall tire out the Government by making salt at any number of places.
('48', 510, 7, 26, 1142452) However, all this can be achieved only when you put into practice the aphorism that ‘swaraj lies in a strand of yarn’.
('48', 510, 7, 27, 1142571) The saying that it is easy to secure swaraj will only be proved true when 30 crores of people start wearing khadi and develop all
('48', 511, 0, 1, 1142701) 512 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 511, 1, 2, 1142743) aspects of swaraj, giving due consideration to rural problems.
('48', 511, 1, 3, 1142806) Swaraj is within our grasp if we practise this simple and easy duty.
('48', 511, 1, 4, 1142875) Consider how the bridge on the river Keem was built in a single night.
('48', 511, 1, 5, 1142946) If people act voluntarily in accordance with their capacities in this manner, swaraj is not difficult to secure.

('48', 511, 2, 9, 1143307) 548. SPEECH AT SURAT April 1, 1930 There is no alternative but for us to do something about our troubles and sufferings and hence we have thought of this salt tax.
('48', 511, 2, 10, 1143471) You may say it is a godsend.
('48', 511, 2, 11, 1143500) It is so beastly and inhuman that through salt the Government taxes even little children and young girls.
('48', 511, 2, 12, 1143606) I have read the texts in which it is claimed that those who would carry on administration must find ways to collect taxes from all members of the public.
('48', 511, 2, 13, 1143760) I have gone through the holy books of Islam, Hinduism, Christianity and Zoroastrianism.
('48', 511, 2, 14, 1143848) All these state that women and the poor should at no time be taxed.
('48', 511, 2, 15, 1143916) If we go through the rules of war, we shall find that they lay down that old persons, children and women should be left untouched in war.
('48', 511, 2, 16, 1144054) The same is applicable to this tax.
('48', 511, 2, 17, 1144090) Muslims, Hindus, Parsis—all consume salt in like quantities.
('48', 511, 2, 18, 1144151) The Government has, however, found a device whereby all have been taxed at an equal rate.
('48', 511, 2, 19, 1144241) This is an inhuman law, a Satanic law.
('48', 511, 2, 20, 1144280) I have not heard of such justice anywhere in the world; where it prevails, I would call it inhuman, Satanic.
('48', 511, 2, 21, 1144389) To bow to an empire which dispenses such justice is not dharma but adharma.
('48', 511, 2, 22, 1144465) A man who prays to God every morning at dawn cannot, must not, pray for the good of such an empire.
('48', 511, 2, 23, 1144565) On the contrary while praying or saying the namaaz he should ask God to encompass the destruction of such a Satanic empire, such an inhuman government.
('48', 511, 2, 24, 1144717) To do so is dharma.
('48', 511, 2, 25, 1144737) Although I have been saying this openly for the last twenty days, the Government has left me and my colleagues free.
('48', 511, 2, 26, 1144854) I admit that this is a familiar trait in this Government.
('48', 511, 2, 27, 1144912) I have been calling this Government inhuman till today.

('48', 511, 2, 31, 1145245) It is ashamed of itself before the world.
('48', 511, 2, 32, 1145287) I have never

('48', 518, 0, 1, 1157636) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 519
('48', 518, 1, 2, 1157682) APPENDIX I VICEROY’S STATEMENT 1
('48', 518, 2, 3, 1157715) I have have just returned from England where I have had the opportunity of prolonged consultation with His Majesty’s Government.
('48', 518, 2, 4, 1157844) Before I left this country I said publicly that as the King Emperor’s representative in India I should hold myself bound to tell my fellow countrymen, as faithfully as I might, of India’s feelings, anxieties and aspirations.
('48', 518, 2, 5, 1158069) In my endeavours to discharge that undertaking I was assisted by finding, as I had expected a generous and sincere desire, not only on the part of His Majesty’s Government but on that of all persons and parties in Great Britain, to hear and to appreciate everything that it was my duty to represent.
('48', 518, 2, 6, 1158369) These are critical days, when matters by which men are deeply touched are in issue and when, therefore, it is inevitable that political feeling should run high, and that misunderstandings, which would scarcely arise in conditions of political tranquillity, should obtain firm foothold in men’s minds.
('48', 518, 2, 7, 1158670) I have, nevertheless, not faltered in my belief that behind all the disquieting tendencies of the time, there lay the great mass of Indian opinion, overflowing all divisions of race, religion, or political thought, fundamentally loyal to the King Emperor, and, whether consciously or not only wanting to understand and to be understood.
('48', 518, 2, 8, 1159007) On the other side I have never felt any doubt that opinion in Great Britain, puzzled as it might be by events in India, or only perhaps partially informed as to their true significance, was unshaken in its determination that Great Britain should redeem to the full the pledges she has given for India’s future.
('48', 518, 2, 9, 1159318) On both countries the times have laid a heavy and in some ways a unique responsibility, for the influence on the world of a perfect understanding between Great Britain and India might surely be so great that no scales can give us the measure either of the prize of success or, the price of failure in our attempts to reach it.
('48', 518, 2, 10, 1159645) In my discussions with the Prime Minister and the Secretary of State, it was inevitable that the principal topic should have been the course of events in India.
('48', 518, 2, 11, 1159806) It is not profitable on either side to discuss to what extent, or with what justification, the appointment of a Parliamentary Commission two years ago has affected the general trend of Indian thought and action.
('48', 518, 2, 12, 1160018) Practical men must take facts andsituations as they are, and not as they would have them be.
('48', 518, 2, 13, 1160111) Sir John Simon’s Commission, assisted as it has been by the Indian Central Committee, is now at work on its Report, and until that Report is laid before Parliament it is impossible, and even if it were possible, it would in the view of His Majesty’s Government clearly be improper, to forecast the nature of any constitutional changes that may subsequently be proposed.
('48', 518, 2, 14, 1160481) In this respect every British party is bound to preserve t itself complete freedom of action.
('48', 518, 2, 15, 1160575) But what must constantly engage our attention, and is a matter of deep concern to His Majesty’s Government, is the discovery of means by which, when the Commission has reported, the broad question of British Indian constitutional advance may be approached in co operation with all those who can speak authoritatively for opinion in British India.
('48', 518, 2, 16, 1160922) I would venture to recall some words which I used in addressing the
('48', 518, 3, 17, 1160990) 1 Vide 1st footnote to “All Parties Leaders’ Joint Statement”, 2 11 1929 & “Draft Resolution for Congress Working Committee”, 18 11 1929.
('48', 519, 0, 1, 1161128) 520 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 519, 1, 2, 1161170) Assembly eight months ago in reference to the then existing political situation.
('48', 519, 1, 3, 1161251) “On the one side,” I said, “it is judgment on the problem as it would be short sighted of Parliament to underrate the importance of trying to reach a solution which might carry the willing assent of political India.” We shall surely stray from the path, at the end of which lies achievement, if we let go either one or other of these two main guiding principles of political action.
('48', 519, 1, 4, 1161634) But there has lately emerged, from a totally different angle, another set of considerations which is very relevant to what I have just stated on this matter to be the desire of His Majesty’s Government.
('48', 519, 1, 5, 1161837) The Chairman of the Commission has pointed out in correspondence with the Prime Minister, which, I understand, is being published in England, that as their investigation has proceeded, he and his colleagues have been greatly impressed, in considering the direction which the future constitutional development which may, at some future time, develop between British India and the Indian States.
('48', 519, 1, 6, 1162231) In his judgment it is essential that the methods, by which this future relationship between these two constituent parts of Greater India may be adjusted, should be fully examined.
('48', 519, 1, 7, 1162411) he has further expressed the opinion that if the Commission’s Report and the proposals subsequently to be framed by the Government take this wider range, it would appear necessary for the Government to revise the scheme of procedure as at present proposed.
('48', 519, 1, 8, 1162668) He suggests that what might be required, after the Reports of the Statutory Commission and the Indian Central Committee have been made, considered and published but before the stage is reached of the Joint Parliamentary Committee, would be the setting up of a Conference in which His Majesty’s Government should meet representatives both of British India and of the States, for the purpose of seeking the greatest possible measure of agreement for the final proposals which it would later be the duty of His Majesty’sGovernment to submit to Parliament.
('48', 519, 1, 9, 1163221) The procedure by Joint Parliamentary Committee conferring with delegations from the Indian Legislature and other bodies, which was previously contemplated and is referred to in Sir John Simon’s letter to myself of 6th February 1928, would still be appropriate for the examination of the Bill when it is subsequently placed before Parliament, but would, in the opinion of the Commission, obviously have to be preceded by some such Conference as they have suggested.With these views I understand that His Majesty’s Government are in complete accord.
('48', 519, 1, 10, 1163769) For, while they will greatly desire, when the time comes, to be able to deal with the question of British Indian political development under conditions the most favourable to its successful treatment, they are, with the Commission, deeply sensible of the importance of bringing under comprehensive review the whole problem of the relations of British India and the Indian States.
('48', 519, 1, 11, 1164149) Indeed, an adjustment of these interests in their view is essential for the complete fulfilment of what they consider to be the underlying purpose of British policy, whatever may be the method for its furtherance which Parliament may decide to adopt.
('48', 519, 1, 12, 1164400) The goal of British policy was stated in the declaration of August 1917 to be that of providing for the gradual development of self governing institutions, as an integral part of the British Empire.
('48', 519, 1, 13, 1164599) As I recently pointed out my own Instrument of Instruction from the King Emperor expressly states that it is His Majesty’s will and pleasure that the plans laid by Parliament in 1919 should be the means by which British India may attain its due place among His Dominions.
('48', 519, 1, 14, 1164871) Ministers of the Crown,
('48', 520, 0, 1, 1164895) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 521
('48', 520, 1, 2, 1164941) moreover, have more than once publicly declared that it is the desire of the British Government that India should, in the fullness of time, take her place in the Empire in equal partnership with the Dominions.
('48', 520, 1, 3, 1165151) But in view of the doubts which have been expressed both in Great Britain and India regarding the interpretation to be placed on the intentions of the British Government in enacting the Statue of 1919, I am authorized on behalf of His Majesty’s Government to state clearly that in their judgment it is implicit in the declaration of 1917 that the natural issue of India’s constitutional progress, as there contemplated, is the attainment of Dominion Status.
('48', 520, 1, 4, 1165609) In the full realization of this policy, it is evidently important that the Indian States should be afforded an opportunity of finding their place, and even if we cannot at present exactly foresee on what lines this development may be shaped, it is from every point of view desirable that whatever can be done should be done to ensure that action taken now is not inconsistent with the attainment of the ultimate purpose which those, whether in British India or the States, who look forward to some unity of all India, have in view.
('48', 520, 1, 5, 1166141) His Majesty’s Government consider that both these objects, namely, that of finding the best approach to the British side of the problem, and secondly, ofensuring that in this process the wider question of closer relations in the future between the two parts of Greater India is not overlooked, can best be achieved by the adoption of procedure such as the Commission has outlined.
('48', 520, 1, 6, 1166522) When, therefore, the Commission and the Indian Central Committee have submitted their reports and these have been published, and when His Majesty’s Government have been able, in consultation with the Government of India, to consider these matters in the light of all the material then available, they will propose to invite representatives of different parties and interests in British India and representatives of the Indian States to meet them, separately or together as circumstances may demand, for purpose of conference and discussion in regard both to the British Indian and the all Indian problems.
('48', 520, 1, 7, 1167128) It will be their earnest hope that by this means it may subsequently prove possible on these grave issues to submit proposals to Parliament which may command a wide measure of general assent.
('48', 520, 1, 8, 1167320) It is not necessary for me to say how greatly I trust that the action of His Majesty’s Government may evoke response from and enlist the concurrence of all sections of opinion in India, and I believe that all who wish India well, wherever and whoever they are, desire to break through the webs of mistrust firmly assured that the course of action now proposed is at once the outcome of a real desire to bring to the body politic of India the touch that carries with it healing and health, and is the method by which we may best hope to handle these high matters in the way of constructive statesmanship.
('48', 520, 2, 9, 1167924) 31st October, 1929 IRWIN VICEROY AND GOVERNOR GENERAL India in 1929 30, pp.

('48', 521, 3, 4, 1168085) ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTEE, 52 HEWETT ROAD, ALLAHABAD, November 4, 1929 MY DEAR BAPUJI, I have thought well for two days.
('48', 521, 3, 5, 1168209) I can take, I think, a calmer view of the situation than I could two days ago but the fever in my brain has not left me.
('48', 521, 3, 6, 1168330) Your appeal to me on the ground of discipline could not be ignored by me.
('48', 521, 3, 7, 1168404) I am myself a believer in discipline.
('48', 521, 3, 8, 1168442) And yet I suppose there can be too much of discipline.
('48', 521, 3, 9, 1168497) Something seems to have snapped inside me evening before last and I am unable to piece it together.
('48', 521, 3, 10, 1168597) As General Secretary of the Congress I owe allegiance to it and must subject myself to its discipline.
('48', 521, 3, 11, 1168700) I have other capacities and other allegiances.
('48', 521, 3, 12, 1168747) I am President of the Indian am intimately connected with the youth movement.
('48', 521, 3, 13, 1168825) What shall I do with the allegiance I owe to these and other movements I am connected with?
('48', 521, 3, 14, 1168917) I realize now more than I have ever done before that it is not possible to ride a number of horses at the same time.
('48', 521, 3, 15, 1169034) Indeed it is hard enough to ride one.
('48', 521, 3, 16, 1169072) In the conflict of responsibilities and allegiances what is one to do except to rely on one’s own instincts and reason?
('48', 521, 3, 17, 1169192) I have therefore considered the position apart from all outside connections and allegiances and the conviction has grown stronger that I acted wrongly the policy underlying it.
('48', 521, 3, 18, 1169369) I am afraid we differ fundamentally on that issue and I am not likely to convert you.
