('48', 521, 3, 20, 1169594) I believe that in our attempts to soothe and retain a few estimable gentlemen we have ruffled and practically turned out of our camp many others who were far more worth having.
('48', 521, 3, 21, 1169771) I believe that we have fallen into a dangerous trap out of which it will be no easy matter to escape.
('48', 521, 3, 22, 1169873) And I think that we have shown to the world that although we talk tall we are only bargaining for some tit bits.
('48', 521, 3, 23, 1169986) I do not know what the British Government will do now.
('48', 521, 3, 24, 1170041) Probably it will not agree to your conditions.
('48', 521, 3, 25, 1170088) I hope they will not.
('48', 521, 3, 26, 1170110) But I have little doubt that most of the signatories—excluding you of course—will be quite prepared to agree to any modification of the conditions which the British Government might suggest.
('48', 521, 3, 27, 1170301) In any event it is quite clear to me that my position in the Congress will become daily more and more difficult.
('48', 521, 3, 28, 1170414) I accepted the presidentship of the Congress with great misgivings but in the hope that we shall fight on a clear issue next year.
('48', 521, 3, 29, 1170545) That issue is already clouded and the only reason for my acceptance has gone.
('48', 521, 3, 30, 1170623) What am I to do with these “Leaders” Conference”?
('48', 521, 3, 31, 1170673) I feel an interloper and am ill at ease.
('48', 521, 3, 32, 1170714) I cannot have my say because I am afraid of upsetting the conference.
('48', 521, 3, 33, 1170784) I repress myself and sometimes the repression is too much for me and I break out and even say things which I do not wholly mean.

('48', 523, 3, 18, 1175403) APPENDIX IV
('48', 523, 4, 19, 1175415) LETTER FROM DR.
('48', 523, 4, 20, 1175431) M. A. ANSARI1
('48', 523, 5, 21, 1175445) JAORA, February 13, 1930 MY DEAR MAHATMAJI, I wrote to you from Delhi last Monday.
('48', 523, 5, 22, 1175528) The letter was dictated in a hurry in a few moments snatched during a very strenuous day.
('48', 523, 5, 23, 1175618) It naturally did not express all that I wanted to tell you.
('48', 523, 5, 24, 1175678) Further, I was hoping I would be able to get away from here in time to be with you on the 14th or the 15th.
('48', 523, 5, 25, 1175786) I find, however, to my disappointment, that my patient here is suffering from peritonitis and is so very ill that I cannot even mention my leaving her.
('48', 523, 5, 26, 1175938) Indeed, it does not seem possible to get away from here for another week or ten days.
('48', 523, 5, 27, 1176024) I am, therefore, writing to you as the next best thing to my being with you in person at such a critical moment.
('48', 523, 5, 28, 1176137) I feel I owe it to Pt. Jawaharlal, Pt. Motilal, yourself, and your colleagues in the Working Committee, who have got the reins of the Congress in their hands and are leading the country, to tell you frankly what I feel abut your policy and programme in relation to the present situation in the country.
('48', 523, 5, 29, 1176440) I would try to be as brief as possible, but you would excuse me if this letter becomes somewhat long in spite of my efforts to curtail it.
('48', 523, 5, 30, 1176579) Hindu Muslim unity is not only one of the basic items in our programme, but
('48', 523, 6, 31, 1176655) 1 Vide “Letter to Dr. M. A. Ansari”, 16 2 1930.
('48', 524, 0, 1, 1176703) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 525
('48', 524, 1, 2, 1176749) according to my firm belief and conviction, the one and only basic thing.
('48', 524, 1, 3, 1176823) I would have liked to trace the whole history of our efforts to achieve unity, but I would take up the most recent history, viz., from autumn of the year 1927. You would remember how the Unity Conference at Simla failed in spite of every effort made there.
('48', 524, 1, 4, 1177080) I felt after its failure that it was not possible to have agreement between extreme communal groups, but that it was feasible to have a workable agreement between Nationalist Hindus and Nationalist Mussalmans.
('48', 524, 1, 5, 1177290) I, therefore, urged Srinivasa Iyengar, the then President of the Congress, to convene another Peace Conference at Calcutta under the aegis of the Congress, and in more suitable surroundings than the Simla Conference.
('48', 524, 1, 6, 1177507) The Calcutta Conference brought about an understanding between the Congress and the Mussalmans of all shades of opinion, as evidenced by the warm welcome given to the Pact even by such Mussalman as Sir Mohd.
('48', 524, 1, 7, 1177715) Shafi, Sir Zulfiqar Ali, Dr. Muhammad Iqbal and many others.
('48', 524, 1, 8, 1177776) This Pact, with certain modifications suggested by you, was passed by the Madras Congress and was agreed to by Pt. Malaviya.
('48', 524, 1, 9, 1177901) I have not the slightest doubt that if we had stuck to it we would have gradually overcome the opposition of the Hindu Mahasabha, and Hindu Muslim unity would have been an accomplished fact by now.
('48', 524, 1, 10, 1178099) But, we wanted to be more just and fair and in our effort to do justice and bring greater harmony and unity in the shape of the Nehru Report at Lucknow, followed closely by the Sikhs.
('48', 524, 1, 11, 1178283) But, at the Calcutta Convention, it was the Hindu Mahasabha which completely did the work of destruction.
('48', 524, 1, 12, 1178389) I cannot help expressing that the speech made by Mr. Jayakar and subsequently the attitude in the Committee taken by Pt. Malaviya, Dr. Moonje, and Hindu Mahasabha friends destroyed all chances of understanding.
('48', 524, 1, 13, 1178600) Jatindra Lal Bannerji’s motion for the reservation of seats for 45 per cent Hindu minority in the Bengal which was carried in the Convention and only withdrawn at my special appeal and request was a painful revelation.
('48', 524, 1, 14, 1178819) Pt. Motilal’s cold reception to Mr. Jinnah, whom I had succeeded after a great deal of effort in persuading to come and see Panditji at his house, was also a great disappointment.
('48', 524, 1, 15, 1178999) After that, the communalistMussalmans got the chance and the Muslim attitude hardened [as] shown by the absurd resolution passed at the All Parties’ Muslim Conference at Delhi and subsequently the fourteen points of Mr. Jinnah.
('48', 524, 1, 16, 1179227) The year 1929, in spite of the great influence and efforts of Panditji, yourself and Pt. Jawaharlal, did not see the constructive programme advance and the quota fixed in May last year was not completed by most of the Congress Committee.
('48', 524, 1, 17, 1179465) The Sikh situation was, in the mean time, going from bad to worse.
('48', 524, 1, 18, 1179532) In such circumstances when I read the advance copy of the Viceroy’s statement of November 1st, 1 I considered it a godsend (as the telephonic message sent by me to Panditji and received by Jawaharlal would bear out).
('48', 524, 1, 19, 1179749) I, at once, took Vallabhbhai with me and met you at Meerut.
('48', 524, 1, 20, 1179809) We found you less enthusiastic, more cautious, but on the whole, taking a very favourable view of the announcement.
('48', 524, 1, 21, 1179925) At the Conference held in Delhi on November 1st, you would remember I pressed for certain parts of Dr. Sapru’s statement to be embodied in yours.
('48', 524, 1, 22, 1180071) The reason was that I found myself in agreement with him.
('48', 524, 1, 23, 1180129) I was representing not only my own personal views, but, those of a group consisting of Messrs Khaliquzzaman, Tasadduq Ahmed Sherwani, Rafi [Ahmed]
('48', 524, 2, 24, 1180276) 1 Vide “Viceroy’s Statement”, 31 10 1929; the statement was issued on October 31, 1929.
('48', 525, 0, 1, 1180364) 526 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 525, 1, 2, 1180406) Kidwai, Dr. Mahmud, and a few others.
('48', 525, 1, 3, 1180444) At Lahore, I expressed the same views in the Working Committee.
('48', 525, 1, 4, 1180508) When asked by Panditji, to give my opinion on the 22nd of last December in Delhi, I told him that owing to our internal dessensions, unpreparedness and weakness, I would advise him not to let the Conference with the Viceroy break up, but to utilize it to the fullest advantage.
('48', 525, 1, 5, 1180786) Panditji characterized my observations as based on weakness.
('48', 525, 1, 6, 1180847) I repudiated the charge, but our conversation ended.
('48', 525, 1, 7, 1180900) When I heard that the Conference between you and the Viceroy had ended without any agreement, I was disappointed.
('48', 525, 1, 8, 1181014) At the meeting of the Working Committee held in Lahore last December and on one or two subsequent occasions, I expressed similar views but with the exception of Mrs. Naidu, I did not find support.
('48', 525, 1, 9, 1181211) I have felt that the situation has been mishandled both by the Viceroy and our own representatives.
('48', 525, 1, 10, 1181311) The Viceroy was obviously very much shaken by the bomb outrage, and was not in his normal frame of mind.
('48', 525, 1, 11, 1181416) For I do not see how even with the limited powers given to him he could have failed to give you the necessary assurance for a scheme of Dominion Status to be the basis of discussion at the Round Table Conference.
('48', 525, 1, 12, 1181629) I cannot, for the life of me, imagine after reading and re reading the statements of the Viceroy and the Secretary of State, what else could be the basis of discussions at the Round Table Conference if not a scheme of Dominion Status.
('48', 525, 1, 13, 1181864) It may be a very incomplete scheme which would form the basis; even our own scheme presented in the Nehru Constitution was not a scheme of complete Dominion Status.
('48', 525, 1, 14, 1182029) The final decision would be matters for adjustments, understandings and bargains, as it is bound to be at any time.
('48', 525, 1, 15, 1182145) But, at any rate, it would have given us the chance of placing the demand of India before the British on communal matters, they would have been obliged to concede our demand of Dominion Constitution to a very great extent.
('48', 525, 1, 16, 1182368) This has been my view all along and is my view today.
('48', 525, 2, 17, 1182422) I did not feel that it would be in the interest of the Congress [for me] to resign from the Working Committee at Lahore and express my views in the All India Congress Committee or in the open Congress.
('48', 525, 2, 18, 1182624) I felt that there were already sufficient divisions in the Congress and one more division would not have improved the situation.
('48', 525, 2, 19, 1182753) Out of loyalty to the Congress and my personal devotion to you.
('48', 525, 2, 20, 1182817) Pt. Motilal and Jawaharlal, I kept quiet.
('48', 525, 2, 21, 1182859) But I deliberately refused the General Secretaryship and the membership of the Working Committee, and took the risk of being misunderstood rather than say or do anything to injure the Congress.
('48', 525, 2, 22, 1183053) At the same time, not being in sympathy with the policy and programme of the Congress, I could not be one of its executive.
('48', 525, 2, 23, 1183177) The same reason led me to resign from the Presidentship of the Preventive.
('48', 525, 2, 24, 1183252) Indeed, the only thing possible for me and those who think like me was to drop out of the Congress Executive.
('48', 525, 2, 25, 1183362) And whilst not opposing the policy and programme of the Congress or doing anything to injure it by our actions or words, to remain as one of its camp followers.
('48', 525, 2, 26, 1183523) So far as I am aware, Mrs. Naidu, Rangaswami Iyengar, Pt. Harkaran Nath Misra, Choudhary Khaliquzzaman, R. A. Kidwai, T. A. K. Sherwani and a few other leading Congressmen (whose names I may not mention) hold similar views.
('48', 525, 2, 27, 1183747) You are taking a great responsibility on yourself by declaring war against the Government today.
('48', 525, 2, 28, 1183844) The situation today is quite the reverse of what it was in 1920, when you started the campaign of non co operation.
('48', 525, 2, 29, 1183960) I would briefly compare the
('48', 526, 0, 1, 1183988) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 527
('48', 526, 1, 2, 1184034) situation in a comparative table as under; of course, it is not complete, but I am giving only the salient features:
('48', 526, 3, 3, 1184151) (1) Great dissatisfaction against the Government, owing to war time promises, owing to war time promises not having been kept.
('48', 526, 3, 4, 1184278) Dissatisfaction against Rowlatt Act, Martial Law, and Khilafat wrongs.
('48', 526, 3, 5, 1184349) (2) Highest water mark reached in Hindu Muslim unity.
('48', 526, 3, 6, 1184403) (3) Sikhs entirely with the Cong ress.
('48', 526, 4, 7, 1184442) (4) Complete unity inside the Congress.
('48', 526, 4, 8, 1184482) Great enthusiasm amongst the workers and the rank and file.
('48', 526, 5, 9, 1184542) (5) Complete non violent atmosphere and yet breaking of violence in Chauri Chaura.
('48', 526, 7, 10, 1184625) (1) Large number of people believe in the goodwill of Labour Government and sincerity of Labour Government and sincerity of the Viceroy, rightly or wrongly.
('48', 526, 8, 11, 1184782) (2) Lowest water mark reached in Hindu Muslim unity.
('48', 526, 8, 12, 1184835) (3) Sikhs almost entirely against the Congress.
('48', 526, 9, 13, 1184883) (4) Disunity in the Congress (Revolt against its mandate), diversity of purpose, complete lack of enthusiasm amongst the workers.
('48', 526, 9, 14, 1185013) Lukewarmness among the rank and file.
('48', 526, 9, 15, 1185051) (5) Obvious existence of violence, even large number of leading Congressmen believing in it and the certainty of violence breaking out.
('48', 526, 10, 16, 1185187) Like Harishchandra you seem to be bent on keeping the word given by you at Calcutta, irrespective of consequences.
('48', 526, 10, 17, 1185302) I feel as if you are deliberately offering yourself as a sacrifice.
('48', 526, 10, 18, 1185370) I earnestly submit to you for your consideration that to the demand made at Calcutta there has been a response.
('48', 526, 10, 19, 1185482) It is not satisfactory from our point of view.
('48', 526, 10, 20, 1185529) But, it is all that the Government can make, and certainly, it cannot be said that there has been no response.
('48', 526, 10, 21, 1185640) I, therefore, urge that the question of keeping your word in case of no response to the Calcutta offer does not arise and, therefore, the idea of keeping your word at all costs is not morally justifiable and certainly it is not politically expedient.
('48', 526, 10, 22, 1185891) I hope I have made my position quite clear to you.
('48', 526, 10, 23, 1185942) Holding the views stated above and feeling that the real test of our preparedness lies more in the results achieved with regard to the enrolment of members and volunteers, collections of funds, and above all, in the achievement of Hindu, Muslim and dependence Day, it is my conviction that the country is not the least ready for starting a campaign of civil disobedience in any shape or form, and it would do an incalculable damage should you decide to embark on such a campaign now or in the near future.
('48', 526, 10, 24, 1186448) I would, therefore, earnestly urge you and the members of the Working Committee to desist from doing
('48', 527, 0, 1, 1186549) 528 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('48', 527, 1, 2, 1186591) I believe, that if you could see the wisdom of passing a resolution asking the Congress organization for intensive preparation including H.M.S. understanding, but, in the mean time, postponing the campaign of civil disobedience for the present, until you find yourself ready and obliged to start civil disobedience, it would meet the present situation much better and give a chance to those countrymen of ours who are thinking of participation in the London Round Table Conference.
('48', 527, 1, 3, 1187073) I wish you to share this letter with Pt. Jawaharlal and Pt. Motilal Nehru.
('48', 527, 1, 4, 1187148) I hope this would find you in the best of health.
('48', 527, 2, 5, 1187198) With kindest regards, Yours sincerely, M. A. ANSARI Ansari Papers.

('48', 527, 3, 7, 1187296) APPENDIX V
('48', 527, 4, 8, 1187307) PENAL SECTIONS OF THE SALT ACT 1
('48', 527, 5, 9, 1187340) SEIZURES, DETENTION SEARCH AND ARREST
('48', 527, 6, 10, 1187378) Section 39 of the Bombay Salt Act which is practically the same as Sections 16 17 of the Indian Salt Act (XII of 1882), empowers any Salt revenue officer to do the following among other things:
('48', 527, 7, 11, 1187572) 1. To enter any place where illicit manufacture is going on;
('48', 527, 8, 12, 1187633) 2. “In case of resistance, break open any door and remove any other obstacle to his entry upon or into such land, building, enclosed place or premises”;
('48', 527, 9, 13, 1187786) 3. To take possession of or destroy salt illicitly manufactured;
('48', 527, 10, 14, 1187851) 4. “To seize in any open space, or in transit, any article which he has reason to believe to be contraband salt and any package or covering in which such article is found and the other contents, if any, of such package or covering in which the same is found, and any animal, vessel or conveyance used or intended to be used in carrying the same”;
('48', 527, 11, 15, 1188198) 5. “To detain and search and, if he thinks proper, arrest any person, whom he has reason to believe to be guilty of any offence punishable under this or any other law for the time being in force relating to salt revenue, or in whose possession contraband salt is found”.
('48', 527, 11, 16, 1188469) THINGS LIABLE TO CONFISCATION
('48', 527, 12, 17, 1188499) Section 50 of the Bombay Salt Act (in which Sec.
('48', 527, 12, 18, 1188548) 12 of the Indian Salt Act is incorporated) lays down that
('48', 527, 13, 19, 1188606) “All contraband salt, and every vessel, animal, or conveyance used in carrying contraband salt and
('48', 527, 14, 20, 1188705) 1 Vide “Penal Sections of the Salt Act”, 6 3 1930.
('48', 528, 0, 1, 1188756) VOL. 48 : 21 NOVEMBER, 1929 2 APRIL, 1930 529
('48', 528, 1, 2, 1188802) All goods, packages and coverings in or among which contraband salt is found, and every apparatus, implement, utensil or material employed for the manufacture, excavation, collection, or removal of salt without a licence or for the purpose of utilizing natural salt or salt earth contrary to any of the provisions of this Act or any rule made thereunder shall be liable to confiscation.”
('48', 528, 2, 3, 1189190) ADDITIONAL PUNISHMENT FOR REPETITION OF OFFENCE
('48', 528, 3, 4, 1189238) Section 10 of the Indian Salt Act (Act XII of 1882) lays down that
('48', 528, 4, 5, 1189305) ‘‘Any person convicted of an offence under Section 9, after having been previously convicted of an offence under that section, or Section II of the In land Customs Act, 1875, or under any enactment repealed by that Act, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, in addition to the punishment which may be inflicted for a first offence under Section 9, and every such person shall, upon every subsequent conviction of an offence under Section 9, be liable to imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months in addition to any term of imprisonment to which he was liable at his last previous conviction.”
('48', 528, 5, 6, 1189952) DUTIES OF OFFICERS
('48', 528, 6, 7, 1189971) Section 41 of the Bombay Salt Act makes it “incumbent on every village officer” to do the following among other things:
('48', 528, 7, 8, 1190091) 1. To communicate to some salt revenue officer of the rank of a Sarkarkun or a Daroga any information concerning offences under the Act;
('48', 528, 8, 9, 1190228) 2. ‘‘To interpose for the purpose of preventing and to prevent, by the use of all reasonable means within his power, the commission of any such offence”.
('48', 528, 9, 10, 1190382) Section 48A lays down among other things that any salt revenue officer,
('48', 528, 10, 11, 1190454) ‘‘who is guilty of cowardice shall on conviction before a magistrate be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to three months’ pay, or with both.”
